Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, 26 October 2017

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (Hon. Tony Smith) took the chair at 09:30, made an acknowledgement of

Speaker: NA
Text: country and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Grayndler) (09:31): Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Does the member for Grayndler claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Yes, on multiple occasions.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Senator Cash, before the Senate estimates yesterday, made statements

Speaker: NA
Text: about me that were untrue, that she now knows were untrue and acknowledges are untrue. She

Speaker: NA
Text: said the following, 'My understanding was that Mr Albanese said that I was tipping off the

Speaker: NA
Text: press gallery personally; that was what was put to me'. On other occasion she told the Senate:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Several outrageous slurs were made against me today-for example, that I was personally

Speaker: NA
Text: phoning the media gallery. If Anthony Albanese would like to apologise for that statement

Speaker: NA
Text: then he can.' On a third occasion, Senator Cash, in response to questions from Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Cameron, said: 'I had a question time briefing with the Prime Minister and that is it. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the only conversation I have had with him where I assured him that the statement made by

Speaker: NA
Text: Anthony Albanese that I had been personally phoning the media was 100 per cent incorrect.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, those statements simply are incorrect. On FIVEaa yesterday, in the Two

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribes segment that I do with the member for Sturt each Wednesday morning, I said, 'We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that Senator Cash's office was ringing around media organisations yesterday afternoon,

Speaker: NA
Text: telling them that this was going to occur.' On other occasion I said, 'People directly got calls

Speaker: NA
Text: from Michaelia Cash's media office.' What I said yesterday was absolutely correct. I also note

Speaker: NA
Text: that the member for Sturt said on FIVEaa yesterday, 'I don't accept that it's true.' I'm sure he

Speaker: NA
Text: now accepts it's true, just as he should accept that Senator Cash should resign for misleading

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate on multiple occasions.

Speaker: NA
Text: MOTIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Gambling

Speaker: Mr WILKIE
Text: Denison) (09:33): I seek leave to move the following motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) a fifth Crown Casino whistleblower has now made allegations consistent with earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: whistleblowers about serious misconduct at the Casino;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) one of the allegations is that one or more machines manufactured by Xcite were illegally

Speaker: NA
Text: tampered with, to reduce the payout to gamblers, through the removal of the "gamble button", a feature

Speaker: NA
Text: which allows users to bet on their winnings, and that the relevant button was replaced by a blank plastic

Speaker: NA
Text: cap;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) this modification is inconsistent with the regulator's approval of this type of machine and is

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore illegal;

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) to verify the veracity of these latest allegations, one of the Member for Denison's staff visited the

Speaker: NA
Text: Casino at approximately 10 pm on Sunday, 22 October and confirmed this machine was operating on

Speaker: NA
Text: the floor of the Casino on the river side, near the membership office, but when that member of staff

Speaker: NA
Text: revisited the Casino on Wednesday, 25 October at approximately 4 pm the machine had been replaced

Speaker: NA
Text: by a different machine and the first machine was nowhere to be found;

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) the illegal machine disappeared after the Member for Denison raised allegations concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Casino in the Parliament, which is clear evidence of someone covering up criminal activity; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) there is a record of this episode which will be forwarded to police and the Victorian gambling

Speaker: NA
Text: regulator as soon as possible;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) further notes, that it is reasonable to assume that the misconduct in question is not unique to Crown

Speaker: NA
Text: Casino and extends to the poker machine industry broadly; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) calls on the Government, and the Opposition, to immediately support a parliamentary inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: the casino industry so that those who allege misconduct, and representatives of the industry, can have

Speaker: NA
Text: their say in an open and transparent way and so that the community, including the 17 million who visit

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Casino annually, can be witness to this.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: won't shut down the suspension motion if the member for Denison wishes to move it as a

Speaker: NA
Text: suspension.

Speaker: Mr WILKIE
Text: Then I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Member for Denison from

Speaker: NA
Text: moving the following motion immediately-That this House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) a fifth Crown Casino whistleblower has now made allegations consistent with earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: whistleblowers about serious misconduct at the Casino;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) one of the allegations is that one or more machines manufactured by Xcite were illegally

Speaker: NA
Text: tampered with, to reduce the payout to gamblers, through the removal of the "gamble button", a feature

Speaker: NA
Text: which allows users to bet on their winnings, and that the relevant button was replaced by a blank plastic

Speaker: NA
Text: cap;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) this modification is inconsistent with the regulator's approval of this type of machine and is

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore illegal;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) to verify the veracity of these latest allegations, one of the Member for Denison's staff visited the

Speaker: NA
Text: Casino at approximately 10 pm on Sunday, 22 October and confirmed this machine was operating on

Speaker: NA
Text: the floor of the Casino on the river side, near the membership office, but when that member of staff

Speaker: NA
Text: revisited the Casino on Wednesday, 25 October at approximately 4 pm the machine had been replaced

Speaker: NA
Text: by a different machine and the first machine was nowhere to be found;

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) the illegal machine disappeared after the Member for Denison raised allegations concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Casino in the Parliament, which is clear evidence of someone covering up criminal activity; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) there is a record of this episode which will be forwarded to police and the Victorian gambling

Speaker: NA
Text: regulator as soon as possible;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) further notes, that it is reasonable to assume that the misconduct in question is not unique to Crown

Speaker: NA
Text: Casino and extends to the poker machine industry broadly; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) calls on the Government, and the Opposition, to immediately support a parliamentary inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: the casino industry so that those who allege misconduct, and representatives of the industry, can have

Speaker: NA
Text: their say in an open and transparent way and so that the community, including the 17 million who visit

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Casino annually, can be witness to this.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a pressing need to suspend standing orders and for the parliament to deal with what I

Speaker: NA
Text: will now call the Crown Casino scandal. No longer are we talking about untested allegations

Speaker: NA
Text: by anonymous whistleblowers. Now we have a credible witness, a senior member of my staff,

Speaker: NA
Text: who went to the casino on two occasions at my direction. On the first occasion he saw an

Speaker: NA
Text: illegal machine in operation on the floor of the casino. It was a machine where a button had

Speaker: NA
Text: been removed and a function had been removed from that machine with the sole intent of

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the revenue from that machine and decreasing the payout to poker machine

Speaker: NA
Text: gamblers. When he went back to the casino several days later, the machine had been removed

Speaker: NA
Text: and was nowhere to be found. So not only do we now have a credible witness-not hearsay;

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a man I will stand by and stand behind; I will vouch for what he tells me-who is a

Speaker: NA
Text: witness in recent days to an illegal poker machine on the floor of Crown Casino, but we also

Speaker: NA
Text: have a credible witness to a criminal cover-up with the removal of that machine as a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: result, obviously, of the allegations I've been airing in the parliament last week and this week.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of a sudden all of the whistleblowers-five have now approached me-and all of their

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations, so far untested, are now to be seen in a different light, because at least one of

Speaker: NA
Text: those allegations, the one allegation I could easily check, we did check and it was found to be

Speaker: NA
Text: true. So I now am shifting from saying these are allegations which need to be explored, to

Speaker: NA
Text: saying quite clearly and unambiguously at least some of those allegations are correct and

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Casino is guilty of criminal behaviour.

Speaker: NA
Text: So far the response in this place has been, 'It's all someone else's problem.' Well, it's not

Speaker: NA
Text: someone else's problem. It is our business. One of the allegations is of money laundering.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a serious criminal offence. We can only speculate at the purpose of that money

Speaker: NA
Text: laundering. Is it to do with drug running? Is it to do with terrorism? Who knows what it's to

Speaker: NA
Text: do with? That should concern us.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the allegations is about the competence of the Victorian regulator, another reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for federal intervention. It comes back to the point that, when it comes to poker machine

Speaker: NA
Text: regulation in this country, we simply cannot trust the state and territory governments to

Speaker: NA
Text: regulate it effectively. And no wonder, because they are deeply conflicted. The state and

Speaker: NA
Text: territory governments receive about one-quarter of the money that's lost on the poker

Speaker: NA
Text: machines in this country. There's over $10 billion a year lost, and about one-quarter of that

Speaker: NA
Text: goes to the state and territory governments. They can't be trusted on the one hand to enjoy that

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue and want to see more of it, and on the other hand to ensure the industry is run well

Speaker: NA
Text: and the welfare of members of the community is protected.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a pressing need for this parliament to act, and the way we can act is to establish a

Speaker: NA
Text: parliamentary inquiry. This is the ideal way, the perfect way, to let those who have made

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations, and others, and representatives of the industry who will want to defend their

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, to come out of the shadows, to stand in the open in front of members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, in front of the media, in front of the community and say what they have to say and

Speaker: NA
Text: to say it in a safe environment, because those witnesses will have the protection of the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: I've now had dealings with five separate whistleblowers about Crown Casino, and some of

Speaker: NA
Text: them are scared. People say, 'Why don't they just go to the police?' Put yourself in their shoes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Making allegations against one of this country's biggest and richest and most powerful

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations-of course they're scared for their safety! We know the sorts of allegations that

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: also circulate about the rough and tumble that you'll see in some parts of the gambling

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in this country. No wonder people are scared. They're worried for their safety.

Speaker: NA
Text: They're worried for the safety of their families. They're worried for their job prospects in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. There are any number of reasons why they don't want their identity to be known, but

Speaker: NA
Text: they come to people like us to do stuff like this, because the justice system, the police, the

Speaker: NA
Text: regulators, the state and territory governments are not doing their jobs well enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: So far the call for an inquiry has fallen on deaf ears. Both the government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition are refusing to weigh into this. I don't doubt there are some really good people in

Speaker: NA
Text: this place, some really good people in the government and some really good people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition: people who care about the community and don't like the current shape of the

Speaker: NA
Text: gambling industry in this country. But, systemically, you're all compromised because the

Speaker: NA
Text: major parties receive millions of dollars in donations from the gambling industry. Crown

Speaker: NA
Text: Casino alone in the last five years has paid three-quarters of a million dollars to the major

Speaker: NA
Text: parties in political donations. And what a great return on that investment Crown has so far

Speaker: NA
Text: gotten from the government and the opposition, both of which are running a hundred miles

Speaker: NA
Text: from the call for a parliamentary inquiry. You know, $750,000 buys a lot of influence in this

Speaker: NA
Text: place, and so far it has bought a refusal to have a parliamentary inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: As of today, it's no longer hearsay; it's no longer untested allegation; it's no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: anonymous whistleblowers. It's me standing here saying that I have a senior member of staff

Speaker: NA
Text: who walked into Crown Casino within the last week and saw an illegal machine on the floor

Speaker: NA
Text: of the casino-a criminal act by Crown Casino. That same member of staff went back several

Speaker: NA
Text: days later and the machine was gone and was nowhere to be found. In the motion, I've even

Speaker: NA
Text: identified where the machine was originally sited. The cover-up of a crime is a crime.

Speaker: NA
Text: The time has come for the government and the opposition to show that they have not been

Speaker: NA
Text: bought by the gambling industry, that they haven't been bought by Crown Casino. Today is

Speaker: NA
Text: the day for them to stand up and show the community that they are their own men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: and that they haven't been bought off-bribed, in effect-by the poker machine industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: by Crown. I again call on the government and the opposition-the good people among you-

Speaker: NA
Text: to say to your leaders that now is the time for a parliamentary inquiry and that it's not good

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to leave an investigation to the police and the regulator. Let's have a proper inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's shine some sunlight on this. Let's get to the bottom of it.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Is the motion seconded?

Speaker: Mr BANDT
Text: Melbourne) (09:46): I second the motion. The Greens demand a full inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: into these scandalous allegations at Crown and will not rest until we get one. If ever there was

Speaker: NA
Text: a case for this parliament to say, 'We're going to put aside the business that we're otherwise

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with to deal with a matter of national urgency,' it is this. We don't currently have a

Speaker: NA
Text: national anticorruption watchdog like some states have. We don't have a national ICAC, so

Speaker: NA
Text: we can't ask such a body to look into it. We should have one, but we don't, because Labor and

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal won't support the establishment of one. We can't trust the state governments, because

Speaker: NA
Text: the state governments are the biggest gambling addicts of all. They're the ones who profit

Speaker: NA
Text: from the misery of people whose lives are broken as a result of gambling. They profit from it

Speaker: NA
Text: and they're in cosy with the casino operators, so we can't trust them to look at it. And,

Speaker: NA
Text: critically, in this case it's alleged that the state regulators have turned a blind eye or have been

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in it. So that is a classic case of where the federal government needs to step in,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: where there are allegations not only of wrongdoing at a casino but of wrongdoing involving

Speaker: NA
Text: the regulators themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we need to step in and have an inquiry, and a full inquiry, where people can front up

Speaker: NA
Text: and give their evidence under parliamentary privilege. You have to have guts to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: whistleblower in this country. If you stand up, you worry that you might face repercussions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whistleblowers have come forward. They've come forward to the member for Denison and

Speaker: NA
Text: made some very, very serious allegations. We should drop everything to take those

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations seriously, because they involve breaches of federal law, they involve state

Speaker: NA
Text: regulators not doing their job and they involve Crown Casino committing a crime. Those are

Speaker: NA
Text: the allegations.

Speaker: NA
Text: We've asked for a full parliamentary inquiry to be established and we haven't got one.

Speaker: NA
Text: Why? It is because the only thing spinning faster than the poker machines is the revolving

Speaker: NA
Text: door between this place and the casino industry. There are members of this parliament who

Speaker: NA
Text: probably can't wait to get out of their job so they can go and take up a cushy job somewhere

Speaker: NA
Text: else, as previous MPs who have gone and got a job lobbying for the casino industry have done

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past. They are continuing to profit from people's lives being broken and made a misery.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, when former members of this place front up on behalf of big business and say, 'No, we'd

Speaker: NA
Text: like you not to have an inquiry,' lo and behold, that's what happens. And when the casinos

Speaker: NA
Text: make big donations to the Labor and Liberal parties, the old parties, they expect a return.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, today the casinos have hit the jackpot. They're getting payday. They're getting the return

Speaker: NA
Text: on their donations, because the old parties in the parliament are in collusion, steadfastly

Speaker: NA
Text: refusing to investigate these allegations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Think about some of the things that this parliament has decided to inquire into before and

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that the government are prepared to spend tens if not hundreds of millions of dollars

Speaker: NA
Text: on a royal commission into unions or into previous government schemes-the insulation

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes, for example. They're prepared to spend money on that. They're prepared to spend

Speaker: NA
Text: money on that for political purposes and political outcomes, but when it comes to something

Speaker: NA
Text: the public genuinely cares about-casinos and the gambling industry, who make their money

Speaker: NA
Text: out of breaking people's lives-people want action. But, sadly, time and time again we see big

Speaker: NA
Text: money dictating what happens in this place. This parliament should act in the public interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: not in the interests of a few private donors.

Speaker: NA
Text: This parliament has been captured by the big end of town. If the government wants to show

Speaker: NA
Text: that it's serious about transparency and the Labor opposition thinks that transparency is

Speaker: NA
Text: important, now's your chance. Now's your chance, Labor and Liberal parties, to show that

Speaker: NA
Text: honesty is more important than money. Support this motion. Support the establishment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: full inquiry. Let's shine a light on what is happening in casinos, because these allegations are

Speaker: NA
Text: getting stronger and stronger, the evidence is mounting up and we need to shine some

Speaker: NA
Text: sunlight.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The question is that the motion be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: A division having been called and the bells having been rung-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The question is that the motion moved by the member for Denison be

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to. As there are fewer than five members on the side for the ayes in this division, I

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: declare the question negatived in accordance with standing order 127. The names of those

Speaker: NA
Text: members who are in the minority will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question negatived, Mr Bandt, Ms MCGowan, Ms Sharkie and Mr Wilkie voting aye.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse Bill 2017

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill and explanatory memorandum to this bill, and to the Commonwealth Redress Scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2017, presented by

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill will establish legislation for a Commonwealth Redress Scheme, which we'll call

Speaker: NA
Text: simply 'the scheme', for survivors of institutional child sexual abuse. With this bill the

Speaker: NA
Text: government introduces a best-practice, simple and supportive redress scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Children placed in the trust of our society's institutions were some of the most vulnerable

Speaker: NA
Text: members in our community and the fact that must be confronted is that many children were

Speaker: NA
Text: sexually abused by the very people charged with their care and protection. No child should

Speaker: NA
Text: ever experience what we now know occurred. That is why it is time for all institutions and all

Speaker: NA
Text: governments to take responsibility for what has happened.

Speaker: NA
Text: The establishment of the scheme is an acknowledgement by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: government that sexual abuse suffered by children in institutional settings; operated by a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of governments state, territory and federal and by a number of non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions was wrong, a shocking betrayal of trust; and simply should never have happened.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Redress Scheme in this bill is designed to recognise the suffering survivors have

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced, to unequivocally accept that these events occurred and to ensure that each

Speaker: NA
Text: institution that has been responsible for abuse in their institutional settings must take

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for that abuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth government acknowledged the need to provide public recognition of

Speaker: NA
Text: the suffering experienced by survivors and investigate the inadequate responses provided by

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions through the establishment of the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses

Speaker: NA
Text: to Child Sexual Abuse. The royal commission's Redress and civil litigation report

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended the establishment of a national redress scheme for survivors of institutional

Speaker: NA
Text: child sexual abuse. All governments and individual institutions were directed to make amends

Speaker: NA
Text: and take responsibility for the shameful acts inflicted on children while in their care.

Speaker: NA
Text: Critically, the royal commission determined that the payment of redress must align with

Speaker: NA
Text: institutional responsibility for the harms that were suffered and so redress should occur on

Speaker: NA
Text: what has become known as a responsible entity basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: The royal commission identified more than 4,000 institutions where sexual abuse took

Speaker: NA
Text: place. More than 2,000 survivors reported sexual abuse in a Catholic institution, 500 survivors

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: reported abuse in Anglican institutions and more than 250 reported abuse in institutions run

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Salvation Army. In total, the royal commission estimated that almost 40,000 survivors

Speaker: NA
Text: were sexually abused in institutions run by non-government bodies such as those run by

Speaker: NA
Text: churches and charities and 20,000 survivors were sexually abused in state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: government run institutions. More than 6,500 people who gave private evidence said more

Speaker: NA
Text: than one person had abused them.

Speaker: NA
Text: These estimates are, very sadly, merely a window into the scale and breadth of historical

Speaker: NA
Text: institutional child sexual abuse in Australia. It is vitally important to survivors that

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible governments and responsible institutions participate in this scheme and provide

Speaker: NA
Text: redress on a nationally consistent basis for survivors.

Speaker: NA
Text: The royal commission has heard evidence of thousands of Australians who when

Speaker: NA
Text: vulnerable children were subject to the most horrendous sexual abuse in institutions

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia. The psychological, physical and emotional injuries inflicted on these

Speaker: NA
Text: children were inevitably severe and are capable of long-lasting destabilising effects on

Speaker: NA
Text: survivors for the rest of their lives. In spite of the severity of the damage done, many

Speaker: NA
Text: survivors have not sought or have not obtained any kind of acknowledgement or redress for

Speaker: NA
Text: the harm suffered.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is evidence that some survivors take years, even decades, to disclose their experience

Speaker: NA
Text: of child sexual abuse. It may also take years or decades for survivors to identify a connection

Speaker: NA
Text: between the abuse they suffered as a child and its impact on them as an adult. By the time

Speaker: NA
Text: many survivors feel ready to seek acknowledgment and compensation from a responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: institution, the natural passage of time is an enemy to traditional mechanisms operating

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively to hear and find the existence of common-law damages, and in many instances this

Speaker: NA
Text: traditional compensatory process is simply not feasible for survivors or may simply no longer

Speaker: NA
Text: be available.

Speaker: NA
Text: The long-term impacts of child sexual abuse can leave many survivors much less able to

Speaker: NA
Text: confront institutions directly and they remain at great risk of retraumatisation. For some, the

Speaker: NA
Text: legality of traditional compensatory processes 'triggers' the memories to an extent that abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes relived.

Speaker: NA
Text: The sexual abuse we know was inflicted on children by the very institutions that were

Speaker: NA
Text: charged with their care and protection means that the acts, and the often inadequate responses

Speaker: NA
Text: of both primarily responsible institutions and governments, were shameful. This is why

Speaker: NA
Text: redress is so badly needed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The establishment of a Commonwealth Redress Scheme demonstrates critical national

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership by acknowledging the wrongs of the past and providing a just response to

Speaker: NA
Text: survivors. It is also an important step towards healing and ensuring governments and

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions take the appropriate steps to safeguard against these heinous, criminal acts being

Speaker: NA
Text: repeated in the future. This bill responds to the royal commission's redress recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Commonwealth government's commitment to establish the foundation for a nationally

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent Redress Scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: All responsible institutions and each state and territory and the Commonwealth government

Speaker: NA
Text: should be ashamed of what occurred on their watch and I urge all of them to join with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth's best-practice approach to delivering redress that is set out in this legislation;

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to survivors that redress must be given in as fair and timely a manner as possible. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Redress Scheme will create a consistent approach, based on the essential and

Speaker: NA
Text: critical principle that 'the responsible entity pays'. If an institution bears real responsibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: the harm, that institution must rightly pay the costs of providing redress for that harm.

Speaker: NA
Text: Matching responsibility with redress is the critical condition for creating a better Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: where these types of outrages are far less likely to occur. No institution should expect another

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay for its often shameful conduct.

Speaker: NA
Text: Detailed negotiations with states and non-government institutions are continuing in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure maximum coverage for survivors across Australia. By establishing this Redress

Speaker: NA
Text: Scheme, the Commonwealth is ensuring that its own survivors will be able to access redress

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1 July 2018.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme will provide survivors with three elements of redress, comprising:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. a monetary payment of up to $150,000 as a tangible means of recognising the wrong that

Speaker: NA
Text: survivors have suffered;

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. access to counselling or psychological services of their choice throughout their lives; and

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. a direct personal response from the institutions responsible, where that is sought by the

Speaker: NA
Text: survivor.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme will adopt a survivor focused and trauma informed approach; access to redress

Speaker: NA
Text: will be simple and support will be available throughout the application and acceptance

Speaker: NA
Text: process.

Speaker: NA
Text: Survivors will not pay income tax on monetary payments they receive through the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: and payments will not be directly garnished to recover any outstanding debts that may exist to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth. Neither will payments be considered income for the purposes of

Speaker: NA
Text: determining social security and veterans' entitlement payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme is not intended to supplant or detract from the enduring and important criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: law or common law avenues to seek justice. It is intended, however, to provide a survivor

Speaker: NA
Text: with a means to access a sense of and process in justice, through monetary redress and

Speaker: NA
Text: through restorative supports. It is intended in this sense to be faster, simpler and less

Speaker: NA
Text: distressing for survivors and provide governments and institutions with the means to deliver

Speaker: NA
Text: justice to their survivors.

Speaker: NA
Text: In developing this legislation, we consulted with, and listened to, a broad range of

Speaker: NA
Text: stakeholders on the development of the scheme and this bill. The bill aligns with the views of

Speaker: NA
Text: the independent advisory council on redress (including many survivor groups), jurisdictions

Speaker: NA
Text: and non-government institutions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Overview of the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: Under this bill, redress will be available for survivors of child sexual abuse that occurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth institutional settings. It will also provide redress to survivors abused in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory when these jurisdictions opt in or if

Speaker: NA
Text: they are ultimately compelled to do so by the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme will be established in 2018 and will run for 10 years, with all applications to

Speaker: NA
Text: be finalised by 30 June 2028, however the scheme can be extended if there is a cogent need to

Speaker: NA
Text: do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: From March 2018, a dedicated telephone helpline and website will be available to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: information on a preliminary basis about the scheme. These services will also connect

Speaker: NA
Text: survivors with specialist community based support services including legal, financial and

Speaker: NA
Text: other social supports.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1 July 2018, the scheme will commence accepting applications from survivors of

Speaker: NA
Text: institutional child sexual abuse for which the Commonwealth and other participating

Speaker: NA
Text: governments and institutions are responsible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eligibility

Speaker: NA
Text: For a person to be eligible for redress they must have suffered sexual abuse where a

Speaker: NA
Text: participating institution is responsible and where it occurred when the person was a child

Speaker: NA
Text: before the scheme's commencement on 1 July 2018.

Speaker: NA
Text: While a person must have suffered sexual abuse to be eligible, the scheme will also

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge related non-sexual abuse, for example physical abuse. Sexual abuse, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: rarely occurs in isolation and it is important to deal with the whole of the survivor's

Speaker: NA
Text: experience as it pertains to the requisite sexual abuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: A person may only make one application for redress, so if they have suffered more than

Speaker: NA
Text: one instance of abuse, applications should disclose all instances in their application. This

Speaker: NA
Text: means that once a decision has been made on an application, a person will not be able to make

Speaker: NA
Text: additional applications to the scheme. This, again, is to ensure the speed and simplicity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme and that the totality of the applicant's experience can be properly considered.

Speaker: NA
Text: While there are no applicant age restrictions, applicants must be living. Families will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to lodge an application on behalf of a deceased relative. However, if a survivor dies after

Speaker: NA
Text: lodging a complete and eligible application, their estate will receive the redress payment due

Speaker: NA
Text: to the survivor.

Speaker: NA
Text: For an application to the scheme to be approved and an offer of redress to be made, the

Speaker: NA
Text: operator must make a determination that there is a reasonable likelihood that the survivor is

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible. Reasonable likelihood is a lower evidentiary threshold than a balance of probabilities

Speaker: NA
Text: test which is generally applied in civil legal processes.

Speaker: NA
Text: To be entitled to redress, a person must accept their offer and, in doing so, release the

Speaker: NA
Text: participating institution deemed responsible from civil liability in relation to abuse within the

Speaker: NA
Text: scope of the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Monetary payment

Speaker: NA
Text: The amount of the monetary payment will be determined by looking carefully and closely

Speaker: NA
Text: at all of the circumstances of each person and applying consistent criteria. The maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of redress payable under the scheme will be $150,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Access to counselling or psychological services

Speaker: NA
Text: Eligible survivors will be provided with access to counselling or psychological services in

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to the assistance already provided by the Commonwealth through Medicare.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consistent with the royal commission's recommendations, the scheme will provide survivors

Speaker: NA
Text: with flexibility to access the counselling or psychological services of their own choice. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will empower survivors to make decisions about their own counselling needs and will support

Speaker: NA
Text: them to maintain existing therapeutic relationships.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Direct personal response

Speaker: NA
Text: Survivors will also have the opportunity to receive a direct personal response from the

Speaker: NA
Text: participating institutions responsible for the abuse. A direct personal response is a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: of acknowledgement, regret and apology and will be delivered to survivors by the relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: participating institution after the survivor has accepted the offer of redress.

Speaker: NA
Text: The response may be delivered through a range of mechanisms including face-to-face

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings with an appropriate representative of the institution or through written engagement

Speaker: NA
Text: with the survivor. The participating institution will be required to make quite clear what they

Speaker: NA
Text: are willing to offer by way of a direct personal response to survivors and what that process

Speaker: NA
Text: will involve.

Speaker: NA
Text: The direct personal response will give the survivor the chance to be directly acknowledged

Speaker: NA
Text: and to tell their personal story of what they experienced and the way in which it has impacted

Speaker: NA
Text: upon them. Through this process, a participating institution can develop a shared

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding, a critical understanding, of what happened to the survivor and the harm that

Speaker: NA
Text: was caused, which will enable the institution to consider what else it may need to do to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent such abuses and harm occurring in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Deed of release

Speaker: NA
Text: Before survivors receive redress, the survivor will accept their offer by signing an

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptance document in the form of a deed of release. Accepting an offer of redress has the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of releasing the responsible participating institutions from any further liability for

Speaker: NA
Text: instances of sexual abuse and related non-sexual abuse of the person the subject of the redress

Speaker: NA
Text: payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means that the survivor by a transparent agreement will, upon accepting the offer of

Speaker: NA
Text: redress, undertake not to bring or continue any civil claim against the responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: participating institution or institutions in relation to the specific abuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ensuring the availability of redress for survivors is dependent on the extent to which states

Speaker: NA
Text: and territory governments and non-government institutions decide to join the scheme. The

Speaker: NA
Text: deed of release is perhaps the most important feature in terms of encouraging those critical

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions to opt in to the scheme and thus it is a mechanism by which we can ensure greater

Speaker: NA
Text: coverage for survivors as without it institutions may be exposed to paying compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: through civil litigation in addition to providing redress under the scheme and so might decline

Speaker: NA
Text: to opt in to the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The release will never preclude any criminal liabilities of the institution or alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrator, nor provide release in relation to any other abuse outside the scope of the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: A survivor may have previously signed a deed of release for money received in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: institutional child sexual abuse. Importantly, the rules of the scheme will contain, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: foundational principle for entry, that institutions will need to waive reliance on a prior deed of

Speaker: NA
Text: release signed by a survivor.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any relevant prior payments made by participating institutions in relation to the abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: within the scope of the scheme will be subtracted from the redress payment. In essence,

Speaker: NA
Text: survivors who have received a previous payment related to circumstances the subject of the

Speaker: NA
Text: present redress application would receive an effective 'top-up' to the previously received

Speaker: NA
Text: payment up to the total redress amount determined under the scheme. If a survivor's monetary

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: payment is reduced to nil as a result of past redress payments, the assurance is that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: still be entitled to access counselling or psychological services or receive the direct personal

Speaker: NA
Text: response available under the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: Responsibility for abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme is based on the critical principle of 'responsible entity pays', which was a key

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation of the royal commission. A participating responsible institution will be

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to pay for redress for their survivors, along with a proportionate share of the

Speaker: NA
Text: administrative costs. This is the best way to ensure fairness and justice for survivors and

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent the prevalence of the conditions of immorality derived from irresponsibility that gave

Speaker: NA
Text: rise to these terrible events in the first instance.

Speaker: NA
Text: For a participating institution to be responsible, the abuse must have occurred in

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances where the institution was primarily or equally responsible for the abuser having

Speaker: NA
Text: contact with the person who is the survivor. In making this determination, the following

Speaker: NA
Text: criteria will be considered:

Speaker: NA
Text:  whether the abuse occurred on the premises of the institution, where activities of the

Speaker: NA
Text: institution took place, or in connection with the activities of the institution;

Speaker: NA
Text:  whether the alleged abuser was an official of the participating institution when the abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred; and

Speaker: NA
Text:  whether the participating institution was responsible for the care of the survivor when the

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse occurred.

Speaker: NA
Text: A participating institution is primarily responsible for an alleged abuser having contact

Speaker: NA
Text: with a survivor if the institution is solely, substantially or primarily responsible for that

Speaker: NA
Text: contact, even if there are other institutions that, in a minor or tangential way, might also have

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for that contact. In such cases, the institution will be required to pay the full

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of redress, that is the institution will pay the full 100 per cent share of redress even if

Speaker: NA
Text: some other institution might have been responsible in a minor or tangential way.

Speaker: NA
Text: A participating institution will be considered equally responsible where they are equally

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible with one or more other institutions for a child having contact with an alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: abuser. In these cases the responsibility for funding redress will be shared equally and each

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible institution will be required to pay an equal 50 per cent share of redress.

Speaker: NA
Text: This structure is designed as the best means of achieving a simple, clear, non-legal scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: which avoids all the complexities associated with exhaustive allocations of divided

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility that causes great cost and time to be expended in civil litigation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Redress Scheme rules will further define the extent of institutional

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility as cases are assessed under the scheme. This will allow the scheme to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: any unanticipated issues that might arise over the 10-year life of the scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to the issue of funder of last resort, in cases where a government is considered

Speaker: NA
Text: equally responsible, they-the government-may be determined to be the funder of last

Speaker: NA
Text: resort. This will occur when the other equally responsible participating non-government

Speaker: NA
Text: institution:

Speaker: NA
Text:  does not exist and does not have a meaningful and substantive connection with an

Speaker: NA
Text: 'umbrella' or 'subsuming' modern organisation; or

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text:  the responsible institution does exist but is unable to pay redress because they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: deemed insolvent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where a funder of last resort arrangement is determined to exist, the government that

Speaker: NA
Text: shares the responsibility will pay the full amount of redress by paying the equal share of

Speaker: NA
Text: redress the participating non-government institution would have otherwise paid.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme will provide for the development of agreed categories of cases where

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible governments will share responsibility with an institution and will be a potential

Speaker: NA
Text: funder of last resort. If a case falls into an agreed category, the relevant government will

Speaker: NA
Text: automatically be determined to be equally responsible and therefore liable for redress.

Speaker: NA
Text: Where a case does not fall into a specified category, other factors will be considered,

Speaker: NA
Text: including: who was responsible for the care of the child; the employment of the abuser; and

Speaker: NA
Text: the placement of the child in the institution at the time of the abuse such that an obligation on

Speaker: NA
Text: the institution could be inferred.

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to the issue of shared financial obligation, in cases where there are multiple

Speaker: NA
Text: instances of child sexual abuse which occurred across multiple institutions, the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: operator will decide which was the responsible institution in each case. Each responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: institution will contribute a share of the redress for the survivor. The redress contribution will

Speaker: NA
Text: be apportioned in accordance with the severity of each instance of abuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to information use, disclosure and mandatory reporting, the bill includes

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions for the use and disclosure of information under the scheme. This will ensure all

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of the scheme's ability to share and gather information is underpinned by law.

Speaker: NA
Text: Information sharing protocols have been balanced against the need for the scheme to have

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate transparency and flexibility, with survivors' rights to privacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Information received by the scheme will be confidential and will not be able to be further

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosed or used for an unspecified purpose. Participating institutions will also be restricted

Speaker: NA
Text: in the ways that they can use protected information provided to them from the scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: operator. Misuse or unauthorised disclosure of scheme information may constitute an offence

Speaker: NA
Text: under legislation and would carry with it a penalty of imprisonment for two years or 120

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty units, or both.

Speaker: NA
Text: In keeping with mandatory reporting obligations, referrals to law enforcement authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: will not require the consent of the survivor or participating institutions and 'blind' reporting

Speaker: NA
Text: will occur (that is, where the individual survivor is de-identified).

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to independent decision makers, the Secretary of the Department of Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Services is the formal operator of the scheme. The bill will allow the scheme's operator to

Speaker: NA
Text: delegate decision-making responsibilities to appropriately qualified, independent assessors,

Speaker: NA
Text: who will be known as independent decision-makers. These independent decision-makers will

Speaker: NA
Text: be supported in their decision-making by recommendations from the dedicated redress

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation team that will be located within the Department of Human Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rules

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to the rules, the bill will include a provision to make legislative instruments

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the Commonwealth Redress Scheme Rules. The rules will set out additional

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements necessary for the implementation of the scheme and may cover matters such as:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: eligibility requirements or exemptions; determining the amount of payments for an eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: person under the scheme; and the form and manner of the direct personal response.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before closing, there have been innumerable individuals who have contributed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction and the advice in preparing the principles for this bill, including those who sat on

Speaker: NA
Text: our independent advisory council. I'd like to personally thank them for their enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance, input and forbearance through a difficult process. I'd like also to make some

Speaker: NA
Text: special mention of the member for Swan, who himself as a child endured some of the worst

Speaker: NA
Text: that these institutions had to offer. His insight, advice and assistance to me as a minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: his ability to act as a conduit with the survivors for whom this bill purely exists has been

Speaker: NA
Text: something for which I personally will be indebted to him for a long time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Summary

Speaker: NA
Text: In summary, the Commonwealth is showing national leadership by introducing a redress

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme that is flexible and as non-legal and as informal as the circumstances will allow. The

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme paves the way for all governments and institutions across Australia to take

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility and provide long-awaited redress to survivors who suffered sexual abuse as

Speaker: NA
Text: children while in their care and protection. It is of course now time to acknowledge these

Speaker: NA
Text: shameful wrongs and finally provide survivors with the recognition they deserve. For these

Speaker: NA
Text: and other reasons, I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: Grayndler) (10:21): I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Rob Mitchell): Does the member claim to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Text: I do. This morning on Sky News, Minister Porter was interviewed by

Speaker: NA
Text: Kieran Gilbert. The interview said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Kieran Gilbert: It was emerged earlier in the day. Mr Albanese made the assertion, then reports

Speaker: NA
Text: emerged. Surely amid the speculation that there was a tip-off there would have been questions asked.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Porter: Well, Mr Albanese's assertion was that the minister herself had called the media,

Speaker: NA
Text: which-

Speaker: NA
Text: Kieran Gilbert: Was not far off.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Porter: Well, that is a very serious assertion itself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kieran Gilber: It wasn't far off. It was from her office.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Porter: It was very far off. It was absolutely wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier this morning I tabled my comments from the FIVEaa program yesterday in a debate

Speaker: NA
Text: with Christopher Pyne in the Two Tribes segment. I think it's now accepted that I absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: said that it was the minister's staff who had briefed the media. We now know that that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: fact. Minister Porter contacted me and apologised for his error. I accept his apology and note

Speaker: NA
Text: that that is a mature way in which members should deal with each other. I'm yet to receive an

Speaker: NA
Text: apology from Minister Cash.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse

Speaker: NA
Text: (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2017

Speaker: NA
Text: First Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the companion bill to the Commonwealth Redress Scheme for Institutional Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Sexual Abuse Bill 2017, which will establish a redress scheme for survivors of institutional

Speaker: NA
Text: child sexual abuse. The establishment of the scheme is an acknowledgment by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government that child sexual abuse suffered by children in Commonwealth institutional

Speaker: NA
Text: settings was wrong and should never have occurred.

Speaker: NA
Text: This companion bill provides consequential amendments to Commonwealth legislation in

Speaker: NA
Text: light of the scheme. For example, amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 and Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements Act 1986 will ensure the payments are not income tested and will not reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: income support payments of survivors who receive payments under the scheme. The

Speaker: NA
Text: payments will also be quarantined from the divisible property of a bankrupt to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: survivor has the full benefit of their payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: This companion bill provides consequential amendments to Commonwealth legislation in

Speaker: NA
Text: light of the scheme. For example, amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 and Veteran's

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements Act 1986 will ensure the payments are not income tested and will not reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: income support payments of survivors who receive payments under the scheme. The

Speaker: NA
Text: payments will also be quarantined from the divisible property of a bankrupt to ensure the

Speaker: NA
Text: survivor has the full benefit of their payment.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the case that this companion bill will also remove external review mechanisms, and

Speaker: NA
Text: allow disclosure of spent, quashed and pardoned convictions to the scheme. These

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments are essential to implement and maintain the integrity of the scheme. It will

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure the scheme remains survivor focused and trauma informed by being a non-legalistic

Speaker: NA
Text: process for survivors who have already suffered so much. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fair Work Laws Amendment (Proper Use of Worker Benefits) Bill 2017

Speaker: NA
Text: Report from Federation Chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill returned from Federation Chamber with an unresolved question; certified copy of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill and schedule of the unresolved question presented.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that this bill be considered immediately.

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposed amendment-

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

Speaker: NA
Text: "whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House calls on the Government to:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) abandon its support of the decision of the Fair Work Commission to cut penalty rates because it

Speaker: NA
Text: will mean nearly 700,000 Australians will have their take home pay cut by up to $77 a week; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) legislate to prevent the decision from taking effect to stop Australians from having their penalty

Speaker: NA
Text: rates cut"-

Speaker: NA
Text: Unresolved question-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the amendment be agreed to.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: leave-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEES

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts and Audit Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: Ms BRODTMANN
Text: Canberra) (10:37): On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Accounts and Audit, I present the committee's report entitled Report 468: Defence major

Speaker: NA
Text: projects report (2015-16): inquiry based on Auditor-General's report 40 (2016-17).

Speaker: NA
Text: Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Speaker: Ms BRODTMANN
Text: by leave-Every year the Department of Defence and the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: National Audit Office work together to produce a consolidated review of selected major

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence acquisition projects, with the resulting report called the Major Projects Report, or the

Speaker: NA
Text: MPR as it has come to be known. The MPR is then reviewed by the Joint Committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Accounts and Audit.

Speaker: NA
Text: The 2015-16 MPR has a total approved budget of approximately $63.7 billion, covering

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly 58 per cent of the budget within the Approved Major Capital Investment Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The MPR reviews risks, challenges and complexities facing major projects in general, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as the status of the selected major projects in terms of cost, schedule and forecast

Speaker: NA
Text: capability.

Speaker: NA
Text: This review of the MPR by the JCPAA also included consideration of ANAO audit report

Speaker: NA
Text: 11 (2016-2017) on the Army's armed reconnaissance helicopter-known more widely as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tiger helicopter.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ANAO found that the Tiger helicopter fleet has not yet delivered the original

Speaker: NA
Text: capability expected by the Australian government, and continues to experience higher-than-

Speaker: NA
Text: expected costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Chief of Army declared final operational capability, or FOC, for the Tiger project in

Speaker: NA
Text: April 2016. The declaration was seven years later than planned, and was accompanied by nine

Speaker: NA
Text: operational caveats.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the time of audit, the Tiger project had 60 capability deficiencies deemed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Defence to be critical.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee examined the ANAO's finding that the Department of Defence had not

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared the Tiger project data summary sheets 'on the basis of the guidelines', and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: project maturity score of the Tiger project did not 'accurately or completely represent the

Speaker: NA
Text: project's maturity' at the time of review.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee gave particular attention to the significance of the Auditor-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified audit finding. Accordingly, the committee agreed to continue to monitor the Tiger

Speaker: NA
Text: project and related issues in future MPRs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Previous committees have taken an interest in transparency across the project life cycle for

Speaker: NA
Text: projects reported in the MPR, and the committee has pledged to continue to maintain and

Speaker: NA
Text: enhance transparency where possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee also examined capability performance reporting and analysis, and noted the

Speaker: NA
Text: ANAO's demonstration that application of different analysis methodologies could yield vastly

Speaker: NA
Text: different results. The committee recommended that Defence review its procedures for the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: development of expected capability estimates and report back to the committee on the

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes of the review within six months and with a progress report within three months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Project maturity scores were another area of interest to the committee. Project maturity

Speaker: NA
Text: scores are designed to provide 'quantification, in a simple and communicable manner, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: relative maturity of capital investment projects as they progress through the capability

Speaker: NA
Text: development and acquisition life cycle'. In 2016 the committee recommended Defence make

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements in project maturity scores, and this year the committee has reiterated that

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation, calling on Defence and the ANAO to commence discussions on updating

Speaker: NA
Text: project maturity scores. The committee has outlined a series of deadlines to progress these

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee is pleased to note the downward trend of time lost over the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: projects, otherwise known as 'schedule slippage', but notes that projects should be properly

Speaker: NA
Text: classified at commencement to ensure that expectations around project delivery are realistic.

Speaker: NA
Text: The committee also noted differing methodologies used by Defence to calculate cost per

Speaker: NA
Text: flying hour between the MPR and the audit into the Tiger helicopters project, recommending

Speaker: NA
Text: that Defence devise a single methodology, one single methodology, to enable clear

Speaker: NA
Text: comparisons to be made between documents or projects. The Department of Defence should

Speaker: NA
Text: provide this information to the committee prior to the first sitting week of 2018.

Speaker: NA
Text: Progress has been made in improving transparency in the reporting of Defence major

Speaker: NA
Text: project expenditure over the years since the MPR was instituted, and incremental

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements occur year upon year thanks to the professionalism of the ANAO and Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of Defence. In concluding, I would also like to extend my thanks to all members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee for their deliberations during this inquiry, and also to the secretariat.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Publications Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: Report

Speaker: Mr CHRISTENSEN
Text: Dawson) (10:42): I present the report from the Publications

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee. I ask leave of the House to move that the report be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr CHRISTENSEN
Text: I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the report be agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 2017

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Ms LAMB
Text: Longman) (10:43): Yesterday I was celebrating the visit from the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for defence, Richard Marles, when he visited Remembrance House in Burpengary to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: talk to a group of returned service men and women. Remembrance House is quite literally a

Speaker: NA
Text: house. It's actually a home, a place for veterans to live and adjust to civilian life. It's a great

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative. We're very fortunate to have one in Burpengary; it's one of two in the country. The

Speaker: NA
Text: other sits in the member for Herbert's electorate up in Townsville. At this meeting with the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member, the shadow minister for defence, Richard Marles, we were resoundingly

Speaker: NA
Text: told of how difficult it can be for veterans to find decent, secure work that matches their

Speaker: NA
Text: needs. And, as a strong advocate for the veteran community, I heard this loud and clear, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been taking action since.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hold the position of the chair of Labor's Australian Jobs Taskforce, a caucus committee

Speaker: NA
Text: listening to people around the country involved in the job market: people in work who are

Speaker: NA
Text: looking for more work; people who are actually looking for any work at all; businesses;

Speaker: NA
Text: industry leaders; job service providers; and councils and state governments, of course. It's an

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative of the Labor Party to help shape policy that will move Australia forward. As I said

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier, listening to people is the only real way to formulate strong policy, particularly in this

Speaker: NA
Text: space of employment. So recently I have been holding a number of conversations with those

Speaker: NA
Text: in the space of employment for veterans, as part of this task force, and we've heard some very

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting things. We've been told in these conversations what the barriers are to people

Speaker: NA
Text: finding work and what support our veterans need in finding work, and of course we have been

Speaker: NA
Text: asking them what the solutions are to finding that work and helping them with that support.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's always good to get their views and their recommendations.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the years that the Abbott and Turnbull governments have been in power, too little has

Speaker: NA
Text: been done for the veterans of Australia-in particular, too little has been done to help them

Speaker: NA
Text: find decent and secure work upon returning to civilian life. I'd have to say that, until Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: gets into power at the next election, I'm more than happy to lend a hand and support any

Speaker: NA
Text: changes that support veterans, no matter how small those steps are.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'd now like to turn to schedule 4 of this bill. These changes are by no means sweeping

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms-the department has already been able to facilitate these employer initiative

Speaker: NA
Text: payments; this bill just legislates them-although, again, we'll welcome anything that helps

Speaker: NA
Text: our veterans. While strengthening the legislative foundation of payments is of course a good

Speaker: NA
Text: thing, it's not groundbreaking reform. What we really need, though, is this government to take

Speaker: NA
Text: a stronger, more considered and deliberate approach, making sure that meaningful policy

Speaker: NA
Text: enacts positive change for our veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also support changes in schedule 5 of this bill, which amends the Military Rehabilitation

Speaker: NA
Text: and Compensation Act 2004, as well as the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1988 for Defence related claims. This schedule will facilitate information-sharing between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission and the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation Corporation, with respect to certain service related compensation claims. The

Speaker: NA
Text: way that the system currently works is that, if someone's discharged for medical reasons, they

Speaker: NA
Text: have to undergo a medical. Then they have to go to the Commonwealth Superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation to organise payments. When they go there, they have to organise for another

Speaker: NA
Text: medical assessment. And then, if they go to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, they have to

Speaker: NA
Text: go through another. These amendments in schedule 5 of the bill go to making sure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: complicated and lengthy claims process for people seeking assistance from the department is

Speaker: NA
Text: smoothed and is easier for them. Enabling that sharing of information between the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: departments will assist the Commonwealth Superannuation Corporation in making speedier

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation benefits assessments and, in turn, assist the department in recognising a

Speaker: NA
Text: person's entitlement to incapacity payments. It's one of the issues with the current process.

Speaker: NA
Text: I've heard time after time that it's lengthy and it's complicated; for vulnerable people, it's

Speaker: NA
Text: additional stress that they just do not need. So of course I support schedule 5. As long as

Speaker: NA
Text: proper safeguards to protect veterans' privacy are in place, Labor and I are always supportive

Speaker: NA
Text: to changes to improve this process. So I'm happy and pleased to support this bill. I'm happy to

Speaker: NA
Text: support procedural processes that smooth the way forward and cut red tape for our veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms MADELEINE KING (Brand) (10:49): Before I speak on the Veterans' Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 2017, I would like to briefly associate myself with

Speaker: NA
Text: and support the comments of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and those of the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister for veterans' affairs, the member for Kingston, earlier this week in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's response to the recent Senate committee report on the inquiry into suicide by

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans and ex-service personnel, The constant battle: suicide by veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's a good thing that the government has accepted all the recommendations of the report,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Labor looks forward to continuing discussions with the government on the

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation of the recommendations. As someone who has a significant defence

Speaker: NA
Text: community-hosting, as Rockingham does, the largest naval base in Australia-veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns are of particular importance to me, and I welcome this action to address the tragic

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of suicide among the ex-service personnel and veteran community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'd also like to take this opportunity to congratulate the member for Kingston on her

Speaker: NA
Text: elevation to the Labor shadow cabinet. The member for Kingston and her office have been

Speaker: NA
Text: invaluable to me as an incoming member of parliament in the seat of Brand by assisting my

Speaker: NA
Text: office in the many and varied questions and issues that are raised by veterans and ex-service

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel and their families that live in my community. So I'd like to congratulate and thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Kingston.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'd like to speak in support of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Omnibus) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2017 and its amendments, that look to improve the operation of veterans' affairs legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The implementation of amendments that will clarify, improve or streamline the operation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the law as it applies to veterans' affairs and processes within the Department of Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs is a good move. My electorate of Brand, as I've said, is home to the Royal Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy's largest base, HMAS Stirling, located just off the coast of Rockingham. Commissioned

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1978, HMAS Stirling now hosts 12 fleet units, including the RAN's Anzac class frigates,

Speaker: NA
Text: with Collins class submarines also stationed here. HMAS Stirling is home to more than 2,300

Speaker: NA
Text: service personnel. HMAS Stirling and Garden Island, on which the base is, have changed a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal since I was a young girl growing up just around the corner in Shoalwater Bay.

Speaker: NA
Text: With many past and present servicewomen and men making the communities across Brand

Speaker: NA
Text: their permanent homes, this bill has the potential to improve the lives of many people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate. This bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence and Trade for consideration and, given the number of schedules and the potential

Speaker: NA
Text: impact they will have on how veterans engage with the department, this referral was

Speaker: NA
Text: supported by Labor. We on this side supported this referral so that the legislation could be

Speaker: NA
Text: thoroughly examined and so that proposed changes would not leave veterans any worse off

Speaker: NA
Text: once enacted. I'm happy to support those proposed changes that will benefit the former

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: servicewomen and men and their families who live in my electorate, and, of course, those

Speaker: NA
Text: across the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'd like to turn to the amendments and what they'll mean for people affected. This bill deals

Speaker: NA
Text: with a number of different elements within the Veterans' Affairs legislation in its eight

Speaker: NA
Text: schedules. Schedule 1 amendments look to align the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements

Speaker: NA
Text: Act under which the Veterans' Review Board operates and those similar provisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This work to align these similar provisions will modernise

Speaker: NA
Text: the board's operation by ensuring the board provides a mechanism of review that is accessible,

Speaker: NA
Text: fair, economical, informal and quick; proportionate to the importance and nature of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter; and promotes trust and confidence in the board's decision-making. The Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Review Board provides independent merits reviews of decisions about pensions and

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. This includes disability pensions, as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: rehabilitation, compensation and other benefits under the Military Rehabilitation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Appearing before the board when dealing with matters relating to pension decisions,

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation issues and rehab issues can be a highly emotional and daunting experience for

Speaker: NA
Text: many veterans. The RSL, in its submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, Defence and Trade, made the point of stating that many veterans who lodge a claim:

Speaker: NA
Text: … are often dealing with emotions associated with the loss of their military career, their inability or

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced ability to provide for their family, difficulty in obtaining employment post-service if they are

Speaker: NA
Text: injured or ill and strained relationships with family

Speaker: NA
Text: Appearing before the board is not an easy or straightforward action for many. This should be

Speaker: NA
Text: recognised as we consider this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 1 amendments also impose an ongoing obligation on both the claimant and on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Veterans' Affairs during the period until the board has determined the matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: to lodge with the board a copy of any document that is in their possession relevant to the

Speaker: NA
Text: review that has not been lodged previously. The amendments provide the board with the

Speaker: NA
Text: power to vary or revoke a decision made under the alternative dispute resolution process, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the consent of the parties and where the board is satisfied that it is within its powers and

Speaker: NA
Text: otherwise appropriate to do so. It also requires the Repatriation Commission or any person

Speaker: NA
Text: representing the commission in a review to use their best endeavours to assist the board in

Speaker: NA
Text: fulfilling their legislated objectives. These are all positive measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, it was proposed that section 6 of schedule 1 would give the Principal Member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Veterans' Review Board the ability to dismiss an application for review should they be

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied that the application, among other things, is misconceived, has no reasonable prospect

Speaker: NA
Text: of success or is otherwise an abuse of process. Stakeholders raised concern about this with the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee, and we on this side had concerns about this provision. The Veterans' Review

Speaker: NA
Text: Board is a less adversarial process than the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Veterans are not

Speaker: NA
Text: represented by lawyers before the board. Appearing before the board gives veterans a chance

Speaker: NA
Text: to have their say. It is their chance to be heard when otherwise they might not be. By taking

Speaker: NA
Text: this chance away from veterans, the government would fundamentally change how veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: engage with the board and how veterans perceive the board. I've been told by a senior

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate who appears before the Veterans' Review Board that most associations who

Speaker: NA
Text: represent veterans at the board would not support this change. People who work in this area,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the volunteers who work to assist vets and their families were very concerned that, while a

Speaker: NA
Text: principal member is usually quite reasonable, there was a risk in introducing this change.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a risk that a person could wrongly interpret documentation, leading to a veteran

Speaker: NA
Text: missing out on their right of review. For these reasons, advocates supported the process that is

Speaker: NA
Text: currently in place, as it is one where further advice can be sought and, in the process, can be

Speaker: NA
Text: used to further review a decision of the board.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed change to section 6 of schedule 1 had the potential to deny veterans the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to be heard. We have heard, again through the committee process, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: principal member would have been presented with the circumstances to use this power to

Speaker: NA
Text: dismiss an application for review only three times in the last seven years. Time and

Speaker: NA
Text: experience have shown that the process of review by veterans to the board is not one being

Speaker: NA
Text: misused by veterans, and legislating against veterans having an opportunity to be heard is not

Speaker: NA
