Text: an action that I would support. There seems to be little point in doing so. It seems this section

Speaker: NA
Text: would deliver very little while, at the same time, causing unnecessary upset and anxiety in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-service personnel community. The Kwinana, Rockingham and Port Kennedy RSL sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: branches in my electorate of Brand would also prefer this section be removed from this bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: We understand that the government, following the Labor opposition's urging, is now moving

Speaker: NA
Text: an amendment to remove this section. We welcome this change, as no doubt will advocates as

Speaker: NA
Text: well, as it recognises the unique nature of the Veterans' Review Board. I am very pleased to

Speaker: NA
Text: see the removal of this section.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendments in schedule 2, however, will work to benefit veterans by simplifying and

Speaker: NA
Text: streamlining processes. The current time it takes to appoint staff to the Specialist Medical

Speaker: NA
Text: Review Council-three months or longer-will be addressed. The long delay can affect the

Speaker: NA
Text: council's ability to do its very important job. The council's an independent body where vets

Speaker: NA
Text: who have issues with the decisions of the Repatriation Medical Authority regarding the

Speaker: NA
Text: content of a statement of principles can go for review. The statement of principles' content is

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of the particular kind of injury or disease or death suffered by the veteran, and this

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment will assist in more timely decisions being made for veterans-and that is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other streamlining measures will enable the Specialist Medical Review Council to adopt

Speaker: NA
Text: electronic lodgement of requests for reviews. That means a hard copy will no longer be

Speaker: NA
Text: required, and so requests for review will not have to be lodged at a Department of Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs office. This measure is broadly supported. Mind you, in particular parts of my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, we do have a lot of difficulty getting internet coverage, and the NBN's a long way

Speaker: NA
Text: away, so some veterans living in communities in Baldivis will still have to go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Veterans' Affairs office because the infrastructure is not in place for them to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to use this modern provision of electronic lodgement.

Speaker: NA
Text: In regard to the electronic lodgement provision, the community has commented it should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be used to the detriment of veterans when submitting claims, appeals or reconsiderations.

Speaker: NA
Text: No doubt, for those who can undertake electronic lodgement, it'll be beneficial for those

Speaker: NA
Text: people in a single-claim situation, but there may be complications if a complex issue is

Speaker: NA
Text: involved. I understand such complications can arise around understanding statements of

Speaker: NA
Text: principles and with the different standards of proof required in different situations. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: important that people who choose to use, or are able to use, this new electronic lodgement

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: method do so knowing they can still seek advice from an advocate should they need it; but,

Speaker: NA
Text: for those who do not require additional support and advice, this amendment in introducing a

Speaker: NA
Text: new, more efficient electronic lodgement of request for review does have the potential to

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit veterans who are, indeed, able to access the internet at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other amendments in this bill will allow for the provision of financial assistance to people

Speaker: NA
Text: attending a Specialist Medical Review Council hearing to make an oral submission. This

Speaker: NA
Text: measure will see individuals, as well as representatives of organisations and any necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: attendants accompanying them, being able to receive financial assistance to attend a hearing

Speaker: NA
Text: to make an oral submission. We've received positive feedback on this measure. I've been told

Speaker: NA
Text: it will ensure a better process as it ensures the hearing is as informed as possible of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons for the applicant pursuing the review. I'm told there is a chance that the panel might

Speaker: NA
Text: not have all the relevant information before them when making their decision. I'm also told

Speaker: NA
Text: that hard copies of complex claims are not circulated in their entirety and that documents,

Speaker: NA
Text: once lodged, have, sadly, become lost or misplaced. Making it financially possible for a

Speaker: NA
Text: veteran or their representative to attend a hearing and make such an oral submission will help

Speaker: NA
Text: alleviate the stress when these things happen, and this is a positive step.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another good step in the bill is a measure that would give the minister the power to make

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements with foreign governments to cover the provision of benefits and the payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits. With this bill, in schedule 3, the minister can enter into agreements in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: reciprocal arrangements with Veterans' Affairs matters. This amendment will broaden the

Speaker: NA
Text: countries with which Australia can enter agreements beyond the Commonwealth. Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: reps in my electorate are supportive of this measure as it is beneficial to veterans who no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer live in Australia. At the moment, only payments payable under the Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Entitlements Act are covered by existing agreements. This bill will now cover allied veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: and Defence Force members with the type of service equivalent to that covered by the VEA.

Speaker: NA
Text: The means that the agreements will relate to payments and treatment provided by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Repatriation Commission or the MRCC. We are supportive of this measure that will extend

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements so that veterans are covered, regardless of the legislative framework.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hear from veterans and advocates about the lengthy and complicated claims process

Speaker: NA
Text: that people can face when seeking assistance. Labor supports the changes that will assist

Speaker: NA
Text: people in this process to make their lives easier, bearing in mind the need to ensure adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguards are in place to protect veterans' privacy. One way this bill will do this is by

Speaker: NA
Text: addressing the doubling and sometimes the tripling of the requirement for veterans to undergo

Speaker: NA
Text: medicals when they engage in the system. The situation at the moment is that a veteran who

Speaker: NA
Text: was medically discharged needs to undergo a medical and then, when they go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Superannuation Corporation to organise their payments, they undergo

Speaker: NA
Text: another medical, and this may be followed by a third medical when they go to the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Veterans' Affairs for assistance. The amendments in this bill will enable information to be

Speaker: NA
Text: shared between the Commonwealth Superannuation Corporation and the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Affairs. This will enable the CSC to access relevant claims information held by the

Speaker: NA
Text: department. Information would include relevant medical and rehab information which would

Speaker: NA
Text: assist the CSC to make quicker superannuation benefit assessments. This will, in turn, assist

Speaker: NA
Text: the department in determining a person's entitlement to incapacity payments. The upside of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: such sharing would be a more timely outcome for veterans at a vulnerable and stressful time

Speaker: NA
Text: in their lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 7 looks to eliminate the unnecessary delays in administrative issues that are

Speaker: NA
Text: caused when certain veterans' affairs portfolio legislative instruments need to be amended to

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporate changes in non-disallowable instruments. Each individual instrument will no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer need to be lodged in parliament. One such example is when a new rehabilitation

Speaker: NA
Text: appliance becomes available. Availability of the new equipment is delayed, as a legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: instrument that incorporates the document under which the applicant may be provided the

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment needs to be amended to refer to the policy document's changed date. Eliminating

Speaker: NA
Text: such delays would have a real and beneficial impact on veterans' lives and should be

Speaker: NA
Text: supported.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor supports the measures in this bill which go to streamlining and improving the law as

Speaker: NA
Text: it improves the processes that affect veterans' lives. With the amendments the government is

Speaker: NA
Text: planning on moving, we on this side of the House offer our support of the legislation. Once

Speaker: NA
Text: again, I congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs on his work and that of his department

Speaker: NA
Text: in this regard, and also the shadow minister for veterans' affairs, the member for Kingston,

Speaker: NA
Text: and her office for all of their work in this portfolio.

Speaker: Mr DICK
Text: Oxley) (11:04): I rise to support the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Omnibus) Bill 2017. In doing so, I want to recognise the great work on both sides of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber. It is a true demonstration of the commitment that I think this whole House has to

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans in our community. Listening to my colleague and friend the member for Brand, I

Speaker: NA
Text: know her deep connection to the ADF through her family and also through her work as a local

Speaker: NA
Text: MP. I echo the sentiments she finished her comments with today about service and

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising the good work of the minister and the shadow minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to spend a little time highlighting the fact that the bill before the House is a clear

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstration that when good ideas are put forward and when simplification is delivered,

Speaker: NA
Text: both sides of the parliament can work together. In the last two weeks, I've probably spoken in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House of Representatives and Federation Chamber more than I have done since I was

Speaker: NA
Text: elected. I've spoken about a range of issues, on a range of portfolio allocations and on a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of local issues, but I have particularly taken time to read and understand this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: because I know it demonstrates to the wider Australian community that when both sides of

Speaker: NA
Text: politics work together and when both sides of the House of Representatives can join forces we

Speaker: NA
Text: can make a huge difference. Contrast that with some of the unfortunately divisive debates and

Speaker: NA
Text: divisions we've seen through the week. This bill before the House today gives a clear

Speaker: NA
Text: indication and a clear pathway forward for dealing with complicated issues surrounding

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans in our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to acknowledge the member for Herbert, who is in the House today, and her

Speaker: NA
Text: powerful speech on this bill yesterday and her strong advocacy as a representative of a large

Speaker: NA
Text: number of serving ADF and personnel in Townsville. Listening to the member for Herbert

Speaker: NA
Text: and talking to her about the advocacy she does when she's in the community in her electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: I know how important it is that government gets it right.

Speaker: NA
Text: Listening to the minister's second reading speech and also to the ministerial statement

Speaker: NA
Text: which was delivered to the House back in August, I know there are around 291,000

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians that the Department of Veterans' Affairs supports. Just over half of these people

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: are veterans or currently serving members of the ADF, around 48 per cent are women, around

Speaker: NA
Text: 82,000 are widows or widowers, and around 2½ thousand are children of veterans. Today,

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 203,000 of DVA's clients are 65 years old or older, while about 23,000 are under

Speaker: NA
Text: the age of 40. They represent every aspect of service, they represent every walk of life and

Speaker: NA
Text: they are across the whole of our nation, in every corner of our cities and towns.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate of Oxley, I'm very proud to be able to work alongside the RSL and

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans' organisations. I know every single member of the House works hard to advocate the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of these people and, more importantly, the services that our serving and former

Speaker: NA
Text: serving men and women need in order to participate and to make sure their lives are

Speaker: NA
Text: honoured, and also to assist the transitions that many people go through as they leave the

Speaker: NA
Text: ADF. In the past 12 months, over 1,400 members of the ADF have separated from the forces

Speaker: NA
Text: for reasons not of their choosing. Ten years ago, just over 740 members separated

Speaker: NA
Text: involuntarily. How we help these men and women, how we provide for their transition and

Speaker: NA
Text: how we look at support for people when they are in the broader community is critical to the

Speaker: NA
Text: work that we do as members of parliament and also as community leaders.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that the Veterans' Review Board plays an important role in the merits review of

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. As the shadow minister, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingston, indicated, Labor is supportive of the changes proposed in this bill which clarify,

Speaker: NA
Text: improve and streamline the operation of the law and processes within the department.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the first things I did when I was elected to this place was to invite the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister to my electorate to meet with veterans and to meet with the local RSLs in my

Speaker: NA
Text: community. It was very clear from that initial meeting that government has a critical role to

Speaker: NA
Text: play in the ongoing support of veterans. I had been to a number of services over the years. I

Speaker: NA
Text: had met with a number of groups in my former role as a Brisbane city councillor, but it was

Speaker: NA
Text: being elected to this place and understanding and listening to the trauma and the difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: that former members of the ADF and their families-particularly their families-suffer and

Speaker: NA
Text: go through.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the son of a World War II veteran who served in the Navy as a signalman, I could

Speaker: NA
Text: always listen to my father talk about his experiences. That was a time when perhaps,

Speaker: NA
Text: following from when he left the Navy, often issues weren't discussed. Often there were times

Speaker: NA
Text: when men and women who served in the armed forces simply said: 'Well, that was wartime.

Speaker: NA
Text: We'll leave that behind. You don't need to talk about that. Get on with your life.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Luckily, those times have changed. Today's amendments broadly set out a goal and an

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement to make sure that veterans who need support, who perhaps have served and are

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with complicated issues, have accessibility improved. This bill today is not just about

Speaker: NA
Text: making it fairer; it's about making it more economical and informal and having a quick

Speaker: NA
Text: turnaround for a whole range of services. It promotes public trust and confidence in the

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions that we need to make and that the board needs to make. It's important that the

Speaker: NA
Text: process is as easy as possible for veterans to have a fair hearing on the merits of the decisions

Speaker: NA
Text: made.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a number of elements to the bill. It's divided into eight schedules. A number of

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers have gone through those schedules in detail, as did the minister and the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. I'm going to focus on one or two today. I know the veterans in my community and

Speaker: NA
Text: those who have come to my office seeking assistance have reflected a concern that the current

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: system causes unworkable administrative issues and, sadly, unnecessary delays. We know

Speaker: NA
Text: from listening to the debate and following this closely, as I have, that the shadow minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: conveyed some of these concerns to the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: After section 155(8), the bill inserts a proposed new subsection (8A), which gives the

Speaker: NA
Text: power to the principal member to dismiss an application for review if it is frivolous or

Speaker: NA
Text: vexatious, has no reasonable prospect of success or is otherwise an abuse of process. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister said in her statement, we thank the government for removing this proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: subsection. As the member for Brand indicated, we did share the concerns conveyed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans community and the RSL, who indicated a strong view on behalf of veterans that this

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed subsection should be removed, so we welcome this change. It reflects the unique

Speaker: NA
Text: nature of the Veterans' Review Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the other great opportunities I've had, apart from meeting and working closely with

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans in my community, was to be able to go onto the ground and visit our troops and our

Speaker: NA
Text: serving personnel when I visited the Middle East through the ADF Parliamentary Program. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was able and privileged to spend time with members of the Defence Force serving in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Middle East. We were able to visit the bases in the Middle East, to visit Afghanistan and to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend time in Kabul. This enabled me as a representative to see very clearly, firsthand, what

Speaker: NA
Text: our men and women go through on a daily basis. You can read about it, you can turn on the

Speaker: NA
Text: television, or you can log on and sometimes view what's happening, but, when you are able to

Speaker: NA
Text: visit a country at war and you see the dangers, the sacrifices and the sheer hard work that our

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women go through every single day, it puts a brand-new perspective on things. That

Speaker: NA
Text: experience left me with a greater respect for the Defence Force and the incredible sacrifices

Speaker: NA
Text: they make.

Speaker: NA
Text: Currently, there are around 1,700 ADF personnel deployed to the Middle East region. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force personnel remain active in advising, assisting and training Iraqi security forces

Speaker: NA
Text: and training and advising the Afghan National Defence and Security Forces in Afghanistan. I

Speaker: NA
Text: was privileged to be able to go and meet them and have a greater and deeper understanding of

Speaker: NA
Text: just what the ADF are doing to assist the men and women serving in the military there to lead,

Speaker: NA
Text: hopefully, to peace and recognition in that region. Our troops are not only doing an incredible

Speaker: NA
Text: job representing our country but, as I said, are working side by side with the local forces to

Speaker: NA
Text: train and equip the Afghan army. Above all, it was amazing. I was honoured to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: professionalism and commitment of our serving personnel on display 24/7.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that our troops are the best in the world and incredibly dedicated to serving our

Speaker: NA
Text: country. But I also know that in my own local community there are many ADF families that

Speaker: NA
Text: are separated from their loved ones. I cannot imagine the trauma, difficulties and fears those

Speaker: NA
Text: family members go through from day to day not knowing due to operational issues where

Speaker: NA
Text: their family members are and whether they are safe. The reputation of the ADF and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families and peacekeepers extends beyond our borders and to accompanying nations who also

Speaker: NA
Text: have personnel serving in the region.

Speaker: NA
Text: From my own experience on the ground, from working with our veterans groups, I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand how critical and important it is to streamline medical and treatment processes for

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans. As I said in my earlier remarks, I have hosted round tables with the shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister. This week we saw the elevation to the shadow cabinet of the member for Kingston

Speaker: NA
Text: as our spokesperson for veterans' affairs. That's a very clear and powerful demonstration of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: strong leadership by an alternative government and by Bill Shorten, the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. We are sending a clear message, when it comes to veterans, that there is strong

Speaker: NA
Text: bipartisan support. The minister and the shadow minister worked closely in cooperation. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: incredibly pleased to see Labor taking a positive step to include the issues of veterans in the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow cabinet. That sends a message to the wider community that we not only take their

Speaker: NA
Text: issues seriously but, if we are privileged to serve the nation as a future Shorten Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government, we will have a veterans' affairs minister sitting at the table making the major

Speaker: NA
Text: decisions-as it should be.

Speaker: NA
Text: I acknowledge all the work of members of parliament in this place. We are very privileged

Speaker: NA
Text: to have on my side of the chamber the member for Solomon, Luke Gosling OAM, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Eden-Monaro, Mike Kelly OAM, who have demonstrated their commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: public service in this place and also in the Australian Defence Force. I know from talking to

Speaker: NA
Text: the members for Solomon and Eden-Monaro the difficulties veterans go through when they

Speaker: NA
Text: leave the force, the difficulties for their families. We heard this week the ministerial statement

Speaker: NA
Text: on suicide within the ADF, and I was so pleased to see both sides of politics joining forces to

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge the rates of suicide are too high and, more importantly, that there is a plan going

Speaker: NA
Text: forward and more work to be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the minister and the shadow minister for their efforts in working constructively

Speaker: NA
Text: together on this piece of legislation. I look forward to voting for this to see improvements for

Speaker: NA
Text: our ADF personnel. But the job is not finished. As a member of parliament, I will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate and represent to make sure the interests of our serving ADF men and women are

Speaker: NA
Text: looked after now and in the future.

Speaker: Ms BUTLER
Text: Griffith) (11:18): This is a very important bill and, as the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Oxley has just told the House, it is a great example of bipartisanship and collaboration

Speaker: NA
Text: between the minister and the shadow minister. I pay tribute to the shadow minister. She's been

Speaker: NA
Text: an excellent shadow minister for veterans' affairs and her diligence has seen the elevation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Veterans' Affairs portfolio to the shadow cabinet, which I think emphasises the

Speaker: NA
Text: significance of the portfolio from the perspective of the opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor is supportive of changes in this bill which will clarify, improve or streamline the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the law and processes within the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This bill is an

Speaker: NA
Text: omnibus bill. It contains eight schedules which deal with a variety of elements in the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. It's fair to say that through the interventions of the shadow minister, amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: will be proposed that will significantly improve the operation of this bill in the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans and ex-service personnel.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do want to talk a little about the importance of veterans and veterans' support, including in

Speaker: NA
Text: my own community. I also want to touch on, as the member for Oxley did, the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial statement in respect of suicide amongst veterans and ex-service personnel, to

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasise the importance of continuing to respond to suicide within that community and to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide support. I'm really fortunate as a member of parliament to have had, for the entire

Speaker: NA
Text: time I have been a member, constant and regular engagement with ADSO to talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans' issues. The local representatives of ADSO were one of the first groups to contact me

Speaker: NA
Text: after I was elected at a by-election in February 2014, seeking to set up regularly scheduled

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings, which we did set up. I want to thank them for the work they have done and continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to do around the country, not just in my electorate, actually helping members of parliament to

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the issues that are unique to and that face the community of veterans and ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: service personnel. I particularly wanted to thank, from ADSO, Ted Chitham and Ross

Speaker: NA
Text: Clelland. They have been quite tenacious and unrelenting in seeking to raise with me several

Speaker: NA
Text: issues that are relevant to the lives of veterans and ex-service personnel. I know they will

Speaker: NA
Text: have seen and noted the work that's been done in respect of suicide in the community, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also wanted to thank the late Peter Snowdon, who was one of the first of the ADSO

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives to visit me. It was very sad to lose Peter from our community, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans' community lost a very good advocate when Peter passed. I want to acknowledge his

Speaker: NA
Text: work as an advocate for veterans' interests and as somebody who would come to my office

Speaker: NA
Text: and talk to me about these really difficult issues. Occasionally, he would send an email

Speaker: NA
Text: directly to me raising any number of issues. We often disagreed, but he was always so

Speaker: NA
Text: positive about it, so willing to engage in a spirited debate and discussion, and such a great

Speaker: NA
Text: supporter of ADSO's continued engagements with members of parliament. I do miss him and

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm very sorry for the community's loss of Peter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm also fortunate to have in the electorate of Griffith the Greenslopes Private Hospital,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is a veterans' hospital and has been a veterans' hospital since it was established.

Speaker: NA
Text: Greenslopes Private Hospital staff are well known in the community for the work they do

Speaker: NA
Text: with veterans. Their very beautifully put together Anzac Day service, which is a service at

Speaker: NA
Text: dawn that is so well attended by the local community, gets hundreds and hundreds of people.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have an amazing Catafalque party from the local Anglican church grammar school, a

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful choir from Somerville House that perform every year exceptionally well, and very,

Speaker: NA
Text: very senior representations from the local community and the veterans' community. It's not

Speaker: NA
Text: just the work they do in commemoration and acknowledgment; it's the work they also do in

Speaker: NA
Text: the real issues facing veterans today, and I'm speaking particularly about the work that that

Speaker: NA
Text: foundation does to support post-traumatic stress disorder research.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Greenslopes Private Hospital also auspices the Gallipoli Medical Research

Speaker: NA
Text: Foundation, which is doing a lot of work in relation to PTSD, including a study in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam veterans which I have referred to in this chamber before. The study found that one in

Speaker: NA
Text: three Australian veterans from the Vietnam War developed PTSD, and that participants with

Speaker: NA
Text: PTSD had four times the chance of having had a heart attack in the past; two times the risk of

Speaker: NA
Text: stomach ulcers; more than triple the risk of acting out their dreams while asleep; almost twice

Speaker: NA
Text: the tendency for restless legs; and increased daytime fatigue and sleepiness, as well as two

Speaker: NA
Text: times the risk of suffering sleep apnoea; double the chance of reflux; a greater tendency to

Speaker: NA
Text: report constipation, diarrhoea and irritable bowel syndrome; and lower levels of good

Speaker: NA
Text: cholesterol, which contributes to an increased risk of heart disease. The ramifications of

Speaker: NA
Text: developing PTSD are physical and psychological, and it is very important that organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: like the Gallipoli Medical Research Foundation continue their work of providing an evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: base about what can be done for veterans who have developed PTSD as a consequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: their service.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to mention the work that is being done by the many RSL sub-branches-and

Speaker: NA
Text: you couldn't talk about the work that's being done for veterans without doing so-in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Griffith. Being an inner suburbs seat in Brisbane, we're fortunate that we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of organisations that provide support for veterans, and we have a range of RSL sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: branches. I couldn't possibly do all of them justice in the short time left to me, but I did want

Speaker: NA
Text: to mention a couple of the RSL sub-branches that I've visited recently.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first is the Holland Park sub-branch. Every sub-branch is special, but this one is special

Speaker: NA
Text: in a particular way. It's a very naval sub-branch of the RSL. It's led by Sonja and Alan Hellier,

Speaker: NA
Text: who are well known in RSL circles in Queensland. They are both excellent people. Someone

Speaker: NA
Text: said to me the other day, 'What Sonja Hellier doesn't know about welfare for veterans could

Speaker: NA
Text: fit on a postage stamp,' and I think that's pretty accurate. She is a wealth of knowledge for the

Speaker: NA
Text: local community in relation to veterans and welfare. The two of them, together with the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee for that RSL, do so much great work to bring the community together and bring

Speaker: NA
Text: the RSL membership together, and I really want to acknowledge them. I went to the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: branch's lunch recently. We heard from a really interesting speaker who'd came to military

Speaker: NA
Text: service quite late in his life-not that late, but not as a young person. That's the sort of thing

Speaker: NA
Text: they do. They bring people together; they bring diverse viewpoints together. And, of course, I

Speaker: NA
Text: also always see them every year at the commemoration of the Voyager disaster at St Mary's at

Speaker: NA
Text: Kangaroo Point, which is a very moving service. So I want to acknowledge them both for the

Speaker: NA
Text: work that they do in our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another sub-branch that I've visited recently is the Norman Park RSL sub-branch. Again,

Speaker: NA
Text: it's very special. It's a sub-branch focused on nashos. They have a really great, active sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: branch with, again, excellent commemorations on Anzac Day and, of course, Remembrance

Speaker: NA
Text: Day, which is forthcoming. The nashos came up with a really lovely idea, which was to seek

Speaker: NA
Text: to obtain from the Australian War Memorial a sapling of a Lone Pine and have that planted

Speaker: NA
Text: right behind the memorial at Norman Park. It's a beautiful memorial, so I was very pleased to

Speaker: NA
Text: donate the sapling from the Australian War Memorial. Recently, I met with the leadership of

Speaker: NA
Text: the sub-branch, Brian and Margaret Besgrove, and also with Ken Cork, who'd been the

Speaker: NA
Text: motivating instigator of the Lone Pine project, for a small ceremony in relation to the planting

Speaker: NA
Text: of that Lone Pine.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do encourage other RSL sub-branches to have a look at what the Australian War

Speaker: NA
Text: Memorial can do in terms of providing Lone Pine saplings. Obviously, for my own electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: I'd be very, very pleased to assist those who don't have them to obtain Lone Pine trees. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: really beautiful acknowledgment, particularly as we are commemorating the Centenary of

Speaker: NA
Text: Anzac over these few years in the current period. The nashos sub-branch at Norman Park is a

Speaker: NA
Text: really beautiful sub-branch. So much work is being done there for the welfare of veterans and

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-service personnel. I went to one of their recent lunches as well where we had a really great

Speaker: NA
Text: turnout and a great opportunity to talk about some of the issues of concern to veterans, and a

Speaker: NA
Text: few other issues as well, of course.

Speaker: NA
Text: In acknowledging the importance of responding to the needs of veterans and ex-service

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel, I did want to mention those organisations. As I say, they are certainly not the only

Speaker: NA
Text: RSL sub-branches in my electorate. There are many of them, and each one of them is unique.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each of them has a specific interest or focus. I went to the Greek RSL sub-branch a little

Speaker: NA
Text: while ago now for a commemoration in Brisbane city. It was a beautiful commemoration for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Greek community as well. I'd better stop because I can't possibly list every single RSL

Speaker: NA
Text: sub-branch in the electorate in this one speech, but I do acknowledge them all for the work

Speaker: NA
Text: that they do.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Like the member for Oxley, I have had family members who have had active service in

Speaker: NA
Text: World War I and World War II, and I do think it is important, whenever we talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans' affairs in this place, to stop and acknowledge what that really means: what active

Speaker: NA
Text: service has meant, what involvement in peacekeeping operations has meant and what it has

Speaker: NA
Text: meant to be a member of the Defence Force, for all ex-service personnel-people who

Speaker: NA
Text: volunteered to make great sacrifices for the country. We owe them a great debt of gratitude,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that willingness, the voluntary nature of it and the sacrifices made, whether in active

Speaker: NA
Text: service or not, ought to be acknowledged at every opportunity when veterans' affairs matters

Speaker: NA
Text: are being considered in this parliament, and I do so now.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also wanted to touch on, as I said, the bipartisanship around suicide prevention for

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans and ex-service personnel. The minister did make a statement and there was bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: support for that. There's a recent Australian government response to a Senate Foreign Affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence and Trade References Committee report in relation to suicide by veterans. It's very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasing to see that the government has accepted the recommendations of that report and has

Speaker: NA
Text: signalled an intention to undertake a range of measures with a view to preventing suicide

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst veterans and ex-service personnel. All of us in this House of Representatives will

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard from local veterans of the loss of friends that they have suffered as a consequence

Speaker: NA
Text: of suicide. All of us will have attended events, like the event that was held here at parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: in recent months, to commemorate suicide amongst veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: So it is incredibly important of course that the minister-having published a response to

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee's report, accepting the recommendations that have been made-now vigorously

Speaker: NA
Text: seek to implement all of those recommendations which he has accepted. We know that, in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to get things done in this place, you need vigorous application to the cause. You need

Speaker: NA
Text: constant follow-up. I'm quite confident that the minister and the shadow minister will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to pursue, with vigour, measures that will improve our response to suicide amongst

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans and ex-service personnel and that that will improve suicide prevention amongst that

Speaker: NA
Text: community as well. It's a very important bipartisan approach that needs to be taken in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to those issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: I did want to say just a couple of things about the bill. As I said at the outset, it is an

Speaker: NA
Text: omnibus bill. There have been a couple of particular amendments to the bill that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: inspired by the concerns raised by the Labor opposition, including in respect of the Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Review Board's ability to dismiss an application for review, which caused some concern in

Speaker: NA
Text: the ex-service community. I'm very pleased that the shadow minister was able to lead

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations for amendments that will deal with some of the concerns that have been raised.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm also very pleased that this is such a wide-ranging bill that will have such bipartisan

Speaker: NA
Text: support in moves to improve the lives of the veterans and ex-service community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Accordingly, Labor is supportive of the changes which streamline or improve the operation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the law, as far as it does improve processes for veterans, and, in light of the amendments that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government is planning to make, we'll support the bill. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr MIKE KELLY (Eden-Monaro) (11:33): It is a great pleasure to speak on the Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs Legislation Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 2017 in the context of the bipartisanship that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been demonstrated on this issue. I think the most enjoyable experience that I've had in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament has been working on security matters on the intelligence and security committee

Speaker: NA
Text: and on issues to do with veterans with members of the coalition. In particular, I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Veterans' Affairs has really had his heart in his portfolio. I still would continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate for, though, and support the suggestions by Neil James and the Australia Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Association that the minister has got too much on his plate, that there should be more people

Speaker: NA
Text: in the portfolio and that the minister should be able to concentrate on the personnel and

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans' issues, and obviously the cybersecurity issues that are also in his space really need

Speaker: NA
Text: greater focus and concentration by support from another person in the portfolio.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister's doing a very fine job, despite those limitations. In particular, I really

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome his support for the bipartisan work of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: References Committee in relation to veteran suicide. That was one of the issues, apart from

Speaker: NA
Text: family experience with that subject, that led me to work with the member for Berowra in

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing a parliamentary friendship group on the prevention of suicide. I'd like to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Health, who is at the table, for his support, and the shadow minister. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have been avid participants and have kept extremely open minds about the types of issues that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been raised in that forum, which have direct relevance to suicide issues for veterans, as

Speaker: NA
Text: well.

Speaker: NA
Text: We'll be together again in Beersheba in a few days time, celebrating the victory at

Speaker: NA
Text: Beersheba and commemorating the service and sacrifice of our men in the field in that battle

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 years ago on 31 October. It is particularly poignant for me, as there were members of my

Speaker: NA
Text: own family in the light horse. They, both of my grandfathers, were back again in the Second

Speaker: NA
Text: World War. They were looked after by the Jewish community in the area while they were

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting in the Middle East, particularly in Syria and Lebanon. They went on to suffer great

Speaker: NA
Text: traumas, one as a prisoner of the Japanese on the Burma-Thai railway and the other with

Speaker: NA
Text: severe injuries he suffered in New Guinea. I learn a lot from the family experiences that I've

Speaker: NA
Text: been exposed to as to some of the worst aspects of the traumas that veterans have had to go

Speaker: NA
Text: through.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every generation of our family has served in the army, going back to the Crimean War, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Indian mutiny, the Afghan War, the first and second world wars, my own service and my

Speaker: NA
Text: father's service-even uncles and aunts. So it is something that I have a lot of understanding

Speaker: NA
Text: of, from the personal experience that's been passed on to me. Since I've entered parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been greatly expanded by the fact that I represent nearly 3,000 veterans in Eden-

Speaker: NA
Text: Monaro, who have an average age of about 66 now. Some of the stories from them have been

Speaker: NA
Text: quite tragic. One of them involved a veteran who had been a prisoner of the Japanese. His

Speaker: NA
Text: wife endured tremendous hardship for 40 years after he returned home after the Second World

Speaker: NA
Text: War, with his terrible nightmares and his resorting to self-medication with alcohol. She

Speaker: NA
Text: endured great hardships. He'd wake up in the middle of the night, strangling her, thinking she

Speaker: NA
Text: was a Japanese soldier. It came to a point where she just couldn't take that any more. Her life

Speaker: NA
Text: was at risk. She was advised that she needed to move out of the household, which she did.

Speaker: NA
Text: Her husband passed away but she wasn't entitled to war widows support, which she

Speaker: NA
Text: desperately needed. We tried to get her some ex gratia payments to support her.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unfortunately, she went into hospital for a hip replacement operation and contracted

Speaker: NA
Text: septicaemia and died in hospital. We were never able to achieve that for her, but her case

Speaker: NA
Text: highlights another aspect we need to look at in these processes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The veterans in my community have raised so many issues with me about the whole issue

Speaker: NA
Text: around process: the point-of-entry experience and trying to get around the complexity of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: making a claim, with the adversarial aspects of it. We need to have a benefit-of-the-doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to these things. They have raised all these issues with me, but as I was sitting here a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of minutes ago, waiting to speak in this debate, I received an email from a veteran

Speaker: NA
Text: which really sums it up. I'll just read that letter to me. It's from Tony Cullinan, who says:

Speaker: NA
Text: Dear Mike,

Speaker: NA
Text: I am a member of your constituency living in Bega.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a lot of service injuries and they are getting progressively worse. I am in varying degrees of pain

Speaker: NA
Text: a lot of the time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I own a small business and get by, but it's pretty tight.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a lot of depression and anxiety around my injuries.

Speaker: NA
Text: I've been sitting here for the last hour waiting to be linked into a directions hearing with the VRB-

Speaker: NA
Text: the Veterans' Review Board-

Speaker: NA
Text: which was supposed to take place at 10. I called at ¼ passed 10 and a lady was surprised and said she

Speaker: NA
Text: would get back to me. I've heard nothing and I am sitting hear waiting.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are no advocacy services in Bega and I have been hooked into Woden – but it's a long way and

Speaker: NA
Text: they don't really know what's going on for me. I really feel overwhelmed by all of this.

Speaker: NA
Text: Respectfully,

Speaker: NA
Text: Tony Cullinan

Speaker: NA
Text: That pretty much sums up the experience of the veterans who have approached me. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously very pleased to see an attempt to address these issues, with this legislation in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the concern that we raised about the principal member process, I'm really delighted the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's picked that up. It really continued to embed in this process the adversarial issue

Speaker: NA
Text: and denied members the ability to have their day in court and be heard, genuinely and openly,

Speaker: NA
Text: so I'm delighted that section has been removed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, I'm really delighted with the aspects that we've been dealing with recently and are

Speaker: NA
Text: promoting in terms of employer incentive scheme payments. That transition process is such a

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult one for all ex-members. You come from a completely different cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: environment-a completely different family-like environment within Defence-and you

Speaker: NA
Text: move into the general community and perhaps bring with you some mental baggage which

Speaker: NA
Text: you know nobody around you understands. And you speak a completely different language, in

Speaker: NA
Text: many cases. I've experienced a lot of this myself. We needed to address more aggressively the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of that transition, so I'm pleased to see that's happening and that the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing some measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my own region, I'd like to highlight two things that I'm really pleased with. One is

Speaker: NA
Text: Remount, a Yass based organisation that works with veterans. They have broken important

Speaker: NA
Text: ground. They take Remount members and employees and they do great work in dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: ex-military members who are suffering from stress related injuries through their service, such

Speaker: NA
Text: as PTSD, by getting them to work with horses and having that experience. We know that a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: of association with animals and pets has been a great way to help our veterans deal with their

Speaker: NA
Text: issues, so I really want to salute Remount. They are sponsored by Lockheed Martin. I'm very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that we're seeing some of the defence industry companies helping us and getting

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: involved now with these issues, knowing that they really do owe their own input into these

Speaker: NA
Text: processes of dealing with our veterans. Well done, Remount at Yass and Lockheed Martin.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was at the Snowy Hydro the other day and talked to Gabrielle Curtin. She raised with me

Speaker: NA
Text: a program that they have where they have transitioning services for men and women and get

Speaker: NA
Text: them into employment. It's great to see them taking that active role. It is another great

Speaker: NA
Text: example of what the Snowy Hydro has done for our country. There are so many ways. They're

Speaker: NA
Text: taking that responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's part of the general culture in our region to support our service veterans. It has the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest voluntary participation rate in the country. You will see a lot of effort in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community to try to assist veterans and honour them. Just the other day, we had the opening

Speaker: NA
Text: of a lovely rock memorial in Bega to the Lucas family. It was an experience that has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: replicated anywhere in the world, as far as we know: there were 10 boys in the Lucas family

Speaker: NA
Text: and nine of them joined up and went to World War II. It was a tremendous sacrifice by that

Speaker: NA
Text: family. Some did not come home from their service. The unique history in our region is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that we celebrate and honour.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another example is the Union Jack memorial that you pass on the way to Tumbarumba. It's

Speaker: NA
Text: not a memorial to the flag, the Union Jack. There used to be a town called Union Jack and,

Speaker: NA
Text: during the First World War, every male of military service age was killed in the First World

Speaker: NA
Text: War. Their names are listed on that memorial. The town was effectively destroyed by a war

Speaker: NA
Text: 12,000 kilometres away because the surviving family members had to move away. It's very

Speaker: NA
Text: special for our region and I appreciate the measures that are being taken to render more

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government support.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a couple of issues. I say this in the spirit of highlighting problems we still need to

Speaker: NA
Text: address and where I think we're going down the wrong track. There were previous proposals

Speaker: NA
Text: to eliminate the Department of Veterans' Affairs and move it into Human Services. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: raised in an ACCI paper that my predecessor published when he was head of ACCI. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: work was being done on that when the coalition came to government. We're seeing it actually

Speaker: NA
Text: playing out in relation to Veterans' Access Networks. The Veterans' Access Network here in

Speaker: NA
Text: the ACT was shut down. It served a lot of veterans from across the border. The services have

Speaker: NA
Text: been shifted into the nearby Centrelink office on Bowes Street.

Speaker: NA
Text: We're of course well aware of the problems we've had with Centrelink: the attempts to

Speaker: NA
Text: automate services, the delays and problems. We just had a story appear-I think it was

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday-about the delays that have left recipients unable to pay for rent or food and about

Speaker: NA
Text: complaints having jumped to more than 50,000 in the past financial year alone. It seems that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is an attempt to remove the 'human' from Human Services, and it's causing so much stress

Speaker: NA
Text: and anxiety.

Speaker: NA
Text: My electorate offices have been absolutely inundated with these issues emerging from

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink. We've basically become an adjunct to that office. We've had people in great stages

Speaker: NA
Text: of stress and anxiety who in fact have been suicidal, and my office workers have been doing

Speaker: NA
Text: such a wonderful job relieving that stress and anxiety by basically getting in and doing what

Speaker: NA
Text: Centrelink should have been doing for them and working with points of contact.

Speaker: NA
Text: It gives me great concern when we're attempting to shut down our vans, shut down the

Speaker: NA
Text: human contact that veterans, in particular in rural and regional areas, really need. You really

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: need a human to go to and talk to and lean on. The isolation that's already there in rural and

Speaker: NA
Text: regional areas can greatly exacerbate the problems these veterans suffer from. To shut down

Speaker: NA
Text: these vans is really the wrong way to go, and I ask the minister to get that one on his agenda

Speaker: NA
Text: too. It's just not right to try and push this into Human Services and Centrelink. These veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: really resent that as well. They do feel that the special nature of their service and their issues

Speaker: NA
Text: warrants them being dealt with in a unique way, and it's an insult to their service and to them

Speaker: NA
Text: to push them into this. But, as I said, it comes back to that broader issue that we're

Speaker: NA
Text: experiencing at the moment with Centrelink in general.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that issue needs to be addressed for the general community as well. They're losing

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs in those Centrelink offices in our region too, and it's part of the grievance that's going on

Speaker: NA
Text: out there in rural and regional Australia-particularly rural and regional New South Wales-

Speaker: NA
Text: at the moment. I was handing out at the Gundagai booth at Gundagai High School a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks ago for the by-election there. There was a 43 per cent swing against the government in

Speaker: NA
Text: that booth. It's just been a perfect storm of issues that they're concerned about: removal of

Speaker: NA
Text: services from their communities, loss of jobs associated with that and forced mergers. They

Speaker: NA
Text: feel that they're under siege from governments at state and federal levels and they're turning to

Speaker: NA
Text: other parties, which is a trend that is not to be encouraged when you think of who some of

Speaker: NA
Text: those other parties might be. So it's incumbent on all of us, the government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition, to listen to what's going on out there in rural and regional areas and to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that it's pointless complaining about phenomena like shooters parties, One Nation or whatever

Speaker: NA
Text: without understanding there is a set of grievances that underpin that which have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those grievances are at the moment greatly affecting my veterans, who we're representing

Speaker: NA
Text: in this debate today. On their behalf and for their interests I would urge the government to

Speaker: NA
Text: back away from what's going on with Centrelink: certain attempts to cut pensions and support

Speaker: NA
Text: in energy supplements and the like, which affect the veterans as well, and attempts to cut back

Speaker: NA
Text: on educational support for war orphans and war widows in some previous budgets. I'm glad to

Speaker: NA
Text: see we've moved away from that, but there's more work to be done, and the government will

Speaker: NA
Text: have our full support in broaching those issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm looking forward to maybe having further discussions on this with the minister when

Speaker: NA
Text: we're in Beersheba in the coming days. I urge Australians to look back at that service, at that

Speaker: NA
Text: history and at that battle, because it's not well known amongst a lot of Australians. I really

Speaker: NA
Text: take this opportunity to commemorate that service. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms HUSAR
Text: Lindsay) (11:49): It's always important to rise and stand in support of our

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans and always good to follow the member for Eden-Monaro, who is a proud veteran

Speaker: NA
Text: himself. The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 2017, which seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: clarify, improve and streamline the operation of law for veterans and their entitlements, is

Speaker: NA
Text: incredibly important. Labor, obviously, supports any measures undertaken to support veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: and ensure they are no worse off with the changes to the legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know that to be a member of the Australian Defence Force is to dedicate your life

Speaker: NA
Text: and your service to the care and defence of our country-it is incredibly important work that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do. Like everyone in this place, I'm incredibly grateful and thankful for their work. I did

Speaker: NA
Text: see this firsthand on my recent deployment to the Middle East. Our defence personnel have a

Speaker: NA
Text: rich and defining place in shaping our identity and our culture. Mateship, a fair go, courage

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and sacrifice are all of the hallmarks of these very, very special people. Those that have

Speaker: NA
Text: served deserve our uttermost respect and admiration, but, most importantly, they deserve our

Speaker: NA
Text: support upon their return. As they return to civilian life, we owe them and their families the

Speaker: NA
Text: best possible services and care. Young women and young men returning from conflict require

Speaker: NA
Text: the stability, security, support and opportunity to get back on their feet.

Speaker: NA
Text: From the First World War, when 300,000 Australians departed our shores-the war where

Speaker: NA
Text: the Anzac legacy would be born on the shores of Gallipoli and where Australia's involvement

Speaker: NA
Text: in battles such as Fromelles and Pozieres and the Battle of the Somme would see the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian spirit, our courage and our mateship shine through-nearly 17,000 of our serving

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel, sadly, did not return home. But our debt of gratitude to returning veterans was

Speaker: NA
Text: forged through these battles as they fought to keep Australia safe and for our way of life. To

Speaker: NA
Text: this day, the veterans who return have seen their mates make the ultimate sacrifice. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: stood on the front line to defend our nation. We absolutely owe it to our veterans to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: them with the best support and care, and the wellbeing of veterans and their families is

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely paramount. Their issues must be dealt with compassionately and correctly the first

Speaker: NA
Text: time around and not be put through administrative processes, which is currently the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are currently just under 60,000 Australians serving in our defence forces and an

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated 329,000 living veterans. The Department of Veterans' Affairs supports

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 291,000 people, with 203,000 being over the age of 65 and 23,000 under the

Speaker: NA
Text: age of 40, and we will certainly see that number of young veterans increase with our ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement in the Middle East region.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate, there are just under 1,000 veterans, as recorded at 17 June this year,

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving assistance through the department, and this includes any current or former serving

Speaker: NA
Text: members eligible for compensation, income support or health treatment under the main

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans' entitlement legislation. This figure excludes ex-service personnel who are ineligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for or who have not sought assistance from the department. Five hundred and seven of these

Speaker: NA
Text: veterans are receiving a disability pension and, in addition, there are 311 war widow

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners. So the electorate of Lindsay does have a significant need to support our veterans,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I'm pleased that, by and large, my community does support our veterans.

Speaker: NA
Text: From the representations that I receive and the discussions I have had in my community

Speaker: NA
Text: and on my visit to Afghanistan last year, those serving and veterans need support to transition

Speaker: NA
Text: back home. Some veterans find it very difficult to blend in with our communities and are

Speaker: NA
Text: often affected by physical health issues, deterioration of mental health, lack of financial

Speaker: NA
Text: support and difficulties finding meaningful employment when they return. The Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Affairs is aware that on any given night across Australia over 3,000 veterans are

Speaker: NA
Text: homeless, affected by their selfless service to our nation. Our veterans have been through

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. They have done everything for their country that we have asked of them and more.

Speaker: NA
Text: To give them the run-around and the third degree to have their matters processed is simply

Speaker: NA
Text: unacceptable.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation seeks to modernise and improve the operations of the Veterans' Review

Speaker: NA
Text: Board, which can only be a good thing for veterans. The legislation seeks to provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: mechanism of review that is accessible, fair, just, economical, informal and quick. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: proportionate to the importance and complexity of the matter and promotes public trust and

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence in the decision-making of the board. The removal of bureaucratic barriers and red

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: tape benefits veterans to ensure their claims are heard in a timely and low-cost manner. No

Speaker: NA
Text: veteran deserves an unfair hearing, and we need to maintain an effective mechanism for

Speaker: NA
Text: review.

Speaker: NA
Text: But veterans are right to be concerned about privacy, given this government's less than

Speaker: NA
Text: stellar track record and blunders when dealing with IT and data security. I've seen firsthand

Speaker: NA
Text: the difficult and stressful work of defence personnel, and that's why I believe their transition

Speaker: NA
Text: to civilian life should be much, much more secure. They are well trained; they are highly

Speaker: NA
Text: skilled and well organised. They are great assets to all types of businesses and the community

Speaker: NA
Text: at large, but they struggle to find employment and to readjust to life at home, far away,

Speaker: NA
Text: thankfully, from distant war zones and constantly being on edge to protect our nation. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: why it's important to help and act when it's required. Many of these veterans with positive

Speaker: NA
Text: attributes on the table have to readjust. They have to deal with their memories and actions of

Speaker: NA
Text: serving the nation. We need to assure them that we will provide a strong and positive safety

Speaker: NA
Text: net.

Speaker: NA
Text: I had the opportunity, as I said earlier, to spend time with troops, visiting four bases during

Speaker: NA
Text: my tour of Afghanistan as part of the ADF Parliamentary Program in July. This commendable

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative provides an opportunity to engage very, very closely with members of the ADF and

Speaker: NA
Text: experience the challenges and rewards of service life. The program also offers a chance to see

Speaker: NA
Text: firsthand the diverse capabilities of our Defence Force in action.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I was there, above all, our troops wanted to know that their contribution is, firstly,

Speaker: NA
Text: supported and, more importantly, highly valued. Having performed in and participated in

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the drills that we put our men and women through and having performed some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: work they do, in a very, very minor capacity, I've got to say it is incredibly nerve-racking. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: intense. It drives up even some of the most dormant feelings of anxiety. A war zone is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasant place to be. Being one of the most protected persons in that war zone, as I was, was

Speaker: NA
Text: comforting, but I'm not the one out there risking my life.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is incredibly important that we support them. It is our duty to absolutely recognise them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our serving men and women had a couple of thoughts for me to bring back, and on my return

Speaker: NA
Text: I was pleased to present those to the Minister for Defence.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am committed to ensuring that our service men and women are supported not only during

Speaker: NA
Text: their service but back into civilian life. Last week I also had the privilege of attending a dinner

Speaker: NA
Text: at the Royal Military College Duntroon as part of our program, where I got to engage some

Speaker: NA
Text: more with Aaron Bell, who was in my office as part of the exchange program. Certainly, I got

Speaker: NA
Text: to benefit from having his knowledge and experience with the Defence Force. With the

Speaker: NA
Text: memories of my trip to Afghanistan in mind, it has been a great opportunity to share

Speaker: NA
Text: experiences and insights into a very different world to what we imagine. During my visit to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Middle East, the troops told me of their longing for and personal attachment to their home

Speaker: NA
Text: back here and the difficulties in maintaining relationships back in this country. You can't talk

Speaker: NA
Text: to your family about what you've seen and what you've done over there, because there are

Speaker: NA
Text: insecure phone networks. The time zones are different, so you often are working at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when your family might not be at home for you to speak to them. They might be at school

Speaker: NA
Text: when it is time for you have the opportunity to call them. There is a big gap for our serving

Speaker: NA
Text: men and women who are in the Middle East right now.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Their selfless sacrifice ensures our personal safety here in this country. Our veterans talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the amount of money that is put into training them to build weapons, to shoot and to

Speaker: NA
Text: care for their soldiers and their personnel while they're in the battlefield. Everywhere I went,

Speaker: NA
Text: across all four bases, there was a huge and heightened sense of anxiety. The topic of

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion about veterans' affairs upon their return to Australia was absolutely the No. 1 issue.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, while they're out there serving and doing their bit for the country, making sure that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: safe and protected and that our way of life continues, our men and women in the Middle East

Speaker: NA
Text: are worried about what's going to happen on their return. I just think that is incredibly unfair.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's certainly not a concern that we should be taking lightly. I think that they've been through

Speaker: NA
Text: enough. The trauma they have experienced can lead to them having issues on return,

Speaker: NA
Text: including suicide, mental health issues and post-traumatic stress once they have returned

Speaker: NA
Text: home.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have family members who were on the HMAS Voyager when it was struck. The things

Speaker: NA
Text: that I witnessed as a small child and a teenager that my uncle went through were quite

Speaker: NA
Text: horrendous, including him not being able to be in a room of an evening with no lights on and

Speaker: NA
Text: not being able to sleep in a dead silent, quiet space. Some noise always had to be going on

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the trauma associated with that accident that he was involved in. Potentially, the

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which that was handled upon their rescue and the way in which their contribution was

Speaker: NA
Text: seen were certainly not helpful to his recovery.

Speaker: NA
Text: Between 2001 and 2015, 325 veterans took their own lives. It is an absolute national

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy when anybody suicides, but in particular, when men and women through their service

Speaker: NA
Text: for this country see no other option than to take their own lives, that is an absolute national

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy. When men and women who have served our nation, upon their return, suffer such

Speaker: NA
Text: deep mental and emotional pain that they take their own lives, we absolutely need to be doing

Speaker: NA
Text: more. We need to find ways to support them and to try to stop this from happening.

Speaker: NA
Text: The representations from veterans that I receive in my office are about dealing with the

Speaker: NA
Text: department and accessing services and support back home. I know and support our local

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations and services in Lindsay that provide critical support and assistance to current

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence personnel, veterans and their families. I thank them for the service that they provide

Speaker: NA
Text: in our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to place on record my thanks to Legacy, which cares for around 80,000 veterans

Speaker: NA
Text: whose dependants range in age from less than 12 months to 109 years. Groups such as Legacy

Speaker: NA
Text: provide valued support to families during really difficult times. The Penrith RSL sub-Branch

Speaker: NA
Text: has 715 members. Penrith owes a great deal of gratitude to the Penrith RSL sub-Branch and

Speaker: NA
Text: its president, Mick MCConnell. The sub-branch's good work includes: welfare for veterans; a

Speaker: NA
Text: drop-in centre opening in November-I'm looking forward to being part of that; a welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: officer helping veterans with their claims; and supporting over 400 war widows. The Penrith

Speaker: NA
Text: RSL sub-Branch finds more and more younger vets are seeking help who have higher rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: mental health issues. The older vets were, in many cases, treated poorly when they returned

Speaker: NA
Text: from Vietnam and other areas of conflict, so they are determined as a cohort not to let this

Speaker: NA
Text: happen to our younger returning vets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Penrith sub-branch is involved with the RAAF at Richmond and Glenbrook bases, and

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Orchard Hills Army and Navy cadets. The women's auxiliary, which is supported by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Penrith RSL sub-Branch, with Colleen Towle as the president, was formed in 1916 and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: continues now. Their job originally in World War I was to send comfort parcels to Penrith

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers serving on the Western Front. The parcels consisted of items that we would look to

Speaker: NA
Text: send now but were probably different then-woollen socks, soap, cakes and other items that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be missed by our soldiers who were serving overseas at the time. We might have slight

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the care packs, but they're still being sent. For many decades, the sub-branch has

Speaker: NA
Text: provided significant pension, welfare and hospital visits for members and members of other

Speaker: NA
Text: sub-branches. Now they hold annual Easter, Mother's Day and Father's Day raffles and other

Speaker: NA
Text: fundraising activities like their biannual gala auction, attending Anzac services, selling Anzac

Speaker: NA
Text: badges, attending the conference for the Central Council of RSL Women's Auxiliaries and

Speaker: NA
Text: also attending other auxiliary functions.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also have the Penrith and Lower Blue Mountains War Widows' Guild providing a

Speaker: NA
Text: range of services to war widows, and it operates with significant volunteer input from its

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of members. We have the Homes for Heroes program, which has built around nine

Speaker: NA
Text: rooms at Governor Phillip Manor for our homeless vets. The program offers a comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: rehabilitation service. For the support residents receive, they're required to give back to the

Speaker: NA
Text: program by doing voluntary work, mentoring other people and engaging in training and

Speaker: NA
Text: rehabilitation. Homes for Heroes does a wonderful job helping homeless young veterans to

Speaker: NA
Text: get back into mainstream life.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other organisations supporting veterans in my electorate include: St Mary's RSL sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: Branch-Ron Blakely is the president and Tony Fryer is secretary; the Royal Marines

Speaker: NA
Text: Association division of Western Sydney; the Red Cross; Vietnam vets at St Mary's, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: also affectionately known as the Train; Nepean Legacy and Legacy Widows' Club Nepean;

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Light Horse Association; the wives of Vietnam vets with Maureen Clements;

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Nashos, of which John Taylor is the secretary and acting vice-president. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: incredibly honoured to take up my first role as patron with the Nashos.

Speaker: NA
Text: I look forward to meeting more and more Defence Force personnel and to having the

Speaker: NA
Text: pleasure of welcoming Amanda Rishworth, the shadow minister, in November. I'm incredibly

Speaker: NA
Text: grateful to the Defence Force personnel I met on my trip to Afghanistan. We're still in regular

Speaker: NA
Text: contact-we're now friends officially on Facebook-and they often communicate with me

Speaker: NA
Text: when they're doing their jobs and going about their business. I'm very grateful for the

Speaker: NA
Text: information and advocacy that they provide to me on the issues that need to be changed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I stand with all the veterans and service men and women of this country, and I will ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that I will always work to achieve the best possible outcomes for them and their families.

Speaker: Mr TEHAN
Text: Wannon-Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister Assisting the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Centenary of ANZAC, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Cyber

Speaker: NA
Text: Security and Minister for Defence Personnel) (12:04): I thank the people who spoke on this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill with the best interests of veterans at heart and who spoke in a very bipartisan manner

Speaker: NA
Text: because, as all of us know in this place, veterans deserve all of our attention and for us to

Speaker: NA
Text: work in this place in a very cooperative way. I thank the shadow minister again for the way

Speaker: NA
Text: that she engages with me to make sure that we can deal with these issues in a bipartisan way.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased to present the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 2017.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill comprises nine schedules that would implement several small but necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to veterans legislation to clarify, improve or streamline the operation of the law.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 1 of the omnibus bill amends the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to modernise and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: align the Veterans' Review Board's operations with those of the Administrative Appeals

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal following the amendments made by the Tribunals Amalgamation Act 2015. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments also support the alternative dispute resolution processes and the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 which provide for a

Speaker: NA
Text: single appeal path for reconsidering decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule 2 would amend the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: the Specialist Medical Review Council to improve the operation of the SMRC, streamline

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the SMRC's administrative arrangements and better reflect the manner in which its

Speaker: NA
Text: functions and processes have evolved over time. The proposed amendments would simplify

Speaker: NA
Text: the nomination and appointment process for councils, enable online lodgements of claims,

Speaker: NA
Text: streamline the notice of investigation requirements and give the SMRC an ability to pay the

Speaker: NA
Text: travel costs of applicants who appear before an oral hearing of the SMRC.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed amendments in schedule 3 of the omnibus bill would enable international

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements to be made that would cover allied veterans and defence force members with

Speaker: NA
Text: service of the type for which benefits and payments, including rehabilitation, can be provided

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Repatriation Commission or the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission under the relevant acts. Currently, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs can only

Speaker: NA
Text: enter into an arrangement with the governments of countries that are or have been dominions

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Crown. This will enable the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to enter into agreements with

Speaker: NA
Text: a broader range of countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed amendments in schedule 4 are intended to clarify that vocational

Speaker: NA
Text: rehabilitation assistance under an employer incentive scheme in the form of wage incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: payments is within the scope of the enabling provisions of the relevant legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed amendments in schedule 5 would amend subsection 409(2) of the Military

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation Act 2004 and subsection 151A(1) of the Safety, Rehabilitation and

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation (Defence-related Claims) Act 1988 to add the Commonwealth Superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation as a person to whom the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: may provide information for purposes allowed under the CSC's legislation. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments would implement a recommendation by the 2011 Review of Military

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation Arrangements intended to improve the information-sharing framework for

Speaker: NA
Text: incapacity and superannuation benefits between DVA and CSC and, therefore, reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: time taken by DVA and CSC to process claims, which would better support injured former

Speaker: NA
Text: ADF members. In addition, enabling the CSC to use medical reports held by the MRCC to

Speaker: NA
Text: determine superannuation claims would also avoid the need to send ADF members for further

Speaker: NA
Text: medical assessment where DVA already holds relevant medical evidence that could be used

Speaker: NA
