Text: by the CSC to determine superannuation benefits. ADF members would be spared from any

Speaker: NA
Text: retraumatisation from having to tell their stories. This is particularly significant for ADF

Speaker: NA
Text: members who suffer psychological conditions, including those that have arisen as a result of

Speaker: NA
Text: physical or psychological abuse.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each of the sets of amendments is relatively modest. They enhance the operation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: department and will mean better outcomes for veterans. I thank members for their

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to the debate and I commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation for the bill, and message

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Administrator recommending appropriation for the proposed amendments,

Speaker: NA
Text: announced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration in Detail

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Minister may, on behalf of the Commonwealth, enter into an arrangement with a foreign

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The provisions of an arrangement that is in force under this section have effect despite anything

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) An arrangement that is in force under this section may be varied or revoked by the Minister on

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Arrangement is not a legislative instrument

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like to give the shadow minister an opportunity to say a few words on the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments.

Speaker: Ms RISHWORTH
Text: Kingston) (12:10): As foreshadowed in my speech on the second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading, I would like to say that Labor will be supporting all of the government's amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: to this bill. Obviously, one of the amendments that we are very, very pleased about is the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment relating to the Veterans' Review Board. This is, I think, an important amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: that addresses the concerns of the ex-service community and apprehensions that were

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed during the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: process. These changes are important to retain the unique nature of the Veterans' Review

Speaker: NA
Text: Board as a place where veterans can have their voices heard. So I do think that this

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment is suitable and, as mentioned in my speech on the second reading, has the benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: of removing the section that would limit the ability of veterans to be heard. This is, I think, an

Speaker: NA
Text: important measure, to keep faith with the veterans community. As I said also, Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: welcomes the aligning of the principles of the Veterans' Review Board with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Administrative Appeals Tribunal, but it was important to us that the nature of the Veterans'

Speaker: NA
Text: Review Board be maintained. So we did bring this to the attention of the government, and I'm

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased that the government has an amendment that will deliver that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, I would note that there are amendments that the government has circulated which

Speaker: NA
Text: seek to restore the concessional pharmaceuticals to those veterans who had lost them as a

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the government's unfair asset-test changes. We do know that these changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: asset test saw more than 13,000 Australians receiving a Veterans' Affairs pension losing part

Speaker: NA
Text: of that pension or indeed being kicked off the pension. While it has been two years too late, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is pleasing to see the pensioner concession card finally being restored to those who had lost it.

Speaker: NA
Text: But I would hope that the government continues to ensure that a wide range of concessions

Speaker: NA
Text: which were received by those part-pensioners who no longer receive them are still available.

Speaker: NA
Text: As to those concessions that were provided by councils, it is unclear what the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: done and how the government has pursued ensuring that those concessions are reinstated. It

Speaker: NA
Text: took two years to reinstate the Commonwealth benefits and it is my understanding that the

Speaker: NA
Text: states, in principle, have agreed. It is incumbent on the government to ensure that all

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions by all three levels of government are restored to this group of people, because

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor did not support this change. We were very, very clear, under the guidance of our great

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow minister, who made it very, very clear that we thought this was an unfair change. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: do hope that the minister responsible for the Department of Social Services preserves these

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions and ensures that they are reinstated for these people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The remaining elements of these amendments seek to address some minor technical

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments. On the whole, we will support the government's amendments. We think they

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the omnibus bill and therefore they have our support.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, as amended, agreed to.

Text: Bill read a third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services Legislation Amendment (Cashless Debit Card) Bill 2017

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Text: Jagajaga) (12:15): I'm speaking today on the Social Services Legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Cashless Debit Card) Bill 2017. In the 2017 budget, the government announced

Speaker: NA
Text: that it would roll out the cashless debit card in two further locations from 1 September 2017.

Speaker: NA
Text: These proposed locations, according to the government, are the Goldfields in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and Bundaberg and Hervey Bay in Queensland. This bill enables this by repealing

Speaker: NA
Text: one section of the Social Security (Administration) Act. The section repealed by the bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: section 124PF, contains the existing limitations on the cashless debit card trial, which require

Speaker: NA
Text: that the trials end on 30 June 2018, that there be the limitation for trials to occur in up to three

Speaker: NA
Text: discrete trial areas, and that the trial areas include no more than 10,000 participants.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill provides the framework for additional cashless debit card locations but does not

Speaker: NA
Text: enable the rollout of the card in any specific location. Any new locations for the rollout still

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: require a legislative instrument to be tabled in the parliament. These instruments are

Speaker: NA
Text: disallowable, which means that the rollout of the card can be agreed or opposed in specific

Speaker: NA
Text: locations and not in others. This is an important point. It means that the potential passage of

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill does not automatically mean that the card will be rolled out in Bundaberg or the

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldfields, for example. It can still be disallowed through a disallowable instrument in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor will not oppose this bill in the House today, but we do reserve our final position until

Speaker: NA
Text: the completion of the Senate inquiry into this bill that's currently underway. I must say, I'm

Speaker: NA
Text: very disappointed that this bill has come on for debate in the House of Representatives before

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate inquiry has concluded. Rolling out this card is a very big decision for any

Speaker: NA
Text: community, and for this parliament, and it should not be rushed. This legislation requires

Speaker: NA
Text: greater scrutiny and deliberation than is being allowed for by the minister by bringing forward

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill for debate today. We certainly, on our side of the House, want to see the findings of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate inquiry before determining our final position.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor also want time to be able to conduct our own consultations with local community

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders in the newly proposed sites of Kalgoorlie and the surrounding communities, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Bundaberg and nearby Hervey Bay. The particular disallowable instruments to enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: card, of course, have yet to be introduced into the parliament, and the government has not said

Speaker: NA
Text: when they will be, so Labor reserves the right to support or oppose specific locations on a

Speaker: NA
Text: case-by-case basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have received a lot of correspondence from people seeking Labor's position on the

Speaker: NA
Text: cashless debit card, so I do today want to take the time to spell out the principles that are

Speaker: NA
Text: guiding Labor's approach to this issue. We do support genuine, community-driven initiatives

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to tackle alcohol abuse. We do understand that many, many communities want

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance in addressing chronic alcohol related abuse. We also know that the cashless debit

Speaker: NA
Text: card alone cannot be a solution in addressing this problem. Labor have consistently said that

Speaker: NA
Text: we would take a community-by-community approach to the further rollout of the cashless

Speaker: NA
Text: card. We'll listen to each community's leaders and talk with them about the consequences of

Speaker: NA
Text: this card being rolled out in their community. Wraparound support services must also be

Speaker: NA
Text: community designed, agreed upon and resourced to address the challenges facing these

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, and, of course, they're different in different places. We understand-and this is

Speaker: NA
Text: a very important point-that the vast majority of social security recipients are more than

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of managing their own personal finances. That's why Labor does not support the

Speaker: NA
Text: cashless debit card being rolled out nationwide.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2015, Labor supported the cashless debit card trials in the east Kimberley and Ceduna

Speaker: NA
Text: and the surrounding communities. We did so after consulting with local community leaders.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also did so after securing additional funding for wraparound services, including drug and

Speaker: NA
Text: alcohol counselling and more mental health support services. It is important to recognise that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the case of Ceduna, there was a formal memorandum of understanding that was signed with

Speaker: NA
Text: community leaders in 2015, and that included not only the Ceduna council and the

Speaker: NA
Text: community heads working group but also community leaders from the surrounding

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: In assessing the best way to address alcohol related abuse and violence, all policy levers

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be considered. Just last week the Northern Territory government released a report by

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Trevor Riley proposing some of the biggest ever changes to the Northern Territory's alcohol

Speaker: NA
Text: management policies, and there are a range of recommendations that are relevant to this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. I'm pleased to see that the Gunner government have said that they will accept, in

Speaker: NA
Text: principle, nearly all of the recommendations from the review-for example, they've indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that they will enact a complete moratorium on all new takeaway alcohol licences-the point

Speaker: NA
Text: being that there's a suite of policy approaches that must be taken into consideration when

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to reduce alcohol consumption in an effort to deal with violence and abuse. I'd say to

Speaker: NA
Text: everyone that's been involved in this cashless debit card trial that it really was never going to

Speaker: NA
Text: be the case that an 18-month trial could meaningfully address multiple generations of

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage, poverty and social dysfunction. I think it was very misguided of those who

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that it could.

Speaker: NA
Text: Income management, of course, is a very complex policy question, and one of the concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: that are often raised with me is: why should it apply to everyone in a community? What

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence is there that income management should apply to everyone in a community to

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively counter alcohol related abuse that only applies to some people? Why shouldn't

Speaker: NA
Text: people go on income management after certain trigger points-for instance, following the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the local department of child protection? These are some of the many

Speaker: NA
Text: questions that are being put that need answers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Communities also want to know how consent by a location will actually be measured and

Speaker: NA
Text: what assessment is being undertaken by the government of the service gaps in each

Speaker: NA
Text: community where the cashless card is being proposed. What access is there to the alcohol and

Speaker: NA
Text: drug treatment services, mental health supports, family violence counselling, housing, health,

Speaker: NA
Text: education, jobs and strong cultural requirements that are, of course, essential for strong

Speaker: NA
Text: communities? All of these issues need to be assessed in deciding whether or not this card

Speaker: NA
Text: should be introduced in any particular place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The intent of the trials of the cashless card in Ceduna and the east Kimberley was to test

Speaker: NA
Text: whether significantly reducing access to discretionary cash by placing a large proportion of a

Speaker: NA
Text: person's welfare payment into a restricted bank account can reduce the habitual abuse of and

Speaker: NA
Text: associated harm from alcohol, gambling and illegal drugs. The government has recently

Speaker: NA
Text: released the ORIMA evaluation of the trials, and this evaluation shows very mixed results.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm sorry to say that the evaluation has been widely criticised for being deeply flawed. I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to go particularly to one detailed analysis of the ORIMA evaluation. Janet Hunt is the

Speaker: NA
Text: deputy director of the Centre for Aboriginal Economic Policy Research at the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: National University and she says that the evaluation showed that the government's cashless

Speaker: NA
Text: card trials had not actually improved safety and violence despite that being one of the trial's

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives. Her research paper on the evaluation is critical of the methodology used in the

Speaker: NA
Text: ORIMA evaluation. She points out that the people interviewed for the evaluation may have

Speaker: NA
Text: told interviewers that they drank less than before the trial began but that such recall over a

Speaker: NA
Text: year 'is not likely to have been very reliable'. She also makes the valid point that, given that

Speaker: NA
Text: people had to give their identification to the interviewer, they may have said exactly what

Speaker: NA
Text: they thought the interviewer wanted to hear and they certainly would not have incriminated

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves by saying that they were taking illegal drugs. I think we can all understand that

Speaker: NA
Text: this would be particularly true for the Aboriginal population, who for historical reasons are

Speaker: NA
Text: likely to view authority figures with serious suspicion.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Human Services described the cashless debit card trials as a huge success,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Prime Minister himself said that the card has seen 'a massive reduction in alcohol

Speaker: NA
Text: abuse, in drug abuse, in domestic violence, in violence generally'. But Janet Hunt made clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that this wasn't the case, stating clearly:

Speaker: NA
Text: Someone needs to tell them that the report does not say that.

Speaker: NA
Text: When participants were asked about the impact of the trial on their children's lives, only 17

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent reported feeing their lives were better as a result. In fact, a bigger group of parents-

Speaker: NA
Text: around 24 per cent-felt that their children's lives were actually worse. Asked to reflect on the

Speaker: NA
Text: trial's impact on their own lives, 32 per cent reported it had made their lives worse, compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with 23 per cent saying their lives had improved. One in three people responding to the

Speaker: NA
Text: survey reported struggling to transfer money to children who were away at boarding school or

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay for things at community fairs, swimming pools or school canteens. Crime statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: remained flat or worsened, the only improvement being lower rates of drunk driving and

Speaker: NA
Text: public intoxication in Ceduna. So we certainly don't believe that the government can justify

Speaker: NA
Text: the further rollout of this card on what is clearly a flawed evaluation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of the rollout of the cashless debit card is also an important consideration in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. According to documents released by the Department of Social Services to the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition under freedom of information, the government has spent up to $18.9 million on

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing and managing the two existing trials between July 2015 and April 2017. The

Speaker: NA
Text: government has paid $7.9 million of that to the debit card provider, Indue, and almost $1.6

Speaker: NA
Text: million to ORIMA Research to provide a frankly substandard evaluation. Wraparound

Speaker: NA
Text: services in the community such as drug and alcohol treatment and financial counselling cost a

Speaker: NA
Text: further $2.6 million. The $18.9 million equates to more than $10,000 per participant.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's quite extraordinary that we're debating this bill today without any indication from the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister about how much it will cost taxpayers to roll out the card in the two new proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: sites in the Goldfields and Bundaberg-Hervey Bay. There is no indication whatsoever about

Speaker: NA
Text: what this will cost taxpayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: In April this year the shadow minister for human services and I went to the east Kimberley

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet with community leaders in Kununurra and in Wyndham. We met with a range of

Speaker: NA
Text: different Aboriginal organisations and also the Kununurra Hospital, St John Ambulance,

Speaker: NA
Text: Kununurra police, the Sobering Up Shelter, Job Pathways, the Department for Child

Speaker: NA
Text: Protection and a number of other organisations in Wyndham. The feedback we received was

Speaker: NA
Text: mixed. I have an enormous amount of respect and regard for Ian Trust, the head of the Wunan

Speaker: NA
Text: Foundation. He is adamant that the card can be a circuit-breaker for his people. The St John

Speaker: NA
Text: Ambulance Brigade in Kununurra said that the call-outs for alcohol related violence had gone

Speaker: NA
Text: down. The police made it clear that, with respect to domestic violence rates within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kimberley, 75 per cent of the incidents are influenced by alcohol, with either the victim or the

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrator, and they're supportive of any policy attempts to tackle alcohol consumption in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the recent Senate inquiry, the Western Australia Police Force released data on domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: assaults. The 12 months to 30 June 2017 saw 508 domestic assaults in Kununurra. For the 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months previous to that, 1 July 2015 to 30 June 2016, there were 319 domestic assaults. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately, the data says that domestic assaults in this area have gone up. It is the case, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Western Australia Police Force noted this, that it's very difficult to fully assess the value

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of the card from a violence perspective because the Kimberley district revised their approach

Speaker: NA
Text: to domestic violence to include a more thorough first response to reports of domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: violence. So it is very, very difficult to make an assessment about whether things have

Speaker: NA
Text: become better or worse in relation to domestic violence. What the data does show, though, is

Speaker: NA
Text: that there has been a uniform increase in the reporting of domestic assaults across the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kimberley. Of course, I'm sure we would all agree that 508 domestic assaults in Kununurra,

Speaker: NA
Text: based on the figures from the Western Australia Police Force, are far too many.

Speaker: NA
Text: The shadow minister for human services and I also visited the women's refuge in

Speaker: NA
Text: Kununurra and talked to some of the women who were staying there, and they did not have a

Speaker: NA
Text: positive view of the card. From their point of view, life had become harder with the card;

Speaker: NA
Text: there was more violence and more crime as cash had become scarce. More recently, others

Speaker: NA
Text: said that they felt let down by the Minister for Human Services, who promised a lot but, in

Speaker: NA
Text: their eyes, had failed to deliver. Mr Lawford Benning, the chairperson of MG Corporation, an

Speaker: NA
Text: original supporter of the card, told the recent Senate inquiry hearing:

Speaker: NA
Text: … the Minister for Human Services, made various commitments to me prior to the introduction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: CDC-

Speaker: NA
Text: the cashless debit card-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial in Kununurra, none of which were delivered on time or as promised.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the issues that were raised in Kununurra with us was that the local Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: community thought that they would be given delegated authority to remove people from the

Speaker: NA
Text: cashless debit card without the process being intrusive. I have to say that it is still the case that

Speaker: NA
Text: the exact process of removing people or reducing the amount of money on the card is very,

Speaker: NA
Text: very opaque. This issue really needs to be cleared up. In Ceduna recently, I met with people

Speaker: NA
Text: who were on the cashless debit card. They then applied to be removed from the card through

Speaker: NA
Text: the community panel and ultimately got off the card, but the exact process by which this took

Speaker: NA
Text: place remains completely unclear. Who in the Department of Social Services ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: makes the decision and on what basis? We really don't know. More importantly, local people

Speaker: NA
Text: in Kununurra, Wyndham, Ceduna and the surrounding communities also don't know.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also met with people who were on the card and found it very difficult to manage their

Speaker: NA
Text: money because they didn't have money to send away to their children in boarding school and

Speaker: NA
Text: a whole range of other reasons. Others said that the sly-grog trade meant that there are,

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunately, ways in which people get around the card if they want to buy alcohol. The

Speaker: NA
Text: policymakers would be better off restricting the sale of alcohol through tougher alcohol

Speaker: NA
Text: management rules and tougher policing of the sly-grog trade rather than introducing a

Speaker: NA
Text: cashless card on all social security recipients.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important to note that the current Takeaway Alcohol Management System in

Speaker: NA
Text: Kununurra allows for people to buy two cartons of full-strength beer, six bottles of wine, or

Speaker: NA
Text: one litre of wine or spirits with an alcohol content of 15 per cent or more per day. That's the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of alcohol that the current Takeaway Alcohol Management System allows for every

Speaker: NA
Text: single day in Kununurra. Of course, this stands in marked contrast to the situation, for

Speaker: NA
Text: example, in Fitzroy Crossing, where only light-strength takeaway alcohol can be sold. The

Speaker: NA
Text: controls were introduced in Fitzroy Crossing, and in Halls Creek two years later, with a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: community support, and the studies of the impact in those two communities have been very

Speaker: NA
Text: positive, showing a dramatic drop in assaults, a drop in domestic violence and a drop in

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: presentations to hospital emergency departments. I must say, this point was made to me again

Speaker: NA
Text: by Ian Trust in Kununurra, where he indicated that he certainly wanted to see tighter alcohol

Speaker: NA
Text: takeaway limits in that community.

Speaker: NA
Text: A common sentiment expressed to the member for Barton and me during our visit was that

Speaker: NA
Text: things are so bad in these communities that they're willing to give anything new a go. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: say that they support the cashless card not out of hope but out of despair. They certainly don't

Speaker: NA
Text: think that this card is a silver bullet. They emphasised just how important it is to help people

Speaker: NA
Text: into work and the need for better employment programs. They want to see young people

Speaker: NA
Text: especially finding meaningful work and also that we implement tougher alcohol management

Speaker: NA
Text: controls.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I mentioned, in September I went to Ceduna and some of the surrounding communities

Speaker: NA
Text: and met with a range of people on the ground there about the rollout of the card. Once again,

Speaker: NA
Text: we received quite a mixed response. The Mayor of Ceduna is a very strong supporter. Corey

Speaker: NA
Text: MCLennan, from one of the local Aboriginal corporations, is a compelling advocate for the

Speaker: NA
Text: card continuing. They really want to see the card continue. By contrast, the Aboriginal health

Speaker: NA
Text: service in Ceduna and their CEO have spoken powerfully against the card. At the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate inquiry, their CEO, Zell Dodd, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: … there is an urgent need for Aboriginal people to be at the centre of building their own capacity and

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose … growing local capacity and training opportunities so that Aboriginal people are equipped

Speaker: NA
Text: physically, mentally and spiritually to deal with the issues that confront them on a daily basis. For many

Speaker: NA
Text: it is on a 24/7 basis. Services have to be in place for a minimum of five years, not three.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's also the case that Zell Dodd raised concerns about the funding certainty of the wraparound

Speaker: NA
Text: services in Ceduna. The health service indicated that the funding associated with the card

Speaker: NA
Text: rollout for an alcohol and drug worker actually only lasted for one year. They also noticed

Speaker: NA
Text: that the nearest alcohol and drug rehab centre was more than four to five hours away in Port

Speaker: NA
Text: Augusta-and, of course, this was not acceptable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other Aboriginal leaders I spoke to gave quite a nuanced perspective on the card. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: said that the card had resulted in some positive change but not as much as claimed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government. It stopped some people drinking as much as they had before, but some people

Speaker: NA
Text: are still drinking. It hasn't encouraged people into work. Many, many people have said to me

Speaker: NA
Text: that the real solution has to be to help people into work, to encourage Indigenous businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: that employ people in their own communities. One thing everyone agreed to throughout my

Speaker: NA
Text: visit to Ceduna and the far west was that the Community Development Program needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed. Everyone, including those who support the card, said how important that is. Corey

Speaker: NA
Text: MCLennan, for example, who is a supporter of the card, was scathing about the Community

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Program. Bob Larking, from Scotdesco Aboriginal Community, was the same.

Speaker: NA
Text: We simply cannot be talking about reducing alcohol consumption and violence without

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about jobs and the failure of the Community Development Program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The government is now proposing to roll out this card in the Goldfields region, including a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of different communities. It wants that to happen from January 2018. I understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: government's proposal is that that be in place for 12 months. The Mayor of Kalgoorlie-

Speaker: NA
Text: Boulder, a supporter of the card, said at the recent Senate inquiry that the failure of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Community Development Program was the 'main reason that we're sitting here today'. By that

Speaker: NA
Text: he meant that they were considering the cashless debit card. The second site the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing is Bundaberg-Hervey Bay. In quite a different approach, the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: proposing that this rollout of the card be targeted at those under 35 years of age and at those

Speaker: NA
Text: who receive Newstart, youth allowance, jobseeker, parenting payment single or parenting

Speaker: NA
Text: payment partnered. At this stage, the Senate inquiry hasn't heard from anyone in this area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor will reserve our final position until the completion of the Senate inquiry that's currently

Speaker: NA
Text: underway.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, we won't oppose the bill today, but I am very, very disappointed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has brought this debate on before the Senate inquiry is finished. We need to have

Speaker: NA
Text: answered all of the questions that I have raised here today. This legislation really does require

Speaker: NA
Text: proper scrutiny. We of course will be conducting our own consultations with communities in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Goldfields and the Bundaberg-Hervey Bay area. We reserve our right to support or oppose

Speaker: NA
Text: specific locations on a case-by-case basis, depending on the views of local communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TED O'BRIEN (Fairfax) (12:42): By all accounts, the government's trial rollout of

Speaker: NA
Text: the cashless debit card has been a terrific success, contrary to what we heard from the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous speaker, the member for Jagajaga. Recently, the published evaluation results said: 'It

Speaker: NA
Text: provided a considerable positive impact.' Published findings include a variety of significant

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements in key measures, such as that 41 per cent of drinkers were drinking less, 48 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of drug users were taking fewer drugs and 48 per cent of regular gamblers were gambling

Speaker: NA
Text: less. In addition, there were also significant increases in positive behaviour, such as 40 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of parents and carers reporting they were better able to look after the needs of their

Speaker: NA
Text: children, and 45 per cent of participating people confirming they were better able to save

Speaker: NA
Text: money. Given this success, the extension of the cashless debit card and its rollout for welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients into additional vulnerable and disadvantaged communities, which is what the

Speaker: NA
Text: passage of the Social Services Legislation Amendment (Cashless Debit Card) Bill 2017 is all

Speaker: NA
Text: about, is a no-brainer.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the two principal locations where the cashless debit card has been trialled, it has quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly worked, and any policy that actually works, especially in the challenging areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare dependence and substance abuse, deserves to be applied to the fullest extent possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: Essentially, the cashless debit card works to reduce the amount of cash available to recipients

Speaker: NA
Text: in trial communities. This works to place downward pressure on the availability of drugs,

Speaker: NA
Text: alcohol and gambling, and, it was hoped-and is now proven-to improve social and family

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The operating mechanism of the cashless debit card is simple enough: having 80 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of welfare payments to recipients quarantined to be spent in the best interest of welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: recipients and their dependants, and not used for the purchase of alcohol, drugs or gambling

Speaker: NA
Text: products. The remaining 20 per cent of welfare payments continues to go into regular cash

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts and can be used for whatever purpose the recipients wish. The aim is to quarantine

Speaker: NA
Text: money for the essentials of life, for those people and families, heavily-and, perhaps, in some

Speaker: NA
Text: cases totally-dependent on welfare and to avoid the problems that too often flow for families

Speaker: NA
Text: and for individuals from spending on products that engender despair and dysfunction, very

Speaker: NA
Text: often with violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is also a way of ensuring that the taxpayers' strong commitment to the provision of a

Speaker: NA
Text: social safety net is honoured. Welfare payments are provided to help people in need with

Speaker: NA
Text: essential living costs, especially food, clothing, shelter, transportation and the like. Welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: payments are not intended to fuel substance abuse, whether alcohol, drugs or other, or to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide an opportunity to gamble. The main game in this program is ultimately to enhance the

Speaker: NA
Text: lives of those people, especially the women and children, who live in communities where the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems of substance abuse, gambling and, too often, violence are prevalent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are fortunate to live in a country and at a time when dealing with, even

Speaker: NA
Text: recognising, these problems is so openly embraced by governments, to the extent that

Speaker: NA
Text: programs like this can provide some much-needed support and help turn the tide on

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage and despair. Not that long ago, domestic violence was a taboo topic, but today,

Speaker: NA
Text: thanks to the dedication of so many-including many victims, might I add, mostly women-

Speaker: NA
Text: both recognition of the problem and the level of support services for families affected by it

Speaker: NA
Text: have finally become a major focus for governments, for institutions and for communities right

Speaker: NA
Text: across the country. Increasing acceptance of the cashless debit card demonstrates that many

Speaker: NA
Text: communities are now ready to do whatever they can to ameliorate suffering, especially at

Speaker: NA
Text: locations where there are clusters of disadvantage and where the problems are greater than

Speaker: NA
Text: they are in more affluent communities elsewhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, this is not to say that problems of domestic violence and neglect are limited to

Speaker: NA
Text: severely disadvantaged communities. Clearly, they're not. As my colleague the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bradfield knows, there are problems on the North Shore of Sydney, which is one of the most

Speaker: NA
Text: affluent pockets of the country. No doubt, that's almost mirrored in Toorak, Brighton and the

Speaker: NA
Text: more affluent suburbs of other cities across the country. Indeed, the theme of the third annual

Speaker: NA
Text: conference of the STOP Domestic Violence organisation, to be held in Melbourne next

Speaker: NA
Text: month, is that domestic violence does not discriminate. And there is more proof of that in very

Speaker: NA
Text: recent statistics from the New South Wales Bureau of Crime Statistics and Research data,

Speaker: NA
Text: which establishes that, in no fewer than 761 suburbs and towns across that state, more

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic violence suspects are picked up by police than for almost any other form of criminal

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, having made that point, there is no doubt that where disadvantage is greatest, the

Speaker: NA
Text: problems of alcohol abuse and other forms of substance abuse-as well as sometimes

Speaker: NA
Text: ridiculously high spending on gambling-and the often closely related domestic violence

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics are also greater. That was certainly the rationale behind the first trial sites for this

Speaker: NA
Text: program last year. These trial sites were in communities with a strong Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: representation-over 78 per cent-and that straightforward fact has attracted some attention.

Speaker: NA
Text: But there's a reason so many leaders in those communities have come out in favour of the

Speaker: NA
Text: program, and that's simply that it has worked. And now they and other leaders in communities

Speaker: NA
Text: across the country, far more diverse communities, are engaged and also wanting to see this

Speaker: NA
Text: program rolled out.

Speaker: NA
Text: One point must be made very clearly: this card, this program, is not directed at particular

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals, or races or religions, or anyone else; it is applied equally to all participants-and

Speaker: NA
Text: only in those communities that strongly support its introduction and only following extensive

Speaker: NA
Text: local consultation. More than 180 consultations were recently conducted in Bundaberg and

Speaker: NA
Text: Hervey Bay. Furthermore, the local MP, the member for Hinkler, seeking to consult directly

Speaker: NA
Text: with his community, sent a direct mail-out to over 32,000 of his constituents, phone polled

Speaker: NA
Text: another 500 and emailed around 5½ thousand more to get their thoughts and feedback on a

Speaker: NA
Text: possible rollout of the cashless debit card for his electorate. The result was that approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: 75 per cent of the feedback received was supportive of the cashless debit card. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence of such a powerful community endorsement, a rollout for Hinkler has now been

Speaker: NA
Text: announced, subject to the passage of this bill. It must be said that the Indigenous population of

Speaker: NA
Text: Hinkler, at 33.5 per cent of the population, is less than that of other trial locations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Safeguards are firmly in place to ensure that if the cashless debit card program is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded, it will grow only in those communities that want to take part. If the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: supports this bill, the government will co-design specially tailored programs for individual

Speaker: NA
Text: communities by working with those communities. And there are many communities that

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to express interest in being part of that extended rollout. A further safeguard is that

Speaker: NA
Text: any growth of the program can only go ahead with the agreement of the parliament via the

Speaker: NA
Text: disallowable instrument process, a process that was also in place for the first trials.

Speaker: NA
Text: The objectives of this program are honourable not only to the Australian taxpayer but also

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to those people the Australian taxpayer has long committed to support in their time

Speaker: NA
Text: of need. This bill, and the highly effective welfare mechanism it seeks to extend, is part of our

Speaker: NA
Text: strong and abiding commitment to the social safety net that is at the very heart of what it

Speaker: NA
Text: means to be Australian. The objectives are clearly set down in the existing legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: authority. They are: to reduce the amount of payments to be available that may be spent on

Speaker: NA
Text: alcohol, gambling or illicit drugs; to determine whether such a reduction decreases violence or

Speaker: NA
Text: harm; to determine whether such arrangements are more effective when community bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: are involved; and to encourage socially responsible behaviour. There is clear evidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: these objectives are now being met.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me address a concern raised by some, and that is that this program somehow impinges

Speaker: NA
Text: on human rights. However important these concerns may be, it is the government's considered

Speaker: NA
Text: view that the expansion of the cashless debit card actually advances the wellbeing and

Speaker: NA
Text: protection of the human beings it impacts. It does so by ensuring that income support

Speaker: NA
Text: payments are spent in the best interests of welfare recipients, their dependents-for whom, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, they carry a responsibility-and the local communities of which they are part. The

Speaker: NA
Text: cashless debit card is assisting to reduce immediate hardship and deprivation, to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: violence and harm and to encourage socially responsible behaviour. These are noble and

Speaker: NA
Text: compassionate goals. On that firm basis the government believes that there are limits on one's

Speaker: NA
Text: rights, limits that are reasonable and proportional in light of the objectives, which are to

Speaker: NA
Text: enhance the dignity and, indeed, the opportunities available to our most vulnerable citizens.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I made clear at the beginning of my address, the problems that this program addresses

Speaker: NA
Text: are some of the most insidious and troublesome that our community suffers from, especially

Speaker: NA
Text: substance abuse and domestic violence. These problems are widespread, even approaching

Speaker: NA
Text: epidemic in some areas. Perhaps such problems offend our aspiration for a model, civil

Speaker: NA
Text: society and an Australia that we all want to see. So, when we find something that works, we

Speaker: NA
Text: should quite deliberately extend the confirmed benefits as broadly as possible, and that's

Speaker: NA
Text: precisely what we're doing in this case.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cashless debit card is an important and now proven policy of this government, a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: that certainly has my enthusiastic support, and, for this reason, I'm delighted to commend it to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: Dr FREELANDER
Text: Macarthur) (12:56): I rise to offer not unqualified support to the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: currently before the House. In saying that, I recognise that this bill seeks to deal with very

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: complex, difficult and deeply ingrained social problems. There are no simplistic answers, in

Speaker: NA
Text: spite of what you might hear from the other side. The Social Services Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Cashless Debit Card) Bill 2017 will allow the existing trial of the cashless debit card to be

Speaker: NA
Text: extended to additional sites. Presently, there's a legislated limit of three sites, with a maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: of 10,000 participants in total. The legislation also sets 30 June 2018 as the end date for the

Speaker: NA
Text: CDC trials. Those limitations will be removed when this bill comes into effect. New trials

Speaker: NA
Text: will require the making of fresh legislative instruments which can be disallowed by either

Speaker: NA
Text: house.

Speaker: NA
Text: I find the government's proposal troubling. I'm open-minded on the use of income

Speaker: NA
Text: management measures, but I'm in total agreement with the commentator Peter Martin from

Speaker: NA
Text: The Sydney Morning Herald when he writes:

Speaker: NA
Text: If you were going to make life much more difficult for people on welfare you'd want to be sure there

Speaker: NA
Text: was a point. You'd want to trial the indignities, you'd want to know they helped.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said in relation to yet another of this government's many bills targeting those at the

Speaker: NA
Text: margins, if anyone in this country has a right to complain about government red tape and

Speaker: NA
Text: overregulation and also about lack of access, it's the poor and the disadvantaged.

Speaker: NA
Text: My personal concerns centre less on the identified trial results or even on the government's

Speaker: NA
Text: effusive and overblown response to them, though these concerns are real enough. What I truly

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt is the CDC's capacity to deliver substantial and lasting benefits over the longer term to

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the most disadvantaged communities. I worry also that the cashless debit card, like its

Speaker: NA
Text: precursors and other forms of income management arrangement, might, in some instances,

Speaker: NA
Text: deepen welfare dependency or even further inure us to it. As one highly experienced social

Speaker: NA
Text: researcher has said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Most trials have some initial effects, the Hawthorne factor, but these usually wear off, so good policy

Speaker: NA
Text: needs very solid data to justify major changes, particularly in areas that deeply affect people's lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's an open question for me whether a better approach might be to trial more extensive and

Speaker: NA
Text: intensive efforts to lift the standard of health and standard of education of those living in

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantaged conditions. There are many things we can do that can improve people's

Speaker: NA
Text: situations without putting in the cashless debit card. By that I mean improving overall

Speaker: NA
Text: health-not just more health care, but infant health, health of young adults and pregnancy

Speaker: NA
Text: health. There are many things we can do before we move to the cashless debit card. I think we

Speaker: NA
Text: also need to try other forms of assistance-some, at times, more radical-and see whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they can produce more lasting and more cost-effective solutions. That's more than I fear we

Speaker: NA
Text: are likely to see from the cashless debit card in the longer term, and I do worry about its

Speaker: NA
Text: persistence as a method of social control in very disadvantaged communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Extensive research work undertaken by those who have spent a lifetime in this field dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with the interrelationship between health, economic and societal wellbeing clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrates that you cannot address health issues without attacking inequality and vice

Speaker: NA
Text: versa. I speak in particular of Sir Michael Marmot, the previous head of the World Medical

Speaker: NA
Text: Association, and his belief in the social determinants of health. As a paediatrician, you might

Speaker: NA
Text: imagine the sorts of things I have in mind, such as early childhood health and pregnancy

Speaker: NA
Text: health. We know now that the science of epigenetics tells us that we can do a lot about

Speaker: NA
Text: people's lifetime health experiences and lifetime education experiences if we intervene to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide good antenatal care and good pregnancy care for people. So, like the Jesuits, I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: you have to get children when they're very young, even before they're born, to make long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term differences.

Speaker: NA
Text: I've read and re-read the minister's second reading speech and the explanatory

Speaker: NA
Text: memorandum, the department's very brief submission to the Senate Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: Community Affairs inquiry and the exchanges between the government and the Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Joint Committee on Human Rights. I am also indebted to the Parliamentary Library for their

Speaker: NA
Text: insights and assistance. If the customary regulatory impact statement had been provided I

Speaker: NA
Text: would have read that as well, but it wasn't. The government has declined to include a financial

Speaker: NA
Text: impact statement in the explanatory memorandum on the basis of commercial confidentiality.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the department has advised through the parliament that the estimated cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: implementing and managing the CDC trial in Ceduna and the East Kimberley from 1 July

Speaker: NA
Text: 2015 to April 2018 is $18.9 million. That's just, of course, for a total of 2,000 participants.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a very expensive program for very limited apparent benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2013, the Australian National Audit Office reported that the estimated cost per person

Speaker: NA
Text: per year for managing income measures such as the CDC could be as high as $7,900 per

Speaker: NA
Text: person per year in remote areas. The income management regime that operated as part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory intervention cost in the order of $410 million and was also roundly

Speaker: NA
Text: criticised, including by a government-commissioned evaluation report, a report prepared by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Social Policy Research Centre at UNSW. All I'd say is that you can get a lot of health

Speaker: NA
Text: care, a lot of medical support and a lot of educational support for that sort of money.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cashless debit card can be used for purchases, excluding certain forms of gambling,

Speaker: NA
Text: illicit drugs, tobacco, alcohol and pornography. The CDC is a Visa debit card issued by the

Speaker: NA
Text: payment company, Indue. Cardholders can use the card at any bricks-and-mortar store that

Speaker: NA
Text: accepts Visa debit cards, unless the store has been blocked. It can also have its uses online. I

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge that the government has made progress in improving some of the technical

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of the scheme, but there's some way to go yet, especially if the CDC is to operate

Speaker: NA
Text: effectively in more densely populated areas. Like earlier cards, the CDC suffers from the

Speaker: NA
Text: limitation that it directly blocks specific merchants and businesses rather than specific goods

Speaker: NA
Text: and services. Blocked merchants can be approved on a case-by-case basis if they undertake to

Speaker: NA
Text: have their staff guard against prohibited activity and if the store refuses to process prohibited

Speaker: NA
Text: transactions, including excluded goods such as alcohol.

Speaker: NA
Text: The manual screening process necessarily adds to the cost and complexity of the scheme. It

Speaker: NA
Text: also makes elements of compliance highly contingent and it is difficult to see how it might

Speaker: NA
Text: readily translate from isolated regional communities to regional centres. The proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: Hinkler and Bundaberg trials will no doubt test this. In each of the two trials to date in the

Speaker: NA
Text: East Kimberley and Ceduna, 80 per cent of an individual's welfare payments are deposited in

Speaker: NA
Text: the cashless debit card account, with the remaining 20 per cent being placed in their ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: savings accounts. Retaining some access to cash does mean that the scheme cannot entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminate the possibility of welfare recipients using some portion of the entitlements on

Speaker: NA
Text: alcohol, prohibited drugs, gambling et cetera. Circumvention and gaming the system have

Speaker: NA
Text: been an issue for all income management schemes trialled in Australia over the past decade,

Speaker: NA
Text: as have cost and effectiveness.

Speaker: NA
Text: ORIMA Research's first evaluation of the Ceduna and east Kimberley trials unearthed at

Speaker: NA
Text: least eight ways in which participants can circumvent the CDC restrictions. That tally is

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: consistent with experience from all welfare card schemes trialled in Australia over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: decade. Even strong and undeniably well-meaning supporters of income management, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: Andrew Forrest and the Minderoo Foundation, argue that both past and current debit card

Speaker: NA
Text: systems suffer from technological limitations that make them difficult and expensive to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement and maintain. The Minderoo Foundation's submission to the as yet uncompleted

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate Community Affairs Committee inquiry argues that the government needs to overcome

Speaker: NA
Text: such technological limitations before extending the card to new communities. Blind to even

Speaker: NA
Text: the advice of those supporting further trials, the government has announced that it does intend

Speaker: NA
Text: extending income management and the CDC trials to at least two new sites: the Goldfields

Speaker: NA
Text: region of Western Australia and the federal electorate of Hinkler, centred on Bundaberg. The

Speaker: NA
Text: PM memorably described this as an act of love. Others might see it more akin to an act of

Speaker: NA
Text: blind faith.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like some, I suspect, on both sides of this House, I do see how a cashless debit card or

Speaker: NA
Text: some other form of income management arrangement might be a useful data source, make a

Speaker: NA
Text: positive difference in the short term or act as an adjunct to other measures. I can also see it

Speaker: NA
Text: playing a supporting role, but only if it is well targeted, supported by local communities and

Speaker: NA
Text: proves cost-effective, meaning that it does not chew up either the scarce community resources

Speaker: NA
Text: and money that would be better spent elsewhere, such as in education, or goodwill that might

Speaker: NA
Text: be better invested elsewhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: In his second reading speech, the minister quotes ORIMA Research's most recent

Speaker: NA
Text: evaluation report, which found that 'overall the trial has been effective to date'-hardly

Speaker: NA
Text: effusive praise. In particular, the trial has been effective in reducing alcohol consumption in

Speaker: NA
Text: the shorter term, illegal drug use and gambling, and has provided some evidence of proof of

Speaker: NA
Text: concept. This is a much more qualified claim than was initially made by the minister, who, on

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 September, in his excitement, ejaculated that the ORIMA evaluation has positive health and

Speaker: NA
Text: social outcomes 'almost without precedent'. Now, that is clearly not true.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Stephen Jones: He did what?

Speaker: Dr FREELANDER
Text: That's my language. I was quoting him. Like the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: 'act of love' remark, this really was a contender for an 'eggbeater of the month' award. I don't

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt the sincerity of the minister and the government on this matter, but I do doubt their

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of the concepts.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can see why some might reasonably conclude that the cashless debit card trials

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken to date have produced some mildly encouraging results, but this is only in the

Speaker: NA
Text: short term and, overwhelmingly, the trial results are more mixed than conclusive. That's a

Speaker: NA
Text: view I share with researchers and commentators such as Eva Cox, Peter Martin, Dr Janet

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunt of the Centre for Aboriginal Economic Policy Research at the ANU, and numerous

Speaker: NA
Text: submissions to the Senate Community Affairs Committee inquiry into the bill. To quote Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Martin yet again on the minister's somewhat eccentric reading of ORIMA's final evaluation

Speaker: NA
Text: report:

Speaker: NA
Text: Forty-five per cent of the of the users surveyed found they were better at saving. Less publicised was

Speaker: NA
Text: that 50 per cent found they were not. Twenty-three per cent said it had made their life better. Less

Speaker: NA
Text: publicised was that 42 per cent said it had made their lives worse.

Speaker: NA
Text: Forty per cent said they could better look after their children. Less publicised was that 48 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: said they could not.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Eva Cox noted:

Speaker: NA
Text: There are serious flaws in data collection, described in the Orima report, some of the limits are

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged in the report … These are not acknowledged by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Western Australian Council of Social Service says in its Community Affairs Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: submission:

Speaker: NA
Text: Our overriding concern with the proposed legislative extension of the Cashless Debit Card trials is

Speaker: NA
Text: the significant gap between the actual evidence of the impacts of the trials carried out to date and the

Speaker: NA
Text: claims being made politically about that evidence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Overstating the positive aspects of the trials not only is misleading and unhelpful but can be

Speaker: NA
Text: harmful, especially if the government falls into the trap of believing its own publicity-

Speaker: NA
Text: something it is very prone to do. A proliferation of further trials or a national rollout of

Speaker: NA
Text: income management would be horrendously expensive and is not supported by the evidence

Speaker: NA
Text: assembled either by the ORIMA study or by earlier ill-fated ventures involving cashless

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare cards and income management arrangements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill has been looked at by two parliamentary committees and is in the process of being

Speaker: NA
Text: examined by a third. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills reported on 6

Speaker: NA
Text: September 2017:

Speaker: NA
Text: … this bill converts authority to run a trial program into a general power to implement that program.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Scrutiny of Bills Committee also raised concerns that the bill reduces parliament's

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to supervise the operation of any extended trial. The committee requested additional

Speaker: NA
Text: advice from the minister as to why the primary legislation does not include more guidance

Speaker: NA
Text: and safeguards on matters such as site selection and participation criteria. These concerns are

Speaker: NA
Text: of the sort routinely raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee about this government's social

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights also examined the bill and queried

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the extension of the trials process is of itself a proportionate limitation on human

Speaker: NA
Text: rights. The Senate referred the bill to its Community Affairs Legislation Committee, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: not due to report until 13 November. The community affairs committee has not completed its

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries, and a further public hearing is scheduled early in November. Quite rightly, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, where the views of individuals and communities should be afforded the most

Speaker: NA
Text: respect, Labor has decided to reserve its final position on the bill until the community affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: committee completes its work. As part of its consultation process, the relevant shadow

Speaker: NA
Text: minister visited the east Kimberley and Ceduna trial sites, and Labor does still see the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for further evidence before strongly supporting this bill. This is entirely consistent with

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's longstanding position on income management arrangements. It's consistent, too, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the findings of two Senate committees and many others on both sides of the House. I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr RICK WILSON (O'Connor) (13:11): I rise today in support of the Social Services

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Cashless Debit Card) Bill 2017. The passage of this bill will provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislative authority to allow the Goldfields region of my electorate to be the third and, to

Speaker: NA
Text: date, largest site for the cashless debit card. On 29 May 2017, I spoke in this place in support

Speaker: NA
Text: of the need in my Goldfields community for the cashless debit card as one tool in a suite of

Speaker: NA
Text: strategies to tackle some of the social and health issues fuelled by alcohol and other drugs in

Speaker: NA
Text: this part of my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Today, I stand here to give voice to my community and the leaders who have so bravely

Speaker: NA
Text: stood up and fought for the introduction of this card. They are people like Leonora Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: leader Nana Gaye Harris, who started the ball rolling when she first sought me out in Leonora

Speaker: NA
Text: in late 2015; people like Laverton Indigenous elders Bruce Smith and Janice Scott, who

Speaker: NA
Text: moved an entire room to tears with their powerful account of children living on the streets of

Speaker: NA
Text: Laverton, abandoned by parents on the grog; and people like Coolgardie community leader

Speaker: NA
Text: Betty Logan and her niece, Amanda Bennell, who in the presence of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: challenged naysayers to look into the eyes of a child suffering the effects of fetal alcohol

Speaker: NA
Text: syndrome and not feel compassion. I give voice to people like Leonora police officer in

Speaker: NA
Text: charge Isaac Rinaudo, who has described children as young as five years of age breaking into

Speaker: NA
Text: houses just to steal food. And I give voices to civic leaders like Laverton's Patrick Hill;

Speaker: NA
Text: Leonora's Jim Epis and Peter Craig; Jill Dwyer and Ian Tucker from the Shire of Menzies;

Speaker: NA
Text: Mal Cullen and Betty Logan from the Coolgardie shire; and Mayor John Bowler of the City

Speaker: NA
Text: of Kalgoorlie-Boulder. They are fighting for what's best for the communities that they know

Speaker: NA
Text: and love and have been committed to for all their lives. Today, I'm their voice in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: On 1 September this year, the Prime Minister came to the City of Kalgoorlie-Boulder and

Speaker: NA
Text: announced that, based on demonstrable need and a willingness reflected through extensive

Speaker: NA
Text: community consultations, the Goldfields would be the next site to roll out the cashless debit

Speaker: NA
Text: card. The Prime Minister's announcement was the culmination of over 18 months of

Speaker: NA
Text: community consultations and followed promising outcomes seen in the cashless debit card

Speaker: NA
Text: trials in Ceduna and east Kimberley. The second independent evaluation of these two trials,

Speaker: NA
Text: conducted by ORIMA Research, was released the same day. This evaluation concluded that,

Speaker: NA
Text: across these two trial sites, which involved a total of 2,141 participants, alcohol consumption

Speaker: NA
Text: and gambling had markedly reduced and alcohol related violence and harm had also

Speaker: NA
Text: diminished significantly. It found in particular that, of people who drank alcohol, 42 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: reported drinking less frequently and 30 per cent of binge drinkers reported they were doing

Speaker: NA
Text: so less often. There was a 37 per cent reduction in alcohol related hospital presentations in

Speaker: NA
Text: Ceduna in the first quarter of 2017 when compared to the same period before the card was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced. Other key findings included that 48 per cent of drug takers were using fewer

Speaker: NA
Text: drugs and 48 per cent of gamblers were gambling less. But, most importantly, the trend

Speaker: NA
Text: showed improving outcomes over time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many ask: why do we need this card in the Goldfields? The Goldfields is an area of

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous mineral wealth, but also considerable social disadvantage. It has a population of

Speaker: NA
Text: around 36,000, of which approximately 10 per cent receive working-age income support

Speaker: NA
Text: payments. Tragically, a considerable amount of this money is being squandered on gambling,

Speaker: NA
Text: alcohol and other drug habits instead of the necessities of life: food, clothing, shelter and

Speaker: NA
Text: transport.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the main street of Kalgoorlie, newsagent Kerry Holman reports that on a daily basis that

Speaker: NA
Text: she sells scratchies to parents on welfare while children plead for food. Other vendors report

Speaker: NA
Text: shoplifting of food and daily essentials as a constant. Meanwhile, government and non-

Speaker: NA
Text: government agencies report providing emergency food and clothing vouchers, even on the

Speaker: NA
Text: days after payments are made into their bank accounts. In Laverton, shire president Patrick

Speaker: NA
Text: Hill reported open gambling in public places, with anything from $2,000 to $5,000 in the ring,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: yet the kids are running around with no food and no clothes. Pat believes, 'If you restrict the

Speaker: NA
Text: cash, you restrict the things that are happening at the moment.'

Speaker: NA
Text: This is supported by findings of the independent evaluation in Ceduna, which showed a

Speaker: NA
Text: marked decrease in requests for emergency food relief and financial assistance, while local

Speaker: NA
Text: merchants reported increased purchases of baby items, food, clothing, shoes, toys and other

Speaker: NA
Text: goods for children. Overall, the independent evaluation also found 40 per cent of cashless

Speaker: NA
Text: debit card participants across both Ceduna and the East Kimberley trial sites reported they

Speaker: NA
Text: were better able to care for their children.

Speaker: NA
Text: The consequential harm from alcohol and other drug abuse is another massive issue for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldfields. WA police data indicates that domestic and non-domestic assaults in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldfields are more than twice the state average, with alcohol being a factor in two-thirds of

Speaker: NA
Text: all domestic assaults and half of all non-domestic assaults. In the Goldfields, alcohol related

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitalisations and deaths is 25 per cent higher than the state average. As mentioned, the

Speaker: NA
Text: independent evaluation of trials in Ceduna and East Kimberley confirmed a decrease in the

Speaker: NA
Text: alcohol related hospital presentations.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm not alone in looking forward to our hospital and emergency service workers having

Speaker: NA
Text: some respite. Mal Cullen, president of the shire of Coolgardie, reported, 'Our police are under

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing pressure, and ambulance service people are being abused.' In the northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldfields, I've been told there are sometimes three Royal Flying Doctor Service medical

Speaker: NA
Text: transfers per day, mostly for alcohol related issues.

Speaker: NA
Text: Publicans in the City of Kalgoorlie, Boulder, Laverton and Leonora, together with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Hotels Association, support the introduction of the cashless debit card, even

Speaker: NA
Text: though these liquor outlets stand to lose income with its introduction. They state the overall

Speaker: NA
Text: impact of less alcohol driven social disorder on the streets will be well worth it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last Friday's front page of the Kalgoorlie Miner quoted the Kalgoorlie police as saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: ice related crime was spiralling out of control, with offenders often between 10 and 18 years

Speaker: NA
Text: of age. Meanwhile, police in Leonora reported that between January and June this year there

Speaker: NA
Text: were more assaults than all other crimes put together. In Laverton, there were three times

Speaker: NA
Text: more assaults than any other crime, with Senior Sergeant Justin Tarasinki citing domestic and

Speaker: NA
Text: non-domestic violence, often as a direct result of alcohol consumption. He added, 'We're also

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about kids who are confronted with the damage alcohol is causing adults, including

Speaker: NA
Text: their own parents, and how they're often exposed to alcohol from an early age.' These

Speaker: NA
Text: testimonies come from respected members of our community who agree there is a real and

Speaker: NA
Text: urgent need for the introduction of the card.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'd like to take a minute now to define what the card actually is and how it will work in

Speaker: NA
Text: practice. This card is a cashless debit Visa card, and for those who say there's a stigma

Speaker: NA
Text: attached, just take a look. It's the same as the Visa card I use for my everyday purchases. No-

Speaker: NA
Text: one on this card will be financially worse off. They'll receive the same welfare benefit they've

Speaker: NA
Text: always been entitled to. Twenty per cent will be available for withdrawal as cash, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining 80 per cent will be deposited onto the cashless debit card, which can be used for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purchase of goods and services, but not to purchase alcohol or to gamble. As an example:

Speaker: NA
Text: a single parent with three children receives just under $1,500 per fortnight in benefit; $1,175

Speaker: NA
Text: of that will be credited to their Visa debit card, with the remaining $294 deposited into an

Speaker: NA
Text: account, which can be withdrawn as cash when required.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I plan to request a cashless Visa debit card myself and to use it when I'm in the Goldfields.

Speaker: NA
Text: With this Visa debit card I can pay for my hotel accommodation, I can buy groceries and I

Speaker: NA
Text: can buy a meal in a licensed premises; however, I can't buy beer and I can't use it to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: punt on the ponies. For those on the card, their benefit will continue to be deposited at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same regular intervals and can be linked to their mobile phone for real-time account balances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Large purchases such as whitegoods or motor vehicles can be catered for. Direct debit

Speaker: NA
Text: payments can be scheduled, and there is financial counselling and practical assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: available. I might add that that has been taken up on a voluntary basis by 40 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: people on the card so far.

Speaker: NA
Text: I aim to ensure that every shire in the rollout area has its own local support officer to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: with the practicalities of managing or replacing the card. In addition, there will be case

Speaker: NA
Text: managers assigned to coordinate wraparound and support services. This card will apply to all

Speaker: NA
Text: working-age benefit recipients; however, in the case of disability support pension recipients, a

Speaker: NA
Text: wellbeing exemption can be applied for.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are those who state that this card is discriminatory, but I'm confident that the

Speaker: NA
Text: cashless debit card trial sites to date have been selected based on a demonstrable need,

Speaker: NA
Text: combined with the support of local leaders. To date, in the two trial sites, which have included

Speaker: NA
Text: 2,241 participants, 78 per cent have identified as Indigenous. In Kalgoorlie-Boulder, over 60

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent of welfare recipients are non-Indigenous. Across the entire Goldfields, there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: fifty-fifty split between Indigenous and non-Indigenous welfare recipients. The Goldfields

Speaker: NA
Text: definitely have a proven need.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have worked hard to secure the support of these dispersed but united communities, that

Speaker: NA
Text: extend from the Shire of Coolgardie in the west to the WA, South Australia and Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory border. I was first exposed to the dire situation in the northern Goldfields in late

Speaker: NA
Text: 2015 when approached to support more place based services to the town of Leonora, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was suffering a spate of youth suicides. I also met a remarkable woman, Nana Gaye Harris,

Speaker: NA
Text: who implored me to help her come up with a way to address the alcohol related harm her

Speaker: NA
Text: community was experiencing. We discussed the potential benefits of the cashless debit card,

Speaker: NA
Text: and her community has been working towards this trial ever since.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since late 2015, I've had countless conversations with community members, Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: and non-Indigenous leaders, business owners, health and other service providers, local

Speaker: NA
Text: government authorities and the police towards consideration of the Goldfields as the next site

Speaker: NA
Text: for the rollout of the cashless debit card. At my invitation, Minister Tudge came to Kalgoorlie

Speaker: NA
Text: in November 2015 to meet with community leaders and service providers. Following my

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting with Gaye Harris, he returned on 22 December 2015, travelling to Leonora to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: with a cross-section of the northern Goldfields community. Shire representatives, service

Speaker: NA
Text: providers, local police, Indigenous leaders and community members from Leonora, Laverton

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Ngaanyatjarra Lands discussed with Minister Tudge the possible rollout of the

Speaker: NA
Text: cashless debit card in dealing with serious social and health issues. The minister made it clear

Speaker: NA
Text: that communities would need to consult widely with their members and would need to

Speaker: NA
Text: commit to being involved in any design, were they to become a cashless debit card site.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since this time, I've committed to consulting widely with adjacent communities and

Speaker: NA
Text: securing the support of residents, business and local governments of the shires of Laverton,

Speaker: NA
Text: Leonora, Coolgardie and Menzies and the City of Kalgoorlie-Boulder. There's been

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable interest expressed by the Shire of Dundas, and I'm working with Minister Tudge

Speaker: NA
Text: for their inclusion in the rollout trial.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prior to announcing the Goldfields as a site for the next cashless debit card rollout, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Social Services conducted more than 285 consultations, including attendance

Speaker: NA
Text: at over 125 meetings across the Goldfields. This incorporated more than 30 consultations with

Speaker: NA
Text: local governments across six Goldfields shires; over 45 consultations with representatives,

Speaker: NA
Text: local service providers and peak bodies working with disadvantaged families; and in excess of

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 consultations with frontline state government officials delivering health and education and

Speaker: NA
Text: public safety services. And the Department of Social Services hosted 10 community

Speaker: NA
Text: information sessions in the greater Goldfields region, attended by more than 180 people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister himself attended further stakeholder meetings. In May 2017, he received

Speaker: NA
Text: strong feedback from the shires of Laverton and Leonora that the time for consultation was

Speaker: NA
Text: over and it was time to get on with it. Minister Tudge listened to an extraordinary plea from a

Speaker: NA
Text: respected elder and grandcarer, Janice Scott of Laverton. She said: 'Our children have no

Speaker: NA
Text: rights. They have no future. Our people are dying. We need this card, and we need to try

Speaker: NA
Text: something now.' At the recent Kalgoorlie hearing of the Senate Community Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Committee, witnesses were asked if there had been enough consultation on the

Speaker: NA
Text: cashless debit card. Jim Epis, who has been the CEO of the Shire of Leonora for over 20

Speaker: NA
Text: years, said:

Speaker: NA
Text: You can only consult so much, and the people in Leonora … have had a gutful. Stop talking about it

Speaker: NA
Text: and just … do it.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal people are the same; they don't want to sit down and meet, meet, meet all the time … Surely

Speaker: NA
Text: we've consulted enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: I firmly believe the time is right to introduce this card into the Goldfields. I want to state for

Speaker: NA
Text: the record that I do not believe that this card is the silver bullet that will fix all the social

Speaker: NA
Text: issues of the greater Goldfields, but, if we can take some of the cash out of these

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, it will address gambling and illicit drug problems. And if this card can be a tool

Speaker: NA
Text: to help reduce the amount of alcohol-related domestic and other violence, if this card can

Speaker: NA
Text: redirect welfare dollars to where they are best spent, on the necessities of life, and if federal,

Speaker: NA
Text: state and local government agencies together are committed to providing the ancillary

Speaker: NA
Text: services to support those on the card, for those wanting to beat an addiction and for those

Speaker: NA
Text: wanting to manage their finances for the benefit of themselves and their dependants, I see no

Speaker: NA
Text: downside in giving this a go. If our communities are behind it, which I firmly believe they

Speaker: NA
Text: are, then we should just pass this bill and get on with it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the shadow minister has indicated that the Labor Party will support this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: through the House, and I sincerely thank her for that. And I welcome the shadow minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: willingness to visit the Goldfields and meet with the leaders of my community. I'm confident

Speaker: NA
