Text: that she'll hear the same message that I've received from my communities: that the time for

Speaker: NA
Text: talk is over and it's time to get on with it. I will close with the words of Laverton elder Janice

Speaker: NA
Text: Scott when she implored: 'Please give our children a chance.'

Speaker: Ms HUSAR
Text: Lindsay) (13:25): 'Cashless'-that's a very interesting term to bandy around

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber today! I rise to speak on the Social Services Legislation Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Cashless Debit Card) Bill 2017, being mindful of a sneaking trepidation that all may not be

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: as it seems. While the intentions of the government and this side of the House are clear and

Speaker: NA
Text: unambiguous, it is still not clear that the cashless debit card will deliver the much-needed

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to communities that they require. Indeed, since its introduction, east Kimberley

Speaker: NA
Text: community leaders have raised concerns regarding the delivery of promised support services

Speaker: NA
Text: surrounding these trials. I would suggest that Labor and other members of this place will be

Speaker: NA
Text: looking closely at these comments and listening to the community leaders and members to

Speaker: NA
Text: find out the real outcomes of these trials. As the shadow minister for families and community

Speaker: NA
Text: services, Jenny Macklin, has rightly pointed out, it is mystifying why the government has

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced this legislation with the Senate inquiry that is already underway. We rightfully

Speaker: NA
Text: reserve judgement until that is complete-and so should the other side of the House. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointing to see them jump the gun and attempt to pre-empt their findings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unlike the east Kimberley and Ceduna trials, the lack of consultation in the Goldfields and

Speaker: NA
Text: Hervey Bay areas is symptomatic of a government that doesn't listen, doesn't communicate

Speaker: NA
Text: and doesn't implement its promises. The actions, or lack thereof, in east Kimberley are in

Speaker: NA
Text: stark contrast to the hope that the trial of the card was thought to deliver. Mothers were

Speaker: NA
Text: hoping that their families would see support programs and training to help break the

Speaker: NA
Text: treacherous cycle of gambling addiction and alcohol and drug abuse. The member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Jagajaga, Jenny Macklin, who probably has more experience than anyone in this place

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the implementation of these policies, rightly points out that surrounding support

Speaker: NA
Text: programs quite simply have not, at this time, been seen.

Speaker: NA
Text: I note that the government likes to trot out the figures, provided through the evaluation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the cashless debit card trial, which were released by ORIMA Research in a flurry of publicity.

Speaker: NA
Text: They claimed that the figures were in and the Messiah had somehow arrived. I would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: first to applaud that, if that were indeed the case. Quite simply, we cannot be sure-and many

Speaker: NA
Text: experts have raised questions about the trial's methodology and the anonymity of participants.

Speaker: NA
Text: Janet Hunt of the Centre for Aboriginal Economic Policy Research in the ANU College of

Speaker: NA
Text: Arts and Social Sciences, in her issues paper, points out that there are too many factors

Speaker: NA
Text: surrounding the evaluation and, importantly, notes the fact that participants were required to

Speaker: NA
Text: identify themselves prior to their participation and that that raises serious questions about how

Speaker: NA
Text: they would respond, and, in some cases, understand the questions and the implications of their

Speaker: NA
Text: answers. As previous speakers have rightly pointed out, it would be surprising if someone

Speaker: NA
Text: with a drug problem who had been identified by the interviewer would suddenly open up and

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss their volume of usage. Similarly, with no or little baseline data, can the stated drop in

Speaker: NA
Text: alcohol use be used with any accuracy? Again, I point to identification as a key problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: We're talking about people who have suffered greatly at the hands of government

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives and others. Yet the original problem of domestic and other violence remains-

Speaker: NA
Text: the very reason for these trials to begin with. This is hardly encouraging for potential

Speaker: NA
Text: participants in the Hervey Bay and Goldfields areas targeted by this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is because of the limitations of the data presented by the government as fact that Labor is

Speaker: NA
Text: highlighting that the section repealed by this bill would still require a legislative instrument to

Speaker: NA
Text: be tabled in parliament, and, as we on this side have said previously, these instruments are

Speaker: NA
Text: disallowable and that means that the rollouts can be agreed or opposed in certain locations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The trial of cashless debit cards has been viewed through a prism of suspicion and distrust,

Speaker: NA
Text: and rightly so. It takes a great leap of faith for these communities to commit to their

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: implementation. That's why Labor has consulted closely with communities in Ceduna and

Speaker: NA
Text: East Kimberley, listening to the communities' views widely, discreetly and humbly. We do

Speaker: NA
Text: support genuine, intuitive policies that acknowledge the problems and opportunities that are

Speaker: NA
Text: unique to remote and discrete communities. Because of the tireless efforts of my colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: Jenny Macklin and Linda Burney, we understand that a cashless debit system may be part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the solution.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Coulton): Order! The debate is interrupted in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with standing order 43. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member for Lindsay

Speaker: NA
Text: will be given an opportunity at that time to conclude her contribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS

Speaker: NA
Text: Mogadishu: Attacks

Speaker: Mr KHALIL
Text: Wills) (13:30): I rise to speak of the abhorrent terrorist attack in the Somali

Speaker: NA
Text: capital of Mogadishu this past Saturday which killed at least 320 innocent civilians and

Speaker: NA
Text: injured 500 more. Al-Shabaab, an affiliate of al-Qaeda, has a history of launching bomb

Speaker: NA
Text: attacks against innocent civilians. This despicable attack is another setback in Somalia's

Speaker: NA
Text: decade-long struggle against these terrorists. The sheer scale of the loss of human life is mind

Speaker: NA
Text: numbing. It's the deadliest-ever attack on Somali soil and the deadliest terrorist attack the

Speaker: NA
Text: world has seen in many, many years.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has greatly shaken the Somali community in my home state of Victoria, many of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: have themselves fled the violence in their homeland to seek refuge in Australia. Their

Speaker: NA
Text: population has grown from less than 250 in 1990 to almost 8,000 today and, during this

Speaker: NA
Text: period of significant growth, they've made remarkable contributions to Australian society and

Speaker: NA
Text: have affirmed their place in our proud multicultural society. Many would have family in

Speaker: NA
Text: Mogadishu, and they are deeply affected by these attacks.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is saddening that there has been relatively minimal media coverage of these attacks. But

Speaker: NA
Text: here in this parliament, I, as an African-Australian MP, say that Somali lives matter, that

Speaker: NA
Text: African lives matter, and I call on the government to provide strong support not only to assist

Speaker: NA
Text: the Somali people to rebuild but to send a strong message to the Somali community here in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and worldwide that we as Australians stand united with Somalia and Somali

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians against this evil.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fadden Electorate: Dreamworld

Speaker: Mr ROBERT
Text: Fadden) (13:31): Today I'd like to acknowledge the first-year anniversary

Speaker: NA
Text: of the tragedy that occurred at Dreamworld on the Gold Coast in my electorate, to pay my

Speaker: NA
Text: respects to the victims and their families and also to the Dreamworld staff and guests who

Speaker: NA
Text: were present on that day. Like so many Australians, I was deeply saddened by the tragic loss

Speaker: NA
Text: of life at a theme park, a place of fun. My heartfelt prayers and sincere condolences go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: families of the three Canberrans, Kate Goodchild, Luke Dorsett and Roozi Araghi, and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Central Coast's Cindy Lowe. I also praise the courage and skill of the first responders on the

Speaker: NA
Text: scene who tried desperately to save and resuscitate those who had such grievous injuries. In

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, I praise Mr Shane Green, the manager of the first-aid department at Dreamworld,

Speaker: NA
Text: for his courageous efforts and recognise the profound impact that fateful day has had on him.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm also aware that the findings of the official investigation into the tragedy are yet to be

Speaker: NA
Text: handed down, but Dreamworld, of course, has invested in safety to ensure that it becomes one

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of the safest theme parks in the world. Dreamworld employs over a thousand people in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate and, with Wet'n'Wild and other theme parks, is one of its major employers. Whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: the tragedy must be examined and victims always remembered, the role of amusement and

Speaker: NA
Text: theme parks goes on. So I encourage all Australians: if you're down at the Gold Coast, pop

Speaker: NA
Text: into Dreamworld, pay your respects, take the family out for a great day and enjoy all that our

Speaker: NA
Text: modern theme parks have in a safe environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Marriage

Speaker: Ms BRODTMANN
Text: Canberra) (13:33): We are in the final days of this expensive,

Speaker: NA
Text: divisive postal survey on marriage equality. The survey closes on 7 November, yet tomorrow

Speaker: NA
Text: is the last day that Australians should mail their survey to ensure it's counted. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Bureau of Statistics, about 12 million surveys have been returned so far, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the one thing that is keeping the yes campaigners awake at night-the realisation that

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of votes may simply never get posted. You could be forgiven for thinking the result

Speaker: NA
Text: was actually in the bag; the most recent poll showed almost 60 per cent of those who had

Speaker: NA
Text: already voted or sent in their survey had ticked 'yes'. But this lead has steadily been

Speaker: NA
Text: decreasing, apparently, over the course of the campaign, so we can't afford to be complacent.

Speaker: NA
Text: In a tightening race, pro-marriage equality campaigners are becoming concerned, not about

Speaker: NA
Text: 'no' voters but about lazy 'yes' voters. Their chief concern is the roughly two million people

Speaker: NA
Text: under the age of 35, most of whom say they'd vote yes but who haven't yet sent in their

Speaker: NA
Text: survey. That apathy could tip the result to no. So I'm calling on all Canberrans and all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians out there-especially young Canberrans and Australians-who haven't yet posted

Speaker: NA
Text: their survey to make sure they get out and post their survey tomorrow. Put it on the to-do list;

Speaker: NA
Text: post that survey tomorrow. I'm calling on you to vote yes for marriage equality in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Forde Electorate: Twin Rivers Centre

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr VAN MANEN (Forde-Government Whip) (13:34): It's my pleasure to rise in the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber today to once again give my congratulations to the Twin Rivers Centre in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Forde, which celebrated its 25th anniversary on Saturday night. I was glad to

Speaker: NA
Text: have the chance at Saturday night's celebration to pay tribute to Twin Rivers Christian Church

Speaker: NA
Text: founding pastors Bob and Naomi Engwicht and current pastors Reuben and Michelle Roos for

Speaker: NA
Text: the incredible work they and the team do in our local community. The Twin Rivers Food Co-

Speaker: NA
Text: op, founded and still run by Noel and Gayle Roberts, also celebrated 25 years of operation on

Speaker: NA
Text: Saturday night. The Twin Rivers church and community centre has become a beacon of hope

Speaker: NA
Text: for our community over the past 45 years, connecting countless families to valuable support

Speaker: NA
Text: networks and programs and inspiring its members to actively commit to make our region a

Speaker: NA
Text: better place to live.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently, the centre has been the beneficiary of various grants from the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government which have supported the rebuild of its kitchen facilities and the installation of

Speaker: NA
Text: solar panels to assist with the centre's electricity bills. It was my pleasure, at the time of those

Speaker: NA
Text: grants being finalised, to announce the good news to such worthy recipients. I thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: hardworking men and women of the Twin Rivers Centre for all you do to support, love and

Speaker: NA
Text: inspire our wonderful communities. Congratulations on 25 years of success.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Cunningham Electorate: Science

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Text: Cunningham) (13:36): This week my local area has excelled in science

Speaker: NA
Text: achievement. I couldn't be prouder-and I'm sure the member for Whitlam joins me in that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week, one of my wonderful local public schools shone in the Prime Minister's Science

Speaker: NA
Text: Awards. Congratulations to Neil Bramsen and Mount Ousley Public School, winners of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister's science prize for primary science teaching. A very proud local MP and the

Speaker: NA
Text: school's principal, Peter Holmes, were in the Great Hall of Parliament House to celebrate one

Speaker: NA
Text: of our great public schools achieving such wonderful recognition. Neil Bramsen instigated the

Speaker: NA
Text: outdoor classroom at Mount Ousley. Students record bird sightings, study the beach and

Speaker: NA
Text: assess levels of marine debris, or read and think in the butterfly garden. They have also talked

Speaker: NA
Text: to astronauts on the International Space Station and made global connections, through Skype,

Speaker: NA
Text: with schools in Africa and America.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the beginning of this week, Professor Gordon Wallace, an outstanding scientist and

Speaker: NA
Text: leader from the University of Wollongong, was announced as the 2017 New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientist of the Year for his groundbreaking work on implantable 3D printed structures

Speaker: NA
Text: containing living cells to regenerate damaged cartilage, bones and even organs. And Gordon

Speaker: NA
Text: paid great tribute to his whole team in receiving the award. We are very proud of them. My

Speaker: NA
Text: sincere congratulations go to Neil Bramsen and Gordon Wallace, leading in science from

Speaker: NA
Text: Wollongong.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bonner Electorate: Foodbank

Speaker: Mr VASTA
Text: Bonner) (13:37): I want to talk about an issue that is particularly important

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Christmas holidays draw near, with some families doing it especially tough-and that

Speaker: NA
Text: is food wastage. I'm proud to have once again partnered with Foodbank Queensland for their

Speaker: NA
Text: annual Christmas donation drive. My office will be taking donations of non-perishable goods

Speaker: NA
Text: until 12 December. Every donation will be going out to people in need this Christmas. Last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, my office was inundated with generous donations. I want to thank the Bonner

Speaker: NA
Text: community for giving so freely. No doubt my constituents' generosity will shine through

Speaker: NA
Text: again this time around. People can donate anything from canned vegetables, pasta sauce, rice,

Speaker: NA
Text: jams and spreads to tinned fruit, long-life products and other non-perishable food items.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's staggering that over 600,000 people in Australia, one-third of them children, seek food

Speaker: NA
Text: relief from charities every month, while Australia produces enough food to feed 60 million

Speaker: NA
Text: people a year. Food wastage costs Australia $20 billion a year and seriously harms our

Speaker: NA
Text: environment. That is why this government is developing a national food wastage strategy,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the goal of halving food wastage by 2030. I commend Foodbank for taking a leading role

Speaker: NA
Text: in the development of this strategy. The government is convening a national food waste

Speaker: NA
Text: summit next month, and I look forward to seeing some great results from that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Herbert Electorate: Broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms O'TOOLE (Herbert) (13:39): The Turnbull government has made a complete mess of

Speaker: NA
Text: the NBN in my electorate. In fact, where I come from, we talk about the 'no broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbours', because that's exactly what is happening in Townsville. In my electorate it is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite common to have one side of the street able to access the NBN and the other side not.

Speaker: NA
Text: Townsville is full of no-broadband neighbours. No-broadband neighbours are homes that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been declared to be service class 0, meaning that NBN Co has made an operational

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: decision that it would be too resource intensive or too time consuming to connect them. These

Speaker: NA
Text: premises are simply left behind until the NBN moves on to the next area.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate, small business operator and director of 2Technical, Luke Cashion-Lozell,

Speaker: NA
Text: has been toing and froing with stakeholders and NBN Co for some time. The NBN has been

Speaker: NA
Text: connected to Luke's office since March but, even though Luke has a notice of completion

Speaker: NA
Text: from NBN Co and 80 per cent of the tenants in his building are connected to the NBN, it

Speaker: NA
Text: appears he is not actually connected. He has reached out to multiple retail service providers,

Speaker: NA
Text: who did not help. He has reached out to NBN Co, who did not help. He has reached out to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, who also did not help. Luke sent me an email in

Speaker: NA
Text: which he wrote: 'I find it horrifying that NBN Co are able to operate like they're seemingly

Speaker: NA
Text: ungoverned by anyone, completely outside of the purview of the Telecommunications

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Ombudsman.' I agree, Luke: this is horrifying.

Speaker: NA
Text: Young Veterans Sunshine Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Health Week

Speaker: Mr WALLACE
Text: Fisher) (13:41): As I rise today, we celebrate Veterans' Health Week.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 21 to 29 October, events are being held around Australia which help veterans and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families improve and maintain their health. This year I was grateful to have the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the Young Veterans Sunshine Coast group and their organisers, Jane MCFadden and Tay

Speaker: NA
Text: Sukhanthapree. The group has 268 members so far and gets together once a fortnight for

Speaker: NA
Text: social activities like yoga and paddle boarding. This kind of companionship can be

Speaker: NA
Text: exceptionally valuable in helping veterans transition into civilian life and in reducing their

Speaker: NA
Text: chances of developing PTSD.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is more to improving veterans' health than formal service provision. As the group

Speaker: NA
Text: says of themselves, 'It's not a sit-down counselling session, just a bunch of people catching up

Speaker: NA
Text: and talking in jargon we all understand and relate to whilst having a great social day.' Sadly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the weather on Sunday prevented the group from swimming with the whales off Mooloolaba

Speaker: NA
Text: as they'd planned, but it didn't dampen their enthusiasm to meet and celebrate. Some frames

Speaker: NA
Text: of tenpin bowling in Alexandra Headland were an excellent indoor alternative. In this

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans' Health Week, on behalf of the House, I want to congratulate Jane and Tay on their

Speaker: NA
Text: simple but life-changing initiative and thank them for their continuing hard work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bushfires

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecommunications

Speaker: Ms SHARKIE
Text: Mayo) (13:42): The countdown to the start of the fire danger season in

Speaker: NA
Text: Mayo and other bushfire prone areas of southern Australia has started. In a little over a month,

Speaker: NA
Text: my community will face the prospect of regular days of declared catastrophic conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Power will be deliberately switched off to protect high-risk areas from the danger of fires

Speaker: NA
Text: ignited by power lines. Under the NBN rollout, my community and others face a new risk: a

Speaker: NA
Text: communication blackout on weather conditions and fire emergency alerts. Households with a

Speaker: NA
Text: downgraded NBN fibre-to-the-node technology will lose their landline and internet service

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately. Residents relying on mobile phones will lose coverage after approximately four

Speaker: NA
Text: hours, when the batteries in towers go flat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last month, I introduced a telecommunications amendment bill in relation to mobile

Speaker: NA
Text: phones, to compel carriers to provide 24 hours of standby power to phone towers in high-risk

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: bushfire areas. It is not much. I've written to every member with a high-risk area in their

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate and I've spoken with Senator Fifield, the Minister for Communications; Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Nash, the Minister for Regional Communications; and the member for Whitlam, the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition spokesperson for regional communications. I thank all three for their time. With a

Speaker: NA
Text: month to go until the start of the fire danger season, we need to address this critical gap in our

Speaker: NA
Text: communications. It cannot be underestimated. I urge the government to take up this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and I strongly encourage every MP in this House to show their support.

Speaker: NA
Text: Robertson Electorate: Environment

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (13:44): I rise to speak about our local environment in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate on the Central Coast, in particular about reports about a potential sale of wetlands

Speaker: NA
Text: in Davistown. There are calls from local residents for the New South Wales government or

Speaker: NA
Text: the Central Coast Council to intervene and purchase the land in question, which I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: is privately owned in some capacity, to help limit its future development. While this does

Speaker: NA
Text: appear to be a matter for the state and local governments and the landowner, there are fears

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed by the local Davistown residents about the protection of our local environment on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Central Coast. So today I wrote to the Minister for the Environment and Energy to ask for

Speaker: NA
Text: clarification on whether the particular area in question may be subject to Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental protection.

Speaker: NA
Text: Next week, on my return to the Central Coast, I also plan to host a round table. I'll be

Speaker: NA
Text: inviting local community advocates and residents, representatives from the Central Coast

Speaker: NA
Text: Council and the New South Wales government to discuss this issue. At the last election,

Speaker: NA
Text: unlike members opposite, we took a clear, local and fully funded environmental plan for

Speaker: NA
Text: Robertson to the community and we will not walk away from it. This plan was a $2.2 million

Speaker: NA
Text: election commitment and included a $250,000 boost to help Clean 4 Shore keep our

Speaker: NA
Text: waterways clean, help upgrade the 5 Lands Walk track, build the Springfield walkway,

Speaker: NA
Text: support surf lifesaving clubs through the Solar Communities program and deliver Green

Speaker: NA
Text: Army teams. One of those teams has been working to identify, survey and monitor the green

Speaker: NA
Text: and golden bell frog at Avoca Lagoon and Davistown. I intend to stand alongside my

Speaker: NA
Text: community at this time. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms O'NEIL (Hotham) (13:45): Last week the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman

Speaker: NA
Text: reported that NBN complaints surged by 160 per cent compared to the previous financial

Speaker: NA
Text: year. The Prime Minister called this a 'calamitous train wreck'. I agree. You shouldn't spend

Speaker: NA
Text: $50 billion on a network that gives you slower, less reliable and more expensive internet; a

Speaker: NA
Text: cost blowout of $20 billion; Australia slipping from 30th to 51st in international broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: rankings; and 76 per cent of NBN users reporting slow speeds, disconnections and dropouts.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a calamitous train wreck, and the buck stops with the man who sits there.

Speaker: NA
Text: Day after day, my electorate office is inundated with calls from Hotham constituents who

Speaker: NA
Text: are so frustrated that they cannot get connected to broadband and then, when they are

Speaker: NA
Text: connected, the problems are endless. I get complaints about faulty installations, poorly done

Speaker: NA
Text: installations, unreliable connections, dropouts, incompatibility with existing medical alarm

Speaker: NA
Text: services, and the unclear division of responsibility between NBN Co and telecommunications

Speaker: NA
Text: providers, leading to poor customer service.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: On the other side, they say this is a mistake by Labor. That is wrong. The NBN was our

Speaker: NA
Text: Snowy Mountains; it was our electricity grid and our roads and our railways of the 21st

Speaker: NA
Text: century. When I ask local businesses to tell me one thing that government can do to help them

Speaker: NA
Text: more, they always talk to me about broadband. We had one chance to do it properly, with

Speaker: NA
Text: fibre. Instead, the government squibbed that opportunity and my constituents are paying the

Speaker: NA
Text: price.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian War Memorial

Speaker: Mr HASTIE
Text: Canning) (13:47): I note that Canberra has been ranked third in the Lonely

Speaker: NA
Text: Planet's Best in Travel, Top Cities list for 2018. In fact, it's the only Australian city to be

Speaker: NA
Text: ranked in the top 10. I don't want to debate that decision. I accept that there are good reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: for it, and one of them is the Australian War Memorial-one of finest national war memorials

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world. Our War Memorial reminds us of the sacrifice that many Australians made in

Speaker: NA
Text: defending our country and preserves their stories and courageous acts for us and future

Speaker: NA
Text: generations. It's fitting that we can see it from parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: It gave me and other MPs and senators great pleasure to see the new exhibition From the

Speaker: NA
Text: Shadows. It is an exhibition developed in partnership with the Australian Special Operations

Speaker: NA
Text: Command that tells the story of Australian special operations in World War II through to

Speaker: NA
Text: Borneo, Malaya, Vietnam, East Timor, Iraq and, most recently, Afghanistan. It displays 600

Speaker: NA
Text: objects, combined with 200 private recollections-often very gripping and moving-told by

Speaker: NA
Text: soldiers who have served Australia in the shadows and their families. There are many objects

Speaker: NA
Text: that tell a story. I think of the gloves of a private who wore them during the day that he

Speaker: NA
Text: dragged Cameron Baird VC from the line of fire after he was fatally wounded in 2013, and

Speaker: NA
Text: there is the CamelBak and antenna of Sergeant D, shot to pieces and still containing a bullet

Speaker: NA
Text: from the day that he ran into machine-gun fire to protect Trooper Jason Brown, who was

Speaker: NA
Text: mortally wounded in 2010. I congratulate Dr Brendan Nelson, Dr Karl James, the historian,

Speaker: NA
Text: and co-curator Danielle Cassar for an excellent exhibition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parramatta Electorate: Diwali

Speaker: Ms OWENS
Text: Parramatta) (13:48): This year saw another round of wonderful Diwali

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrations in Parramatta as we marked the Hindu new year and celebrated the triumph of

Speaker: NA
Text: light over darkness and good over evil. Every year in Parramatta, it's fireworks, lights, food,

Speaker: NA
Text: fashion and great company. I attended a number of events this year and I'd like to thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: organisers and volunteers who made them such a great success. Thanks to the Hindu Council

Speaker: NA
Text: Diwali Fair in Parramatta Park and thanks to the president, Nihal Singh Agar. Thanks to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Little India Diwali Fair in Harris Park, for the first time hosted by the Council of Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. Thanks to the president, Mohit Kumar. Thanks to the guys at BAPS Shri

Speaker: NA
Text: Swaminarayan Mandir for the Annakut Festival in Rosehill, and thanks to Deshan Desai for

Speaker: NA
Text: the invitation. Of course, Diwali was celebrated right here in Parliament House.

Speaker: NA
Text: There were a few events I couldn't make it to, and some of them I was very sorry to miss. I

Speaker: NA
Text: missed the Diwali celebration dinner organised by the Cumberland Council. I don't know how

Speaker: NA
Text: I missed the Diwali cruise on Sydney Harbour. And I don't know how I missed the India Club

Speaker: NA
Text: grand Diwali party. I am definitely going to that one; it is first on my list next year. I am sorry

Speaker: NA
Text: too to the Australian Hindi Indian Association; I didn't make yours either.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: In Parramatta we seem to have Diwali every day over a two-week period. There is an

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary number of events as our wonderful Subcontinent community goes out and

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrates one of the great Hindu festivals of the year. Thanks for the invitations, and I'll see

Speaker: NA
Text: you all next year!

Speaker: NA
Text: Small Business Day

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr RICK WILSON (O'Connor) (13:50): This Saturday is Small Business Day. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: take the opportunity today to put on the record my admiration for the small business owners

Speaker: NA
Text: in my electorate. I'm proud of the fact that O'Connor is home to 19,265 medium to small

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. It's a remarkable statistic and one of the reasons I'm so proud to live in and

Speaker: NA
Text: represent O'Connor in this parliament. It takes courage, ambition and determination to start

Speaker: NA
Text: your own business, and the road isn't always easy. As a farmer and small businessman I have

Speaker: NA
Text: travelled this road and lived the highs and lows that risking your own capital and backing

Speaker: NA
Text: your judgement can bring.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm proud to be part of a government where many of our members share my experience in

Speaker: NA
Text: small business and share a common goal of supporting our small businesses. To this end, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government is cutting the company tax rate for small to medium businesses because we

Speaker: NA
Text: believe in supporting the people who have the courage to pursue their dreams. The instant

Speaker: NA
Text: asset write-off for capital items up to $20,000 is always well-received in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's the work ethic and the drive of our small business owners that creates so many jobs for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians. They create tens of thousands of jobs in my electorate and 5½ million jobs across

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Saturday I'll be home for the 126th Katanning Agricultural Show, an event that

Speaker: NA
Text: wouldn't be possible without the support and sponsorship of our local businesses. We should

Speaker: NA
Text: all take a moment this Saturday to show our appreciation and celebrate the contribution of our

Speaker: NA
Text: small businesses to our great nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: Bendigo) (13:51): We quite often talk about how we're moving to a

Speaker: NA
Text: cashless society. I say bring it on, because after last night in Senate estimates we know that

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Cash misled the Senate estimates at least five times about her office's involvement in

Speaker: NA
Text: the AWU AFP raids. But this minister has form. This is the same minister that knowingly

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed the ABCC commissioner, Nigel Hadgkiss, who's now had to resign. She appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: him, knowing he had broken the law. He had actually breached the Fair Work Act. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: at the same time as the minister was presiding over some horrible situations going on in

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace health and safety.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since the reintroduction of the ABCC, whilst this minister has been in charge, construction

Speaker: NA
Text: deaths, sadly, are up. This time last year they were at 21; today they are at 27. Wage theft is

Speaker: NA
Text: now a growing problem in our workplaces. Celebrity chefs are getting away with ripping their

Speaker: NA
Text: staff off, underpaying them by $2.6 million. Worker exploitation is out of control. This

Speaker: NA
Text: minister should resign, not just because of what she has done in Senate estimates but because

Speaker: NA
Text: of what she is doing in her role as minister across the workspace.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Smarter About Drugs

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TIM WILSON (Goldstein) (13:54): In August I had the pleasure to attend the launch

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Smarter About Drugs program by Australia21 at Star of the Sea College in the

Speaker: NA
Text: wonderful electorate of Goldstein. The program is designed as a resource to help educators

Speaker: NA
Text: facilitate critical and informed discussions among students about drug and alcohol issues-

Speaker: NA
Text: something I'm sure is dear to everybody's heart. Australia21 is, of course, a leading voice in

Speaker: NA
Text: the conversation about how Australia can respond to drugs more effectively and safely.

Speaker: NA
Text: Crucially, they are also giving young people a voice on policy issues that are important to

Speaker: NA
Text: their future. That's why I was so pleased to attend the launch of their event at Star of the Sea

Speaker: NA
Text: College in Brighton, which was attended by the principal of Star of the Sea, Ms Mary

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Connor. I'd also like to congratulate the politics teacher, Peter Farrar, for his contribution in

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing Australia21 and the students together as part of the conversation about being smarter

Speaker: NA
Text: about drugs.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'd also like to acknowledge Rebecca Bunn, the chair of YoungA21; Yvonne Bonomo, the

Speaker: NA
Text: director of addiction medicine at St Vincent's Hospital, who also presented; David Stanley

Speaker: NA
Text: from Harm Reduction Australia; and Carl von Stein, the deputy chair of the Drug Awareness

Speaker: NA
Text: Foundation. They came together to have a conversation about drugs, to help young people

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the risks and how they can be properly addressed. Together they are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: phenomenal work to protect young Australians from substance abuse. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Intersex Awareness Day

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Intersex Australians are people whose biological sex characteristics at birth are not typically

Speaker: NA
Text: male or female. These people make up the 'I' in LGBTIQ. These are the people most

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians never hear about and have little understanding of. Being born with intersex

Speaker: NA
Text: characteristics is statistically as common as being born with red hair, yet intersex Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: remain largely invisible.

Speaker: NA
Text: As one of the co-conveners of the Parliamentary Friendship Group for LGBTIQ

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, I hosted a breakfast here in Parliament House last week in recognition of Intersex

Speaker: NA
Text: Awareness Day. In this place there are many parliamentary friendship groups, but I'm

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly proud of the friends of LGBTIQ, along with Warren Entsch from the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party and Greens' Senator Janet Rice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Around 20 members and senators attended the breakfast, where the intersex community

Speaker: NA
Text: generously shared some of their own very personal stories. They eloquently expressed that

Speaker: NA
Text: intersex Australians simply want the same rights as all: body autonomy, self-determination

Speaker: NA
Text: and legal recognition. The breakfast was a very moving and informative event, one that I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: will be repeated annually. I also hope that it will be the impetus for a much wider

Speaker: NA
Text: conversation about the rights of intersex Australians. So today, on Intersex Awareness Day,

Speaker: NA
Text: let's make sure intersex Australians are seen and heard and proud to be citizens of this nation,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that not one of them is ever invisible again.

Speaker: NA
Text: La Trobe Electorate: Bunjil Place

Speaker: Mr WOOD
Text: La Trobe) (13:56): Excitement is mounting in La Trobe, with the opening

Speaker: NA
Text: this weekend of Bunjil Place, which is a fantastic new arts, culture, leisure and entertainment

Speaker: NA
Text: precinct on the edge of my electorate. Bunjil Place will be the first facility of its kind in

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, bringing together creative entertainment and community in a way that is

Speaker: NA
Text: unparalleled anywhere else in the country. This art precinct will offer a variety of exciting

Speaker: NA
Text: entertainment activities for visitors, such as comedy acts, orchestras and theatrical

Speaker: NA
Text: performances.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm very proud to report that the federal government has contributed $10 million towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the overall cost of $125 million for this landmark project. Covering almost 25,000 square

Speaker: NA
Text: metres, Bunjil Place will feature a diverse mix of facilities all in one place, including an 800-

Speaker: NA
Text: seat theatre with a full fly tower and orchestra pit, which will be suitable for theatre, musical

Speaker: NA
Text: recitals, ballet and opera; a studio with retractable seating for 200 people, suitable for

Speaker: NA
Text: professional community use, theatre, cabaret, circus performance, exhibitions and debates;

Speaker: NA
Text: and a 350-seat function centre with technology for weddings, conferences, gala dinners and

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrations. For the people of La Trobe and Casey, this is a very exciting time. Bunjil Place

Speaker: NA
Text: will be the resident new home for arts in La Trobe.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr STEPHEN JONES (Whitlam) (13:58): Over the last 48 hours we have watched in

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute dismay as another scandal unfolds over this government. This time it's Minister Cash

Speaker: NA
Text: who has been caught as the mastermind of a gross abuse of government power, where they

Speaker: NA
Text: have used the scarce resources of the Australian Federal Police for a political purpose-that

Speaker: NA
Text: is, to go after their political enemies.

Speaker: NA
Text: When this travesty was discovered, instead of taking responsibility, the minister misled the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament and then blamed her staff. Well, frankly, the minister's stories do not stack up.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are unbelievable. She should not have organised a raid on the union office. She should

Speaker: NA
Text: not have turned it into a media spectacle. And she should not have misled parliament about

Speaker: NA
Text: her role in the entire affair.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister sets a very high standard for union members all around the country. She

Speaker: NA
Text: should not set a standard that she is not willing to apply to herself. So, if the minister is not

Speaker: NA
Text: willing to take responsibility for her gross misuse of government power, it is time for this

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister to do the right thing. This is about telling the truth and taking responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister should do the right thing and sack the minister today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Day for Daniel

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TED O'BRIEN (Fairfax) (13:59): We in this House are all federal MPs, but in our

Speaker: NA
Text: houses and homes we are all mums and dads-at least a lot of us are. I should acknowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: that we're doing a pretty good job as mums and dads, and I acknowledge the members for

Speaker: NA
Text: Higgins, Hotham and Adelaide, who this very year have brought new life into this world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, dads deserve a bit of recognition. The member for Mitchell, the member for Canning

Speaker: NA
Text: and the member for Deakin have also all had children this year. Also, the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Berowra's wife is pregnant, as is mine.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a serious thing to say about this. As much as each and every one of us loves our

Speaker: NA
Text: children, so too did Bruce and Denise Morcombe love their child, Daniel, who in 2003, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: age of only 13, was abducted and murdered-and they've given their lives to education ever

Speaker: NA
Text: since. Tomorrow, I walk with the Morcombes for Day for Daniel. I carry a message from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, and, with the blessing of this House, I would also like to carry your best

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes to the entire Morcombe family.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members: Hear, hear!

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: In accordance with standing order 43, the time for members' statements

Speaker: NA
Text: has concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (14:01): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister confirm the following events: by midday yesterday

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Cash had told the Senate five times her office was not aware of imminent police raids

Speaker: NA
Text: before they began, but at 6.10 pm Alice Workman of BuzzFeed reported that journalists had

Speaker: NA
Text: received a leak about the raids from Senator Cash's office, and at 7:30 pm, realising that the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth had been exposed, Senator Cash finally admitted she'd misled the Senate?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:02): What I can confirm is that

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Cash defends the interests of trade union members in a way the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition never did. She defends them. Let's look at this bastion of advocacy for the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the AWU. This is what the Leader of the Opposition said at the royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commission:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is perfectly consistent with the tradition of the trade union movement to have services provided by

Speaker: NA
Text: unions paid for by employers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regrettably, it is, and one of the services provided by unions to employees is trading away

Speaker: NA
Text: their penalty rates-that's what they get paid for, in example after example of hundreds of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of dollars.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The members for Bendigo and Griffith are both warned.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Over a million dollars was paid to the AWU by employers when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition was the secretary. There was one payment after another from

Speaker: NA
Text: Thiess-John Holland, ACI Glass, Chiquita Mushrooms-that really worked out well for the

Speaker: NA
Text: members, didn't it?-and Huntsman chemicals. It's a long list, and one payment after another

Speaker: NA
Text: was found by the royal commission to have no benefit for members and, indeed, to

Speaker: NA
Text: compromise the interests of the members because it compromised the ability of the union to

Speaker: NA
Text: represent them.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we have done is pass legislation to prevent those corrupt payments being made-to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent secret payments being made.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Catherine King interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Ballarat is warned.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: The Labor Party, who are shouting and yelling out, shouted and yelled

Speaker: NA
Text: then. They hated it. They thought there was nothing worse than allowing members to know

Speaker: NA
Text: when the employer was actually paying money to the union.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fact is that what Senator Cash has done is ensure that the standards of integrity and

Speaker: NA
Text: impartiality are applied to the union movement. That's what she has done, and in a way that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition never did when trading away penalty rates and taking money

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: from employers. That was the pattern and that is coming to an end because of legislation we

Speaker: NA
Text: passed and they opposed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Economy

Speaker: Mr VASTA
Text: Bonner) (14:05): My question is to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister update the House on actions taken by the government to support Australian workers,

Speaker: NA
Text: including putting downward pressure on power prices?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:05): I thank the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question. Every policy of my government is focused on delivering more investment

Speaker: NA
Text: and more jobs, and we have seen that delivered in the last year: 371,500 new jobs, with 85 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of them full-time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Brian Mitchell interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lyons is warned.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: That is the longest run of job creation in 23 years. Jobs and growth is

Speaker: NA
Text: not just slogan; it's an outcome. If you want to see the parallel universe where the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: dwells, it's not just one where it's legitimate for unions to take backhanders for employers and

Speaker: NA
Text: to trade away penalty rates. That's one element, but there's another interesting element. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have the member for MCMahon talking about the need for inclusive growth. Labor does not

Speaker: NA
Text: have one policy that would encourage one business to invest one dollar or hire one employee.

Speaker: NA
Text: We say we support inclusive growth, and what we mean by inclusion is that people get

Speaker: NA
Text: included in the workforce-they actually get employment. They get the opportunity to get

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's not just that Labor wants to hit Australians with $150 billion more in taxes. It's not just

Speaker: NA
Text: that Labor wants to jack up the taxes on small businesses and medium businesses, like the

Speaker: NA
Text: bakery I was at with the minister for energy

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier in the week. It was started by a couple, Nick and Louise. As with so many businesses,

Speaker: NA
Text: they built it up from their retained earnings. Labor has two messages to them: (1), your tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: going to go up, so you'll have less to invest; and (2), your energy costs are going to go up.

Speaker: NA
Text: With some of the honourable members opposite, I know there's a great interest in meat pies

Speaker: NA
Text: and the way in which they're delivered. I'm sure they'd realise that energy is a very large part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the cost of a bakery. What Labor offers is this: more expensive, less reliable energy and

Speaker: NA
Text: higher taxes. What does that mean? It means less investment, less employment and less

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities. What the member for MCMahon and his leader should think about very

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully is that you can't have inclusive growth without growth. You can't have inclusive

Speaker: NA
Text: growth without jobs. Everything we're doing supports growth and jobs. Everything Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: does undermines it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Frydenberg interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Minister for the Environment and Energy is warned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Sydney-Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (14:08): My question is to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister, and I refer to the Prime Minister's answer yesterday. Can the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister confirm the employment minister and her senior media adviser, who has now

Speaker: NA
Text: resigned for leaking details to the media of imminent raids, attended his question time

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: briefing yesterday? At what time did the meeting take place, did it take place in his personal

Speaker: NA
Text: office, and who else was present, including, but not limited to, ministers, MPs and members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Prime Minister's office?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:09): The Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is not going to do a very good impersonation of Perry Mason today. She may

Speaker: NA
Text: embark on a fishing expedition, but I repeat what I said yesterday: the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment assured me she did not advise any journalists about the raid, and that is precisely

Speaker: NA
Text: what she has said in the Senate during estimates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Snowdon interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lingiari will cease interjecting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy

Speaker: Ms FLINT
Text: Boothby) (14:09): My question is to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to

Speaker: NA
Text: data that reveals Adelaide power prices increased by more than twice the national average

Speaker: NA
Text: over the September quarter. Would the Treasurer outline why it is crucial to have a national

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to energy security and affordability? Is he aware of any alternative approaches?

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Text: Cook-Treasurer) (14:10): I thank the member for Boothby for her

Speaker: NA
Text: question. She makes reference to those September quarter figures for inflation and the impact

Speaker: NA
Text: of electricity prices. She would also be aware that electricity prices for Adelaide went up 24.3

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent through the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm asked about comparisons to other cities. I'm happy to oblige the member. This is more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 1½ times the rate of increase in Sydney, almost three times the rate of increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, almost seven times the increase in Brisbane and 27 times the rate of increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: Hobart. The member for Port Adelaide thinks somehow South Australia is a leader on energy

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis. The only thing they're leading on is ruining the energy market and ruining the

Speaker: NA
Text: household budgets of South Australian families. This week, the Productivity Commission also

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed that South Australia experienced the most volatility in wholesale prices, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest number of price spikes of any state: 610 between January 2013 and August of 2016.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Boothby and, I think, most South Australians-except for the Premier and

Speaker: NA
Text: maybe the member for Port Adelaide-understand why this is happening in South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's because of the irresponsible energy policies of South Australian Labor government, who

Speaker: NA
Text: have put unrealistic renewable energy targets ahead of affordability for families and reliability

Speaker: NA
Text: for the supply of energy to businesses. That's the trade-off they've made.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can't allow the Labor experiment in South Australia, which has failed and continues to

Speaker: NA
Text: fail, to infect the rest of the national energy market in Australia. The recommendation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: COAG-appointed independent Energy Security Board is that we have to go forward in one

Speaker: NA
Text: direction together. That direction is the National Energy Guarantee, which provides certainty

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase investment in new energy supply, to provide households and business with the

Speaker: NA
Text: reliability that they deserve, to provide savings of up to $115 per year and to act to ensure we

Speaker: NA
Text: meet our emissions reduction targets. That's what the National Energy Guarantee delivers.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's time for the Labor Party to get on board with the National Energy Guarantee, to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have bipartisanship in this place that means we can move as one entire nation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: direction that household and businesses demand of this parliament and demand of state and

Speaker: NA
Text: territory governments all around the country. Labor knows, as the shadow Treasurer knows,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that their policies and the 50 per cent RET will force up prices by at least $192 per year. If he

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to be very lippy about this topic, maybe we'll get a question today; he hasn't had one in

Speaker: NA
Text: a while. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR (Gorton) (14:13): My question is to the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Does the Prime Minister expect Australians to believe the employment minister's office

Speaker: NA
Text: watched the minister mislead the Senate five times before midday yesterday, but didn't say a

Speaker: NA
Text: thing? The senior media adviser, who has now resigned, attended the Prime Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: question time briefing with the minister but said nothing, and the adviser then heard the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister be asked twice about the matter during question time, but still did nothing.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:13): I thank the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for his question. He's addressed a number of questions to the media adviser concerned, who

Speaker: NA
Text: has properly resigned after a very, very wrong, improper act of indiscretion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Champion interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Wakefield!

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: He was wrong to do what he has admitted to, but he was right to

Speaker: NA
Text: resign.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Champion interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Wakefield will leave under 94(a).

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Wakefield then left the chamber.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: I want to draw honourable members' attention-in the context of the

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks made yesterday by the member for Gorton and indeed some very intemperate

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks by the member for Whitlam just before question time-to a statement from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police Commissioner, Andrew Colvin. This is what Commissioner Colvin

Speaker: NA
Text: says. He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The AFP requires the ongoing assistance and support of the public to serve the community in which we

Speaker: NA
Text: all-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Ryan interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lalor will cease interjecting. The Prime Minister will

Speaker: NA
Text: resume his seat. The member for Gorton.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Brendan O'Connor: Speaker, on relevance: I did not ask a question about the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of the Federal Police; I asked about-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Gorton will resume his seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Brendan O'Connor interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Gorton will resume his seat!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Brendan O'Connor interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Gorton is warned. He has a habit of ignoring me when I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask him to resume his seat. It is not an opportunity in a point of order to rant and rave across

Speaker: NA
Text: the dispatch box when you do not have the call. The Prime Minister has the call.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: The commissioner, Andrew Colvin, notes:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The AFP has this week been the subject of commentary and innuendo regarding its independence and

Speaker: NA
Text: the ability of AFP members to carry out their work objectively and without political interference.

Speaker: NA
Text: He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The AFP requires the ongoing assistance and support of the public to serve the community in which we

Speaker: NA
Text: all live, and undertakes its activities without fear or favour. The AFP rejects in the strongest terms any

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion to the contrary. The AFP makes all its operational decisions independently, based on

Speaker: NA
Text: experience, operational priorities and the law.

Speaker: NA
Text: The AFP's primary obligations are to ensure the safety and security of the Australian community and

Speaker: NA
Text: enforce the rule of law.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Khalil interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Wills is warned.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: He says:

Speaker: NA
Text: The AFP prides itself on its independence and integrity, and has a proven track record of these values

Speaker: NA
Text: while operating under the remit of eight individual Prime Ministers and their governments since it was

Speaker: NA
Text: founded in 1979.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's about time the Leader of the Opposition disowned all of these disgraceful, reckless attacks

Speaker: NA
Text: on the integrity of the AFP by his members. The Leader of the Opposition should reflect on

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that the Australian Federal Police, the men and women of that force, keep us safe.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are independent. They uphold the rule of law, and it's about time Labor did too.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Just before I call the member for Kennedy, I've got some business to get

Speaker: NA
Text: through here.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Catherine King interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I warned the member for Ballarat yesterday. Again today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Catherine King: Sorry.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: No, I'm not accepting 'sorry'. We don't do that. It's not a negotiation.

Speaker: NA
Text: You can leave under 94(a).

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Ballarat then left the chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (14:17): I'd like to make a very special welcome to the Hon. Peter

Speaker: NA
Text: Watson, the Speaker of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members: Hear, hear!

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: North Queensland: Insurance

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Text: Kennedy) (14:18): My question is to the Minister for Revenue and

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial Services. In May 2014, I raised the issue of skyrocketing North Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: insurance premiums. ACCC figures show northern premiums rising 80 per cent in five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: With 400 per cent increases, North Queensland is the lead contributor. With pre-Cyclone-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tracy old-building-code buildings all gone, this discrimination cannot now be justified. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 2006, Cyclone Larry damages were $1.5 billion; in 2011, Cyclone Yasi, only $800 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: When will the Prime Minister establish an authority to underwrite exceptional circumstances,

Speaker: NA
Text: providing the platform for yarding profiteering insurers?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: Applause of relief!

Speaker: Ms ODWYER
Text: Higgins-Minister for Revenue and Financial Services) (14:19): I very

Speaker: NA
Text: much thank the member for Kennedy for his question, and I note his very strong interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring that Queenslanders pay appropriate insurance premiums and not one dollar more

Speaker: NA
Text: than they are required to. I'm happy to report to the parliament that this is exactly why the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government has directed the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to

Speaker: NA
Text: monitor prices, costs and profits in the insurance market in northern Australia in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: home, contents and strata insurance. This commenced on 1 July 2017, and it will continue for

Speaker: NA
Text: three years. The government have committed $7.9 million to this inquiry, and we will very

Speaker: NA
Text: closely monitor the findings of the surveillance that the ACCC conducts. The government will

Speaker: NA
Text: consider whether there is any need to take action in improving insurance affordability as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of this very important inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr TED O'BRIEN (Fairfax) (14:19): My question is to the Minister for the Environment

Speaker: NA
Text: and Energy. Will the minister update the House on the government's action to guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: affordable and reliable energy for hardworking Australians and businesses, including in my

Speaker: NA
Text: home state of Queensland? And how does this compare with alternative approaches?

Speaker: Mr FRYDENBERG
Text: Kooyong-Minister for the Environment and Energy) (14:20): I

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the member for Fairfax for his question. He comes from the great state of Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it's not a great state for energy policy because, as a result of the actions of the Labor state

Speaker: NA
Text: government, the Palaszczuk government, the green light has been given the to the

Speaker: NA
Text: government-owned generators to game the system and, as a result, Queenslanders have paid

Speaker: NA
Text: on average 30 per cent more for their wholesale electricity prices in the first five months of

Speaker: NA
Text: this year than the other states in the National Electricity Market. And it's been left to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull government to do the heavy lifting on energy policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Through the National Energy Guarantee, we have delivered a credible, workable, practical

Speaker: NA
Text: policy that will deliver more reliable and affordable power-no subsidies, no taxes, no trading

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes-and it's been broadly welcomed by business, big and small, as being a way forward

Speaker: NA
Text: for this country. It builds on the work that we've done in other areas of energy policy, such as:

Speaker: NA
Text: passing legislation just a couple of weeks ago to stop the gaming by the networks of the poles

Speaker: NA
Text: and wires; the work that we've done with the retailers to ensure that hundreds of thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians save hundreds of dollars a year on their retail bill; and the work that we've done

Speaker: NA
Text: with the gas companies. As a result of the Prime Minister's intervention, we will not see a

Speaker: NA
Text: shortfall in the domestic market, as was expected for 2018 and 2019.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can inform the House today that AP LNG have announced that they will provide 41

Speaker: NA
Text: additional petajoules to the domestic market starting from next week. That's the equivalent of

Speaker: NA
Text: enough gas to power two million homes across New South Wales, an enormous amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: extra gas that has been delivered as a result of the Turnbull government's intervention.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's been days since we've had a question from those opposite on energy. They've gone

Speaker: NA
Text: silent. The member for Port Adelaide has turned into the Marcel Marceau of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: politics. The Leader of the Opposition said that when it comes to energy policy, time for talk

Speaker: NA
Text: is over. I didn't know that he'd take his own advice, the reason being that he knows that under

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party's policy, Australian households will be $300 a year worse off. Shame on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party. Shame on the Labor Party for their energy policy! It's time they realise that the

Speaker: NA
Text: way forward for this country to get reliable and affordable power is to listen to the experts, as

Speaker: NA
Text: they asked us to do, and to give us a bipartisan consensus to ensure that the National Energy

Speaker: NA
Text: Guarantee becomes a reality. It's time the Labor Party got on board.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: Watson-Manager of Opposition Business) (14:23): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister expect Australians to believe that the media reported

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday an allegation that the employment minister's office had leaked the raids? The

Speaker: NA
Text: employment minister then came to the Prime Minister and said that she herself had not

Speaker: NA
Text: personally leaked the raids. And the Prime Minister, with all his training as a cross-examiner,

Speaker: NA
Text: didn't think to ask if her office had leaked the raids, which was the only allegation that had

Speaker: NA
Text: been made? Did the Prime Minister, in fact, ask this question? Or had he already been advised

Speaker: NA
Text: it was safer not to ask?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:24): The member for Watson does

Speaker: NA
Text: his best at innuendo, but he's not a particularly talented cross-examiner. Here are the facts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The minister gave me the assurance I told the House about yesterday-that she'd not disclosed

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter to journalists before the raid. That was the assurance that she gave me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Subsequently, as honourable members know, her media adviser admitted his wrongful

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct and he's resigned. I understand why the Labor Party want to focus on the wrongful

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct of a ministerial staffer rather than on why $100,000 of AWU members' funds were

Speaker: NA
Text: given to an organisation that wants to put most of those members out of a job. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: question. And they want to know why, when the Registered Organisations Commission asked

Speaker: NA
Text: for documentary information from the AWU, they weren't provided it. They want to know

Speaker: NA
Text: about that too. But what I think Australians will find very hard to understand-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Butler interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Griffith will leave under 94(a).

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Griffith then left the chamber.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: is why the opposition, at this time of economic challenges, at this time

Speaker: NA
Text: of high electricity prices, has now no interest in asking about the National Energy Guarantee,

Speaker: NA
Text: no interest in talking about measures that will improve employment and no interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: economic issues. They're only interested in one thing, and that is to protect union officials

Speaker: NA
Text: from transparency and accountability. And the law is catching up with those traditions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade union movement, thanks to the hard work and dedication of the employment minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Cash.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Conroy interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Khalil interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Brian Mitchell interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Shortland! And I remind the member for Wills and the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lyons that they've warned.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy

Speaker: Mr LITTLEPROUD
Text: Maranoa) (14:27): My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources and Minister for Resources and Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Will the Deputy Prime Minister advise the House why the government's National

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy Guarantee is crucial to the success of hardworking Australians in the agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: sector, including those in my electorate of Maranoa? Is he aware of any alternative

Speaker: NA
Text: approaches?

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: New England-Deputy Prime Minister, Minister for Agriculture and Water

Speaker: NA
Text: Resources and Minister for Resources and Northern Australia) (14:27): It's great to have all

Speaker: NA
Text: their attention for once. I'd like to thank the member for Maranoa for his question, and he

Speaker: NA
Text: understands full well how important energy prices are and how important it is to keep blue-

Speaker: NA
Text: collar workers in a job, especially in the meat-processing industry, especially in the abattoirs.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are so many abattoirs in his electorate, like John Dee at Warwick and Western Meat

Speaker: NA
Text: Exporters at Charleville. I remember actually getting the deal through for Western Meat

Speaker: NA
Text: Exporters in Charleville when I worked for QIDC. It was a big deal then-$8 million. It now

Speaker: NA
Text: employs hundreds of people. That was a great outcome for Charleville.

Speaker: NA
Text: For Hall egg farms at Millmerran and all the irrigators in the Darling Downs and out at St

Speaker: NA
Text: George, electricity prices are terribly important. We're now seeing, in places such as St

Speaker: NA
Text: George, that they're going from electricity back to diesel. Why are they doing that? They're

Speaker: NA
Text: doing that because power prices under the Queensland Labor government are hopeless.

Speaker: NA
Text: What's happened is Queensland now has the dearest power prices in Australia, and that is a

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable effort for Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk, because she had to get around South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to get the dearest power prices, and South Australia's were the best in the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: world!

Speaker: NA
Text: So what we have to do in our policy is to make sure we get clear transparency so that

Speaker: NA
Text: people can change between accounts. We're making sure that the gas prices, at Wallumbilla,

Speaker: NA
Text: are down, and now the spot price is down between $7 and $8. Wallumbilla is also in the

Speaker: NA
Text: member's electorate. At one point in time Darren Lockyer played there. We're also making

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that we keep the coal fire burning, because, if we don't keep that coal fire burning, you're

Speaker: NA
Text: not going to have any blue-collar workers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr JOYCE
Text: They're laughing because they don't believe in blue-collar workers anymore.

Speaker: NA
Text: They don't. They believe that blue-collar workers are now politically incorrect and they're

Speaker: NA
Text: doing everything in their power to turn themselves into a party that represents the inner

Speaker: NA
Text: suburbs and other sections of the workforce but no longer blue-collar workers. There's very

Speaker: NA
Text: little experience in blue-collar work on that side of the chamber. Very few of them have ever

Speaker: NA
Text: actually been labourers. There are very few labourers in the Labor Party. They've given up on

Speaker: NA
Text: labourers in the Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: They've also given up on making sure that we look after the dignity of the people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: weatherboard and iron, in towns such as Augathella, Eulo, Eromanga, Birdsville,

Speaker: NA
Text: Goondiwindi, Kingaroy-that we look after these people who are doing it tough on the

Speaker: NA
Text: peripheries of society. We make sure that they have the dignity of affordable power in their

Speaker: NA
Text: house so they can keep themselves cool in summer and warm in winter and we make sure that

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: we don't create second-class citizens of a section of Australian society. This is something that

Speaker: NA
Text: I know, in the National Party and in the coalition, we hold closest to our heart. Every time we

Speaker: NA
Text: look at policy, we are saying: 'How does this affect those at the margins of society? How do

Speaker: NA
Text: we make sure there's dignity in these people's lives?' We are not there for those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: more interest- (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (14:31): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's answer. Is it now the position of the

Speaker: NA
Text: government that staff can mislead their ministers, that ministers can mislead the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the minister will remain entirely unaccountable? How are your ministers meant to be

Speaker: NA
Text: running the country when they can't even run their office?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the House will cease interjecting.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Minister for Social Services will cease interjecting.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:31): The honourable member knows

Speaker: NA
Text: very well that a minister is accountable for what she says, and her obligation is to speak the

Speaker: NA
Text: truth. She was misled, as she said, and, once her staffer told her the truth and made the

Speaker: NA
Text: admission that he'd done the wrong thing, she corrected the record. She acted entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: properly. And that stands in stark contrast to the actions of the Leader of the Opposition. It's

Speaker: NA
Text: not a question of his staff; it's a question of the people that own him. He is a wholly owned

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidiary of the CFMEU. He is a wholly owned subsidiary of a militant trade union, cashed

Speaker: NA
Text: up and powerful, that defies the law. It treats judges, courts and fines as of no account. And,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, he has delivered for them. He sent messages of joy and comradeship to the rally

Speaker: NA
Text: that John Setka addressed in which he attacked the Australian Federal Police as a political

Speaker: NA
Text: henchman-exactly the same criticism that his own industrial relations spokesman, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Gorton, made about the Federal Police. The Leader of the Opposition has not

Speaker: NA
Text: disowned either of them; he does not dare-they own him. He has no ability to stand up to

Speaker: NA
Text: that union, despite being called to account by Bob Hawke and by Kevin Rudd. Bob Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: said that when he was Prime Minister he had the courage and the commitment to disaffiliate

Speaker: NA
Text: the BLF. He deregistered the BLF. He had the courage to do that. What does the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition do? He just takes more money from them. He just gets the old receipt book out

Speaker: NA
Text: and takes more money from them, just as he took money, when he was the secretary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: union, from one employer after another and did not tell his members about it. He did not tell

Speaker: NA
Text: his members about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Husar interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Lindsay is warned.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Then, when we sought to change the law, to do no more than oblige

Speaker: NA
Text: unions to disclose to their members the money they were getting from employers and to take

Speaker: NA
Text: that money only for legitimate purposes-transparent, openness; you'd think everyone would

Speaker: NA
Text: sign up to that-not the party opposite. They are not the party of the workers. They're the

Speaker: NA
Text: party of the workers' representatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Moreton will leave under 94(a). He's lucky he's not

Speaker: NA
Text: named.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Moreton then left the chamber.

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Text: Bowman) (14:34): My question is to the Minister for Health. I'm asking

Speaker: NA
Text: the minister to outline to the House why an affordable and reliable energy supply is important

Speaker: NA
Text: for health services in Queensland, including both Mater and Redland hospitals in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Bowman. Is the minister aware of any threats that may jeopardise the delivery of

Speaker: NA
Text: services for my patients?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: Flinders-Minister for Health and Minister for Sport) (14:35): I want to thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Bowman. He's not just a great local advocate for hospitals such as Mater and

Speaker: NA
Text: Redland but also a lifelong medical professional. He is, in fact, an eye surgeon, and to this

Speaker: NA
Text: day he continues to hold pro bono clinics in eye health care-really something extraordinary.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the things he knows is that Labor loves higher electricity prices, and those higher

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity prices are a threat to patients. They're a threat to hospitals such as Mater and

Speaker: NA
Text: Redlands and they're a threat to every hospital in Queensland. That's why we're introducing a

Speaker: NA
Text: National Energy Guarantee. That is why only today you're seeing the benefits of the work of

Speaker: NA
