Text: the Prime Minister and the Minister for the Environment and Energy in pushing the gas

Speaker: NA
Text: companies to make more gas available, which will bring down the price of gas in this country,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in fact he's already so doing. We're also seeing the benefits of the abolition of limited

Speaker: NA
Text: merits review, another government initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are things that are aimed fairly and squarely at bringing down the cost of electricity

Speaker: NA
Text: and energy and bringing down the impact of that on hospitals-not just in the electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowman and not just in Queensland but right around Australia. And the member has also

Speaker: NA
Text: done something that not one person on the Labor side has done: he voted against a carbon tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor introduced a carbon tax that had a $2,425 impact per annum on each hospital bed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland. That was the impact of the carbon tax, on the Queensland Treasury's own

Speaker: NA
Text: modelling. And right now he is fighting against the Queensland government's impact-

Speaker: NA
Text: gouging, with regard to their own state-owned enterprises in electricity, and the 50 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: RET in Queensland-which we have seen is posing blackout threats this summer.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member's next task, which he's committed to, is to join all of us in fighting against

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's attack on hospitals around Australia. Their 50 per cent renewable energy target

Speaker: NA
Text: national pledge is going to have an impact of $300 per year compared with our approach.

Speaker: NA
Text: That's $300 per family per year, and that is going to hurt each and every hospital. So, the

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bowman isn't just an advocate for better health care and isn't just a practitioner of

Speaker: NA
Text: better health care; he's an advocate for hospitals that don't face the impact of Labor's assault

Speaker: NA
Text: on their electricity prices. He's going to continue to fight against Labor's bad practices, and so

Speaker: NA
Text: will we.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: Watson-Manager of Opposition Business) (14:38): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. During the 'Utegate' scandal, the Prime Minister spoke about misleading the

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament, saying:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That is an offence that should result in the dismissal or resignation of a minister. It is perfectly clear.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given that it is perfectly clear that the employment minister misled the Senate five times, why

Speaker: NA
Text: won't the Prime Minister, under his own standards, sack the employment minister?

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: Wentworth-Prime Minister) (14:39): The honourable member knows

Speaker: NA
Text: very well that the Minister for Employment, Senator Cash, gave evidence in the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates in which she described the facts of the matter as known to her at the time. When her

Speaker: NA
Text: staffer admitted to having done the wrong thing, she corrected the record in light of that

Speaker: NA
Text: admission. That is precisely what she should have done, and she did it-with an integrity that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member might reflect has been all too rarely shown by those who claim to

Speaker: NA
Text: represent and lead trade unions in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Albanese interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Grayndler!

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade Unions

Speaker: Mr GEE
Text: Calare) (14:39): My question is to the Minister for Defence Industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: representing the Minister for Employment. Will the minister outline to the House why it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important that the union movement is run honestly on behalf of hardworking Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: families and businesses? Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: thank the member for Calare for his question. Yesterday on Radio National, the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition, on the Fran Kelly program, in answer to a question about the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: that we've been discussing in the last couple of days, said the government set up a royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commission, the Heydon royal commission, which 'found nothing'. Saying the royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commission found nothing is like saying that, in 1492, Columbus sailed the ocean blue and

Speaker: NA
Text: found nothing. He didn't come across North America. What would finding something look

Speaker: NA
Text: like? Finding the lost city of Atlantis? Would that have been finding something? The Ark of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Covenant-would that have been finding something, Member for Sydney? What a

Speaker: NA
Text: ludicrous statement!

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me remind the Labor Party of some of the things the royal commission found. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence of the royal commission, there have been 10 successful prosecutions, eight

Speaker: NA
Text: criminal convictions and two civil penalties. Eleven matters are currently before the courts in

Speaker: NA
Text: criminal and civil matters. One hundred and nineteen referrals have been made to the DPP

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the Heydon royal commission, because of illegal activity. Because of the Heydon

Speaker: NA
Text: royal commission, the Australian Building and Construction Commission has been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: established. Because of the royal commission, the Registered Organisations Commission has

Speaker: NA
Text: been established and the corrupting benefits legislation has been passed by both houses of

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament. Before the House now is the ensuring integrity bill and the proper use of workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits bill. That's all happened because of the Heydon royal commission, which the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition says found nothing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem with the Labor Party and their relationship with the union movement is they

Speaker: NA
Text: are addicted to the rivers of gold that the union movement funnels to the Labor Party for their

Speaker: NA
Text: election campaigns. If the Leader of the Opposition had any integrity, he would turn his back

Speaker: NA
Text: on the CFMEU rivers of gold that hold up his leadership. The problem is-and the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public get it-that, if the Leader of the Opposition isn't strong enough to stand up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: CFMEU, he certainly isn't strong enough to stand up for the nation's interests at home or

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (14:43): My question is to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister. Is the reason that the Prime Minister hasn't sacked his employment minister

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Prime Minister is in this up to his neck?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I've got a problem with that question. It's very short and the last part was

Speaker: NA
Text: about 'in this'. It might be very obvious to members of the opposition what they're referring to,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I don't believe it conforms with standing orders.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Rob Mitchell interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: And I will tell you what: if you want to watch the rest of it back in your

Speaker: NA
Text: office, Second Deputy Speaker, I can accommodate you. I will hear from the Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business.

Speaker: Mr Burke
Text: Speaker, I move that so much of the standing and sessional orders-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: No. The Manager of Opposition Business will resume his seat. That's

Speaker: NA
Text: quite out of order. I'm ruling on the question and whether it's in order or not. I called you on

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis that you were going to do what you normally do and argue with me that the question

Speaker: NA
Text: is in order. The Manager of Opposition Business can resume his seat. This will be very

Speaker: NA
Text: simple. The question is out of order. I'm going to the next question.

Speaker: NA
Text: National Security

Speaker: Mr WOOD
Text: La Trobe) (14:44): My question is to the Minister for Immigration and

Speaker: NA
Text: Border Protection. Will the minister update the House on the work the Australian Border

Speaker: NA
Text: Force has undertaken with the Australian Federal Police to protect Australian families and the

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity of our borders?

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Dickson-Minister for Immigration and Border Protection) (14:44): I

Speaker: NA
Text: think I know how this is going to be book-ended now. I think the Manager of Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: Business went a little bit too early, didn't he? He often stuffs up just at the wrong moment, but

Speaker: NA
Text: there you go. I want to thank the member for La Trobe for his question because he has the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest respect for our law enforcement officers across the country. He supports the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police, he supports very strongly the Australian Border Force and so does

Speaker: NA
Text: this government. This government has absolute and complete faith in our law enforcement

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies because they are independent and they are proud of the fact that they are

Speaker: NA
Text: independent. We have stood up Counter Terrorism Unit officers in our international airports

Speaker: NA
Text: because we recognise the significant threat from terrorists, both those here and those that

Speaker: NA
Text: might seek to come to our country as well. We have seen 884 people stopped by the CTU

Speaker: NA
Text: officers since 2014, and those officers attached to the Australian Border Force walk hand in

Speaker: NA
Text: glove with the Australian Federal Police at our airports around the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Imagine how those Federal Police officers would have felt in the last 24 hours when their

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity has been questioned by those opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Tim Wilson interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Goldstein is warned.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: Imagine those officers who stand there every day to protect us. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: led by an exceptional leader in Commissioner Andrew Colvin. Imagine how he feels and his

Speaker: NA
Text: officers feel when up hill and down dale those members on the frontbench, those members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, have questioned the integrity of the Australian Federal Police. It is a disgraceful

Speaker: NA
Text: episode but, I'm sorry to say, it's not without precedent. It's not without precedent because the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact is that, for many years, union leaders in this country have seen themselves above the law.

Speaker: NA
Text: So when the Leader of the Opposition interjected earlier that the Prime Minister was up to-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Brian Mitchell interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The minister will pause for a second. The member for Lyons has been

Speaker: NA
Text: warned numerous times, which is a regular occurrence. He can anticipate my next sentence;

Speaker: NA
Text: that's even quicker, thank you. The minister has the call.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Lyons then left the chamber.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: That's an improvement in the IQ level already.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The minister will withdraw.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: I withdraw, Mr Speaker. So when the Leader of the Opposition said to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister before that-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Conroy interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Shortland is warned.

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Text: he was up to his neck in it, I will tell you who is up to his neck in it: it is

Speaker: NA
Text: this bloke here. The Australian public are on to this Leader of the Opposition. Throwing these

Speaker: NA
Text: red herrings out will not distract from the fact that the Australian Federal Police, of their own

Speaker: NA
Text: volition, decided to raid the AWU because they are worried about the integrity of this Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition. And he has form: he has fronted the royal commission; he has been part of

Speaker: NA
Text: a union movement that has been proven to be corrupt in the courts; and they have paid

Speaker: NA
Text: penalties. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: MOTIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Employment

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: Watson-Manager of Opposition Business) (14:48): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business from moving immediately:

Speaker: NA
Text: The House:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) notes:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) yesterday morning, the media aired an allegation the Employment Minister's Office had leaked

Speaker: NA
Text: the raids, which allowed television crews to turn up to the raids before the police did;

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) by midday yesterday, the Employment Minister had five times denied that her office had been

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in leaking the raids;

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) at the Prime Minister's Question Time briefing yesterday, attended by the Employment Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Senior Media Adviser who has now resigned for leaking the raids, the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the Government's account, failed to ask a single question about the involvement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's office in leaking the raids;

Speaker: NA
Text: (d) at 6.10 pm, Alice Workman of Buzzfeed reported that journalists received a leak about the raids

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Employment Minister's office before the raids began;

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) at 7.30 pm, after the truth had been exposed, only then did the Employment Minister finally

Speaker: NA
Text: admit that she had misled the Senate on five separate occasions; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (f) during the utegate scandal, the now Prime Minister himself said that misleading the Parliament "is

Speaker: NA
Text: an offence that should result in the dismissal or resignation of a Minister. It is perfectly clear"; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) therefore, calls on the Prime Minister to:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) sack the Employment Minister for breaching Ministerial Standards by repeatedly misleading the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) explain to the House his involvement, his office's involvement and his Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement in this serious matter where the publicly stated version of events doesn't add up.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Federal Police upholds the law, but this government-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Manager of Opposition Business will resume his seat. The Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House has the call.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the House will resume his seat. The Manager of

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition Business has the call.

Speaker: Mr BURKE
Text: The Australian Federal Police upholds the rule of law, but the government

Speaker: NA
Text: does not. This began with a complete abuse of power-

Speaker: Mr FRYDENBERG
Text: Kooyong-Minister for the Environment and Energy) (14:50): I

Speaker: NA
Text: move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Member be no longer heard.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The question is the Manager of Opposition Business be no further heard.

Text: The House divided. [14:54]

Text: MCVeigh, JJ Morrison, SJ

Speaker: NA
Text: Morton, B O'Brien, LS

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Brien, T O'Dowd, KD

Speaker: NA
Text: O'Dwyer, KM Pasin, A

Speaker: NA
Text: Pitt, KJ Porter, CC

Speaker: NA
Text: Prentice, J Price, ML

Text: Pyne, CM Ramsey, RE (teller)

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert, SR Sharkie, RCC

Speaker: NA
Text: Sudmalis, AE Sukkar, MS

Speaker: NA
Text: Taylor, AJ Tehan, DT

Speaker: NA
Text: Tudge, AE Turnbull, MB

Speaker: NA
Text: Van Manen, AJ Vasta, RX

Text: Wallace, AB Wicks, LE

Text: Wilson, RJ Wilson, TR
