Speaker: NA
Text: Question negatived.

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation

Speaker: Mr COLEMAN
Text: Banks) (15:12): My question is to the Minister for Revenue and

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial Services. Will the minister update the House on action the government is taking to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect the retirement savings of hardworking Australians and improve transparency of the

Speaker: NA
Text: system? How does this compare with alternative approaches?

Speaker: Ms ODWYER
Text: Higgins-Minister for Revenue and Financial Services) (15:13): I thank

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Banks for his question. He knows that the Turnbull government has

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced very comprehensive reforms to Australia's compulsory superannuation system to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect members and to protect members' money. The government is determined to see the

Speaker: NA
Text: very highest standards of accountability, transparency and independent oversight of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's $2.3 trillion superannuation industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's be very clear: successive Australian governments have compelled hardworking

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to set aside around 10 per cent of their wages for superannuation funds. They

Speaker: NA
Text: deserve to know what is happening to their money. They must be confident that the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are put in charge of these funds are acting only in the interests of members.

Speaker: NA
Text: Questions were asked of the former RBA governor and industry fund director Bernie

Speaker: NA
Text: Fraser in a recent Senate committee inquiry about a payment made by AustralianSuper to the

Speaker: NA
Text: AWU in the 2006-07 financial year. It was specifically described by the AWU in its 2007

Speaker: NA
Text: AEC declaration as a 'donation'. The $27,500 payment was made at the same time that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition was the AWU national secretary and also a director of

Speaker: NA
Text: AustralianSuper alongside Bernie Fraser, current Labor Senator Doug Cameron and former

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor MP Greg Combet.

Speaker: NA
Text: Coincidentally, a similar sized donation was subsequently made by, yes, the AWU to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition's political campaign in the seat of Maribyrnong. But it was only

Speaker: NA
Text: when this payment from AustralianSuper to the AWU came under scrutiny in June, following

Speaker: NA
Text: reports by The Australian newspaper, that the AWU resubmitted its original AEC declaration,

Speaker: NA
Text: changing the very nature of the AWU payment from 'donation' to 'other receipt' on 15 June

Speaker: NA
Text: this year, some 10 years later.

Speaker: NA
Text: What role did the Leader of the Opposition have in deciding that a payment should be

Speaker: NA
Text: made to his own union when he was both a director of AustralianSuper and the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary of the AWU? What steps did the Leader of the Opposition take to fully disclose his

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict to the board and how did he and fellow AustralianSuper directors satisfy themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: that this was an appropriate use of members' money?

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that superannuation is not the government's money, not the employers' money,

Speaker: NA
Text: not the executives' money, not the trade unions' money and not the Labor Party's money; it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the members' money.

Speaker: Mr Turnbull
Text: I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: DOCUMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Presentation

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Documents are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable members earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: today. Full details of the documents will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull Government

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (15:16): I have received a letter from the honourable Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: for discussion, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The failure of this Government to respect proper standards and accountability.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those honourable members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their

Speaker: NA
Text: places-

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: Maribyrnong-Leader of the Opposition) (15:17): This matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: importance must start with this observation: Labor's criticism of the government's bungled

Speaker: NA
Text: raids is not about the integrity of the AFP; it's about the lack of integrity in this rotten

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Yesterday morning I said that these raids were the desperate action of a grubby

Speaker: NA
Text: government led by, quite frankly, a grubby Prime Minister-and I repeat that today. This isn't

Speaker: NA
Text: a throwaway line, but everything that has happened in the previous 36 hours, since I first

Speaker: NA
Text: made that statement, and everything that this government has done since yesterday morning

Speaker: NA
Text: confirms the truth that Australia has a grubby government and an increasingly grubby Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. During question time, this point was most clearly illustrated when the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister had a chance to defend Senator Cash. When the opposition moved a resolution

Speaker: NA
Text: condemning her, they did not defend her; they simply gagged the debate. Of course, the

Speaker: NA
Text: events this week-the unprecedented actions of this government-are occurring because this

Speaker: NA
Text: government is a desperate government running out of time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Cash should try and salvage what remains of her reputation by resigning

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately. After all, if she seeks inspiration on the matter she should listen to the words

Speaker: NA
Text: that her leader, the member for Wentworth, said during the 'Utegate' scandal in 2009. He said

Speaker: NA
Text: that misleading the parliament:

Speaker: NA
Text: … is an offence that should result in the dismissal or resignation of a minister. It is perfectly clear.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, like so many other issues under this current Prime Minister, we've seen a pattern of

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour emerge again. What this Prime Minister and this government do is focus all their

Speaker: NA
Text: energy on their opponents and none on the people of Australia. What this government and this

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister do, whenever confronted by a choice to take the high road for national interest

Speaker: NA
Text: and put people first, is always look for the low road of their self-interest and to attack their

Speaker: NA
Text: opponents.

Speaker: NA
Text: We see the classic Turnbullian power play: wild, wild accusations, extreme language, big

Speaker: NA
Text: promises. You can just see him when he was a barrister with the clients the night before the

Speaker: NA
Text: case: 'We've got this in the bag. I'm the best that money can buy, and we've got this in the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: bag.' But the next morning, as we saw yesterday morning, we see that the case has changed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The facts are actually not as good-poor old client. 'Oh, my learned leader, the barrister,

Speaker: NA
Text: says-oh, the facts are changing. I'll be back to you in a moment.' You could just see the

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointed ranks of the government: 'But, dear leader, you said that we would win this.

Speaker: NA
Text: We've got Shorten where we want him. We have Labor where we want them. We have the

Speaker: NA
Text: unions where we want them.' And what happened? Classic overreach. Deep down, every

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the government knows that their Prime Minister lacks judgement.

Speaker: NA
Text: What should the government have been doing this week? They should have been

Speaker: NA
Text: prioritising first home buyers, but instead they defend the negative-gearing tax interests. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are a government who, when they have the chance to pull the trigger on gas exports, instead

Speaker: NA
Text: spend their time defending their beleaguered Deputy Prime Minister. They are a government

Speaker: NA
Text: who, when they talk about workplace relations, always talk about unions and union

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives. They say they like the workers, but they've never seen a worker whose

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty rate they don't want to cut arbitrarily. I've got no doubt that they pop into 7-Eleven

Speaker: NA
Text: when the coffee maker at home is broken, and they get served by workers, but does it ever

Speaker: NA
Text: cross their born-to-rule elitist minds that maybe the workers who are serving them in these

Speaker: NA
Text: fast-food operations are not getting paid properly; they're the victims of wage theft? They love

Speaker: NA
Text: to talk about employment, but they never talk about casualised employment. They never talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about the people who are underemployed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Falinski interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The member for Mackellar is warned.

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: You're better off keeping your mouth shut so we're still left to wonder if

Speaker: NA
Text: you're a fool, mate. Now, the test for the Prime Minister today is simple-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: The Leader of the Opposition will withdraw.

Speaker: Mr Shorten
Text: All right. I withdraw. Misleading the parliament just once is an offence that

Speaker: NA
Text: demands a resignation. But old Senator Cash, not content to mislead the parliament, misled it

Speaker: NA
Text: five times-five times! If she won't resign, the Prime Minister must sack her. He must put the

Speaker: NA
Text: national interest and the integrity of the parliament ahead of his own political interest.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the problem is that this born-to-rule Prime Minister thinks that he is above the rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the problem, the infection which infects the whole of the government. They think,

Speaker: NA
Text: these conservatives, that they're born to rule and that they're always right, no matter what the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts. The problem is: they are born to rule, but they're unfit to govern.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know, we understand, that this isn't the minister's first offence; it was just her worst

Speaker: NA
Text: performance. Credit to Senator Cameron, Senator Watt and Senator Kitching, who pushed

Speaker: NA
Text: through a shameful and deliberate conservative filibuster to uncover the truth. Imagine if we

Speaker: NA
Text: had an employment minister who actually focused on the 700,000 Australians who are

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed and the 1.1 million Australians who are underemployed, someone who cared

Speaker: NA
Text: about the fact that she presides over the lowest wage growth since records were kept or the

Speaker: NA
Text: 700,000-plus workers who are having their penalty rates cut? Imagine if we heard speeches

Speaker: NA
Text: from the government about workplace safety or industrial diseases or labour hire exploitation?

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead, this minister appointed a law-breaker to head up the ABCC and is now asking

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians to pay another $400,000 to pay his legal bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: But it wasn't just Senator Cash who humiliated herself last night. They say that you don't

Speaker: NA
Text: get a second chance to make a first impression. In its first public outing, the Registered

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisations Commission has shown its true colours: nakedly political, grossly incompetent,

Speaker: NA
Text: shamefully partisan and hopelessly compromised. It must be amazing to Australians when

Speaker: NA
Text: they hear that the government can whistle up 13 police to chase up documents 10 years old

Speaker: NA
Text: within a day, based on an unknown caller. Imagine how many Australians are frustrated to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear that.

Speaker: NA
Text: An honourable member interjecting-

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Text: I remind the member that he's been warned.

Speaker: Mr SHORTEN
Text: They might be worried about law and order, their personal safety. No-

Speaker: NA
Text: one other than the government can get 13 police to chase up documents 10 years old, when

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary Australians can't get the attention and the safety they want. This is a government not

Speaker: NA
Text: focused on the priorities of the people. But, of course, we know that this is a government that

Speaker: NA
Text: doesn't care about the conditions of ordinary people. We're not going to let the government

Speaker: NA
Text: off the hook for the abolition of the Road Safety Remuneration Tribunal, putting pressure on

Speaker: NA
Text: drivers to cut corners and take risks. We've already seen a seven per cent increase in the rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of fatal crashes involving articulated trucks. And the consequences of letting ideological

Speaker: NA
Text: obsessions control industrial relations policy are that workplaces are less safe, wages are flat

Speaker: NA
Text: and the rip-offs and the rorts against workers continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst this government spends every week obsessing about its political opponents,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians suffer. In the last financial year, 55 million calls to Centrelink went unanswered-

Speaker: NA
Text: families looking for support, people with disability looking for help, and jobseekers trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: pick themselves up and get back into the employment market. This is a government that can't

Speaker: NA
Text: answer the phone to its citizens but can find their address to send the debt collectors to. And

Speaker: NA
Text: in The Courier-Mail today we see another cabinet leak, saying the Prime Minister's decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: turn his back on constitutional recognition for the First Australians. This is a government that

Speaker: NA
Text: never misses an opportunity not to represent and put the people first.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to say-and I don't mind admitting this, even as Leader of the Opposition-that,

Speaker: NA
Text: when the member for Wentworth rolled the former Prime Minister, I thought my job would

Speaker: NA
Text: get harder but I actually thought politics would get better. I think the Australian people

Speaker: NA
Text: genuinely thought it was a chance to put some faith and hope back into politics. But the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, by all his actions ever since that event two years ago, has systematically destroyed

Speaker: NA
Text: the faith and hope of people who thought he'd be better than what he's turned out to be. And

Speaker: NA
Text: we know that the Prime Minister has a particular style of destruction: when all else fails him,

Speaker: NA
Text: he chases his opponents. Ask Peter King, the former member for Wentworth. Ask Brendan

Speaker: NA
Text: Nelson. Ask Tony Abbott. Ask Kevin Rudd. Well, I just want to advise the government on

Speaker: NA
Text: this fact: Australians have worked this Prime Minister out; they know he doesn't believe in

Speaker: NA
Text: anything except his own survival. That's just not good enough for Australia. Every day

Speaker: NA
Text: between now and the next election, we will put people first: we will stand up for better quality

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs, housing affordability, better energy prices and a fair go all round.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition is not going to be lectured by the Labor Party about standards. I have been in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber for quite a while, and I could give you example after example of the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: standing by some of the worst members the House of Representatives has produced-the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Dobell being a classic case. But I don't even need to go back that far because

Speaker: NA
Text: right now, in the current Labor caucus, are two people who should not be in the positions they

Speaker: NA
Text: are in: Senator Kitching, who the Leader of the Opposition referred to earlier, and Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Dastyari, who is back on the frontbench of the Labor Party. Senator Dastyari was required to

Speaker: NA
Text: stand down because he got donors to pay his personal bills for him. He didn't just fail to

Speaker: NA
Text: declare donations from Chinese donors, from foreign donors, to the Labor Party in some kind

Speaker: NA
Text: of administrative muck-up; he actually asked donors to pay for his own personal expenses!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Champion interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Irons): The member for Wakefield has already been

Speaker: NA
Text: tossed out once today; it can happen again.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter of months. This week the Leader of the Opposition, incapable of standing up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: CFMEU, is even incapable of standing up to Sam Dastyari. So he's put Sam Dastyari back on

Speaker: NA
Text: the frontbench and he's in the decision-making team of the Leader of the Opposition's office.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, there is Senator Kimberley Kitching, the hand-picked candidate of the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition to go into the Senate. She was hand-picked by the Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: against the advice of most of his frontbench from Victoria, including the member for Isaacs,

Speaker: NA
Text: who threatened to resign as shadow Attorney-General over the appointment of Kimberley

Speaker: NA
Text: Kitching but then didn't have the courage of his convictions. Senator Kitching was referred by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Heydon royal commission-the royal commission that the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition says found nothing-to the DPP for criminal charges. In spite of knowing that, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition put her into the Senate, over the complaints and objections of some

Speaker: NA
Text: of his frontbenchers. She was referred to the DPP for possible criminal charges for aiding and

Speaker: NA
Text: abetting the false and misleading statements of six other HSU officials by sitting their right-

Speaker: NA
Text: of-entry test. Apparently, she bragged that she got 100 per cent in some of the tests, saying,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Did another one-got 100 per cent again.' This is the person who the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition thought should sit in the Australian Senate and who he is praising right now in the

Speaker: NA
Text: House for her pursuit of the Minister for Employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it's not just Senator Dastyari or Senator Kitching; the Leader of the Opposition himself

Speaker: NA
Text: has amongst the lowest standards of any Leader of the Opposition who's ever sat in that seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: The issue that we are debating today is the misuse of union members' money. The opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks that the indiscretion of a ministerial staffer is a capital offence but that the misuse of

Speaker: NA
Text: union members' money is something that should be ignored. In fact, people who do it are

Speaker: NA
Text: promoted in the Labor caucus. The issues that we're discussing are the questions the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition needs to answer about the donation of $100,000 to GetUp! in start-up money,

Speaker: NA
Text: when it was first getting started, when he was on the board of GetUp! and also the national

Speaker: NA
Text: secretary of the Australian Workers' Union. So, when he was secretary of AWU, $100,000

Speaker: NA
Text: went to GetUp! from the AWU, and he was on the board of GetUp! when it got started. And,

Speaker: NA
Text: quite legitimately, members of the fourth estate have asking the Leader of the Opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: answer questions about whether the correct processes were followed in the union, and he has

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to answer those questions. He has refused to cooperate, and the AWU has refused to

Speaker: NA
Text: cooperate. That is why the offices of the AWU in Melbourne and Sydney were raided-

Speaker: NA
Text: because the ROC had evidence, enough suspicion to suspect, that those documents could be

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: destroyed. The ROC and the AFP obtained a warrant from a magistrate in Victoria, who

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed that they had good enough cause to have that suspicion that the offices should be

Speaker: NA
Text: raided.

Speaker: NA
Text: The AFP don't go around raiding union offices for the fun of it; they did it because they

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to make sure the law was upheld. In the Labor Party, that is a capital offence as well,

Speaker: NA
Text: and their response to that has been to attack the AFP-to attack the integrity of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police-which is utterly disgraceful. One day, perish the thought, the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: might be back in office again, and the AFP will serve them as well as it has served this side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House and the other side of the House over the last 30 or so years, with complete fairness

Speaker: NA
Text: to both sides. In fact, it was appalling that the AFP commissioner felt the need to defend the

Speaker: NA
Text: AFP by putting out a statement today. Andrew Colvin should not have been placed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: position by the Leader of the Opposition. He was placed in this position by the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition and by the disgraceful statements of the member for Gorton about the AFP and its

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of integrity, accusing of it being a political tool of the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: A government member: What a disgrace!

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The AFP has this week been the subject of commentary and innuendo regarding its independence and

Speaker: NA
Text: the ability of AFP members to carry out their work objectively and without political interference. The

Speaker: NA
Text: AFP … undertakes its activities without fear or favour. The AFP rejects in the strongest terms any

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion to the contrary.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other two matters that have been discussed and that the Leader of the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to provide the facts about are the donation of $27,000 that Australian Super gave to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Workers Union when the Leader of the Opposition was the National Secretary of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Workers Union, was on the board of Australian Super and was the candidate

Speaker: NA
Text: for Maribyrnong. Amazingly-coincidently-not very long later, the AWU made a $26,000

Speaker: NA
Text: donation to the Maribyrnong campaign.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition refuses to answer questions about that. Which part of probity

Speaker: NA
Text: doesn't this Leader of the Opposition understand? Thirdly, in 2007 the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition cut out the middle man: 'I'm sick of wasting time with Australian Super or the

Speaker: NA
Text: GetUp! organisation; I'll get a donation of $25,000 directly from the Australian Workers

Speaker: NA
Text: Union to the Maribyrnong campaign.' That was when he was the candidate for Maribyrnong

Speaker: NA
Text: and the National Secretary of the AWU.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hawke interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: money transferred directly across. And this is the man who lectures us about standards and

Speaker: NA
Text: transparency and accountability? He has absolutely zero credibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: Could I also say in relation to the defence of the AFP: what a disgraceful performance it

Speaker: NA
Text: has been. It is totally contrary, once again, to the Leader of the Opposition's past statements

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Australian Federal Police.

Speaker: Mr Champion
Text: Tell us about the New South Wales Liberal Party! Tell us about their

Speaker: NA
Text: donation history!

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: time to go through Eddie Obeid; Joe Tripodi; Ian Macdonald-is he still in prison? I think Ian

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Macdonald is still in prison, isn't he? I would love to talk about the New South Wales Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, but I've only got so much time. Bill Shorten said in 2015-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Champion interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill Shorten said in 2015:

Speaker: NA
Text: We recognise that the AFP is independent, they'll make their own decisions about what they choose to

Speaker: NA
Text: investigate or not and that's as it should be.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition knows full well that the smokescreen he's trying to create is just

Speaker: NA
Text: that, a smokescreen to cover his embarrassment about his addiction to being connected to the

Speaker: NA
Text: union movement and his inability to stand up to the CFMEU or the AWU, or even Sam

Speaker: NA
Text: Dastyari or even Senator Kitching. If he won't stand up to the union movement, he won't

Speaker: NA
Text: stand up for the nation's interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Irons): I call the member for Sydney and would just

Speaker: NA
Text: remind those behind her that it's her turn to speak and they're interfering with her speech.

Speaker: Ms PLIBERSEK
Text: Sydney-Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (15:37): Listening to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the House is like listening to Catweazle ranting about elec-trickery, the telling

Speaker: NA
Text: bone-the conspiracies. It is like a pantomime character getting excited: 'Look out! He's

Speaker: NA
Text: behind you!' But what was notably absent from that spirited defence was a single mention of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Employment, Michaelia Cash, and why she should remain in her position.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we know for certain is this minister has misled the parliament five times, and she

Speaker: NA
Text: should go. If the Prime Minister had any courage, he would make her go. Don't forget, this is

Speaker: NA
Text: a Prime Minister who has already lost five government ministers: the former member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mayo, the member for Fadden, the former member for Fisher, the member for Farrer and

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Canavan. Today we're likely to get No. 6. Tomorrow we might get Nos 7 and 8. This

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister is going to break John Howard's record for losing ministers-what an

Speaker: NA
Text: incredible achievement!

Speaker: NA
Text: Only a Prime Minister who is weak, who doesn't have the confidence of his party, would

Speaker: NA
Text: be too gutless to take the action that is obviously necessary to anybody watching. We can

Speaker: NA
Text: only conclude that he's too weak to act because he doesn't have the support of his colleagues

Speaker: NA
Text: or that he was in it up to his neck. I've got to say, it really does not bear examination, does it?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister summons the minister down to his office and says: 'There are all these

Speaker: NA
Text: very concerning reports this morning that you or your office have tipped off the media to a

Speaker: NA
Text: raid that happened yesterday. What have you got to say to that?' We are expected to believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that Guthrie Featherstone QC, MP asked just one question: 'Did you do it?', that the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: just answered: 'No. It wasn't me,' and that Guthrie Featherstone QC, MP didn't ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious next question. This Prime Minister's so great at cross-examining that he wrote a book

Speaker: NA
Text: about it-The Spy Catcher Trial-talking about what a fantastic lawyer he is, but he didn't

Speaker: NA
Text: say, 'Actually, Minister, the reports aren't about you tipping off the media; the reports are your

Speaker: NA
Text: staff tipping off the media.' It absolutely beggars belief.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a classic tactic of those opposite to try and say that we have asserted this or asserted

Speaker: NA
Text: that. I have to be very clear about what the problem is here. It's often not the crime but the

Speaker: NA
Text: cover-up that gets you, and this is the case with this minister too. If she had been frank about

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that her staff had done the wrong thing instead of misleading the parliament five

Speaker: NA
Text: times, instead of trying to drag out proceedings last night so she could get past the media cut-

Speaker: NA
Text: off times and past the dinner break, I think people might have a bit of sympathy for her. But

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that she has persisted in misleading and persists with the same today makes our

Speaker: NA
Text: sympathy evaporate.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to be clear about this other element: the Leader of the House tried to imply that we

Speaker: NA
Text: are somehow criticising the Australian Federal Police. That is the very last thing that we are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing. We heard evidence just this week from the Federal Police that government cuts will:

Speaker: NA
Text: … mostly apply to our discretionary funding. That is areas that fund a large portion of our anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: narcotics, our organised crime work, our general operation work, our fraud and anti-corruption.

Speaker: NA
Text: In those circumstances, every Australian will be asking themselves why the Federal Police,

Speaker: NA
Text: who are so good at their work, so good at protecting Australians, instead of being out busting

Speaker: NA
Text: organised crime gangs, drug traffickers and gun traffickers are doing work that Star Track

Speaker: NA
Text: Express could have done: going down the road and picking up some documents because the

Speaker: NA
Text: ROC sent them to do so. This is an outrageous use of tightly stretched resources when we are

Speaker: NA
Text: hearing how tightly stretched those resources are.

Speaker: NA
Text: What we know is that this government will always use taxpayers' resources to pursue

Speaker: NA
Text: political opponents. They will say anything. They will do anything, because this Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister- (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr FALINSKI
Text: Mackellar) (15:42): It is sad. Their concocted outrage can't even limp to

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of five minutes. To have the Deputy Leader of the Opposition stand here in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament and compare the AFP work to that of a Star Track Express courier is a disgrace.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's an absolute disgrace, and she should stand up here now and apologise to the hardworking

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Australian Federal Police. The truth of the matter is this: those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: would not have put this motion if Michaelia Cash was not a woman, if she was not an

Speaker: NA
Text: effective minister and if she was not calling their mates to account. The fact of the matter is

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can throw up as much dust as they like, they can make as much noise as they want

Speaker: NA
Text: over there but they can't obscure the fact that they are running away from the facts. They can't

Speaker: NA
Text: cover up the secret payments any longer. They can't cover up the secret deals, the self-interest

Speaker: NA
Text: and the corruption that is rampant in the Labor Party, rampant in the union movement and

Speaker: NA
Text: rampant in their associated entities. They can't win this argument. They can't convince anyone

Speaker: NA
Text: of their views, so they're left to do one thing and one thing only: try to confuse people. They

Speaker: NA
Text: try to claim the AFP's work is that of a Star Track Express courier, because what else would

Speaker: NA
Text: you expect of the party of Eddie Obeid, Ian Macdonald, Joe Tripodi, Bob Carr and Luke

Speaker: NA
Text: Foley?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Champion interjecting-

Speaker: Mr FALINSKI
Text: The member for Wakefield wants to be heard. It's a shame he doesn't try

Speaker: NA
Text: as hard to be understood!

Speaker: NA
Text: They're led by a man who complained when he was a minister in the previous government

Speaker: NA
Text: that his $300,000 salary wasn't enough, that he was underpaid. He is a person who is opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to increased funding for schools, opposed to lowering taxes for small businesses, opposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: completing the funding for the NDIS that those opposite left dangerously unfunded, opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to more jobs and higher wages, and opposed most of all to the legislation that would end

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: corrupting benefit payments to unions. He, now, and the Labor Party now, say that a minister

Speaker: NA
Text: should resign because a staff member leaked a story about police raids on a union. Okay, fair

Speaker: NA
Text: enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: So where were those opposite when Tony Hodges, a former member of Julia Gillard's

Speaker: NA
Text: media team, spread information in order to incite a riot against the then Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, the member for Warringah? The same media unit then put out stories how Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Gillard's security team had to protect the poor frail member for Warringah. What a

Speaker: NA
Text: story. In full technicolour for everyone to see, the Prime Minister lost her shoe, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition was escorted by AFP officers. But don't worry; I am sure if there

Speaker: NA
Text: had been some StarTrack couriers standing nearby they could have stepped in and done the

Speaker: NA
Text: job, according to the deputy leader. That's why Prime Minister Gillard resigned, of course. If

Speaker: NA
Text: you leak a story to a newspaper about a union getting raided, that's the same as inciting a riot

Speaker: NA
Text: against the Leader of the Opposition, right? Of course it is. They're the standards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Champion interjecting-

Speaker: Mr FALINSKI
Text: The member for Wakefield, back again; thanks for helping us out. The

Speaker: NA
Text: fact of the matter is there is nothing they won't say and do to obscure the facts here. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition stands up and talks about the poor quality of the coffee he gets in

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne and how poorly paid the person making the coffee is but, let's not forget, it was his

Speaker: NA
Text: Fair Work Commission, appointed by him, who he referred this decision to, that came to this

Speaker: NA
Text: decision. So there we have it. We have a party over there that can't remember anything and

Speaker: NA
Text: forgets everything, including the fact that they get payments from people like the CFMEU,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the fact they used to have a minister in New South Wales by the name of Eddie

Speaker: NA
Text: Obeid and the fact that they gave $100,000 to GetUP! (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR (Gorton) (15:47): This is a very important debate we are

Speaker: NA
Text: having today because it goes to whether in fact the government has colluded with the media in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to expose raids by the Australian Federal Police. I want to make it very clear: the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition support the Australian Federal Police. They are an independent statutory body and

Speaker: NA
Text: they had to do what they did because a warrant was issued. But let's be very clear about what

Speaker: NA
Text: we're talking about. This is the relationship between the government and the regulatory body

Speaker: NA
Text: it established for these purposes. At the time, when the government foreshadowed its interest

Speaker: NA
Text: to create the Registered Organisation Commission, Labor said we had concerns with this

Speaker: NA
Text: particular body because we said it would be used for political purposes. We said, instead, we

Speaker: NA
Text: would be very happy to see these responsibilities within the remit of ASIC and we argued that

Speaker: NA
Text: that should be the body that deals with serious alleged breaches by officers of registered

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations. We argued that would be the better place. We even explained to the crossbench

Speaker: NA
Text: before the legislation was enacted that the government would use this commission as its

Speaker: NA
Text: political tool to attack its political opponents, because that's the pattern of behaviour of this

Speaker: NA
Text: government since it was elected in 2013.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's outline the pattern we have here. We have a government that established a trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: royal commission in order to attack its political opponents. We have a government that's had

Speaker: NA
Text: two royal commissions and summonsed three Labor leaders, two of whom were prime

Speaker: NA
Text: ministers of this country. It is unprecedented that a government would actually set up these

Speaker: NA
Text: executive inquiries and call former Prime Ministers in that way, and yet, of course, that is

Speaker: NA
Text: what this government did. What they did with respect to the trade union royal commission

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: was call the Leader of the Opposition. He sat in the dock for two days; he actually answered

Speaker: NA
Text: 900 questions. There were no findings against the Leader of the Opposition, despite the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the commission itself was discredited. It was discredited because we found out that the

Speaker: NA
Text: commissioner of the trade union royal commission was someone who had accepted an

Speaker: NA
Text: invitation to raise money for the Liberal Party at the same time as he was commissioner of the

Speaker: NA
Text: royal commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: So the reality is this: this is a pattern of behaviour by this government to use state power to

Speaker: NA
Text: attack its political opponents. It did so with the establishment of that trade union royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commission and it's done so now by creating a standing commission, because that's what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Registered Organisations Commission is. It's a standing commission to investigate,

Speaker: NA
Text: ostensibly, registered organisations. But, of all its investigations and inquiries, which one hit

Speaker: NA
Text: the media? Of all the inquiries and investigations of this new body, which investigation was

Speaker: NA
Text: referred by the minister to the commission? Only one, and that is, of course, the one that

Speaker: NA
Text: relates to the allegations made against the AWU in an attempt to smear the federal leader and

Speaker: NA
Text: federal Labor. That is the only matter that's been referred by the minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's get the chronology right. The Prime Minister and the minister created the Registered

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisations Commission, the minister appointed the regulator of the commission, the

Speaker: NA
Text: minister referred the investigation of this matter to the commission, the minister's office

Speaker: NA
Text: leaked information about the raids of the investigation to the media, and then the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested she had done nothing wrong and the minister suggested that her office had done

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing wrong, and she said so five times in the Senate. She misled the parliament on five

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions. It beggars belief that she did not know what her office was up to in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter, given the extent to which she was involved from the establishment of the agency to

Speaker: NA
Text: the referral of the investigation and, of course, to the collusion with the media in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that they elevated this matter by publicly broadcasting the raids.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no way that a reasonable person would conclude that the minister has been

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in anything other than gross abuse of ministerial power, and that's why she has to

Speaker: NA
Text: resign. That's why she has to resign: she has misused her office and, indeed, she has breached

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial responsibility. If she does not resign and the Prime Minister wants to adhere to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Westminster system and ministerial responsibility, he must sack the minister. If he doesn't

Speaker: NA
Text: sack the minister, this government clearly shows it wants to continue this corrupt behaviour.

Speaker: Ms PRICE
Text: Durack) (15:52): I rise on yet another absurd motion by those opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: Haven't we heard some fire and brimstone in this place over the last 24 hours! We've heard

Speaker: NA
Text: some frankly unbelievable claims by those opposite, trotting in here one after the other and

Speaker: NA
Text: sticking up for their union mates, as they do. It's laughable that today's MPI is about proper

Speaker: NA
Text: standards and accountability when those opposite, who claim to represent the workers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, have failed to support our legislation to protect those workers, to protect union

Speaker: NA
Text: funds and to ensure that workplaces are safe. Let's look at our record. The government have

Speaker: NA
Text: done an exemplary job at exposing the criminal and often despicable behaviour of the union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement in this country. We were responsible for the introduction for the ABCC, removing

Speaker: NA
Text: the rotten apples from the building sites and ensuring that the construction sector once again

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes a functioning, workable industry. But did those opposite support that piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation? No, they didn't.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Husar interjecting-

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Irons): I remind the member for Lindsay that she's

Speaker: NA
Text: already had one warning today.

Speaker: Ms PRICE
Text: What about corrupt payments? Did they support the corrupting benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation? No, they did not. Did they support the government in stamping out under-the-

Speaker: NA
Text: table corrupt payments, criminal payments, from employers and unions? No, they did not. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have also established the Registered Organisations Commission, which was responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: the recent raid on the AWU that we are discussing here today, but did Labor support that

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation? No, they did not. And why is that? We all know why, because those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: dance to the tune of the union movement every day, day after day. As sure as night follows

Speaker: NA
Text: day, we know the rules.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's worth reflecting on why the AFP raided the AWU. The Registered Organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission opened their investigation into the Leader of the Opposition's union last Friday,

Speaker: NA
Text: but such is their experience and others' experience with the union movement, with their

Speaker: NA
Text: arrogance towards the rule of law, that the Registered Organisations Commission believed

Speaker: NA
Text: that, if they had requested the information, the information would have been destroyed. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: that just sink in. It's all quiet now; how wonderful!

Speaker: NA
Text: How outrageous that those members opposite come in here, day after day, defending those

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations that display such a criminal lack of respect for our laws and our country's

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions that they would potentially destroy damning evidence against the man who wants

Speaker: NA
Text: to be the next Prime Minister! That is why the commission advised the AFP to raid the offices

Speaker: NA
Text: to collect those documents. The raid was conducted because the Registered Organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission thought there was sufficient evidence of union wrongdoing in regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition leader's donation of $100,000 to GetUp! 10 years ago. That is why the AWU was

Speaker: NA
Text: raided.

Speaker: NA
Text: But this is not the first instance of unions playing fast and loose with the rule of law, is it?

Speaker: NA
Text: We've seen this year CFMEU bosses in Victoria telling rallies of workers that they would find

Speaker: NA
Text: out where the ABCC inspectors lived and would target their children. Or how about the

Speaker: NA
Text: CFMEU walking off the job at the Lady Cilento Children's Hospital in Brisbane? That caused

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of dollars in excessive government expenditure-

Speaker: NA
Text: An opposition member interjecting-

Speaker: Ms PRICE
Text: What? That didn't happen? I'll take that interjection. And it delayed the

Speaker: NA
Text: project. How about the illegal Commonwealth Games industrial action where CFMEU

Speaker: NA
Text: officials threatened a safety inspector?

Speaker: NA
Text: But don't take my word for it. We've got at least three former Labor prime ministers who

Speaker: NA
Text: have come out to talk about the despicable behaviour of the CFMEU. Kevin Rudd, only two

Speaker: NA
Text: days ago, told the Labor Party it should sever its ties with the CFMEU. Former Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Bob Hawke said last year that the ALP should sever its ties with the CFMEU, and

Speaker: NA
Text: also former Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating said that the party should reduce the power

Speaker: NA
Text: that the union has over it. I would suggest the current Leader of the Opposition take some

Speaker: NA
Text: advice from his predecessors. So as we, on this side of the House, have all said today, this

Speaker: NA
Text: MPI is truly ridiculous, and those in the Labor Party should hang their heads in shame for the

Speaker: NA
Text: comments they've made in this place today.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Everything we on this side of the House do is about protecting Australian workers. It's

Speaker: NA
Text: about protecting the workplace. It's about protecting their funds. Those opposite do everything

Speaker: NA
Text: in their power to protect the union movement, their union mates, while selling out the union

Speaker: NA
Text: members, as we've seen with the example of the workers at Cleanevent, and we know that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do this to protect their union mates, and we know that it's done to protect the rivers of

Speaker: NA
Text: gold that are given to them to help with their election campaigns. It is shameful that we even

Speaker: NA
Text: have to debate this today, and it is shameful that those opposite do not protect the workers that

Speaker: NA
Text: they claim, day in and day out, that they represent. Shame on you.

Speaker: Ms ROWLAND
Text: Greenway) (15:57): When it comes to the failures of this government to

Speaker: NA
Text: respect proper standards and accountability, the Prime Minister's track record on the NBN is

Speaker: NA
Text: an absolute pearler. In 2013, this Prime Minister stood up with the then Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: looked the Australian people in the eye and said that they would deliver a National Broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: Network for $29 billion and have it finished by 2016. He declared that it would be open and it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be transparent. But then the first test came: the December 2013 strategic review. In this

Speaker: NA
Text: report it was revealed that the Prime Minister's multitechnology mix for the NBN had blown

Speaker: NA
Text: out from $29 billion to $41 billion. Did he offer any explanation as to how the high cost of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NBN had become even $12 billion more expensive overnight, or any explanation as to why it

Speaker: NA
Text: would now not be delivered until 2020? He offered no explanation whatsoever. Worse still, if

Speaker: NA
Text: you want to talk about proper standards and accountability, every key assumption in the 2013

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic review remains redacted and blacked out. So much for the transparency promised by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Prime Minister. Even to this day, this government refuses to release that information.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then we saw information emerge about further cost blowouts and delays and failures in the

Speaker: NA
Text: rollout with this Prime Minister's multitechnology mix-the rollout that was supposed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: 'faster, sooner and more affordable'. Here are some of the things that we learned. We started

Speaker: NA
Text: to learn about secret trials where the NBN had reduced the cost and time to deploy fibre. We

Speaker: NA
Text: began to hear about the cost of fibre to the node-about how this Prime Minister's copper

Speaker: NA
Text: NBN's cost was blowing out even further. We heard about how the cost of copper remediation

Speaker: NA
Text: had blown out by more than 1,000 per cent. We learned that the HFC network, which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister touted as a game-changer, was actually not fit for purpose.

Speaker: NA
Text: Did we see any transparency and accountability as a result of that? No. I'll tell you what we

Speaker: NA
Text: saw, Mr Deputy Speaker. We saw a raid. We saw an unprecedented AFP raid in the middle of

Speaker: NA
Text: an election campaign in Australia in 2016. We had the NBN chairman then publish a most

Speaker: NA
Text: politically charged opinion piece about that raid, defending the NBN's actions. Bear in mind

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is the hand-picked chairman of the NBN, hand-picked by this Prime Minister. This

Speaker: NA
Text: was despite advice from the nation's top public servant saying that doing so would breach

Speaker: NA
Text: caretaker conventions. Just to quote from an article at the time:

Speaker: NA
Text: NBN chairman Ziggy Switkowski wilfully breached caretaker conventions during an election campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: and did so against the express advice of the nation's top public servant.

Speaker: NA
Text: We see the full extent of these failures again revealed in the August 2015 corporate plan,

Speaker: NA
Text: where the NBN again blew out in costs from $41 billion to up to $56 billion. But did we get

Speaker: NA
Text: more transparency? We had scrapped external oversight of the NBN corporate plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we have a project personally undertaken by this Prime Minister, who is so invested in

Speaker: NA
Text: it-the one in which he declared we would have full transparency and openness. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: seen nothing of that. This born-to-rule Prime Minister, who fancies himself as a genius, has

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: been exposed on every front when it comes to the NBN. He has lurched from failure to

Speaker: NA
Text: failure. He was a failure as communications minister. He is a failure as Prime Minister. He

Speaker: NA
Text: stuffed up the National Broadband Network. Just look at the evidence. We dropped from 30th

Speaker: NA
Text: in the world for internet speeds to 50th. There has been a 160 per cent increase in complaints

Speaker: NA
Text: about the NBN from consumers. We are now placed last out of 28 countries in the world for

Speaker: NA
Text: broadband satisfaction. Last! Last in the world. This great Liberal hope, this champion of

Speaker: NA
Text: copper-he coveted the prime ministership his entire life-exposed as nothing more than

Speaker: NA
Text: shallow and glass jawed. In the immortal words of Paul Keating: you light him up, there's a

Speaker: NA
Text: bit of fizz, but then nothing. Nothing. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (16:02): I'm pleased to speak on this matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: importance because the people of my electorate on the Central Coast absolutely demand and

Speaker: NA
Text: expect proper standards and accountability from the government. Since the coalition came to

Speaker: NA
Text: government in 2013, including by winning the seat of Robertson, that's exactly what they've

Speaker: NA
Text: got from this government. We have been delivering on every single one of our commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: to my electorate and we can be held accountable to it by the people of Robertson while also

Speaker: NA
Text: being completely up-front about how we are transforming our critical region, which for six

Speaker: NA
Text: long years prior to September 2013 had been woefully neglected by the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's compare and contrast. We're delivering 600 new jobs into Gosford with the ATO, a

Speaker: NA
Text: $45 million investment towards a world-class Central Coast medical school and medical

Speaker: NA
Text: research institute, the new state-of-the-art Woy Woy oval on the Peninsula, and many more

Speaker: NA
Text: projects that I don't have time to mention. The Central Coast, and the seat of Robertson in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular, is now seeing a real uplift thanks to this government. But we need to be fully aware

Speaker: NA
Text: of the flaws and the risks of the approach to accountability and proper standards taken by the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Labor Party. Under Labor, we need to ask ourselves: what did our region, the

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful Central Coast, actually become known for? Do I even need to mention the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor member for Dobell, Craig Thomson? Do I need to mention the chaos of the Rudd-

Speaker: NA
Text: Gillard-Rudd Labor years, which in Robertson was also reflected in the short-lived stints of

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor representative Belinda Neal-do you know who she is?-and Deborah O'Neill? Do I

Speaker: NA
Text: need to mention the failure to deliver or plan for more local jobs and better infrastructure? Do

Speaker: NA
Text: I need to remind members opposite, including the shadow minister, who ought to remember

Speaker: NA
Text: this, about the big red button that was pushed with great fanfare on Gosford waterfront by the

Speaker: NA
Text: then member for Gosford-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Husar interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Irons): I just remind the member for Lindsay that she's

Speaker: NA
Text: been warned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Husar interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: You've been warned already during question time, and I'm

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to get you to leave the chamber if you keep interjecting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mrs WICKS: Let me just repeat this point, as it's clearly worth remembering: do I need to

Speaker: NA
Text: remind members opposite about the big red button that was pushed with great fanfare by

Speaker: NA
Text: Stephen Conroy and Deborah O'Neill on the Gosford waterfront? They said that fibre to the

Speaker: NA
Text: premise, rolled gold, high-speed broadband was coming to Gosford, only for the poor

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: residents and businesses of Gosford to find out that 90 per cent of homes and businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: couldn't actually connect.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Leader of the Opposition, just like during his time as a union boss, will say and do

Speaker: NA
Text: anything for the sake of politics while, at the same time, ignoring or brazenly voting against

Speaker: NA
Text: anything that actually delivers the critical reform our nation needs. Labor's approach is to

Speaker: NA
Text: respect its union bosses, ignore the decisions of an independent umpire and have no credible

Speaker: NA
Text: plans for jobs or small businesses. For example, for many years local small businesses have

Speaker: NA
Text: been competing on an uneven playing field against big businesses like Woolworths,

Speaker: NA
Text: MCDonald's and KFC, as big businesses have negotiated enterprise agreements with big

Speaker: NA
Text: unions to lower Sunday penalty rates. The Leader of the Opposition has been totally

Speaker: NA
Text: hypocritical on this issue. As a union boss, he cut penalty rates to low-paid workers. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition is happy for big businesses and big union leaders to do deals cutting

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty rates, but it appears Labor quickly whistles to a different tune on penalty rates when

Speaker: NA
Text: an independent umpire does it for small business.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition says he's against foreign workers, but his record of granting

Speaker: NA
Text: 457 visas shows that he brought foreign workers in at the expense of Australians looking for

Speaker: NA
Text: work. He said he was in favour of a cut in the company tax rate, but now Labor is opposing

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition's company tax cut. Labor wants to attack Central Coast's small businesses and

Speaker: NA
Text: their employees by repealing the coalition's enterprise tax cut plans, and yet you can see how

Speaker: NA
Text: the coalition's plan is working. Just look at the fantastic response of local businesses in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate to the instant asset write-off. Close to 300,000 Australian small businesses have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken advantage of this, including more than 2,200 in my electorate.

Speaker: NA
Text: We've got a strong record of delivering on reform, including strong changes in industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations, such as protecting firefighters from union takeovers and legislation to restore the

Speaker: NA
Text: rule of law and stop union thuggery in the building and construction sector. We've secured the

Speaker: NA
Text: passage of the corrupting benefits legislation that will bring an end to the dodgy deals done

Speaker: NA
Text: between employers and unions that do nothing to benefit workers, and much, much more.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, sadly, because the Leader of the Opposition always puts politics and his own interests

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead of the national interest, he cannot be trusted to deliver for our nation or for the Central

Speaker: NA
Text: Coast. Labor, it would seem, is short on standards and short on accountability.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms O'NEIL (Hotham) (16:07): It has been another shocking week for the government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The NBN is a flaming catastrophe; the budget is in bigger debt than it has ever been. This

Speaker: NA
Text: week the government has been busted massively underfunding the Australian Federal Police.

Speaker: NA
Text: And we've got a minister in the other place who has been shown up for misleading parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday five times, and probably by the end of the week we'll see a few more ministers out

Speaker: NA
Text: the door.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a basic sign of maturity to take responsibility when things go wrong, but that is not

Speaker: NA
Text: what we see from the Prime Minister. In fact, the finger is pointing at anyone he can find. It's

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor's fault. It's the unions' fault. But the biggest bait and switch that has been put this week

Speaker: NA
Text: in parliament, and which I want to speak to today, is the inference that by attacking the

Speaker: NA
Text: government, which as an opposition we are entitled and supposed to justly do, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: somehow attacking the integrity of the Australian Federal Police. That is wrong. I speak on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of all my Labor colleagues when I say how incredibly proud we are of the brave men

Speaker: NA
Text: and women who work in this incredible organisation. We represent a lot of people who put on

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: uniforms and do incredible things with their daily work, but it is quite rare to come across a

Speaker: NA
Text: group of people who put themselves in danger, who put themselves in the line of fire, every

Speaker: NA
Text: time they get out of bed and put on a uniform, and go to do work protecting us every single

Speaker: NA
Text: day.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the most difficult areas of law that I have responsibility for in my party is the work

Speaker: NA
Text: we do with child exploitation, and that's been discussed this week. The Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police are at the front line of that, and just about every other major security threat that we talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about in this parliament. Whether it's terrorism, whether it's the work that we do trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: fight drugs, trying to fight gun importation-all of these things-the Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police is absolutely at the epicentre of.

Speaker: NA
Text: We've heard a lot of frustrated commentary from those on the other side, who are getting

Speaker: NA
Text: up and talking about how much they are enamoured with the work of the Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police. I say to those on the other side of the House that, if you were so committed to

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting the brave men and women who protect us on the beat every day, you would

Speaker: NA
Text: probably be making sure that you pay those officers properly. We know that the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police have not had a pay rise for more than two years. That means, in real terms, the

Speaker: NA
Text: people whose work you stand up and laud when you're talking about the incredible work that

Speaker: NA
Text: they do are actually going backwards, and that is because of your government and because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the cuts that you have made to that organisation. Earlier this year, the Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police were offered a pay deal which would see them getting a very minimal pay rise; some

Speaker: NA
Text: officers, though, were going to go right backwards in pay, including a set of officers who

Speaker: NA
Text: were going to receive a $35,000-a-year pay cut. The organisation has refused that industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement, but I want to read to you from a letter to the Prime Minister written by the head of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Federal Police Association, Angela Smith. She writes:

Speaker: NA
Text: As Prime Minister, you take every opportunity to praise the operational successes of AFP employees,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet this adulation rings hollow if those same employees are rewarded by cuts to their pay and

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has not taken that view. We have fought for those police officers in their pay agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: and we hope that that will get a good outcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: We saw the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police in estimates this week. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: to say that I feel a lot of sympathy for Commissioner Colvin as he tries to navigate a difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: situation, because the truth is that the government has cut $184 million from this organisation

Speaker: NA
Text: over the coming four years. He revealed in estimates this week that the organisation has lost

Speaker: NA
Text: 117 staff over the last year alone. How can the Prime Minister stand up in question time and

Speaker: NA
Text: say that he is so much in favour of this organisation? He speaks with one voice in this

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament and then he and the Minister for Justice go down to the cabinet room and do

Speaker: NA
Text: something absolutely contrary to those comments, and that is gut this organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: This week, the ABC came forward with a memo written by a senior Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police officer which showed that, over the last period of time, 23 critical raids have not been

Speaker: NA
Text: properly investigated because the Australian Federal Police does not have the resources to do

Speaker: NA
Text: it. The ABC reported that there was a 1.6-tonne cocaine importation that could not be fully

Speaker: NA
Text: investigated by the Australian Federal Police due to lack of resources.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: We are so supportive of this organisation-and we're genuinely supportive of the

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation. I only wish that the government's commentary about the Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police was backed up by real support for those officers and funding for that organisation.

Speaker: Mr LITTLEPROUD
Text: Maranoa) (16:12): The theatrics of those opposite that we've seen

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last 24 hours are nothing more than a desperate attempt to take attention away from

Speaker: NA
Text: the very core of the issue that we are talking about-the very core of what has happened in

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 24 hours and why those raids were undertaken. The values and principles of the union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement have been shown up because a statutory authority saw fit to raid a union because

Speaker: NA
Text: they failed to provide the information that was required of them. Let's talk about the values

Speaker: NA
Text: and principles of the organisation and their link to the Labor Party. How can you say, in any

Speaker: NA
Text: fairness, that a fair organisation would do that? If they have nothing to hide, then why would

Speaker: NA
Text: they undertake those actions in such a public way? The reality is that this MPI is nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: more than just cheap theatrics to hide the Leader of the Opposition from the questions that he

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to answer about the actions that he took when he was part of the union movement-and

Speaker: NA
Text: the union movement and Labor are so intrinsically tied.

Speaker: NA
Text: The standards and values of the CFMEU are seen in my home state of Queensland. We're

Speaker: NA
Text: seeing now the actions of the CFMEU at Oakey Creek up in Queensland, where they are

Speaker: NA
Text: saying the most abhorrent things about men's and women's children. You come in here with

Speaker: NA
Text: the sanctimony and the way in which you criticise this side for the way that we handle

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves, yet you sit there and take money from the CFMEU and you defend the actions of

Speaker: NA
Text: these deplorable human beings who would dare to utter those words. Would you not hold

Speaker: NA
Text: them to account? If you had the morals and the values to stand up to that behaviour, then you

Speaker: NA
Text: should do that today. But you don't. You turn your back-you turn your back on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people and you turn your back on the workers at Oakey Creek.

Speaker: NA
Text: What a disgrace that you would tie yourself to an organisation that would say deplorable

Speaker: NA
Text: things about children. I'm a father of three young boys and I can tell you I would be

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely disgusted if someone made those accusations, those assertions, about my children.

Speaker: NA
Text: If you are parents and you look deeply inside your heart instead of putting your heads down in

Speaker: NA
Text: shame, which you should, then you should stand up here today and say that those are not the

Speaker: NA
Text: actions of proper human beings that anybody should be associated with. That is an absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: disgrace to be associated with that sort of action. You should stand up and do that today, as

Speaker: NA
Text: should the Leader of the Opposition, not have a distraction. The Labor Party members are

Speaker: NA
Text: running around trying to distract everybody about the real core of the issues here, about the

Speaker: NA
Text: values and principles of the union movement in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: But let's think about what could happen if the Labor Party were to be put into parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let's think about what impacts that would have on our nation, the absolute deplorable state

Speaker: NA
Text: that we will see in our economy and the values and principles that they will bring.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms Madeleine King interjecting-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order. The member for Brand has had a fair say.

Speaker: Mr LITTLEPROUD
Text: She has, Mr Deputy Speaker. These are the sorts of values and

Speaker: NA
Text: principles that they want to defend and they cannot defend those actions. The reality is, if we

Speaker: NA
Text: were lumbered with a Labor government after the next election, we would see these values

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and principles trickle down through our nation and that is not something that we can allow to

Speaker: NA
Text: happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, because of the work that we in the government have done, we are pulling the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic levers to get growth within this nation. Over 800,000 jobs have been created on our

Speaker: NA
Text: watch. We are pulling the economic levers that are creating jobs. But because those opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: are so intrinsically tied to the union movement, because they are so part of the union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement, because they are part of the values and principles of the labour movement, they

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot understand how an economy works and they will bring those values and principles of

Speaker: NA
Text: big government. Those opposite don't understand that if you empower your nation, if you give

Speaker: NA
Text: people the environment and the infrastructure to create wealth and to create the jobs, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: do it for our nation because they are good people who understand what a hard day's work will

Speaker: NA
Text: do for them and for this nation. They are the principles and values this side uphold, every day

Speaker: NA
Text: of the week. Those low union movements that come out and attack children in this day and

Speaker: NA
Text: age are deplorable.

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm proud to say that we on this side will hold firm on this. We will make sure that we

Speaker: NA
Text: won't be distracted from where we need to go in isolating the union movement and the actions

Speaker: NA
Text: that they've undertaken over the last years. This is something I'm proud to say that we will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue, despite the theatrics that we see from those opposite.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The discussion is now concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: BUSINESS

Speaker: NA
Text: Days and Hours of Meeting

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: That the program of sittings for 2018 be agreed to.
