Speaker: NA
Text: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Veterans and Their Families

Speaker: Mr TEHAN
Text: Wannon-Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister Assisting the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Centenary of ANZAC, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Cyber

Speaker: NA
Text: Security and Minister for Defence Personnel) (16:22): I seek leave today to present a

Speaker: NA
Text: response by representatives of the defence and veterans community to the first ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: statement on veterans and their families.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr TEHAN
Text: I present the response. In the first ministerial statement on veterans and their

Speaker: NA
Text: families, I set out a challenge to the veteran and ex-service organisations to provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: response with a single voice. While this is not a response from all sections or all ex-service

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, I commend those who have contributed to this response and their engagement

Speaker: NA
Text: with the government on my statement. The government thanks the Defence Force Welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: Association and the Alliance of Defence Service Organisations, including the RSL, for

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: providing me with this response. It is a very good first step in engaging and representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: views of the wider veterans community. The same will be done next year, and I look forward

Speaker: NA
Text: to tabling a response and also outlining the government's position on this response that the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: service organisations have provided the government.

Speaker: Ms RISHWORTH
Text: Kingston) (16:24): On indulgence-I haven't had the chance to read

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence community's response to the ministerial challenge; I've only just received it. But I

Speaker: NA
Text: would say in very, very brief comments that I certainly value my engagement with the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: service community and I think the best outcomes are served if everyone is pulling in the same

Speaker: NA
Text: direction and coordinating their response. Government and opposition can only get the policy

Speaker: NA
Text: and the policy settings right with a vibrant ex-service community that does give free and frank

Speaker: NA
Text: advice. So I certainly look forward to considering the defence community's response to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial challenge and my ongoing engagement with them.

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services Legislation Amendment (Cashless Debit Card) Bill 2017

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Ms HUSAR
Text: Lindsay) (16:25): Labor supports the genuine, intuitive policies that

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge the problems and opportunities that are unique to remote and discrete

Speaker: NA
Text: communities. Because of the tireless efforts of Jenny Macklin and Linda Burney, we

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that a cashless debit system may be part of a solution. While I mention Linda

Speaker: NA
Text: Burney's name, I would just like to pass on my sincere condolences to my colleague Linda

Speaker: NA
Text: and thank her for all of her work and efforts in making sure that this system is got right. It's a

Speaker: NA
Text: shame that she isn't here today, but I am very privileged to stand up and honour the work that

Speaker: NA
Text: she's been doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also understand that most people are quite capable of managing their own incomes. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is vital that we understand that it can be only a part of and not a holistic answer to complex

Speaker: NA
Text: historical problems. These problems vary from community to community, country to country

Speaker: NA
Text: and state to state. There is no one-size-fits-all answer. We need to develop the levers that

Speaker: NA
Text: provide access to support when and where it is suitable: programs that address alcohol and

Speaker: NA
Text: drug-related problems, not empty promises and half-baked attempts that may be more likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to hinder and not help. We need to listen to communities to find out what assistance they

Speaker: NA
Text: require and to tailor programs to suit specific localities. We also need to empower people to

Speaker: NA
Text: help themselves. One size does not fit all.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is one of the reasons that Labor does not support a nationwide rollout of the cashless

Speaker: NA
Text: debit card. I also note that Labor only supported the rollout of the cashless debit card in 2015

Speaker: NA
Text: after extensive consultation and the promise of additional programs designed to work in

Speaker: NA
Text: partnership with the trials. This position was decided after-and only after-consultation with

Speaker: NA
Text: community leaders. The development of a memorandum of understanding with the Ceduna

Speaker: NA
Text: community was also critical to this process.

Speaker: NA
Text: At this point I note that some community leaders in Kununurra have changed their position

Speaker: NA
Text: on the card due to the lack of support programs wrapping around and actually working in their

Speaker: NA
Text: communities. We support local community action in delivering tailored programs that suit

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: their needs: programs that complement the objectives of the cashless debit card. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: considered vital for the success of any trial. We need to understand the reasons for the shift in

Speaker: NA
Text: support in Kununurra.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn to the cost of these trials undertaken so far. As we have previously heard, the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has spent around $18.9 million on the East Kimberley and Ceduna trials alone.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe the Senate inquiry will reveal whether this money has been well spent, but that is

Speaker: NA
Text: an extraordinary amount of money. It is also hoped this will shed light on the $7.9 million

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to Indue to manage the payment system. Surprisingly, ORIMA Research was funded to

Speaker: NA
Text: the tune of $1.6 million for research that in the opinion of many has questionable value as

Speaker: NA
Text: either indicator or research tool.

Speaker: NA
Text: We rightly question the reason why this legislation is being brought forward when there are

Speaker: NA
Text: still so many questions that need to be answered. The 2016 census tells us that Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous population has grown by 17.4 per cent since 2011. That's an estimated 3.3 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of our total population, an estimated just under 800,000 people who are concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: implications of a rollout of a cashless debit card system. We need to be mindful of the

Speaker: NA
Text: implications of those trials and the psychological impact they have on every single Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: person, regardless of where they live. It is imperative that we take the actions of previous

Speaker: NA
Text: governments into account when we are discussing serious amendments, such as the one

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House today. It is also important to note that these populations are centred in the

Speaker: NA
Text: major cities, particularly in electorates like mine in Lindsay.

Speaker: NA
Text: The impact of these trials is surely an underlying worry for many people in how they view

Speaker: NA
Text: their future. These are people who have suffered and have been hurt by our collective actions,

Speaker: NA
Text: however well-intentioned they may have been. These people need to be reassured of our

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment to the implementation of effective education, rehabilitation and training

Speaker: NA
Text: programs as essential. They are essential to ensure that the inequity, suspicion and historical

Speaker: NA
Text: dislocation is addressed in ways that are well researched, well resourced and effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: delivered.

Speaker: NA
Text: While we know that most people have the ability to self-manage their incomes, we also

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that some people need a hand. Whether extending the rollout of the cashless debit

Speaker: NA
Text: card is the answer is yet to be fully understood. Labor is committed to consulting widely in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hervey Bay and Goldfields areas. I reiterate that we mean proper consultation that

Speaker: NA
Text: includes working together with communities to ensure they get the programs they need and

Speaker: NA
Text: desire, and not lecture them. We will not lecture the communities we visit, but we will

Speaker: NA
Text: commit to listening, discussing and acting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: The SPEAKER (16:30): It being 4.30 pm, I propose the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Macquarie Electorate: Blue Fringe Arts

Speaker: NA
Text: Vocational Education and Training

Speaker: Ms TEMPLEMAN
Text: Macquarie) (16:30): Some wonderful artists and writers were

Speaker: NA
Text: honoured this weekend in the Blue Mountains at the 25th Blue Fringe Arts Awards. These

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: began as the Adrienne Brown Awards in 1992, in honour of Adrienne, who had schizophrenia

Speaker: NA
Text: and who found relief through her love of poetry, the arts and music. Her family recognised the

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable role that artistic expression played in their daughter's life, and from this emerged the

Speaker: NA
Text: Blue Fringe Arts Festival. Anyone who has a lived experience of a mental health issue is able

Speaker: NA
Text: to enter, and there are art, sculpture, photography, textiles and writing prizes.

Speaker: NA
Text: The festival has an organising committee which includes representatives from Aftercare;

Speaker: NA
Text: Neighbourhood Centres across the mountains, including Springwood and Katoomba; Ability

Speaker: NA
Text: Links; and TAFE, as well as volunteers from the community and the artists themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: They're generously supported by sponsors from local businesses including Botanical Art,

Speaker: NA
Text: Vivability, Bendigo Bank, Belle Property Leura, Mountain High Pies, Richards Financial

Speaker: NA
Text: Services and Blue Mountains Explorer bus.

Speaker: NA
Text: The works were diverse and glorious, and I am the very proud owner of a beautiful

Speaker: NA
Text: charcoal piece called Shoal Bay Sunset by a young artist, Alan Bridges, which won the

Speaker: NA
Text: People's Choice Award and is now in my Parliament House office. Congratulations to all the

Speaker: NA
Text: artists involved and thanks to volunteers and sponsors for a quarter of a century of this

Speaker: NA
Text: important event.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have just been talking about one of the many important roles our local Wentworth Falls

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE plays in our community, as the host venue for the Blue Fringe Arts Awards. My

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Macquarie includes the Wentworth Falls and Katoomba TAFEs, specialising in

Speaker: NA
Text: things like outdoor education, hospitality and community health, and Richmond TAFE, which

Speaker: NA
Text: has a huge equine training capacity as well as venomous snakes training, landscaping, plus

Speaker: NA
Text: much more.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE is one institution that has taken a battering in recent years, but it is vital to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: having a skilled workforce and vital for people in the Blue Mountains and Hawkesbury to

Speaker: NA
Text: access further education. When Labor left office in 2013, there were around 420,000

Speaker: NA
Text: apprentices; now it is 280,000. The population has grown, and yet apprentice numbers have

Speaker: NA
Text: fallen. Nationally, there was a 30 per cent cut in government-funded training at TAFE

Speaker: NA
Text: between 2013 and 2016.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE teachers and students past and present tell me TAFE is in serious danger if changes

Speaker: NA
Text: are not made soon. In spite of the constant undermining of their positions, the dedicated

Speaker: NA
Text: TAFE teachers have hung in there, putting the needs of their students at the forefront. Let's

Speaker: NA
Text: talk about the students. The stories they tell me are inspiring, about how attending TAFE has

Speaker: NA
Text: helped them feel better about themselves, especially if they've been out of the workforce

Speaker: NA
Text: because of illness or because of caring for someone else. It has helped them feel more

Speaker: NA
Text: confident about their skills and helped them feel more motivated to seek work. TAFE gives

Speaker: NA
Text: people a second chance. We know it can transform lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to make sure it keeps doing this long into the future in a way that prepares people

Speaker: NA
Text: for future employment. We need to work with business and industry to ensure that alongside

Speaker: NA
Text: trade skills students get to solve problems, collaborate and create. They need great facilities to

Speaker: NA
Text: do that in and their teachers need to be recognised for the contribution that they make. I'm

Speaker: NA
Text: very fortunate to have in my electorate the New South Wales President of the TAFE Teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: Association, Annette Bennett. We are well aware of what needs to know done. We need to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure TAFE is better at meeting the emerging needs of the 15to 25-year-olds as they

Speaker: NA
Text: transition from school to work. We need to better meet the additional needs of students who

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: have a disability or come from disadvantaged backgrounds so they can participate in an equal

Speaker: NA
Text: educational opportunity. We need to better address the needs of special equity groups such as

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals, migrants and women returning to work or looking to participate in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor will do what needs to be done. For a start, Labor will return to vocational education

Speaker: NA
Text: and training the $637 million that was cut in the last budget. We have announced that we will

Speaker: NA
Text: secure funding for vocational education and training and ensure that at least two-thirds of it

Speaker: NA
Text: will go to the most trusted provider in the country, and that is TAFE. The remainder will go to

Speaker: NA
Text: only the very best providers in the private sector, because, at the heart of it, we need TAFE. It

Speaker: NA
Text: does more than any other educational institution in this space.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryrie, Major General Sir Granville de Laune, KCMG, CB, VD

Speaker: Mr ZIMMERMAN
Text: North Sydney) (16:35): On 31 October, Australia will

Speaker: NA
Text: commemorate the centenary of the famous charge of our 4th Light Horse Brigade at the battle

Speaker: NA
Text: of Beersheba. This was the last great charge of the Light Horse, the world's greatest mounted

Speaker: NA
Text: column to take the field since Alexander the Great. We will commemorate our soldiers'

Speaker: NA
Text: courage in defence of their ideals, the mateship they showed under fire and their solidarity

Speaker: NA
Text: with the allies they fought alongside, and we will remember a battle and a victory that for so

Speaker: NA
Text: long was understated in the annals of Australian military history, despite its scale and

Speaker: NA
Text: importance in bringing an end to the Ottoman Empire.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today I want to pay special tribute to one of our great leaders during that battle and a

Speaker: NA
Text: leader of his community in this parliament, Major General Sir Granville Ryrie, the third

Speaker: NA
Text: member for North Sydney. Granville Ryrie, or 'Bull' Ryrie, as the Light Horse affectionately

Speaker: NA
Text: called him, was born in Michelago in country New South Wales on 1 July 1865, not far from

Speaker: NA
Text: where our national capital would be later established. As a young man, Sir Granville worked

Speaker: NA
Text: as a jackeroo, learning the horseback skills which later earned the respect of the Light Horse.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even more interestingly, he took the time to learn about the local Indigenous people and to

Speaker: NA
Text: learn their language.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Granville Ryrie joined the 1st Australian Horse in 1898, serving in the South African

Speaker: NA
Text: war, where he was wounded. In 1904, the regiment became the 3rd Light Horse, and he

Speaker: NA
Text: became its commanding officer. In the same year, Sir Granville entered the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislative Assembly, representing Queanbeyan, before joining the still-nascent federal

Speaker: NA
Text: parliament in 1911 as the member for North Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1914 he volunteered for the front, telling his wife he couldn't look fellow Australians in

Speaker: NA
Text: the face if he stayed. In a sign of the respect he had won among his own constituents, the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of North Sydney came together to buy Sir Granville Plain Bill, a black charger which,

Speaker: NA
Text: despite the homely name, was regarded as one of the best mounts in the Allied forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leading the 2nd Light Horse Brigade, Sir Granville was wounded twice at Gallipoli. He won

Speaker: NA
Text: the hearts of his men through his solidarity with them in the trenches and when he protested

Speaker: NA
Text: successfully against an attack order which he knew would've been a bloody failure. In tribute,

Speaker: NA
Text: they named their position on Holly Ridge Ryrie's Post.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1916, Granville's 2nd Light Horse Brigade was incorporated into the Anzac Mounted

Speaker: NA
Text: division and, with this division, Sir Granville took part in the battle of Beersheba, seizing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hebron road. In a letter home, Sir Granville told the story of the charge his own men made

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: through an enemy camp and in pursuit of Turkish cavalry and guns. In his book Beersheba,

Speaker: NA
Text: the journalist Paul Daley wrote that Sir Granville 'forged a reputation as one of his country's

Speaker: NA
Text: most fearless soldiers and finest leaders of men'. Another predecessor of mine comes into the

Speaker: NA
Text: story here. Joe Hockey's grandfather and namesake, Joseph Hokeidonian, was appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: deputy town clerk of Beersheba after the Allied victory.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Granville continued to serve until the Armistice and was decorated several times. I want

Speaker: NA
Text: to particularly pay tribute to his honour and his humanity towards prisoners, on one occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing 5,000 Turkish prisoners to keep their arms and to bivouac with his own soldiers to

Speaker: NA
Text: protect them from the anger of local Allied troops.

Speaker: NA
Text: After the war, Sir Granville and the Light Horse returned to Sydney to a rapturous

Speaker: NA
Text: welcome. Some have estimated that 200,000 Australians waited at the docks for their arrival.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suspect no current politician would receive such a welcome on returning to their electorate!

Speaker: NA
Text: Back in parliament, Sir Granville served as Assistant Minister for Defence from 1920 to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1921. In 1922, when Bendigo was at risk, he gave up his seat for Billy Hughes. Sir Granville

Speaker: NA
Text: himself was moved to the newly-created seat of Warringah and became its first member. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1927, Sir Granville became High Commissioner to London, representing Australia at the

Speaker: NA
Text: League of Nations in Geneva as well. He passed away in 1937 and was buried in his home

Speaker: NA
Text: town, where his family still lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier today, I had the pleasure of meeting with his great-grandson, Xander Ryrie, who

Speaker: NA
Text: followed the example of Sir Granville and served in the Australian Army for several years.

Speaker: NA
Text: His own service took him in Sir Granville's footsteps, as a peacekeeper on the Israeli-

Speaker: NA
Text: Egyptian border, wearing the blue cap.

Speaker: NA
Text: Granville Ryrie was a man who served North Sydney and who served his country with

Speaker: NA
Text: courage and honesty and with a sense of the value of each Australian. He showed an interest

Speaker: NA
Text: in Indigenous Australians when few did and always stood beside the soldiers he led in several

Speaker: NA
Text: wars, as his wounds bore witness to. He was not the only North Sydney resident to show such

Speaker: NA
Text: qualities when their fellow Australians needed it, but he is representative of them all. In

Speaker: NA
Text: paying honour to him today I do so with a salute to the thousands of Australians who marched

Speaker: NA
Text: or rode beside him. We shall never forget their service to our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration Detention

Speaker: Mr NEUMANN
Text: Blair) (16:40): The incompetence of the Minister for Immigration and

Speaker: NA
Text: Border Protection was on full display during Senate estimates this week. The minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: failures runs widely and deeply when it comes to the management of the offshore processing

Speaker: NA
Text: centres on Manus Island and Nauru and his failure to secure other third-country resettlement

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements for eligible refugees. The Manus Island RPC will close on 31 October as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of a ruling of the Supreme Court of Papua New Guinea and in agreement with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Papua New Guinean government. The Department of Immigration and Border Protection

Speaker: NA
Text: confirmed during Senate estimates that alternative accommodation arrangements for refugees

Speaker: NA
Text: won't be completed until 29 October, only two days prior to the closure of Manus Island RPC.

Speaker: NA
Text: Contracts worth between an estimated $150 million and $250 million to provide basic

Speaker: NA
Text: services for refugees in PNG after 31 October will be undertaken, but those contracts are yet

Speaker: NA
Text: to be signed. I emphasise the word 'estimated', because that's the closest thing to a guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: that the immigration minister's department could provide.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not as if these issues have sneaked up on the government. For months the immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: minister has been unclear about and unwilling to explain Australia's involvement in offering

Speaker: NA
Text: support for refugees and the PNG government after 31 October. He's left it to the very last

Speaker: NA
Text: minute. The closure of Manus Island RPC was confirmed by both the Prime Minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea in April this year. The Australian said

Speaker: NA
Text: on 8 April:

Speaker: NA
Text: Neither leader signalled any plan to find an alternative resettlement option for those who are not sent to

Speaker: NA
Text: the US under the refugee rearrangements that they had.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's clear the immigration minister should have made securing third-country resettlement

Speaker: NA
Text: options, apart from the US, a priority since he became immigration minister in 2014. Instead,

Speaker: NA
Text: we see he's left his department to scramble in the final weeks before the closure of the Manus

Speaker: NA
Text: Island RPC. Manus Island and Nauru were set up by Labor as regional transit facilities for

Speaker: NA
Text: processing, but they have become places of indefinite detention by this government in its fifth

Speaker: NA
Text: year of operation and governance. Labor strongly supports the refugee resettlement agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: with the US and thanks the US for what they are doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was revealed during Senate estimates that, in a similar fashion to the contracts for PNG,

Speaker: NA
Text: contracts for services in Nauru RPC after 31 October have not yet been finalised. The

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration minister needs to ensure that health services and welfare services for those in

Speaker: NA
Text: Nauru will be delivered when the current contractors pull out. A letter of intent was issued on

Speaker: NA
Text: 28 September for a company to take over these services, but that falls short of a contract.

Speaker: NA
Text: When it comes to a suitable contractor being selected, a limited tender process was run by the

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration minister's department. Senate estimates confirmed it was well and truly limited,

Speaker: NA
Text: with only one contractor being considered, and that company having no experience in

Speaker: NA
Text: delivering welfare services and limited experience in delivering garrison services. This flies

Speaker: NA
Text: entirely in the face of recommendations from the Auditor-General in the report Offshore

Speaker: NA
Text: processing centres in Nauru and Papua New Guinea: procurement of garrison support and

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare services, which read:

Speaker: NA
Text: Of most concern is the department's management of processes for contract consolidation and the open

Speaker: NA
Text: tender.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was no open tender to ensure ongoing services in Nauru were secured and no

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration of value for money or even whether basic service delivery standards would be

Speaker: NA
Text: met. It is another case of too little, too late with the immigration minister's last-minute plan to

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer refugees from Manus Island to Nauru. Only two eligible refugees have expressed

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in a transfer. The minister needs to find third-country arrangements other than the US.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate estimates also confirmed that the department is yet to replace its Chief Medical

Speaker: NA
Text: Officer and Surgeon General, following his resignation months ago. This means thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: people across Australia's onshore and offshore immigration network are still without an

Speaker: NA
Text: advocate to ensure that medical care is based on the best medical advice. The secretary of the

Speaker: NA
Text: department couldn't even remember whether he'd briefed the immigration minister, his own

Speaker: NA
Text: minister, about the resignation of the Chief Medical Officer. Most Australians would expect a

Speaker: NA
Text: boss to know when one of their most senior employees has resigned. But apparently it's a

Speaker: NA
Text: different set of standards for the immigration minister. Australia deserves better than an

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetent minister who can't even secure the cybersafety of his own department. It should

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: have complied with the top four mitigation strategies by June 2014. The government should

Speaker: NA
Text: do much better than this. (Time expired)

Speaker: NA
Text: Marriage

Speaker: Ms BANKS
Text: Chisholm) (16:45): I rise today to talk about marriage equality. I'm sure I'm

Speaker: NA
Text: not the only person in Australia who has enjoyed that wonderful feeling of a belly laugh

Speaker: NA
Text: brought on by watching Magda Szubanski herself or in character mode. Magda has made me

Speaker: NA
Text: laugh so many times over the years. And recently she made me cry when she told the story of

Speaker: NA
Text: her friend with a cancer diagnosis who was denied being with her same-sex partner of many

Speaker: NA
Text: years during her treatment as she wasn't regarded as next of kin. I cried not only for her friend

Speaker: NA
Text: but for all those Australians who have similar experiences. These people in 10, 20 or 30 years

Speaker: NA
Text: time may have stories like Magda Szubanski's friend. Their stories will be depicted in movies

Speaker: NA
Text: in years to come-and we will all wonder why we hadn't sorted this out earlier Well, 2017 is

Speaker: NA
Text: the year we can make this change and stop any more of these experiences happening to future

Speaker: NA
Text: generations of Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my late 20s, I was told by a doctor I had cancer. They didn't know if it was cancer A or

Speaker: NA
Text: B. If it was cancer A, it would be aggressive and terminal. Cancer B, on the other hand, was

Speaker: NA
Text: the best cancer to have-totally curable. It turned out to be cancer B, but they wouldn't know

Speaker: NA
Text: which it was until I had surgery in 10 days time-the darkest days of my life but also the most

Speaker: NA
Text: loving. Why? Because during that time I had love and family all around me. Specifically,

Speaker: NA
Text: during that time my partner, Mike, was my rock and my lifeline; and, importantly, during that

Speaker: NA
Text: time he asked me to marry him. My darkest hours became brighter; simply by looking

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to a commitment of marriage I felt safe, secure, loved and courageous.

Speaker: NA
Text: When I heard Magda's story I despaired, because I simply felt it is not fair that two loving

Speaker: NA
Text: people cannot get married in our great country-that two loving people are not able to have

Speaker: NA
Text: equal rights at law that millions of Australians currently enjoy in their committed, loving

Speaker: NA
Text: marriages. Some will say it is courageous and risky for an MP in a marginal seat to be so

Speaker: NA
Text: vociferous in supporting marriage equality. Fighting for marriage equality is not about

Speaker: NA
Text: political courage; rather, it is about standing for equality for all, regardless of their gender,

Speaker: NA
Text: race, sexuality or ethnicity. Before the election, I personally promised hundreds of people

Speaker: NA
Text: that, under a Turnbull government, we would ensure all Australians would have a right to

Speaker: NA
Text: have their say on this issue, that their vote would count as much as mine. We have maintained

Speaker: NA
Text: the integrity of that promise to the Australian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians are decent people and known around the world for their sense of humour,

Speaker: NA
Text: goodwill and camaraderie towards others. Respectful debate is the cornerstone of our

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy. Telling Australians how to vote is not the way to go, and some have done a

Speaker: NA
Text: disservice to their cause by their behaviour and overreaching statements. However, a 'yes'

Speaker: NA
Text: vote is an acknowledgement that social mores change and should be reflected in a change to

Speaker: NA
Text: the law. Many predict that the 'no' vote will win because young voters, not being the postal

Speaker: NA
Text: generation, won't post their vote. People say, 'They will only do things online or on their

Speaker: NA
Text: mobile phones.' I have never bought into these views. Being the technological generation

Speaker: NA
Text: doesn't make young people complacent and not passionate about issues. Young Australians

Speaker: NA
Text: are making their vote count. They are the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: And then there is the argument in the 'no' campaign which I find personally disturbing-

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, that only a marriage between a man and a woman will ensure the protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: children. Children need two things in life: love and stability. Early in my legal career, when I

Speaker: NA
Text: practised in family law, I saw firsthand that love and stability is not automatically afforded to

Speaker: NA
Text: children simply because they have a mother and a father. Love and stability are being

Speaker: NA
Text: provided to Australian children all over the country right now. The presence of love and

Speaker: NA
Text: stability is not limited to traditional nuclear families like my family; rather, it's in the homes

Speaker: NA
Text: of single parents, widows, divorced parents, separated parents, same-sex parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: grandparents, aunties, uncles and special friends, regardless of their gender or sexuality.

Speaker: NA
Text: Marriage equality is about equality before the law. It's about fairness. It's about love and

Speaker: NA
Text: family. I hope that as Australians, when we watch that movie in the future, all 'yes' voters will

Speaker: NA
Text: feel that in 2017 they made their contribution to a fair, equal and modern Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania: Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRIAN MITCHELL (Lyons) (15:54): Before I begin, I'd like to thank the member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Chisholm. That was a great speech and I'd like to associate myself with her remarks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rebecca White has been the leader of the Labor Party in Tasmania since March this year

Speaker: NA
Text: and, if all goes as hoped, by March next year she will be our state's next Premier. Since taking

Speaker: NA
Text: on the leadership following the dignified and selfless retirement of Bryan Green, Rebecca has

Speaker: NA
Text: traversed the state listening to Tasmanians. The state election is due by March but could come

Speaker: NA
Text: at any time. Rebecca White and the Tasmanian Labor team are ready for an election whenever

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal Premier Will Hodgman can find the courage to call one. Labor has the policies and

Speaker: NA
Text: the people to deliver a strong and effective majority Labor government that will focus on key

Speaker: NA
Text: services, such as health and education, while continuing to grow our state's economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rebecca has represented the state seat of Lyons since 2010. I was delighted to have played

Speaker: NA
Text: a part in her campaign long before I came to this place, and she has been a great strength to

Speaker: NA
Text: me as I serve our common constituents at the federal level. In just the past few months,

Speaker: NA
Text: Rebecca and her team have announced plans for Lyons, including a pledge to fix a notorious

Speaker: NA
Text: intersection on the Bass Highway, at Christmas Hills near Deloraine, and a pledge to invest

Speaker: NA
Text: $1 million in mountain-biking tourism at St Helens.

Speaker: NA
Text: Statewide, the big issue is undoubtedly health. It is an area that has been completely

Speaker: NA
Text: mismanaged by the Liberals at both the state and the federal levels. Ambulance ramping is out

Speaker: NA
Text: of control. We have ongoing bed shortages and people with mental illness are simply being

Speaker: NA
Text: shut out of access to quality care. I don't pretend that health is an easy policy area. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: diabolically difficult to manage competing needs within a limited budget, but it has to be said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Tasmanian health minister, Michael Ferguson, a former Liberal member of this place,

Speaker: NA
Text: has been an unmitigated disaster. Like so many of his colleagues, he puts ideology before

Speaker: NA
Text: practicality; he puts dollars before care. A Rebecca White Tasmanian Labor government will

Speaker: NA
Text: invest an extra $88 million over three years into our state's struggling health system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Community nurses and health worker numbers will be increased and hospitals will run over

Speaker: NA
Text: seven days a week. This will keep people closer to their families when they need weekend

Speaker: NA
Text: and ongoing treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The federal government recently ripped funding from well supported and popular regional

Speaker: NA
Text: preventative health programs, redirecting it to chronic care. This was appallingly handled,

Speaker: NA
Text: with no consultation and a haphazard changeover. I am yet to be convinced that the change

Speaker: NA
Text: has been for the better. The preventative programs kept people, particularly older people,

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: happy and active within their local communities and kept them out of hospital. I think it's a

Speaker: NA
Text: terrible shame that the Liberals have axed those valuable programs. Labor have listened to

Speaker: NA
Text: regional communities and, in government, will move to commit more resources to

Speaker: NA
Text: preventative-care models.

Speaker: NA
Text: With Rebecca White as Premier, two additional ambulance crews and two trucks will hit

Speaker: NA
Text: the road to get Tasmanians treated faster. I should note that Rebecca and I have both been

Speaker: NA
Text: working in recent months to secure funding commitments for Rural Alive and Well, based in

Speaker: NA
Text: Oatlands in our electorate. I am pleased to see today that the federal government provided a

Speaker: NA
Text: one-year lifeline to this vital outreach service. I would have liked to have seen a three-year

Speaker: NA
Text: commitment, but one year is better than nothing. I certainly do not want to see one-year

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments become the norm. They make it impossible for organisations to plan and they

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel fear and insecurity within the workforce and amongst vulnerable clients.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rebecca and her team have announced wider policies, including a rollout of six new child

Speaker: NA
Text: and family centres across the state to support families and nurture young children. School

Speaker: NA
Text: starting ages will stay where they are. There is also a commitment to ensure that people can

Speaker: NA
Text: pay their utility bills in instalments without financial penalty and a public commitment to

Speaker: NA
Text: aquaculture and national parks. We both share a commitment to TAFE as a pillar of

Speaker: NA
Text: vocational training. Rebecca is a hardworking and compassionate Labor leader with a steely

Speaker: NA
Text: determination to achieve practical results. She understands regional communities in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: because, like me, she lives in one. It brings a perspective to her policy suite that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to fathom when you live in a nice house in the middle of a city, surrounded by

Speaker: NA
Text: amenities and services. I know Rebecca White well. I consider her to be a very good friend.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania will be well served by a Rebecca White majority state Labor government at the

Speaker: NA
Text: next election in March.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mallee Electorate: Mildura

Speaker: Mr BROAD
Text: Mallee) (16:54): I wish to update the House on the strategic plan that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have been implementing in the township of Mildura. Prosperity doesn't just happen; it is

Speaker: NA
Text: actually as a result of choices that we make. The first thing the federal government have done

Speaker: NA
Text: since we have come into power is put common sense back into water policy. We've made it

Speaker: NA
Text: clear that we are not going to participate in buybacks. We wanted to give confidence to

Speaker: NA
Text: irrigators that water is going to be there and available for them to irrigate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second thing that the federal government has done is delivered $103 million for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sunraysia Modernisation Project, which has been built and has now put a lot of the earthen

Speaker: NA
Text: channels into pipes and has driven efficiency and confidence in the region. We are also

Speaker: NA
Text: advocating for stage 2 of the Sunraysia Modernisation Project to expand the irrigation

Speaker: NA
Text: footprint by a further 25 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing we've done is put in on-farm tax deductibility for irrigation infrastructure,

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as the $20,000 instant tax write-offs. This has meant that not only have we built

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure but agriculturalists and horticulturists have put infrastructure on their own

Speaker: NA
Text: farms.

Speaker: NA
Text: The fourth thing we've done is developed three free trade agreements, with China, Korea

Speaker: NA
Text: and Japan. The prosperity that has come out of those has been phenomenal. They have driven

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: over a billion dollars of additional money into this community and have really set us up for

Speaker: NA
Text: the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, of course, we've got to be able to get the product to the market. The federal

Speaker: NA
Text: government has contributed $240 million to build the Murray Basin Rail Project. That's with

Speaker: NA
Text: $200 million from the state government, so it's a $440 million project now to have Victoria's

Speaker: NA
Text: busiest freight line taking all the horticultural products we produce to the marketplace.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, it continues. If you're going to have cutting-edge producers, you need to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the NBN. We now have 11 NBN towers built around the township of Mildura. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: building the building blocks for prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next thing we have done, which we will be opening in a week's time, is to upgrade the

Speaker: NA
Text: Mildura runway, which has cost the federal government $10 million in a $25 million upgrade.

Speaker: NA
Text: We now have 737s daily coming into Mildura and 140 commercial flights a week. You can

Speaker: NA
Text: fly direct to Sydney, Adelaide, Broken Hill and Melbourne, and perhaps in the future to

Speaker: NA
Text: Brisbane. This opens us up to the business community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, we wanted to make Mildura a great place to live. Also in a week's time, we'll be

Speaker: NA
Text: opening the $18 million Mildura waterfront, a beautiful place to walk down by the water. It

Speaker: NA
Text: means that we are investing in the quality of life in our region.

Speaker: NA
Text: We do want to build stage 2 of the irrigation infrastructure. We believe there's a strong

Speaker: NA
Text: future there, and we want to expand it. Additionally, we are working on the Mildura Future

Speaker: NA
Text: Ready project. This is a strategic vision of the council. They need to invest in a sporting

Speaker: NA
Text: precinct; our sporting precinct is full. It needs some significant upgrades, and I'll be certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: fighting for $10 million to build part of the Mildura South sports precinct in the next round of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Building Better Regions Fund.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other thing that has been a success for our community, which has the largest

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous community in the state of Victoria, is that we've had Indigenous employment

Speaker: NA
Text: programs. One of the things you will not see in Mildura is people from the Indigenous culture

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting at the river drinking alcohol. We have people actively engaged in getting people into

Speaker: NA
Text: work. We have businesses that are very proactive in making sure they provide culturally

Speaker: NA
Text: sensitive workplaces. We want to make sure that even though our community has prosperity,

Speaker: NA
Text: the prosperity is shared among everyone and that no-one is left behind.

Speaker: NA
Text: The things that are building the prosperity in the town have been quite strategic. It hasn't

Speaker: NA
Text: been an accident. It's been really about building those key infrastructures. When you knit

Speaker: NA
Text: them all together, you're taking the products you produce to the market; you're opening up

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities to the world; you're ensuring that there is first-rate telecommunications; and

Speaker: NA
Text: you're ensuring that we have a place where people want to live. I just want to say to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Mildura: the National Party have delivered for you.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sometimes people in Mildura say that they feel like they miss out. Clearly, when I outline

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the federal government expenditure that goes into the town, they haven't missed out.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, because they are the furthest point from the capital of the state of Victoria, the furthest

Speaker: NA
Text: point from Melbourne, they believe at times they miss out. But I believe that when we work

Speaker: NA
Text: together, when we fight together and we put the case, we should be very proud of what we've

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved in that small town.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mildura is a great inland city. I notice that Minister Taylor is here, and I hope that he sees

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is a long future for our inland city.

Speaker: Mr Taylor
Text: Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr BROAD
Text: Unfortunately, it doesn't fit into your remit, because it's only 52,000; it's not

Speaker: NA
Text: 80,000 yet. But I believe there's a strong future there, and we'll continue to advocate for good

Speaker: NA
Text: outcomes for that town.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate interrupted.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 17:00

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, 26 October 2017

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Ms Vamvakinou) took the chair at 10:00.

Text: Broadband

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: has contacted my office on numerous occasions during his efforts to have a landline

Speaker: NA
Text: connected to his property. This might sound like overkill-a member of parliament being

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: all of the help he can get. He is an 84-year-old. He moved to a new, smaller home on 4

Speaker: NA
Text: September this year. He did everything required to ensure his services were connected to his

Speaker: NA
Text: new home. On 2 August he filled in the paperwork with Telstra for the landline at his old

Speaker: NA
Text: house to be disconnected and for a landline to be connected to his new home on 4 September.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: me that he had visited his local Telstra store four times to ask for the landline to be connected

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: home on 18 September to install a landline. This was pushed out to 21 September. On 28

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a landline. A technician had attended his home the day before but did not put the phone in the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra has advised us that the landline appeared to be working and a phone number had

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: and the second phone in the socket. Neither one connected and no dial tone was available.

Speaker: NA
Text: Telstra again told us that either NBN had taken over the area or the developer had not

Speaker: NA
Text: provided the wiring needed and the matter would be escalated. We were advised that on 10

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: technician to install a landline. Telstra has advised that the problem with installing a

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone for my 84-year-old constituent is that the area in Calista in which he lives has been

Speaker: NA
Text: handed off to NBN Co, and, whenever a provider processes an order for a new connection for

Speaker: NA
Text: a landline in this area, NBN immediately cancels the order.

Speaker: NA
Text: To add insult to injury NBN is not scheduled to roll out in Calista until 2020. So we have

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Failure to install a landline in three months means he has to wait a further two to three years

Speaker: NA
Text: for a landline phone. This is 2017. Is this what the Prime Minister calls having the NBN

Speaker: NA
Text: rollout in hand. This government is a train wreck. It wrecks everything it touches, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: NBN is its champion disaster. I have listened to government members in this place, Liberals

Speaker: NA
Text: and Nationals, and they are unbelievable. They yell out across the chamber, 'I've got the NBN.

Speaker: NA
Text: My NBN is fine!' Jolly good, job done! Put your feet up and take a load off! Have a break!

Speaker: NA
Text: For God's sake, fix the NBN, fix this mess and do your job.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian Government

Speaker: Mr MORTON
Text: Tangney) (10:03): Our national anthem speaks of wealth and toil and

Speaker: NA
Text: says that our land abounds in nature's gifts. How true. What a lucky state Western Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: to be blessed with so many natural resources and a population that is educated,

Speaker: NA
Text: entrepreneurial and hardworking, that can turn these gifts into a better life for many. The one

Speaker: NA
Text: thing WA doesn't have is a state government that understands or even cares about our

Speaker: NA
Text: resources industry. The WA Labor government just sees the extra money it can grab,

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever the dire consequences for jobs, families, businesses and investment. The WA Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government has zero understanding of supply and demand or the enormous cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: acceleration and development. But that is the history of WA Labor, from the appalling waste

Speaker: NA
Text: and corruption of WA Inc to the incompetence of the Carpenter Labor government, which lost

Speaker: NA
Text: the INPEX project, which my state colleague Sean L'Estrange, the shadow minister for mines

Speaker: NA
Text: and petroleum, informed the WA parliament cost us in WA $24 billion in investment and up

Speaker: NA
Text: to 4,000 jobs at peak construction.

Speaker: NA
Text: Added to that, there was a backlog of 13,000 mining and exploration licences awaiting

Speaker: NA
Text: approval. Labor was asleep at the wheel-lazy and incompetent, even when success was there

Speaker: NA
Text: for the digging. Today, the new WA Labor government is doing its best to deny Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians a chance to work in mining, to build businesses and to help everybody prosper,

Speaker: NA
Text: firstly, by trying to increase the gold royalty by 50 per cent, something that the premier, prior

Speaker: NA
Text: to the WA state election, promised he would never do. The Kalgoorlie Miner, on 29 October

Speaker: NA
Text: 2015, stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mark MCGowan says a Labor Government will not increase gold royalties, labelling the move a

Speaker: NA
Text: counterproductive method of raising revenue …

Speaker: NA
Text: But, typically, Labor said one thing before the election and the opposite after. The WA

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberals opposed the increase. Labor has also banned fracking, despite more than 600 wells

Speaker: NA
Text: having been fracked in WA in the past 55 years. Again: ignorance, laziness, destructive virtue

Speaker: NA
Text: signalling. On uranium, finally, Labor has excelled itself. The Minister for Mines and

Speaker: NA
Text: Petroleum promised that the projects approved by the previous coalition government would

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed-the right and honest thing to do. Then he was mugged by the unions, who showed

Speaker: NA
Text: their usual total disregard for their members' jobs and the future and showed the minister

Speaker: NA
Text: who's boss. The West Australian, on 18 April 2017, reported that the AMWU state secretary,

Speaker: NA
Text: Steve MCCartney, said that the minister had been misquoted and there was 'no way in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world projects would be able to go ahead'. Labor in WA is subservient to its pay masters and

Speaker: NA
Text: its puppet masters-always has been and always will be.

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic and Family Violence

Speaker: Ms LAMB
Text: Longman) (10:06): I rise today in absolute and utter condemnation. That

Speaker: NA
Text: absolute and utter condemnation is directed at Pauline Hanson's One Nation party. It's a party

Speaker: NA
Text: whose entire existence is based on a pathetic strategy of making outrageous claims to generate

Speaker: NA
Text: headlines. It's a strategy that is harmful and dangerous. I cannot believe I have to stand here

Speaker: NA
Text: today and argue that domestic violence is a bad thing. I cannot believe I have to stand here

Speaker: NA
Text: and make note of how damaging the legislation that the Queensland wing of Pauline Hanson's

Speaker: NA
Text: One Nation has proposed is. They say they are 'thinking of the children' but really they're

Speaker: NA
Text: throwing vulnerable children into the crossfire. One Nation are using children as a political

Speaker: NA
Text: tool. It is absolutely despicable behaviour. Pauline Hanson and her Queensland leader, Steve

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Dickson, should be ashamed. Putting children at risk of harm is the lowest form of low, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is absolutely disgusting that One Nation would do this to seek political gain.

Speaker: NA
Text: Just over an hour ago I was speaking on the phone to Estrelle from Caboolture Regional

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic Violence Service. She's an expert in the field of domestic violence, having

Speaker: NA
Text: supported countless victims in the Moreton Bay region. She was shocked and appalled at One

Speaker: NA
Text: Nation's policy. She said, 'Has anybody from One Nation consulted with the experts, looked

Speaker: NA
Text: at the figures, spoken to victims?' Estrelle noted, when she was speaking to me, how

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrators of domestic violence are already using children to get to their partners-

Speaker: NA
Text: manipulating them into attacking them both verbally and physically-and now One Nation

Speaker: NA
Text: want to make things worse. One Nation's domestic violence spokesperson described their

Speaker: NA
Text: policy by saying that a victim must 'prove victimisation through injuries; otherwise visitation

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be restricted'. Can you believe that, Madam Deputy Speaker? It essentially means

Speaker: NA
Text: that unless a victim, be they a woman or a man, has a black eye, One Nation want to push

Speaker: NA
Text: their children back into the hands of the perpetrator. In doing this they are showing absolute

Speaker: NA
Text: disregard for the welfare of children, all for the sake of some headlines or TV interviews.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nearly 26,000 offenders breached protection orders last year-26,000 offenders. How many

Speaker: NA
Text: children involved in those situations would be forced back under One Nation's policy?

Speaker: NA
Text: Diwali

Speaker: Mr LEESER
Text: Berowra) (10:09): The triumph of good over evil, hope over despair and

Speaker: NA
Text: darkness, knowledge over ignorance-these ideals were the cause of celebration in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Indian-Australian community last week as part of Diwali, or the festival of lights, celebrated

Speaker: NA
Text: by Hindus, Sikhs, Jains and Buddhists. There are around 600,000 Australians of Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: heritage, and I have 6½ thousand of them living in the Berowra electorate. They play an

Speaker: NA
Text: active role and make a much valued contribution to our community, and I wish I had more

Speaker: NA
Text: Indian-Australian constituents.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Chair of the Parliamentary Friends of India, Diwali is my favourite festival on the

Speaker: NA
Text: multicultural calendar. Diwali is a time of joy when family and friends come together. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Hindu story of Diwali tells of the return of Lord Rama and his family after 14 years of exile

Speaker: NA
Text: during which he defeated the demon king Ravana. To honour Lord Rama's return and his

Speaker: NA
Text: victory, the villagers lit diyas to illuminate their path and celebrate the belief that good

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately triumphs over evil. To symbolise this, every year on Diwali homes are filled with

Speaker: NA
Text: light. Diyas and candles are lit, children play with sparklers and fireworks are set off in

Speaker: NA
Text: celebration. People open their doors and windows to welcome Lakshmi, the goddess of

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth, fortune and prosperity and ask her for blessings for a good year ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Sikh version of the festival, Bandi Chhor Divas, is held at the same time as Diwali

Speaker: NA
Text: commemorations and notes the release of the Guru Hargobind Ji and his arrival in Amritsar

Speaker: NA
Text: on the eve of Diwali in 1619. He was imprisoned by the Mogul emperor Jahangir and won his

Speaker: NA
Text: release with 52 fellow prisoners. When he arrived in Amritsar, the people lit up the whole city

Speaker: NA
Text: with candles and lamps. Bandi Chhor Divas is a time for family and is celebrated with feasts,

Speaker: NA
Text: gift giving and the lighting of homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Diwali also marks the end of the Hindu year. I attended Hindu New Year celebrations for

Speaker: NA
Text: 2074 and the festival of Annakut at BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir. The highlight of the

Speaker: NA
Text: festival is the offering of Annakut, a mountain of food traditionally arranged in tiers or steps

Speaker: NA
Text: in front of the altar, resulting in a spectacular display.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I particularly would like to acknowledge the people who organised the various Diwali

Speaker: NA
Text: celebrations I attended, including Mohit Kumar, the President of the Council of Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians, and Shubha and Aksheya Kumar from the India Club at Castle Hill where I did a

Speaker: NA
Text: famous bangara dance, which has gone viral, to the tune of Dil Ka Maamla Hai Dilbar. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me acknowledge the highly talented and very patient Mona Grover, my dance teacher. I also

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledge Professor Nihal Agar from the Hindu Council, where I spoke in Hindi, Harbir

Speaker: NA
Text: Bhatia from the Turramurra Gurudwara Sydney, where I participated in worship services and

Speaker: NA
Text: feasted on vegetarian food, and Darshan Desai from the BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir in

Speaker: NA
Text: Rosehill for Annakut, where I tried out my Gujarati. I appreciate the encouragement and

Speaker: NA
Text: support I have received from the community in Berowra and more broadly around the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. I wish all the people in the Indian-Australian community a very happy Diwali. May

Speaker: NA
Text: this Diwali bring joy and prosperity. Shubh Diwali. Dhanyavaad.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ballarat Electorate: Artober

Speaker: NA
Text: Ms CATHERINE KING (Ballarat) (10:12): Earlier this month I was given the wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to launch Artober in Daylesford, a beautiful town within my electorate of

Speaker: NA
Text: Ballarat. Since being launched in 2014, this arts program has stood as a centrepiece of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Daylesford region's busy arts calendar. The events of Artober are a truly unique opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to experience art in all of its forms and in different environments. Throughout Artober, you

Speaker: NA
Text: can not only attend large-scale events such as the Daylesford Art Show, which is still going

Speaker: NA
Text: strong in its 33rd year and showing many works from over 100 local artists, but also enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller experiences, such as visiting workshops, open studios or community events. It is hard

Speaker: NA
Text: to enter any of these sites, look at the work produced by some of the most talented within our

Speaker: NA
Text: community and emerge without having been inspired by their artistic creations. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: experiences like this that bring thousands back to Daylesford and this event each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: In just the short time I've been able to spend at Artober so far, I've been able to enjoy the

Speaker: NA
Text: works of Brian Nash and the words of Warren Maloney at their exhibition, Villages of

Speaker: NA
Text: Hepburn. These two men from the local area have been engaged in a project visiting the small

Speaker: NA
Text: towns and villages dotted around Hepburn to paint the landscapes and write down the stories

Speaker: NA
Text: of this wonderful place. For anybody who has had the joy of visiting this region, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: know just how beautiful it is. Brian and Warren have truly done these towns justice with their

Speaker: NA
Text: paintings and beautiful words.

Speaker: NA
Text: Once again, the Artober event is being run as a not-for-profit, meaning that not only do

Speaker: NA
Text: visitors get to enjoy the works on display but we can do so knowing that all funds raised will

Speaker: NA
Text: support the region, the community and beyond. We know that it is events like this which

Speaker: NA
Text: bring together our local artists in a cooperative effort that ensures regional artistic

Speaker: NA
Text: communities both survive and thrive. I want to congratulate all of the artists who have been

Speaker: NA
Text: involved in Artober. I particularly acknowledge the work of the volunteers and the service

Speaker: NA
Text: community who put on the art show and have been doing so for a long period of time,

Speaker: NA
Text: ensuring its continuity. Daylesford and the Hepburn shire is an incredibly beautiful part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. I would encourage members to visit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Artober is nearly finished as we head out of the month of October, but I want to thank the

Speaker: NA
Text: artists, the volunteers and the organising committee for again putting on such a terrific event.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that tourism is a vital part of the economy in our part of the world, and certainly this

Speaker: NA
Text: event contributes substantially to the many, many suites of events that are available across the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: calendar year and makes sure that our economy continues to thrive both through the Hepburn

Speaker: NA
Text: shire and the Greater Region of Ballarat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Armistice Centenary

Speaker: Ms LEY
Text: Farrer) (10:15): As this will be my last opportunity to speak before

Speaker: NA
Text: Remembrance Day next month, I would like to pay tribute to the many community groups

Speaker: NA
Text: across my electorate of Farrer who go to so much effort to ensure this day is a special one in

Speaker: NA
Text: the calendar. From Wentworth to Walla Walla, Greater Hume to Griffith, Remembrance Day

Speaker: NA
Text: is attentively marked to ensure this and future generations remember the effort and sacrifice

Speaker: NA
Text: so that we can enjoy the freedoms that each of us experiences today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the red poppy has become synonymous with this day. During the First World

Speaker: NA
Text: War, red poppies were amongst the first plants to spring up in the devastated battlefields of

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern France and Belgium. The poppies soon became widely accepted throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: Allied nations as the flower of remembrance to be borne on Armistice Day. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: returned soldiers and sailors league first sold poppies for Armistice Day in 1921, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: continues today to raise funds for its vital welfare work. While this coming 11th of the 11th

Speaker: NA
Text: will be observed as solemnly as ever, the commemoration in 2018 strikes importantly on the

Speaker: NA
Text: 100th anniversary of Armistice Day. In fact, my father was born in 1918. He is turning 100

Speaker: NA
Text: next year. His two older brothers went to war and did not return.

Speaker: NA
Text: The call has gone out to knitters from around Australia to help create 60,000 poppies to

Speaker: NA
Text: carpet part of the grounds at the Australian War Memorial for those commemorations. Each

Speaker: NA
Text: poppy knitted will represent an Australian life lost in World War I, with the Great War

Speaker: NA
Text: remaining the costliest conflict to Australia in terms of deaths. One of my local CWAs at

Speaker: NA
Text: Jindera is taking on the challenge. The ladies at Jindera, led by my dear friend Mrs Helen

Speaker: NA
Text: Glachan, are already experienced in this field. Three years ago they knitted 2,000 poppies to

Speaker: NA
Text: adorn the local service at the start of the Anzac Centenary. Seven CWA members at Jindera

Speaker: NA
Text: want to make as much of a contribution as possible to that very important and symbolic scene

Speaker: NA
Text: that we will witness here next year in Canberra. With each poppy taking about an hour to

Speaker: NA
Text: assemble, this is no small effort, and I thank them in advance for their special efforts to

Speaker: NA
Text: remember the fallen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another way that communities can participate is through the Australian government's

Speaker: NA
Text: Armistice Centenary Grants Program. Applications for grants will open next month to support

Speaker: NA
Text: projects or activities in our region to commemorate the end of the war. To acknowledge this

Speaker: NA
Text: historic day, $7.5 million has been allocated through the Armistice Centenary Grants

Speaker: NA
Text: Program, allowing total funding of about $50,000 to each of Australia's federal electorates.

Speaker: NA
Text: One-off grants from $3,000 are available, and I encourage anyone in Farrer who wants to

Speaker: NA
Text: contribute to this significant moment in our nation's history to submit an expression of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: through my office.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aged Care

Speaker: Ms MCBRIDE
Text: Dobell) (10:18): It is our turn to care. Tony and his wife, Sheelagh,

Speaker: NA
Text: migrated to Australia from Liverpool, England, and raised three sons. When Sheelagh

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered a heart attack 17 years ago, Tony stopped work to care for her. A few years later, she

Speaker: NA
Text: was diagnosed with frontal lobe dementia. Tony managed as Sheelagh's health gradually

Speaker: NA
Text: deteriorated, but, when her leg was amputated two years ago, doctors advised that she should

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: move into an aged-care home. The fees and charges were complex and difficult to understand,

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving the family struggling to meet full-fee payments and missing out on a place for

Speaker: NA
Text: Sheelagh in the aged-care home of her choice. Despite the move being caused by the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: her leg, not dementia, Sheelagh was placed with other dementia patients, many very

Speaker: NA
Text: advanced. She became isolated and lonely. Tony said:

Speaker: NA
Text: In January last year we celebrated our golden wedding anniversary. I asked my wife what very

Speaker: NA
Text: special present I could give her. She replied, "Tony, please take me home".

Speaker: NA
Text: So he bought a hospital bed, lifter and commode, modified their home and Sheelagh came

Speaker: NA
Text: home. Tony had applied for in-home care, but the waitlist was long and it was many months

Speaker: NA
Text: before a package was finally approved. After a year Sheelagh's needs were beyond home care,

Speaker: NA
Text: and she moved permanently into an aged care home, but an administrative bungle by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Human Services, which lost her income and asset assessment, meant a delay of

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 weeks and financial strain for Tony. At each step in the process the government failed to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the support and dignity we expect for Tony and Sheelagh. This system is broken. It

Speaker: NA
Text: needs to be fixed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last week the Health Services Union launched their Our Turn to Care campaign in Lake

Speaker: NA
Text: Haven in my electorate. Their survey of aged care workers showed that 58 per cent believed

Speaker: NA
Text: they were unable to provide the care their residents deserved and they wanted to give. Eighty-

Speaker: NA
Text: one per cent blamed short staffing. People like Sheelagh and Tony can't receive the care they

Speaker: NA
Text: deserve until there are enough staff to care for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: The increasing demand for aged care is driven largely by our ageing population and the

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing prevalence of dementia. Over the next eight years an extra 55,000 aged care

Speaker: NA
Text: workers are needed to keep up with demand. Aged care workers are dedicated, but many burn

Speaker: NA
Text: out due to high workloads and low wages. This, combined with poor resourcing of My Age

Speaker: NA
Text: Care and an alarming lack of in-home services, is hurting older people when they are most at

Speaker: NA
Text: risk. The aged care system should support decent care for older Australians, but as Marta,

Speaker: NA
Text: who came to Australia in 1983 from Chile, told members at the HSU launch last week, 'I love

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. This is my home, but I didn't think Australia would treat their elderly like this.'

Speaker: NA
Text: Illicit Drugs

Speaker: Mr LITTLEPROUD
Text: Maranoa) (10:21): I rise to bring attention to the scourge of drug

Speaker: NA
Text: addiction, particularly in rural and remote communities like those I represent in the electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Maranoa, which covers nearly 43 per cent of the state of Queensland. Recently I held a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of ice forums, because I became increasingly aware of the concerns of citizens across

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate about the impact the drug ice was having. In these small communities in the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate of Maranoa the effects are far more visible than they are in metropolitan areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: They tear away at the very fabric of that community because it is so prevalent. You see the

Speaker: NA
Text: pain and anguish of those families. I have to admit that before I became the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Maranoa I was ignorant of the effects of drugs on families and individuals. It wasn't until I sat

Speaker: NA
Text: and listened to the harrowing stories of some of the families and the addicts themselves about

Speaker: NA
Text: the impact it has had on their lives and the way it has destroyed families, destroyed their

Speaker: NA
Text: financial status and destroyed these communities. It took a toll on me and made me realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that we had to take action.

Speaker: NA
Text: This government proudly put in place $300 million for tackling ice, but it became apparent

Speaker: NA
Text: to me, as the local member, that we needed to make sure that those funds were put at a

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: grassroots level and that it was actually impacting those people not just in larger metropolitan

Speaker: NA
Text: areas but also in those smaller communities. As I heard when I went around having these ice

Speaker: NA
Text: forums across rural and regional Australia, there is a small window of opportunity when

Speaker: NA
Text: people reach out for help, and unless there's someone there to grab them in that hour of need,

Speaker: NA
Text: invariably they fall back into their old ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: It became apparent that we were being underrepresented in terms of clinical workers on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ground. I am proud to say that as a result of these ice forums that we've had we now have, for

Speaker: NA
Text: the first time, a clinical worker in Chinchilla, a community of nearly 4,000 to 5,000 people.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the first time we have someone in Kingaroy. We are bolstering services in Kingaroy as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as Dalby, Goondiwindi and Warwick, and for the first time in Roma and now St George.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only in the last couple of weeks you would have heard of the raids by the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Police Service, where they laid charges on 44 people. There were 214-odd charges laid

Speaker: NA
Text: against these people in that community and I have to congratulate the Queensland Police

Speaker: NA
Text: Service, Detective Inspector Paul Hart and the local St George police, Senior Sergeant Paul

Speaker: NA
Text: Tabrett and liaison officer Adam Osborne. They are true country coppers who care about their

Speaker: NA
Text: community, making it a better place and not walking past anything they would not accept.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are true people that care about their community and about making a difference to the

Speaker: NA
Text: lives of the young people in that community, so that they will have a way forward and can

Speaker: NA
Text: live in a community with safety and pride. Members, I implore you all to tackle this together

Speaker: NA
Text: as a community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Workplace Relations

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: Bendigo) (10:24): It's been a big 24 to 48 hours in the workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: relations area in regards to the Registered Organisations Commission, or 'ROC', as it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: nicknamed, and in regards to the Minister for Employment. It may come as a surprise to

Speaker: NA
Text: people if they have been fixated on Senate estimates that there also has been a break in the

Speaker: NA
Text: case with the locked-out Tieri miners. They have been locked out now for 112 days and

Speaker: NA
Text: counting. Many people in this place have stood up and criticised the Oaky North coalminers

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been locked out of their workplace. They have said many things in this place which

Speaker: NA
Text: have since been found to be untrue, but what they have not done is come in here and criticise

Speaker: NA
Text: Glencore, although on Monday the Fair Work Commission actually found, as an AFR article

Speaker: NA
Text: reports:

Speaker: NA
Text: … Glencore had breached the good faith bargaining requirements of the Fair Work Act by operating a

Speaker: NA
Text: "… quasi military" surveillance project, by delivering 26 workers disciplinary notices for alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: misbehaviour on picket lines and on social media, and by forcing union members to change their

Speaker: NA
Text: normal workwear to ensure that the union logo was not worn at the mine.

Speaker: NA
Text: The commission 'slapped down' Glencore for engaging quasi-military security-because they

Speaker: NA
Text: had been following their workers outside of work hours. They had been surveilling them in

Speaker: NA
Text: their homes. They had been surveilling them when they dropped their children off to school.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tieri is a small mining town, and people notice when a quasi-military group is taking photos

Speaker: NA
Text: of their neighbours. We haven't yet seen anybody on the government side slap down Glencore

Speaker: NA
Text: for their behaviour. All we have seen, all we continue to see, from this government are

Speaker: NA
Text: repeated attacks on workers and repeated attacks on union members.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are other questions that this government still needs to answer. Will the immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: minister say no to INPEX? They want to bring in foreign workers to work on our offshore gas

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities. The AWU, again, are saying, 'We have unemployed workers willing to do that

Speaker: NA
Text: work.' Will the immigration minister stand by those workers and ensure that Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: workers get those jobs first? We also have another case where the CFMEU has had a win

Speaker: NA
Text: against-

Speaker: NA
Text: Proceedings suspended from 10:27 to 10:40

Speaker: Ms CHESTERS
Text: In conclusion, earlier this month the Fair Work Ombudsman proved

Speaker: NA
Text: that 457 visa workers in this country have been unlawfully discriminated against because of

Speaker: NA
Text: their nationality and race. There are serious issues going on in Australian workplaces and with

Speaker: NA
Text: employers. This government is not doing enough to crack down on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Groom Electorate: Family Week

Speaker: Dr MCVEIGH
Text: Groom) (10:40): In late 2005 a number of business and community

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders met with the goal of developing and promoting Toowoomba as a caring and

Speaker: NA
Text: supportive environment for families. Out of this meeting an organisation called Toowoomba

Speaker: NA
Text: Supports Families was formed. The Family Week activity is an initiative of theirs, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: main strategy of promoting the Toowoomba region as a great place for families to live. Its

Speaker: NA
Text: goals include businesses, clubs and individuals organising initiatives, activities and other

Speaker: NA
Text: events which recognise the importance of families in our region as the basis of our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. It's about celebrating all of the wonderful qualities that make families special and

Speaker: NA
Text: helping to support and strengthen families on the Darling Downs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Over the years, Family Week has enjoyed amazing support from the Toowoomba

Speaker: NA
Text: community, with thousands of people participating in activities and events right across our

Speaker: NA
Text: city. Participants include: leading business people; community organisations; leaders at local,

Speaker: NA
Text: state and federal government levels over the years; faith community leaders; and, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: our mayor, Paul Antonio, in particular. The support this activity receives right throughout our

Speaker: NA
Text: community, particularly from these leaders, is magnificent. Just this morning there was an

Speaker: NA
Text: official Family Week breakfast, which attracted 150 family groups and leaders to the

Speaker: NA
Text: University of Southern Queensland's refectory to hear a number of speakers on the topic of

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Family as the basis of our society'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Week is very much about celebrating family, obviously, and building community

Speaker: NA
Text: through that focus. Being a part of Family Week has been so easy for may people over the

Speaker: NA
Text: years in Toowoomba: inviting friends, family members or neighbours over for barbecues and

Speaker: NA
Text: so forth, or organising for those at work to enjoy picnics and other family based activities in

Speaker: NA
Text: workplaces right across our city. School fetes and the Come to the Table event are other ways

Speaker: NA
Text: for students and families to attend Family Week, and for community to be developed. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: early childhood centres use Family Week as a great opportunity to celebrate families in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community, and that is certainly a feature of the activity.

Speaker: NA
Text: This week recognises that every generation has a role in building this community

Speaker: NA
Text: activity-young and old. For many people as they age, life can become isolating. Helping a

Speaker: NA
Text: neighbour, inviting them over for a cuppa or lending a hand can make such a difference and

Speaker: NA
Text: build that sense of community for everyone. This week runs from 21 October to 29 October,

Speaker: NA
Text: so we're right in the middle of it. I applaud those behind Family Week in Toowoomba. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the most recognised family-friendly cities in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: BILLS

Speaker: NA
