Text: Australian Grape and Wine Authority Amendment (Wine Australia) Bill 2017

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr HART
Text: Bass) (10:44): The intent of the Australian Grape and Wine Authority

Speaker: NA
Text: Amendment (Wine Australia) Bill 2017 is to mitigate some of the unfortunate consequences

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Turnbull government's decision to reduce the wine equalisation tax-the WET-rebate

Speaker: NA
Text: in their 2016 budget. In the 2016 budget, the Turnbull government announced two major

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the WET: the reduction of the rebate cap from $500,000 to $350,000 and a

Speaker: NA
Text: declaration that only wine producers with a financial interest in a winery can claim the rebate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reformation of the WET was long overdue. There was evidence that the system was being

Speaker: NA
Text: rorted by bulk and unbranded operators and creative entity structuring in order to access the

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate. The Winemakers' Federation of Australia said that it was compromised on three fronts:

Speaker: NA
Text: firstly, the ability of brokers, intermediaries and uncommercial arrangements to access the

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement; secondly, the role of the rebate in delaying the correction of the supply and

Speaker: NA
Text: demand imbalance by underpinning the conversion of uncommercial grapes into bulk wine

Speaker: NA
Text: and ultimately low-equity cleanskins and home brands; and thirdly, the ability of New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand entities to access the entitlement on unfair preferential terms.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reducing the perceived rorting of the WET rebate is something that certainly required

Speaker: NA
Text: attention. Unfortunately for the industry, the Turnbull government also saw it as an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for a revenue grab-a tax grab that has hit the bottom line of winemakers very

Speaker: NA
Text: hard. The government initially planned to pocket $300 million from the first reform proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: that was put forward. Following significant industry backlash and expressions of concern

Speaker: NA
Text: from Labor, the government backed down and went back to the drawing board. This

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation is the result. The government still plans to pocket $160 million as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms and the implementation of this industry support package.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill does a number of things. Firstly, it will formally change the name of the authority

Speaker: NA
Text: previously responsible for industry regulation, the Australian Grape and Wine Authority, to

Speaker: NA
Text: Wine Australia. It will also enable Wine Australia to implement all program activities under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Export and Regional Wine Support Package, including for the purposes of cider and

Speaker: NA
Text: international wine tourism. It will enable Wine Australia to administer grant programs for

Speaker: NA
Text: wine, including the cellar door grant. The grant programs are necessary to enable transition

Speaker: NA
Text: for wine, including from the previous scheme, but those programs may not be enough for

Speaker: NA
Text: transition. The wine support package and the cellar door grant were announced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: government in an attempt to allay fears from the industry to assist them in transitioning to

Speaker: NA
Text: their reforms of the WET. The wine support package will allocate $50 million for an export

Speaker: NA
Text: and regional wine support package. The program will allow entities with below $20 million

Speaker: NA
Text: annual turnover to claim 50 per cent of their promotional activities up to a cap of $50,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: This fund unfortunately is limited, and the money will be allocated on a first-in best-

Speaker: NA
Text: dressed basis. It is also limited to marketing promotion in China, Hong Kong, Macau and the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States. There will be $10 million allocated for a wine tourism and cellar door program.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a cash grant program allocated in part on the amount of sales at the cellar door. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: also capped and, if oversubscribed, every successful applicant's grant will be reduced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion necessary to bring all applicants under the cap.

Speaker: NA
Text: This WET legislation is of particular significance to my home state of Tasmania. I consider

Speaker: NA
Text: myself most fortunate not only to live in my electorate of Bass but also to represent an area of

Speaker: NA
Text: northern Tasmania that has a focus on wine, food and tourism. The Tasmanian wine industry

Speaker: NA
Text: is unique within Australia; 100 per cent of the product is premium product. That attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: detail-that focus on premium product-and the cellar door experience have also infected or

Speaker: NA
Text: transferred to the craft beer industry. I know there is a real and sensible link between the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of craft beer and tourism, but I think most people concede that the cellar door

Speaker: NA
Text: experience, particularly a cellar door experience in Tasmania, provided much of the

Speaker: NA
Text: inspiration for the potential represented by craft beer.

Speaker: NA
Text: My electorate is blessed with some of the best sparkling wine in Australia, if not some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the best sparkling wine in the world, potentially. This has been recognised by some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: oldest producers of sparkling wine in Europe, who have chosen to establish or acquire

Speaker: NA
Text: vineyards in northern Tasmania. The acclaim for Tasmanian wine is widespread. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, James Halliday, in the 2014 Australian Wine Companion, said that the best

Speaker: NA
Text: sparkling wines are now predominantly sourced from Tasmania. Anthony Rose, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Independent, from the United Kingdom, said that Tasmania is rapidly becoming Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: 'little Champagne'. Nevertheless, most of the producers within Tasmania are small producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the largest Australian wine producers do operate within Tasmania, but all of their

Speaker: NA
Text: product that is grown within Tasmania is premium product.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst Labor recognises and supports the necessity for amendments within this legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly the changes made to the WET, it is very important, particularly for the premium

Speaker: NA
Text: producers of wine within my home state of Tasmania, to acknowledge and recognise that a

Speaker: NA
Text: disproportionate burden is imposed on the small premium producers as a consequence of this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. Eighty per cent of Tasmanian product derives from approximately 20 producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The small producers in particular, as I said, will be hit very hard. There is a disproportionate

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of a reduction of the rebate for a small producer. While it might be the case that a very

Speaker: NA
Text: large producer of wine can absorb the reduction in rebate, notwithstanding that there is some

Speaker: NA
Text: financial effect across the whole industry, it is obvious, as a matter of financial necessity, that

Speaker: NA
Text: a small producer will be disproportionately disaffected.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the government seeks to ameliorate the effect of the reduction of assistance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction of these grants programs, this in turn requires the parliament to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: government on trust that the grants program will be effectively run with the stated aim of

Speaker: NA
Text: supporting regional producers. These programs need to be well designed and money must be

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated on a merits basis. Labor will be watching this process closely.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can tell you that there has been considerable disquiet in the industry as a result of this

Speaker: NA
Text: process. Quite appropriately, the industry has asked whether the elements of this package

Speaker: NA
Text: align with the strategic focus of Wine Australia. That question has yet to be answered. The

Speaker: NA
Text: peak representative wine bodies within the states of South Australia, New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania, Victoria and Western Australia have submitted a joint response to the draft grant

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines. The organisations have been actively involved in discussions and consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding the changes and are very keen to ensure that the grants programs are successful and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that they support the long-term repositioning of their members in the Australian wine sector

Speaker: NA
Text: more broadly. This is essential for the premium wine industry of Tasmania.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cellar door and wine tourism grants are good in principle. However, the state wine

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations are very concerned about the impact of the proposed grant processes on

Speaker: NA
Text: organisational cash flow and the overall profitability of wine businesses. The potential impact

Speaker: NA
Text: on a wine business is that it would lose up to $150,000 from the bottom line immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: following the rebate reduction in 2018-19; yet it will not be able to access any additional top-

Speaker: NA
Text: up grant of $100,000 until November 2019. That is, of course, assuming the administration of

Speaker: NA
Text: the grant program will be effective and efficient.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to this, there is uncertainty over the potential for over-subscription, which must

Speaker: NA
Text: create additional pressure on financial planning and performance of the small businesses. Put

Speaker: NA
Text: another way, the grant programs which are designed to support regional producers need to

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the potential effect of the withdrawal or reduction of the rebate and the potential

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties in replacing at least a portion of that funding through the grant program. Again,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Export and Regional Wine Support Package is good in principle, but, as a response to the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial effect of the reduction of the rebate, the effect is still to be determined. The intention

Speaker: NA
Text: is that this will be restricted, and the competitive grants program is designed to support a

Speaker: NA
Text: collaborative, strategic approach towards attracting and maximising international wine

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism.

Speaker: NA
Text: The various state wine organisations have specific strategies and priorities which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: developed in partnership with their respective members and, I understand, the regional

Speaker: NA
Text: associations. The state wine associations may be in the best position to determine what will be

Speaker: NA
Text: the appropriate activities to support their members in their regions, particularly where these

Speaker: NA
Text: regions are negatively impacted by these and other changes. It is obvious, therefore, that any

Speaker: NA
Text: grant oversight and/or assessment process, to be effective and responsive, will need to have

Speaker: NA
Text: very good and clear insight into the views of the state wine organisations. The various state

Speaker: NA
Text: wine organisations are not-for-profit and are supported, in the main, by wine producers. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence there may be difficulty with the proposed co-contributions which are proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: within the draft grant guidelines. I urge the government to work with the state wine

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations to ensure that the state wine organisations are able to access the funds which are

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to support their members for trade and tourism outcomes which are for the benefit of

Speaker: NA
Text: the wider industry and, of course, our regional communities. The proposed wine export grants

Speaker: NA
Text: are likely to be very quickly exhausted, according to industry feedback. It will be most

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate that the government put in place real-time updates with respect to approved and

Speaker: NA
Text: pending applications so that the individual businesses can determine whether it's appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: or not to submit a particular application.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I indicated earlier, Tasmania produces high-value wines, and when sold domestically

Speaker: NA
Text: they are taxed on their value at 29 per cent. The change to the WET rebate disproportionately

Speaker: NA
Text: affects Tasmania's wine producers, dominated by small premium producers. The state's wine

Speaker: NA
Text: industry has projected that production could triple over the next five years. I've been speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: with producers in my electorate who have had to question decisions on expansion and hiring

Speaker: NA
Text: plans as a direct consequence of this government's decision. The small to medium wineries, as

Speaker: NA
Text: I indicated earlier, will be most impacted by this. Rebecca and Tim from Holm Oak

Speaker: NA
Text: Vineyards in the Tamar Valley have put their expansion plans on hold. Shane and Fran from

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Delamere Vineyards, who have six full-time staff, have raised a number of concerns with

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to maintaining their current staffing levels.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania is proactive in marketing itself as a place to invest in the wine industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly at the premium end. My home state enjoys and celebrates a national and

Speaker: NA
Text: international reputation as a leading producer of premium cool climate wines. The state

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently wins high praise, not to mention an array of medals from wine judges and critics

Speaker: NA
Text: alike. Industry and government need to work together to facilitate the expansion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and further develop our reputation in wine and food tourism. The industry is seen as

Speaker: NA
Text: a priority sector with excellent growth prospects. Successive Tasmanian governments have

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently argued the case for securing value-added investment within the state.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation measures, like these taxation measures, often affect behaviour of consumers and

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses, and these measures are no different. The initial proposal for the reduction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate was, quite correctly, rejected. The two funds created as part of the rebate reforms-the

Speaker: NA
Text: $50 million Export and Regional Wine Support Package and the $10 million Wine Tourism

Speaker: NA
Text: and Cellar Door Grant program-are both necessary and appropriate. Labor supports them. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is, nevertheless, essential that the government does the hard work, in consultation with the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry at the national and state levels, to ensure that the administration of the grant program

Speaker: NA
Text: is effective. This is necessary to ensure that those who are disproportionately affected by the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes to the rebate receive appropriate assistance in transitioning to the new regime.

Speaker: NA
Text: The premium wine industry in my state of Tasmania is now part of the identity of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania. It has built a well-deserved reputation for excellence and innovation. The small

Speaker: NA
Text: producers need to have their voices heard through the state-based wine organisation-in this

Speaker: NA
Text: case, Wine Tasmania-and their interstate counterparts. It is also most important that the

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic focus of the grant program is aligned with the strategic focus of Wine Australia so

Speaker: NA
Text: that there is no inconsistency between the application of funds and the strategic interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry as a whole.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is very important legislation, particularly as it affects my home state. As I've said on a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of occasions, we have a predominantly premium based industry made up of small

Speaker: NA
Text: wine producers. Those small wine producers need an effective transition program. The

Speaker: NA
Text: transition program might not be so effective if those grant programs are not administered

Speaker: NA
Text: correctly. The government must continue to talk to the wine industry organisations at both

Speaker: NA
Text: state and national levels. It's essential for the reputation of Wine Australia that these programs

Speaker: NA
Text: are effective in transitioning to the new WET regime. This industry is too important in my

Speaker: NA
Text: home state to fail. It is a focus of industry expansion for the future. These taxation measures

Speaker: NA
Text: can't put any limitation on those expansions.

Speaker: Ms BRODTMANN
Text: Canberra) (10:58): I welcome this opportunity to speak on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Grape and Wine Authority Amendment (Wine Australia) Bill 2017. The bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: enable the authority to implement all program activities under the wine support package; it

Speaker: NA
Text: will enable the authority to administer grant programs for wine, including the cellar door

Speaker: NA
Text: grant; and it will change the name of the authority from the Australian Grape and Wine

Speaker: NA
Text: Authority to Wine Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I've got a significant interest in wine, not just because I like to imbibe it but also because

Speaker: NA
Text: my sister is an internationally renowned winemaker-she is Australia's first female Master of

Speaker: NA
Text: Wine-and there are fabulous wineries in the capital region around Canberra. Now, it's a

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively young wine industry. While South Australia and Victoria were already established

Speaker: NA
Text: as wine regions by the end of the 1800s, Canberra had a few small, fairly unremarkable

Speaker: NA
Text: vineyards planted near Yass. Our fortunes changed when we had the great honour of our

Speaker: NA
Text: CSIRO scientists and other academics getting involved in the local wine industry. Dr Edgar

Speaker: NA
Text: Riek, a pioneer of the region, planted vineyards in 1971. He had a distinguished academic

Speaker: NA
Text: background, as many of the founders in the capital region wine district had, and he saw the

Speaker: NA
Text: potential in the region as a premium wine-growing area. He started the Canberra District

Speaker: NA
Text: Vignerons Association and instigated the National Wine Show, which is arguably the

Speaker: NA
Text: country's most important wine show.

Speaker: NA
Text: After Riek's initial plantings at Lake George in the early 1970s, others soon followed.

Speaker: NA
Text: International award-winning scientist John Kirk established Clonakilla in 1971. Ken and

Speaker: NA
Text: Judith Helm started their vineyard and winery in 1973-the famous Helm Wines. Like Kirk

Speaker: NA
Text: and Edgar Riek, Ken Helm has been instrumental in putting Canberra district, capital region,

Speaker: NA
Text: wines on the map with the cool-climate international riesling challenge that he conducts every

Speaker: NA
Text: year. It draws hundreds of people from all around the country and also from all around the

Speaker: NA
Text: world to the Canberra region. It is a very prestigious competition. Ken Helm has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: driving force behind it. We have a cool climate here, and we specialise in cool-climate wines.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is why Ken Helm has been a major driver of the riesling challenge and cool-climate

Speaker: NA
Text: wines more generally.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1978, Sue and Dave Carpenter planted vines at Lark Hill winery at Bungendore. A

Speaker: NA
Text: decade later, Mount Majura's first vines were planted. In 1997, inspired by Riek, Jim Lumbers

Speaker: NA
Text: established Lerida Estate at Lake George, adjacent to Riek's original vineyard. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: many other winemakers in Canberra who are now producing wines. Bryan Martin, who was

Speaker: NA
Text: an assistant winemaker at Clonakilla estate, has used his expertise to establish Ravensworth at

Speaker: NA
Text: Mawson. Microwinery Eden Road shot to fame in 2009, winning the Jimmy Watson Trophy

Speaker: NA
Text: for its 2008 Hilltops Shiraz and the Best New Winery at the inaugural Sydney Morning

Speaker: NA
Text: Herald's Good Wine awards in 2010. Guiding Eden Road wines is winemaker Nick Spencer.

Speaker: NA
Text: As many here in the chamber would know, Nobel Laureate and Vice-Chancellor of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian National University-none other than Professor Brian Schmidt-has established

Speaker: NA
Text: his vineyard, Maipenrai, at Sutton. His pinot noir has wowed the fans. Mount Majura was

Speaker: NA
Text: established in 1991 by winemaker Frank van de Loo, who has also been producing award-

Speaker: NA
Text: winning wines, particularly chardonnays, ever since.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, Canberra is well-known now around the world for producing internationally-

Speaker: NA
Text: renowned, award-winning wines-award-winning cool-climate wines. We are very proud of

Speaker: NA
Text: the winemakers here in the capital region. It is yet another reason to come to Canberra. As we

Speaker: NA
Text: heard this week, there are many reasons to come to Canberra. I've always known that

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra is the best place in the world. I've always known that it is the best place in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to visit. We had that confirmed this week with Lonely Planet's Best in Travel 2018

Speaker: NA
Text: nominating Canberra as one of the top three cities to visit in the world in 2018. I am not

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that it should be limited to 2018. I am saying: come on down to Canberra any year,

Speaker: NA
Text: because it is the best place in the world. Unfortunately, we came behind Seville and Detroit.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my view, we should have been ranked No. 1. That said, this ranking is the highest that has

Speaker: NA
Text: ever been achieved by an Australian city.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Lonely Planet's travel experts compile the top cities list based on strict criteria including

Speaker: NA
Text: topicality, excitement, X factor and unique experiences. For Canberra, next year is such a

Speaker: NA
Text: unique and exciting year, and the events our city will host include the 100th anniversary of

Speaker: NA
Text: the World War I Armistice, at the Australian War Memorial, which will be an extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: commemoration; and the first cricket test match at Manuka Oval. Both of these venues are in

Speaker: NA
Text: my wonderful electorate of Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: We're claiming to be one of the coolest little capitals, and we are the coolest little capital

Speaker: NA
Text: because we offer a rich history; amazing world-leading design elements that are based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: principles of democracy, transparency and openness; culture and entertainment; world-class

Speaker: NA
Text: national institutions; and something for every type of traveller. The Lonely Planet website

Speaker: NA
Text: rightfully states that Canberra is 'criminally overlooked' and 'packs a punch' for the small city

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are.

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra boasts expansive open spaces, as we know, with those huge, gorgeous skies that

Speaker: NA
Text: are blue and beautiful even when it is about minus 10 degrees. Unlike other cities where it's

Speaker: NA
Text: grey in summer and grey in winter, it is blue sky for a lot of the time here in Canberra, even in

Speaker: NA
Text: winter. So we have these beautiful open spaces overlooking the Brindabellas, the ranges that

Speaker: NA
Text: you can see from every corner of our wonderful city. We have popular attractions, including

Speaker: NA
Text: this very building-this beautiful, iconic, Giurgola-designed building. We've got Questacon,

Speaker: NA
Text: Floriade and the Old Bus Depot Markets. The list goes on and on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Countless new and modern places to eat and drink have followed the revitalisation of areas

Speaker: NA
Text: like Braddon and New Acton, and these suburbs add to the establishment of our hip and

Speaker: NA
Text: contemporary style. As we are talking about imbibing, I just want to mention we also are

Speaker: NA
Text: home to craft beers BentSpoke, Pact, Capital and Tortured Gum; craft beer taverns and

Speaker: NA
Text: breweries, as in the Wig & Pen; and craft gins and spirits, with Underground Spirits and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra Distillery. Most of these breweries and distilleries are in my electorate. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: give a shout-out to BentSpoke, who recently made it into the top 10 of GABS Hottest 100

Speaker: NA
Text: Aussie Craft Beers. There is also Zierholz, in Fyshwick.

Speaker: NA
Text: This announcement by Lonely Planet adds further hopes of connecting Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: internationally and encouraging tourists to visit Canberra, our nation's capital, which has so

Speaker: NA
Text: much to offer. Like all Canberrans, I cannot wait to welcome the world to our fabulous

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's capital.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, as I mentioned earlier in my speech, my sister Meg is Australia's first female

Speaker: NA
Text: Master of Wine, an extraordinary achievement and one of which I am very proud. She's a

Speaker: NA
Text: winemaker who has travelled all around the world for the last 25 years, since she graduated

Speaker: NA
Text: with her degree from Roseworthy. She brought to my attention, when she was here just

Speaker: NA
Text: recently, the significant challenges that women in the wine industry still face. We know that

Speaker: NA
Text: women are increasingly moving into the wine industry. Women make up 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: winemaking and viticulture graduates, but women comprise only 10 per cent of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: wine industry workforce. So, even though 50 per cent of the graduates in this area are women,

Speaker: NA
Text: women are only 10 per cent of the workforce. With Australian wine exports now topping $2.3

Speaker: NA
Text: billion, at June 2017, and the wine industry providing a major source of employment,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in regional and rural Australia, this is simply unacceptable.

Speaker: NA
Text: A survey of women in the wine industry by wine identity Jane Thomson last year revealed

Speaker: NA
Text: that 42 per cent of women knew or believed they were being paid less than their male

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: counterparts. Two-thirds of women replied that they'd experienced sexist behaviour in the

Speaker: NA
Text: workplace, and one in four women had endured unfair treatment in regards to pregnancy, sick

Speaker: NA
Text: children or maternity leave. A quarter of the respondents believed that they did not have equal

Speaker: NA
Text: career opportunities in their workplaces. I know that my sister Meg and a number of women

Speaker: NA
Text: are getting together now to bring these shocking statistics to people's attention-because they

Speaker: NA
Text: are quite shocking, given the fact that women make up 50 per cent of graduates in this area

Speaker: NA
Text: but only 10 per cent of the actual wine industry workforce.

Speaker: NA
Text: The wine industry has to change. That starts with shining a light on the lack of diversity.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why this survey Jane Thomson has conducted is especially useful. We need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: asking the questions: why is female representation so much better overseas than in Australia?

Speaker: NA
Text: Why the lack of national and international recognition and exposure of Australian female

Speaker: NA
Text: winemakers? Why is there no critical mass of women on wine-judging panels? Why the

Speaker: NA
Text: dramatic attrition rate? We are talking about this extraordinary attrition rate just from

Speaker: NA
Text: graduation. Why the limited career paths? Why the perception that winemaking is a male

Speaker: NA
Text: industry?

Speaker: NA
Text: We need to institute change, and that's why I welcome the Australian Women in Wine

Speaker: NA
Text: Awards that were held last month at Australia House in London. I commend the women who

Speaker: NA
Text: took out those awards. I'll just quickly run through a few of them. Winemaker of the Year was

Speaker: NA
Text: Virginia Willcock from Vasse Felix. Viticulturist of the Year was Jennifer Doyle from Jansz.

Speaker: NA
Text: Owner/Operator of the Year was Sarah Collingwood from Four Winds Vineyard. Workplace

Speaker: NA
Text: Champion of Change was Professor Eileen Scott from the University of Adelaide. Cellar

Speaker: NA
Text: Door Person of the Year was Jasmine Morgan from Caudo Vineyards. Researcher of the Year

Speaker: NA
Text: was Dr Christine Bottcher from CSIRO. Marketer of the Year was Ebony Tinkler from Usher

Speaker: NA
Text: Tinkler Wines.

Speaker: NA
Text: These awards are a great way of shining a light on the achievements of female winemakers

Speaker: NA
Text: from Australia and on the fact that so many women are going overseas. We have got a huge

Speaker: NA
Text: brain drain in female talent here, because the opportunities and exposure just aren't here. The

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledgement is just not here. That is why it is important that the Australian Women in

Speaker: NA
Text: Wine Awards are highlighting these achievements and focusing attention on the issue of the

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of diversity in this industry and the fact that we have so many women leaving Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to go and work overseas. My sister was a classic example. As I said, she spent most of her

Speaker: NA
Text: early career working in France, Germany, South America, the UK and Eastern Europe. That

Speaker: NA
Text: was because the opportunities, particularly as a young graduate, just weren't there. She

Speaker: NA
Text: became what is known as a 'flying winemaker'. These awards are fantastic. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledging the achievements of Australian winemakers. It is unfortunate they actually

Speaker: NA
Text: have to take place overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: But what is happening at the domestic level also needs to be acknowledged. My sister has

Speaker: NA
Text: joined with a number of women from the Yarra Valley wine area to set up Yarra Valley Wine

Speaker: NA
Text: Women. Again, it is designed to highlight the achievements of women in this area. We've got

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 150 wine brands, 85 cellar doors and 65 wine production facilities. Within this pool

Speaker: NA
Text: is a group of women winemakers challenging the statistics of the industry average.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fortunately, there seems to be a critical mass there. This group manage 12 per cent of those

Speaker: NA
Text: 150 wine brands and have a collective 200 years experience in the industry. I say to those in

Speaker: NA
Text: the wine industry: I am watching, I will be calling this out and I will be shining a light on this

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: issue. This is not the last conversation I will be having about the lack of diversity in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian wine industry.

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Text: Cowper-Assistant Minister to the Deputy Prime Minister) (11:13):

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Grape and Wine Authority Amendment (Wine Australia) Bill 2017 amends

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Grape and Wine Authority Act 2013 to facilitate wine and cider tourism and

Speaker: NA
Text: cellar door development activities. These amendments are part of the reforms to the wine

Speaker: NA
Text: equalisation tax, WET, to bring greater integrity to the WET debate. As part of these reforms,

Speaker: NA
Text: the government is investing in a $50 million Export and Regional Wine Support Package and

Speaker: NA
Text: a $10 million investment in the Wine Tourism and Cellar Door Grant scheme. These were

Speaker: NA
Text: changes originally driven by industry. The government has consulted extensively with the

Speaker: NA
Text: wine and cider industries through the national and state wine associations on the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of the WET rebate reforms, the wine support package and the cellar door grant scheme.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill enables the authority to administer and fund all aspects of the wine support

Speaker: NA
Text: package and the cellar door grant scheme. The bill will also enable industry to refocus greater

Speaker: NA
Text: attention on the export and tourism markets, both internationally and domestically, through

Speaker: NA
Text: cellar door sales, which offer it the greatest opportunity for growth and sustainability. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: also changes the name of the authority from the Australian Grape and Wine Authority to

Speaker: NA
Text: Wine Australia. The bill is important to industry and it is important that the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: supports the industry in its endeavours to increase wine exports and international wine

Speaker: NA
Text: tourism.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fisheries Legislation Amendment (Representation) Bill 2017

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr HOWARTH
Text: Petrie) (11:16): It is great to rise today to speak on the Fisheries

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Representation) Bill 2017, because I have great childhood memories

Speaker: NA
Text: when it comes to fishing. Growing up in the northern outskirts of Brisbane on the doorstep of

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreton Bay, my father, Ron, would often take me out fishing. He developed a love of

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing in me from a very young age. My father had an eight-foot punt and a 12-foot punt

Speaker: NA
Text: with small engines on the back, so we had flat-bottom boats. We would often get up Saltwater

Speaker: NA
Text: Creek, the Pine River, Cabbage Tree Creek and Nundah Creek. We would go mudcrabbing

Speaker: NA
Text: and fishing for bream and flathead-great childhood memories. Sometimes we would get out

Speaker: NA
Text: the front around Scarborough reef, or out in Bramble Bay and around Woody Point.

Speaker: NA
Text: One day, when I was about 12, we went out and caught a massive flathead of about 70

Speaker: NA
Text: centimetres-this was before you let them go; this was when there were plenty of them

Speaker: NA
Text: around-a stingray, a grey nurse shark, which we let go, and a whole lot of whiting. Great

Speaker: NA
Text: childhood memories. We would come home and have a bit of a feed. I love eating seafood.

Speaker: NA
Text: We would also camp up on the banks of Saltwater Creek, which is now all a state green zone

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow crabs and fish to breed up and repopulate. We would camp up there and go crabbing

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: for a couple of days. Great childhood memories. As a father of three boys myself, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: important to me that my sons can also enjoy fishing when they choose, as they get older.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aussies are a nation of seafood lovers. We consume some 14 kilos of seafood every year.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is below red meat, which is about 31 kilos, and chicken, which is 21 kilos, but I think we

Speaker: NA
Text: would eat more seafood if there was more of it and it was a little bit cheaper. Seafood,

Speaker: NA
Text: generally, is health for you. Fish is. It is a good thing to eat. Throwing another shrimp on the

Speaker: NA
Text: barbie is not only a part of our national identity but an important part of our economy, too,

Speaker: NA
Text: even though that phrase was used for a tourism campaign in America. We call them prawns

Speaker: NA
Text: here. Currently in Australia, the fishing industry is worth $2.8 billion and employs over

Speaker: NA
Text: 14,000 people. We want to ensure that the fishing industry continues to grow-not just

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational fishing but commercial fishing as well, which is very important.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill before the House today seeks to amend the Fisheries Management Act 1991 and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Fisheries Administration Act 1991 to recognise and give a greater voice to Aboriginal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Torres Strait Islander fishers and recreational fishers in the management and decision-making

Speaker: NA
Text: process related to our Commonwealth waters. Other minor amendments include increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: the size of the Australian Fishing Management Authority board from seven people to 10

Speaker: NA
Text: people and extending the eligibility criteria to ensure that those appointed have expertise in

Speaker: NA
Text: matters relating to recreational Indigenous fishing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Extending the board will allow a broader range of views and ensure the committee has an

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate mix of skills, knowledge and experience to fulfil its role. It has also taken steps to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the Australian Fishing Management Authority is completely independent. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will only strengthen the integrity of our fishing industry. We are proposing that no person

Speaker: NA
Text: who holds an executive position on a fishing representative organisation be allowed, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: think is important, because they can be biased. If you have someone just representing a board

Speaker: NA
Text: of recreational fishers, some of those people want to close down commercial fishing, which I

Speaker: NA
Text: think is wrong. So, they need to be independent, with independent skills. We further propose

Speaker: NA
Text: that no person holding an executive position in a fishing industry association be allowed to be

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed as an Australian Fishing Management Authority commissioner.

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments will give a greater voice to and recognition of all parties involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing practices. Currently, there is little input from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

Speaker: NA
Text: fishers in fisheries management. We believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander

Speaker: NA
Text: customary fishing should be incorporated into fisheries management systems.

Speaker: NA
Text: To quickly explain what we mean when we are talking about Commonwealth waters, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: the waters that surround Australia from three nautical miles to 200 nautical miles out to sea. It

Speaker: NA
Text: accounts for only six per cent of our commercial fishing, which I think is a bit of a shame. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think we could do a lot better in that space. New Zealand, which has waters a lot smaller than

Speaker: NA
Text: ours, has output that is much bigger. Part of that is because the fish down there are fed better

Speaker: NA
Text: and grow better, apparently, and the environment is better for them to repopulate quickly. But

Speaker: NA
Text: I still think that in commercial fishing Australia isn't doing enough. Australians want to eat

Speaker: NA
Text: fresh Australian seafood, and not everyone wants to go out and catch it themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of the eastern side of my electorate of Petrie is on the waterfront-the Moreton Bay

Speaker: NA
Text: area, Bramble Bay and Deception Bay. Over the Christmas period in 2014 I went out on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Marvin, a prawn trawler that works in state waters but not in Commonwealth waters. Gee,

Speaker: NA
Text: those guys work hard. I went out about 6 pm and came back at about 8 am the next morning.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: You set the nets at about 8 pm and it trawls, and at 10 pm you have to pull up the nets and sort

Speaker: NA
Text: the catch. The net is immediately dropped back out, at 10, so by the time you finish sorting

Speaker: NA
Text: the catch, which takes about an hour-and-a-half, you have half an hour before the net comes

Speaker: NA
Text: in again and you have got to do it all again-no sleep, right through the night. They work

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely hard. We were catching bay prawns, tiger prawns and sand crabs. A lot of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bycatch is thrown overboard. There isn't a lot of bycatch. There were a few small whiting and

Speaker: NA
Text: small crabs. Interestingly enough, the dolphins are down at the back of the boat knocking off

Speaker: NA
Text: the part of the bycatch that goes back, and sharks underneath that get the crabs. It was an

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting night, and I encourage members from all parties who have local trawlers-I know

Speaker: NA
Text: the member for Solomon would in his electorate-to ring them up and go out with them for a

Speaker: NA
Text: night. It is extremely interesting. You see how hard they work and you develop a better

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of commercial fishing.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a few little things-red tape-that frustrate commercial and recreational fishers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The boat I was on had two licences, a 45-foot licence and a 30-foot licence, and they were

Speaker: NA
Text: using, I think, the 30-foot licence that night. They are not using the 45-foot licence because

Speaker: NA
Text: they don't have a 45-foot boat at the moment. They wanted to lease their licence out to

Speaker: NA
Text: another 30-foot boat, but they couldn't do it under the 45-foot licence. It just doesn't make

Speaker: NA
Text: sense that a smaller boat couldn't use the larger boat's licence-it has to be exactly 45 feet. A

Speaker: NA
Text: lot of the boats are older. There isn't a standard 45-foot new boat-you have to have one

Speaker: NA
Text: custom-made and it costs millions. I mention that because red tape can be an issue. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: state government issue in Queensland, but we need to think about that federally, as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are three types of fishing. With Indigenous fishing, Aboriginal and Torres Strait

Speaker: NA
Text: Islanders are allowed to catch fish, turtles, dugong and whatever it is they catch for their own

Speaker: NA
Text: consumption. I think that is appropriate, as long as it is not sold commercially ongoing. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: for only what they can eat.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said, recreational fishing is extremely important-thousands of jobs; people like to do

Speaker: NA
Text: it. I went out fishing in commercial boats on the Coral Sea with my father in my early 20s. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been fishing up in the electorate of the member for Solomon, on Melville Island, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing lodge on Indigenous land up there. It's a great thing, recreational fishing, and we need

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow Australians to fish in Australian waters. We need to make sure we have appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: rules that enable it to be sustainable for generations to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: Commercial fishing is also important, and I don't think parliamentarians do enough to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that we can support them. We have the third-largest fishing waters in the world, yet

Speaker: NA
Text: we are 60th in productivity, which goes to my point about commercial fishing. Queensland I

Speaker: NA
Text: think is also lagging behind, because we make up only 11 per cent of commercial fishing in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. If you look at somewhere like Tasmania, they have a lot more commercial fishing

Speaker: NA
Text: than we do, but partly that is because they have a lot of aquaculture down there, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: great; we all like to eat Tasmanian salmon. But I think Queensland should also be trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: look at how we can improve aquaculture in our state and make the most of it. Not everyone

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to eat cheap Indonesian basa or Vietnamese fish. We want to be able to go and buy

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian fish, and it's very difficult, if you go to the local fish and chip shop, to get it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We've also done a little bit with green zones. In November 2012 the previous, Labor,

Speaker: NA
Text: government expanded the marine protected area to some 3.2 million square kilometres.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following considerable concern from communities around Australia-recreational fishers

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: who would have been locked out and commercial fishers who would have been locked out-

Speaker: NA
Text: part of our election commitment in 2013 was to review it. There were a lot of keen

Speaker: NA
Text: consultations. It was robust, comprehensive and scientific. The Director of National Parks is

Speaker: NA
Text: currently preparing management plans for Australia's marine parks following two public

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation periods, and these plans will soon be provided for government's consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: The coalition government is investing a substantial amount of money into marine parks for

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation, for fishing and for recreation. We've allocated $56 million to implement new

Speaker: NA
Text: zoning, and we'll wait for the formal advice. We have increased the proportion of the estate

Speaker: NA
Text: that is under a higher level of protection from 60 to 63 per cent. My understanding is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: actual conservation side of it will increase from 60 to 63 per cent. We maintain the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: high-value ecological features protected at 331, and we've significantly increased the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of ecological features protected on the sea floor from 192 to 265. The plans cut the impact to

Speaker: NA
Text: business in half, which I think is important when compared with the previous zoning, from

Speaker: NA
Text: 8.21 million to 4.1 million. Eighty per cent of the estate is open to commercial fishing,

Speaker: NA
Text: compared with 64 per cent under Labor. I'm not being political when I say that; I'm just

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that we need to make sure we are looking after commercial fishers as well. The draft

Speaker: NA
Text: plan also restores access for recreational fishing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill has received widespread support from peak industry bodies, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Fisheries Association and Seafood Industry Australia. These amendments

Speaker: NA
Text: were not considered lightly. The various bodies consulted on the amendments were the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Fisheries Management Authority, the Department of the Prime Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: Cabinet, the Department of Finance, the Australian Public Service Commission, the Office of

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliamentary Counsel, the Commonwealth Fisheries Association, the Australian Recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: Fishing Foundation, the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation's Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: Reference Group, and the Prime Minister's Indigenous Advisory Council. I wonder how we

Speaker: NA
Text: get anything done when we consult that widely, quite frankly. I mean, that's a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: consultation. If we have to go through that for everything, then, yes, I do have concern, once

Speaker: NA
Text: again, regarding red tape. That's a lot of consultation. I think we need to be much better at

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing red tape. A number of bodies representing recreational and Indigenous fishers made

Speaker: NA
Text: comments on the inquiry-the Victorian Recreational Fishing Peak Body and the Tasmanian

Speaker: NA
Text: Association for Recreational Fishing-but, once again, I can see nothing from Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: there. So I would say to those in this place that recreational fishing is important, and this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: gives them a voice on the board.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know the member for Solomon has established a group here, the Parliamentary Friends of

Speaker: NA
Text: Recreational Fishers, to support recreational fishing. But I still think we should be focusing on

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial fishing as well. We can have a great environment, make sure we have good

Speaker: NA
Text: breeding grounds and make sure there is a certain bag limit, but, please, whoever's in

Speaker: NA
Text: government: let's look after commercial fishing as well. Our population will only get bigger.

Speaker: NA
Text: We want to eat clean seafood, and most Australians do not have the time to go and throw a

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational line in or go out fishing. We need to make sure they can buy it at a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: price. More thought needs to be given to aquaculture as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is important that governments continually revise their legislation to ensure they are

Speaker: NA
Text: looking after Australia's needs. Recreational fishing is becoming more and more prevalent in

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth waters as boats and so forth improve. It's important that the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational fishers are considered in Commonwealth fisheries management, but not at the

Speaker: NA
Text: expense of commercial fishing, which also should be encouraged. I do support this bill.

Speaker: Mr GOSLING
Text: Solomon) (11:31): I rise to support the government's changes contained

Speaker: NA
Text: within the Fisheries Legislation Amendment (Representation) Bill 2017, and I will make

Speaker: NA
Text: some other comments as well that are relevant to the topic. Indigenous and recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing issues are really important to people in my electorate, which covers Palmerston and

Speaker: NA
Text: Darwin, the northern capital of Australia. But in fact these issues, as the member for Petrie

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned, are important to people Australia-wide. I've been very fortunate to enjoy fishing in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Territory, with first nations friends, and in other magical parts of Australia-and not only

Speaker: NA
Text: in the member for Petrie's electorate. Last night I caught up with my brother-in-law, who lives

Speaker: NA
Text: in the member for Franklin's electorate now, and we've thrown a line in down there in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Derwent. But previously, when he was living in north-east Arnhem Land, in the member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Lingiari's electorate, we've pulled in some barra down at East Woody Beach, and seeing first

Speaker: NA
Text: nations people fishing on their country is a special thing, a sacred thing. It is one of the many

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons we support this legislation, because it's important that there is a stronger voice for

Speaker: NA
Text: them and for recreational fishers in general. We recognise the cultural and family importance

Speaker: NA
Text: of fishing as well as the importance of protecting our marine environment and resources. It's

Speaker: NA
Text: important to rec fishers but it's obviously incredibly important to first nations peoples.

Speaker: NA
Text: A couple of weeks ago I went fishing, again in the member for Lingiari's electorate, with

Speaker: NA
Text: some first nations friends to a beautiful place in the Top End called Bynoe Harbour. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: put on the record my thanks to the extended Clarke family for that opportunity. We did all

Speaker: NA
Text: right. We caught a couple and we got some muddies. It was a great feed and a great

Speaker: NA
Text: experience to be out on country with them. To Indigenous Australians, fishing is a source of

Speaker: NA
Text: joy and helps forge family bonds. It also results in a great feed of fish-normally; you can

Speaker: NA
Text: have some slow days.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the member for Petrie mentioned just a little while ago, it's for some of these reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: that we established, on the member for Hunter's suggestion, the Parliamentary Friends of

Speaker: NA
Text: Recreational Fishers group. It is a multiparty group, and one thing we've done in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks, on 15 October, was to go on Gone Fishing Day. Well done to the national rec fishing

Speaker: NA
Text: body, which had a great activity down on Sydney Harbour, but for Gone Fishing Day I went

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing locally in my electorate at the mouth of Rapid Creek. I was joined by David Ciaravolo

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Amateur Fishermen's Association of the Northern Territory-he's the executive

Speaker: NA
Text: officer there-and also by my good friend Kenny Vowles, the NT government's Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Primary Industry and Resources. It was a great morning. We had many members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community come down with their kids and throw in a line, and both AFANT and my office

Speaker: NA
Text: presented-and will do when I get back to my electorate-just small tokens for those families

Speaker: NA
Text: who took their kids out fishing. Through AFANT, the amateur rec fishers of my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: and the broader Northern Territory have a voice. But this legislation is important because we

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that that voice has a proper place in the discussion of issues around that balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: marine protections, enabling the commercial fishermen to make a living and provide fish for

Speaker: NA
Text: those who can't go fishing and get their own feed of fish; but also that enables fishing stocks

Speaker: NA
Text: to be sustainable, so that rec fishers, including first nations fishers, can continue to enjoy that

Speaker: NA
Text: pastime.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Through all these experiences that I've outlined I had the opportunity to hear Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: and rec fishers' concerns with the current legislative framework and processes around the

Speaker: NA
Text: management of Commonwealth fisheries. They've been unhappy with the lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: representation or genuine engagement avenues available to them. I think that is fair to say.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous and rec fishers are particularly concerned with the process undertaken to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: supertrawlers to fish in Australian fisheries, due to the fact that there was no formal process

Speaker: NA
Text: by which they, rec fishers and first nations fishers, could have their say. Recreational and first

Speaker: NA
Text: nation fishers obviously deserve the opportunity for better engagement with government. Rec

Speaker: NA
Text: and first nations fishers are entitled to a genuine say in key decisions about access to and

Speaker: NA
Text: management of key fisheries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, as I've stated, Labor is supporting this bill, because it does provide for explicit

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition of recreational and first nations fishers in Commonwealth legislation. I welcome

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that these amendments will require the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that the interests of all fishers are taken into account in Commonwealth fisheries

Speaker: NA
Text: management decisions. I also welcome that other minor amendments in the bill allow for

Speaker: NA
Text: increased opportunities for membership of AFMA advisory bodies and extend the eligibility

Speaker: NA
Text: criteria for serving on the Australian Fisheries Management Authority Commission to include

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise in matters relating to recreational and first nations fishing.

Speaker: NA
Text: In practice this bill will require the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to take

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable steps to ensure it has received adequate advice on relevant recreational and first

Speaker: NA
Text: nation interests, in addition to commercial fishing and environmental interests and scientific

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise, prior to making management decisions for Commonwealth commercial fisheries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me be clear that, while we support these changes, Labor will ensure that the consultation

Speaker: NA
Text: and opportunities for engagement enabled by this bill actually do occur.

Speaker: NA
Text: The member for Petrie mentioned the need to support commercial fisheries that are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: the right thing. That is very true. As I said a little while ago, Indigenous and first nations and

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational fishers are particularly concerned with the process undertaken to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: supertrawlers to fish in Australian fisheries due to the fact that there was no formal process by

Speaker: NA
Text: which they could have their say. So, owing to the potential impacts that industrial fishing

Speaker: NA
Text: processes, such as supertrawlers, can have on fish populations in the marine environment far

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond where they actually operate, it's important the Australian community, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous and recreational fishers, are afforded the opportunity to scrutinise the proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many instructive examples from our region of what can happen if industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: practices are allowed to occur without adequate oversight. In Timor-Leste, a near neighbour

Speaker: NA
Text: of my electorate of Solomon, boats of Chinese fishing companies have been found with

Speaker: NA
Text: massive numbers of sharks on board. The effect that this has on the economy and wellbeing

Speaker: NA
Text: of fishers in Timor-Leste, with the economic cost and health cost of taking away that food

Speaker: NA
Text: source, is a very serious issue. This is in our region, to the north of our country. A joint

Speaker: NA
Text: operation was conducted at dawn on 9 September this year by the marine conservation group

Speaker: NA
Text: Sea Shepherd Global with the Timor-Leste National Police, which resulted in the capture of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Hong Long Fisheries Pingtan Marine Enterprises fishing fleet at anchor off the coast of

Speaker: NA
Text: Com in Timor-Leste. Com is one of the most beautiful places in the world. It is on the north-

Speaker: NA
Text: east side of the half-island of Timor-Leste. That is where that joint operation occurred. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: request of the Timorese police, Sea Shepherd's patrol vessel, Ocean Warrior, approached

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: these foreign fishing vessels. Once those vessels were secured by the Timorese police, the Sea

Speaker: NA
Text: Shepherd crew members assisted in documenting the catch on board, confirming suspicions

Speaker: NA
Text: that the fleet were targeting sharks as opposed to engaging in broad-scale fishing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to commend the Timorese national police force and the other organisations involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in the operation. In particular, I want to commend the Australian Federal Police on the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity-building work that they do with the Timorese national police, including in areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: investigations and enforcement operations. The Timorese police force were aided by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police. It is very important work for the Australian Federal Police to be

Speaker: NA
Text: doing, I'm sure members would agree. The Australian Defence Force's Defence Cooperation

Speaker: NA
Text: Program is also working very closely with the Timor-Leste Defence Force, doing great work

Speaker: NA
Text: with the navy and army over there in Timor-Leste. I commend them on that work they are

Speaker: NA
Text: doing also. Inconveniently, fish do not abide by international boundaries. This highlights the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of acting together with our regional partners to protect fish stocks and our marine

Speaker: NA
Text: environment.

Speaker: NA
Text: On a more local level, these examples highlight the potential impact that industrial-scale

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing practices can have on marine ecosystems well beyond the area in which the fishing

Speaker: NA
Text: occurs. We need to be acting together. Something I want to raise with my colleagues is that

Speaker: NA
Text: we need to look further into ways to ban these supertrawlers and industrial-scale fishing

Speaker: NA
Text: practices for good from the Small Pelagic Fishery. On 7 September 2015 the Senate referred

Speaker: NA
Text: the following matter to the Senate Environment and Communications References Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: for inquiry, to report by 30 April 2016:

Speaker: NA
Text: The environmental, social and economic impacts of large-capacity fishing vessels commonly known as

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Supertrawlers' operating in Australia's Marine Jurisdiction.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let it be noted that the reference was opposed by the Liberal and National coalition senators.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a problem. It's a problem in this country and not only for amateur recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: fishes. It's not just a problem for first nations fishers. It is a problem for commercial fishers.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the committee's recommendations was that the Australian government ban all factory

Speaker: NA
Text: freezer mid-water trawlers from operating in the Commonwealth Small Pelagic Fishery. The

Speaker: NA
Text: coalition-those opposite-rejected that recommendation. Labor, having listened to ongoing

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns from the community and across the country, proposed this inquiry in August 2015 to

Speaker: NA
Text: examine the environmental, social and economic impacts of large capacity factory trawlers in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's marine jurisdiction, and in government Labor ensured appropriate consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: was given to the impact of large capacity factory trawlers on Australia's fisheries by amending

Speaker: NA
Text: the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. Our amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteed Australia's waters were adequately protected from risks associated with the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: large capacity factory trawlers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor remains committed to preventing the operation of large capacity factory trawlers in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian waters unless a thorough assessment against the most up-to-date science can verify

Speaker: NA
Text: that such operations will not undermine small pelagic fisheries and recreational fishing spots.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have used the example of Timor Leste. If the Timorese allowed foreign vessels to take

Speaker: NA
Text: everything away, that would wreck a sustainable fishing industry for that developing country,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is unacceptable. I support this bill to give a greater voice to first nation and rec fishers.

Speaker: Ms KEAY
Text: Braddon) (11:46): I've risen from my sickbed to speak on the Fisheries

Speaker: NA
Text: Legislation Amendment (Representation) Bill because recreational fishing in my electorate is

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: highly important. I apologise if I struggle, but I will do my best. It won't be pretty but we'll

Speaker: NA
Text: give it a go. On this side of the House we welcome this legislation, although I will suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: later in my contribution that the government could go further. More than 85 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's population lives within 50 kilometres of the ocean. Fishing in Australia is a

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural pastime embraced by all Australians. There have been many attempts to quantify the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of recreational fishing and none yet agreed upon. The Australia Institute of Marine

Speaker: NA
Text: Science's December 2016 report contained an analysis of the value of Australia's marine

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. Contained within that report was information that recreational fishing contributed

Speaker: NA
Text: almost $2.2 billion directly to the economy in the 2013-14 years. It also stated that a further

Speaker: NA
Text: $1.5 billion was indirectly contributed to the economy, giving a total value of $3.7 billion.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are significant figures, but they do not take into account the value of repairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance, marinas and other infrastructure or tourism activity. AIMS do not attribute the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of these sectors between the recreational and commercial sectors. It would be fair to

Speaker: NA
Text: say, though, the conservative $3.7 billion figure demonstrates how big recreational fishing is.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania's peak recreational fishing body, TARFish, is currently in discussions with other

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies in the Commonwealth to finalise an agreed methodology to properly determine the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of recreational fisheries.

Speaker: NA
Text: The AIMS figures are also interesting when compared to the commercial sector. AIMS

Speaker: NA
Text: state that the value of Australia's recreational fishery in 2013-14 was more than twice the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of Australia's commercial wild fisheries and four times the value of marine based

Speaker: NA
Text: aquaculture. In my state and nationally there continues to be significant growth in

Speaker: NA
Text: aquaculture, but on these figures the commercial sector has some way to go in terms of its

Speaker: NA
Text: economic value. The AIMS data in itself demonstrates a clear need to strengthen the

Speaker: NA
Text: engagement of recreational fishers in Commonwealth legislation and decision-making. In my

Speaker: NA
Text: state and my electorate the recreational fishing sector will welcome this legislation. In some

Speaker: NA
Text: ways it mirrors Labor's national recreational fishing policy that we took to the last federal

Speaker: NA
Text: election.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recreational fishing is part of Tasmania's social and economic fabric. As an island state,

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania actually has a longer coastline than either New South Wales or Victoria. Our inland

Speaker: NA
Text: waters are home to Tasmania's world-class trout fishery. This fishery is estimated to make an

Speaker: NA
Text: economic contribution of around $50 million per annum to Tasmania's economy. It attracts

Speaker: NA
Text: visitors from interstate and overseas who wish to be challenged by some of the best site

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing opportunities for trout in our pristine inland waters, many of which are contained

Speaker: NA
Text: within the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our marine waters are home to world-class game fishing, a stunning rock lobster fishery

Speaker: NA
Text: and the best inshore flathead fishing in Australia. Catching a feed of flathead is one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: great Tasmanian pastimes, which can be enjoyed all year round. It's been estimated that

Speaker: NA
Text: around 115,000 Tasmanians, or one in four people, enjoy recreational fishing. I remember as

Speaker: NA
Text: a child going to my local port, to the wharf-when you used to be allowed onto the wharf-

Speaker: NA
Text: and fishing for flathead. Nowadays it's a bit hard to do that on our wharves. Still, it's such an

Speaker: NA
Text: important pastime that generations of Tasmanians have enjoyed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine and Safety Tasmania, or MAST, has stated that Tasmania has the highest level of

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational boat ownership of any state or territory in Australia, at one in 17. For the 2016-17

Speaker: NA
Text: year, over 30,000 boats were registered in Tasmania. It has also been established that 90 per

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of all registered boats are used for recreational fishing. Conservative estimates place the

Speaker: NA
Text: value of Tasmania's recreational fishery in excess of $200 million. Tasmania's Institute for

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine and Antarctic Studies, IMAS, has just commenced a survey of the Tasmanian

Speaker: NA
Text: population to determine the number of persons who go fishing and their demographic make-

Speaker: NA
Text: up. IMAS previously researched the major drivers of recreational fishing in Tasmania, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: states:

Speaker: NA
Text: Overall, Tasmanian recreational fishers assigned the highest importance to non-catch related motives –

Speaker: NA
Text: "being outdoors" and "relaxing/unwinding" - followed by catch-related motives – "catching fish for

Speaker: NA
Text: food" and "for enjoyment/sport". Social motives – "spending time with family" and "spending time with

Speaker: NA
Text: friends" - were next in importance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Given the value of recreational fishing, it is somewhat extraordinary how the fishery has been

Speaker: NA
Text: treated by this government when it comes to the debate over large-scale factory freezer

Speaker: NA
Text: trawlers that operate in Commonwealth waters. The public record states that this government

Speaker: NA
Text: has been and continues to support supertrawlers, initially in the Margiris and then the

Speaker: NA
Text: Geelong Star.

Speaker: NA
Text: When Labor was in government we stopped the supertrawler, but once the coalition

Speaker: NA
Text: assumed office there was no greater champion of supertrawlers than the former assistant

Speaker: NA
Text: minister from Tasmania, Senator Colbeck. In 2015 Labor tried to ban the Geelong Star but

Speaker: NA
Text: was stopped by the coalition. Labor still holds genuine concerns about the impact of

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial-scale fishing operations in the small pelagic fishery. It is true that the fishery

Speaker: NA
Text: operates under a scientifically assessed quota management system. Equally true is that there

Speaker: NA
Text: have not been sufficient scientific studies to give the wider community confidence that large-

Speaker: NA
Text: scale harvesting of fish stocks from a single area would not have a long-term impact on the

Speaker: NA
Text: overall fishery. Localised depletion is a genuine concern for recreational fishers, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: those from Tasmania. Tasmania's peak recreational fishing body, TARFish, believes there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of knowledge on the rates of movements of species within the fishery, a lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge on the time it will take for local populations to recover from industrial-scale

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing and a lack of knowledge on one particular species, the jack mackerel, on the east coast

Speaker: NA
Text: of Tasmania. The jack mackerel is a particularly important species as a source of food for our

Speaker: NA
Text: tuna populations. It is also an important species for the recreational tuna sector.

Speaker: NA
Text: A real contrast exists between the precautionary approach of this side of the House when it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to supertrawlers and the approach of the other side. I do welcome that this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: contains some provisions from the Senate Environment and Communications Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into factory freezer trawlers. It may be that another Margiris or Geelong Star could be

Speaker: NA
Text: avoided in the future with a new requirement for AFMA to consider recreational fisheries in

Speaker: NA
Text: its decision-making process, as recommended by the Senate inquiry. Perhaps if this legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: had been in place a few years ago this entire debate could have been prevented.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt the coalition has suffered political damage in my state with their blind

Speaker: NA
Text: support of supertrawlers. At the Tasmanian level the Liberal Party's ignorance could never be

Speaker: NA
Text: more stated than by having a passing glance at the actions of the Hodgman government. For a

Speaker: NA
Text: long period they were happy to stay silent and let their federal colleagues do the running. But

Speaker: NA
Text: in an effort to minimise the political damage inflicted by their federal colleagues, and with an

Speaker: NA
Text: election less than 12 months away, the Hodgman government introduced legislation to ban

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: trawling in state waters-a political stunt if there ever were one, because trawling has been

Speaker: NA
Text: banned in Tasmanian waters for decades.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the commencement of my contribution I mentioned that Labor will be supporting this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. I also mention that on this side we believe things could be still done in a way that

Speaker: NA
Text: complements this legislation. At the last election Labor had a policy to establish a national

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational fishing council that would give our recreational fishers a seat at the decision-

Speaker: NA
Text: making table. Chaired by the agriculture, fisheries and forestry minister, the council would

Speaker: NA
Text: include representatives of both recreational fisheries and relevant government departments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The council would tackle issues like small pelagic fisheries management, boating and fishing

Speaker: NA
Text: infrastructure, conservation, access to national marine parks, and other issues of concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational fishers. In effect, this body would have been the national peak body at

Speaker: NA
Text: government level for recreational fishers. It would have given recreational fishers a direct say

Speaker: NA
Text: in management decisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having perused the explanatory memorandum for this legislation, I would be interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: hearing from the opposite side as to whether recreational fishers will have that direct say in

Speaker: NA
Text: future AFMA management decisions. For example, will there be a recreational fisheries

Speaker: NA
Text: representative on AFMA's management advisory committees, or will this legislation just be

Speaker: NA
Text: lip service? I hope one of the government's speakers can clarify this point, as it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important to Tasmania's recreational fishers.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation is well overdue and I know recreational fishers from my state and

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate will welcome it. The proof, as they say, will ultimately be in its implementation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: look forward to seeing it becoming a reality and to recreational fishers being placed in

Speaker: NA
Text: national fisheries management decision-making.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr JOSH WILSON (Fremantle) (11:58): Like my colleagues from Braddon and

Speaker: NA
Text: Solomon, I am glad to speak on the Fisheries Legislation Amendment (Representation) Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: 2017, which we support, while recognising what it does in terms of fisheries management-

Speaker: NA
Text: there is bigger question of fisheries management and ocean protection-is relatively minor. It

Speaker: NA
Text: must be seen against the background of other actions or inactions that are the responsibility of

Speaker: NA
Text: this government that don't help in putting Australia on the path to sustainable fisheries and a

Speaker: NA
Text: properly protected ocean environment. There's no doubt that careful, clear-eyed and rigorous

Speaker: NA
Text: management of Australia's fisheries is critical as part of the wider task of protecting our

Speaker: NA
Text: oceans. We are the only continental island nation and as such we have one of the largest and

Speaker: NA
Text: most important responsibilities when it comes to the stewardship of the sea. We should never

Speaker: NA
Text: underestimate the significance of that role.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has the sixth-largest land mass but the third-largest exclusive economic zone.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is because we take responsibility for a large area of sea. So Australia, among all nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: should understand that the ocean is the lifeblood of our planet. It's the once great primordial

Speaker: NA
Text: soup of the earth's biodiversity which now suffers species depletion and habitat loss through

Speaker: NA
Text: our neglect. It is the largest source of protein on the planet, but its potential as a food source is

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened by overuse. It is a significant factor in shaping our climate, as well as a clear

Speaker: NA
Text: medium through which the effects of climate change can be felt and measured. For all those

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons, Australia has to approach fishery and ocean management with the utmost seriousness

Speaker: NA
Text: and the utmost care.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that we have the potential to be a leading influence in modelling and

Speaker: NA
Text: practising the highest standard of ocean protection and sustainable use. We have been a leader

Speaker: NA
Text: at times in the past, especially in relation to Antarctica. We have both a national interest and

Speaker: NA
Text: an international responsibility to look after our oceans. Sensible and sustainable fisheries

Speaker: NA
Text: management is core to that work. Fishing is central to the social and economic life of

Speaker: NA
Text: communities around Australia and, certainly, in my electorate of Fremantle. I will say a little

Speaker: NA
Text: bit more about that in a minute.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is, of course, an economic use aspect to sound fisheries regulation, but there is also

Speaker: NA
Text: an essential ocean protection aspect. Ultimately, ocean protection is paramount. Ocean

Speaker: NA
Text: protection has to be the overarching concern, because, if you don't preserve marine

Speaker: NA
Text: ecosystems, fisheries will inevitably deteriorate and eventually collapse. So when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: good fisheries management, the false dichotomy between economic use and conservation has

Speaker: NA
Text: to go straight out the door. There is no fundamental conflict between economic use and

Speaker: NA
Text: conservation. They are really one and the same.

Speaker: NA
Text: The value of Australia's wild-caught fisheries is considerable. In 2014-15 it was $1.6

Speaker: NA
Text: billion. Within the Commonwealth fisheries, which is principally what we are concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: with, it was $350 million, and that doesn't include bluefin tuna, which is caught in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery and towed to mariculture pens in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to be grown out. The value of that fishery is a further $120 million. While we

Speaker: NA
Text: manage our fisheries, particularly in Commonwealth waters, reasonably well by international

Speaker: NA
