Text: standards, we don't have a perfect record. It is salient for us to reflect on the fact that, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 93 fish stocks managed solely by the Commonwealth, in 2015 three were classified as being

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to overfishing and a further 11 were classified as being uncertain with regards to

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing mortality.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned before that fishing is a big part of life in my electorate of Fremantle.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recreational fishing is a significant pastime for people in Western Australia across the board.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Fremantle we have the beautiful Indian Ocean as our coastline, and the Swan River as well,

Speaker: NA
Text: and fishing is something that thousands of people in my electorate enjoy as part of their

Speaker: NA
Text: birthright. Fremantle has a significant commercial fishing tradition and industry. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: over 400 fishing vessels that currently operate out of Fremantle. It is an industry that started at

Speaker: NA
Text: the turn of the century. It was largely created by Greek and Italian migrants who, in 1947,

Speaker: NA
Text: created the Fremantle Fishermen's Cooperative. The industry continues to be a very vital

Speaker: NA
Text: social and economic part of my community. In fact, this coming Sunday I will march as part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the annual blessing of the fleet, which is a distinctive ritual in Fremantle that is devoted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the safety and wellbeing of the fishing fleet and all of the fishing men and women who are

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in it.

Speaker: NA
Text: WA does have a history of commitment to sustainable fisheries and it has made some new

Speaker: NA
Text: ground in that area in the 21st century. In fact, I think it is right to say that the Western Rock

Speaker: NA
Text: Lobster Fishery was the first fishery in the world to be certified by the Marine Stewardship

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, in 2000, and it has maintained that certification ever since-for 17 years, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: incredibly laudable and they are to be congratulated for that. Western Australia's Peel-Harvey

Speaker: NA
Text: Estuary Blue Swimmer Crab Recreational Fishery is the first recreational fishery to be

Speaker: NA
Text: certified by the Marine Stewardship Council, and our South Sea pearl fishery was the first

Speaker: NA
Text: gem fishery to complete that certification. That is something that is worth noting.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill, essentially, makes some changes to the way that the Australian Fisheries

Speaker: NA
Text: Management Authority operates. AFMA has a central role in managing our fisheries

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainably. The bill requires that AFMA now take input from, and consider the interests of,

Speaker: NA
Text: all users of fisheries, including recreational, Indigenous and commercial fishers. That is a

Speaker: NA
Text: sensible and welcomed change that the government has brought in, and we support it. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: change that is not being made before time. It responds to the Senate inquiry into factory

Speaker: NA
Text: freezer trawlers. Other contributors to this debate have made reference to that, and I will come

Speaker: NA
Text: back to it. It also responds to the Productivity Commission's inquiry into marine fisheries and

Speaker: NA
Text: aquaculture. As members may know, the terms of reference of that inquiry were to look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent to which fisheries management regimes align with and protect the interests of the wider

Speaker: NA
Text: community, in particular the balance between commercial, recreational and Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing, conservation interests and consumer interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: A key point made in that draft report was that the impacts of recreational and Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: customary fishing activity have been largely uncounted in Commonwealth, state and territory

Speaker: NA
Text: fishery management regimes. There needs to be a greater recognition of recreational fishing in

Speaker: NA
Text: fisheries management and there has been relatively poor input from Indigenous people in

Speaker: NA
Text: fishery management. Indigenous customary fishing should be incorporated into fishery

Speaker: NA
Text: management systems. I thank the member for Solomon for speaking about some of those

Speaker: NA
Text: matters in depth.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do want to put the change in this bill in the wider context of ocean protection because it is

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible to separate them. I guess that goes back to what I was saying about supertrawlers.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the pursuit of effective and sustainable marine protection, Labor continued the work begun

Speaker: NA
Text: by the former Howard government in moving towards a system of national marine protected

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. That was based exhaustively on the science and on extensive consultation. I will take

Speaker: NA
Text: people back to 2012, when the network was settled. The World Wildlife Fund welcomed that

Speaker: NA
Text: reform and congratulated the federal government of Australia on finalising the boundaries and

Speaker: NA
Text: basic layout of what was to be the world's largest network of marine parks. They stated at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time:

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an historic moment for marine conservation in Australia. The establishment of this national

Speaker: NA
Text: network of marine parks is a world-first at this scale. It's an essential step forward for the protection of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's diverse and unique marine wildlife.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today's announcement is in line with scientific advice and has strong public support. We understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that in this phase, the government received 80,000 submissions which overwhelmingly supported the

Speaker: NA
Text: new marine parks. This latest demonstration of support builds on the waves of enthusiasm from

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of thousands of people all around the country over the past couple of years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I thoroughly agree with that. It was a properly conducted process and it established a new

Speaker: NA
Text: high standard in marine protection, which I think is rightly Australia's role in the world for

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the reasons I've mentioned before.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since that time, and certainly since the Abbott-Turnbull government was elected in 2013,

Speaker: NA
Text: that reform has been steadily diminished, chipped away at, torn down and undermined. We've

Speaker: NA
Text: had four years of unnecessary delay. The member for Petrie talked about processes that go on

Speaker: NA
Text: forever and the fact that the community gets frustrated when there are interminable delays,

Speaker: NA
Text: endless reviews and so on. In 2012, following on from the work that had occurred under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard government and the exhaustive process that took the science as its No. 1 reference

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: point and took as its next point of reference the submissions of tens of thousands of people in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community, this historic reform was delivered.

Speaker: NA
Text: So we were there in 2012. We then went into a further unnecessary bureaucratic process,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has taken most of the last four years. Where has it got us to?

Speaker: NA
Text: It has got us to a moth-holed, shredded, torn-up version of that historic and rigorous marine

Speaker: NA
Text: plan. It has reduced marine protected areas by 50 per cent. It has stripped away 40 million

Speaker: NA
Text: hectares of marine reserves, including reserves that cover the Coral Sea; the deep ocean area

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the Diamantina Fracture Zone; and in my area, the Perth Canyon, one of the very

Speaker: NA
Text: few known feeding zones for the blue whale. One thousand, four hundred and sixty scientists

Speaker: NA
Text: worldwide have signed a petition decrying that backward step, including Dr David Suzuki,

Speaker: NA
Text: who described the vandalism as 'sickening', and I agree.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the most disappointing aspects of the government's gutting of Labor's national

Speaker: NA
Text: marine protection network is the removal of huge areas of marine sanctuaries, despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: overwhelming public submission support for that protection. The only apparent logic to this

Speaker: NA
Text: removal in relation to some of these far offshore areas is that, although they don't have any

Speaker: NA
Text: fishing use now, they might have some prospective fishing value. But, as I understand it, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this is based on my close engagement with the fishing industry, including the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Fishing Industry Council, the only possible fishing value of those areas would be

Speaker: NA
Text: through large trawling vessels with on-board refrigeration-in other words, supertrawlers. So

Speaker: NA
Text: the government have gutted this historic and scientifically supported marine plan in the name

Speaker: NA
Text: of supertrawlers in the future, essentially. They've taken away 50 per cent, or 40 million

Speaker: NA
Text: hectares, of marine protection based on the possibility, at some point, of supertrawlers coming

Speaker: NA
Text: in-which everybody knows, and all the science shows, would be devastating to the marine

Speaker: NA
Text: environment, to fish stocks and to the local fishing industry. That is very, very hard to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor members support the bill because it makes some minor but laudable changes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: way that AFMA works. But the bill does nothing to counteract or mitigate the enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: harmfulness of the government's vandalism in relation to marine sanctuaries. In every area, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a strange pattern: Labor creates; the government tears away. The national marine protection

Speaker: NA
Text: plan; needs based school funding; the NDIS; NBN-they all start with 'n', interestingly: all of

Speaker: NA
Text: these things that Labor comes along and creates, the next lot come in and hollow out and strip

Speaker: NA
Text: away. They find reasons to make them, at best, a far, far weaker version of what was created.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a very bitter irony in the fact that this bill we're looking at today puts in place the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for recreational, Indigenous and commercial fishers to have greater input into

Speaker: NA
Text: fisheries management, but that the government's approach to the national marine network

Speaker: NA
Text: completely ignores all of the evidence from the community about its view of Labor's national

Speaker: NA
Text: marine protected area plan. The Department of the Environment and Energy itself has

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed there were 82,000 submissions received on the marine management plan through this

Speaker: NA
Text: further, pointless four-year process-82,000 submissions-and they were overwhelmingly in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of the plan as Labor had settled it. Ninety-seven per cent of the submissions from

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational fishers supported the plan that Labor put in place in 2013. So 97 per cent of all of

Speaker: NA
Text: the recreational fishers said, 'Leave it as it is,' but this government is intent on ripping it down.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BRIAN MITCHELL (Lyons) (12:13): My electorate has some of the best fishing

Speaker: NA
Text: spots in the country, if not the world. I know colleagues from Queensland and the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory, and perhaps my friend the member for Fremantle, may scoff. Jealousy is a terrible

Speaker: NA
Text: thing! From the east coast beaches to the many lakes in the Central Highlands, people travel

Speaker: NA
Text: across the globe to come to Lyons to fish. My state of Tasmania also has a long, enduring and

Speaker: NA
Text: resilient Indigenous culture, and, as you might expect, with a landmass cut off from the

Speaker: NA
Text: mainland for tens of thousands of years, the ocean forms a significant part of that culture. For

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of years, people have fished the waters off Tasmania for sustenance, and, more

Speaker: NA
Text: recently, for recreation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased to support the Fisheries Legislation Amendment (Representation) Bill 2017,

Speaker: NA
Text: as it seeks to strengthen official engagement between recreational fishers, Indigenous fishers

Speaker: NA
Text: and commercial fishers regarding the management of Commonwealth fisheries. For tens of

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of years, Indigenous Australians managed fisheries, and that is why it is important

Speaker: NA
Text: that their voices are heard and taken into account when decisions are made about

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth waters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year, a study was announced by the Tasmanian Centre for Marine Socioecology to

Speaker: NA
Text: investigate the potential for Indigenous and commercial fisheries to operate as a key

Speaker: NA
Text: economic component in Tasmania's regional communities. The study, titled ‘Wave to Plate':

Speaker: NA
Text: establishing a market for Tasmanian Aboriginal cultural fisheries, is funded by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: government's Fisheries Research and Development Corporation, in association with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and Environment and the CMS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Stewart Frusher, director of the CMS, says that the project has great significance

Speaker: NA
Text: and will begin the journey to understand how Indigenous fishery cultural practices can

Speaker: NA
Text: integrate with and help to build regional economies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Emma Lee, a Tasmanian Indigenous woman and PhD candidate, recently spent six months

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Basque Country of northern Spain studying the fishing industry to bring that knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: back to Tasmania. Emma is the first Tasmanian Aboriginal recipient of the Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: Fellowship in the prestigious and internationally competitive Endeavour Scholarships and

Speaker: NA
Text: Fellowships program. She sees this study as a way to connect fishing-which boosts

Speaker: NA
Text: communication, self-esteem and connectedness-with land, building pride and self-worth.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is nothing like providing food for one's family to generate a sense of pride and self-

Speaker: NA
Text: respect. Emma says that, if we can harness that positivity, we can transform regions of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment into vibrant food-producing regions. The study's end-vision is to incorporate

Speaker: NA
Text: Indigenous culture with Tasmania's growing seafood and tourism market. The Wave to Plate

Speaker: NA
Text: movement is, like the more well-known Paddock to Plate movement, gaining traction in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania as our community and particularly visitors to our great state seek more

Speaker: NA
Text: connectedness with the origins of their food. There are 1,900 businesses involved in the

Speaker: NA
Text: movement, servicing 1.26 million visitors, who spend around $2.23 billion in Tasmania-and

Speaker: NA
Text: I am confident those numbers will grow.

Speaker: NA
Text: This legislation will also ensure that the Australian Fisheries Management Authority takes

Speaker: NA
Text: into account the interests of recreational and commercial fishers. Recognition of Indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: and recreational fishers is not currently explicit in Commonwealth fisheries legislation, which

Speaker: NA
Text: primarily regulates commercial harvest of fish stock. The bill inserts an objective that will

Speaker: NA
Text: require AFMA, the minister and joint authorities to have regard to ensuring that the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: of commercial, recreational and Indigenous fishers are taken into account in the context of

Speaker: NA
Text: managing Commonwealth commercial fisheries.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Other minor amendments in the bill allow for increased opportunities for membership of

Speaker: NA
Text: AFMA advisory bodies and extend the eligibility criteria for serving on the AFMA

Speaker: NA
Text: commission to include expertise on matters relating to recreational and Indigenous fishing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am pleased to see recommendations included in this bill that arose from the Senate's

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry into factory freezer trawlers, but I am disappointed that the legislation does not

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporate the inquiry's key recommendation, which is to ban the vessels. There is simply no

Speaker: NA
Text: place for factory freezer trawlers in Australia. I made it clear during my election campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: that I was opposed to these vessels and that I would be, and I remain, a voice within the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party that wants to see these vessels permanently banned from Australia. I note that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate inquiry recommendation to ban these vessels from operating in Commonwealth waters

Speaker: NA
Text: was reached with the full support of Labor senators. Labor stands with recreational fishers

Speaker: NA
Text: against factory freezer trawlers. I do accept that scientific experts contend that our fisheries

Speaker: NA
Text: can accommodate the quotas allocated to such vessels, but that doesn't mean we should accept

Speaker: NA
Text: such vessels as part of our commercial fishing sector. As I have said before, just because a

Speaker: NA
Text: fishery can accommodate a quota being taken from it, it doesn't mean the quota should be

Speaker: NA
Text: taken. By all means, if the expert advice is that a fishery needs to be harvested to head off

Speaker: NA
Text: environmental imbalance or harm then it should be fished. But it may be better to allow a

Speaker: NA
Text: fishery to simply remain in place, unharvested, rather than sell it for peanuts to these factory

Speaker: NA
Text: freezer vessels. Let the fishery grow. I see no harm in allowing fish stocks to grow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members may recall the Geelong Star, which was given permission by this government to

Speaker: NA
Text: harvest the Small Pelagic Fishery off the south coast of the mainland and the east coast of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania. This vessel was of negligible benefit to the Australian economy. It provided few

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs, certainly none that were ongoing, and its other economic inputs were marginal at best.

Speaker: NA
Text: While here, that vessel killed a number of dolphins and seals, and the fate of the protected

Speaker: NA
Text: whale shark remains unknown. There were no tears shed in Tasmania when the Geelong Star

Speaker: NA
Text: headed off over the horizon. In fact, I challenge anyone opposite who supports factory freezer

Speaker: NA
Text: trawlers to point out any community in the world where these vessels have fished that have a

Speaker: NA
Text: happy story to tell. The only people who benefit from factory freezer trawlers are the

Speaker: NA
Text: corporations that own them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's commercial fishing sector is best served by Australian flagged commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: trawlers, crewed by Australians, home porting in Australia, being maintained in Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: processing and exporting from Australia. Commercial management of our fisheries should

Speaker: NA
Text: examine not only what can occur but what should occur and, when determining whether

Speaker: NA
Text: quotas are allocated, the community benefit should be weighed alongside the private benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our fisheries belong to all of us, not just a handful of international shipping corporations.

Speaker: NA
Text: As members might expect, Tasmania has a thriving recreational firing sector. Indeed, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest participation rate of any state or territory of the Federation-115,000 Tasmanians

Speaker: NA
Text: fish, which is about one in five Tasmanians, and there are 30,000 registered recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: vessels. Unfortunately, we can only guesstimate the economic value of recreational fishing to

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania-we guesstimate it's around a couple of hundred million dollars-because the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal government is dragging its feet on working with the Tasmanian recreational fishing

Speaker: NA
Text: sector and businesses to draw up a detailed economic profile.

Speaker: NA
Text: Earlier this month, thousands of Tasmanians enthusiastically took part in the second annual

Speaker: NA
Text: Gone Fishing Day calendar of events, with five days of saltwater events and five of

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: freshwater. We are truly blessed in Tasmania with great fishing. Whether it is in a creek, a

Speaker: NA
Text: lake, a beach or the deep ocean, we have some of the best in the world. We will have the

Speaker: NA
Text: World Fly Fishing Championships in Tasmania in 2019, and we have a burgeoning

Speaker: NA
Text: swordfishing sector off the south-east coast. A three-year research project into the

Speaker: NA
Text: sustainability of swordfish is concluding this year and early indications are very promising for

Speaker: NA
Text: a sustainable fishery ahead. Swordfishing is a sector of the industry that is growing by word

Speaker: NA
Text: of mouth. The chatter has gone through the community like wild fire about how good it is in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania and the fact that in Tasmania it's a daytime experience. You don't have to be out in

Speaker: NA
Text: the dead of night. In fact, the sector is becoming so popular that, without proper management,

Speaker: NA
Text: it does risk becoming-oh, my speechwriter!-a double-edged swordfish. I should read these

Speaker: NA
Text: speeches before I give them! That is why it is important for recreational fishers to have a seat

Speaker: NA
Text: at the table-because they know the issues involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fishing season in Tasmania is just kicking off. I am told squid is a bit quiet and it is a little

Speaker: NA
Text: early for swordfish, but there was very good southern bluefin fishing up until a month ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is later than usual. It used to be a threeor four-month season but it is now nine months

Speaker: NA
Text: long. As we know, waters are getting warmer over summer off Tasmania and this is bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: different species down, including albacore and marlin. The warming of Tasmania's coastal

Speaker: NA
Text: waters does of course have significant implications for fishery management, and the input of

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational and Indigenous fishers will be invaluable in developing appropriate mechanisms

Speaker: NA
Text: to take account of it. That is one of the reasons Labor are happy to support this bill. It is long

Speaker: NA
Text: past time that Indigenous and recreational fishers had a seat at the table in the management of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth fisheries, and we are very pleased to support the bill.

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Text: Cowper-Assistant Minister to the Deputy Prime Minister) (12:24):

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill, the Fisheries Legislation Amendment (Representation) Bill 2017, reflects the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian government's ongoing commitment to the long-term sustainable use and

Speaker: NA
Text: development of Australia's fishery resources for all fishery users-commercial, recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: and Indigenous. As stakeholders in Commonwealth fisheries, it is important that recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: fishers' and Indigenous fishers' interests are identified and taken into consideration by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Fisheries Management Authority, or AFMA.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill improves the transparency of arrangements for AFMA, giving consideration to the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of all fisheries users in its decision-making process. The bill improves recreational

Speaker: NA
Text: fishers' and Indigenous fishers' formal mechanisms for conveying their interests around the

Speaker: NA
Text: management of Commonwealth fisheries. The inclusion of an additional objective in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fisheries Management Act 1991 and the Fisheries Administration Act 1991 is consistent with

Speaker: NA
Text: representations from recreational and fishing advocacy groups and Indigenous advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eligibility criteria for appointment of AFMA commissioners will be broadened to include

Speaker: NA
Text: expertise in matters relating to recreational and Indigenous fishers. This will enhance the

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity of the commission to respond to future challenges in fisheries management.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increasing the maximum number of members on AFMA's advisory committee from seven to

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 improves opportunities for representation from all relevant stakeholders, including

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational fishers.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is welcome legislation that provides significant improvement with regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: management of our fisheries. It ensures that the interests of Indigenous fishing groups and

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational fishing groups are appropriately taken into account. I certainly commend the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regulatory Powers (Standardisation Reform) Bill 2016

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration resumed of the motion:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Dr ALY
Text: Cowan) (12:27): This is a fairly uncontroversial bill that has bipartisan support.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nonetheless, it is worthwhile to come and speak on some of the aspects of the bill within the

Speaker: NA
Text: broader context of a regulatory reform agenda because the Regulatory Powers

Speaker: NA
Text: (Standardisation Reform) Bill 2016 makes amendments to 15 Commonwealth acts to

Speaker: NA
Text: implement the Regulatory Powers (Standard Provisions) Act 2014. The government

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced an almost identical bill in the Senate in the last parliament, which lapsed upon

Speaker: NA
Text: dissolution of the parliament without being debated.

Speaker: NA
Text: As part of its regulatory reform agenda, the former Labor government developed a

Speaker: NA
Text: framework for standard regulatory powers across a range of Commonwealth laws. This

Speaker: NA
Text: project, started by Labor, was intended to reduce the volume and complexity of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth legislation and work across a more consistent approach to regulation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor government's legislation to implement the first stage of this reform lapsed with the

Speaker: NA
Text: dissolution of the 43rd Parliament and was reintroduced by the Abbott government in the 44th

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, in 2014. The project was always intended to proceed in several stages. The first

Speaker: NA
Text: stage, the implementation of the act, is only the development of a suite of standard powers.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I mentioned, the bill makes amendments to 15 Commonwealth acts to repeal current

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions providing for regulatory regimes in those acts. They include the Australian Sports

Speaker: NA
Text: Anti-Doping Authority Act 2006, the Tobacco Plain Packaging Act 2011, the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Reserve Service (Protection) Act 2001, the Greenhouse and Energy Minimum Standards Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 2012, the Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Act 1995 and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Privacy Act 1998, among others. In most instances, the bill will not alter existing

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements, because triggering the act will substitute an equivalent provision for existing

Speaker: NA
Text: powers that reflects modern best practice drafting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor supports the bill, which continues the work undertaken by the former Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: government. We are pleased that the Abbott government reintroduced the bill and that Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: supported it. The regulatory powers act formed part of the Labor government's border

Speaker: NA
Text: regulatory reform agenda. It doesn't have a force in its own right. For its standard provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: to be applied, it must either be referred to in new bills or in amendments of existing bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor hopes that the government will continue to build on our regulatory powers. It is indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: good to see that the government is continuing the work that we started. These are all worthy

Speaker: NA
Text: reforms and I commend them to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: Mr HASTIE
Text: Canning) (12:30): I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Federation Chamber do now adjourn.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fairfax, Mr Bruce Leslie

Speaker: Mr HART
Text: Bass) (12:31): I rise today to honour and reflect upon the life and influence

Speaker: NA
Text: one of Tasmania's leaders in education, Bruce Leslie Fairfax, who became tragically lost in

Speaker: NA
Text: bushland this month. There are many debates in this place about the transformative power of

Speaker: NA
Text: education. There is not enough said of, too few words offered for and not enough recognition

Speaker: NA
Text: of the educators who inspire and mould young brains, making learning fun, challenging

Speaker: NA
Text: stereotypes and preparing young people for the wider world and, most importantly, for an

Speaker: NA
Text: uncertain future. Sometimes popular culture goes close to identifying the special relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: and the special responsibility of a great teacher to his or her students. An example might be

Speaker: NA
Text: Robin Williams's performance in Dead Poets Society. One thing I can be certain of is that

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce Fairfax was regarded by all who encountered him as an inspiring teacher for over three

Speaker: NA
Text: decades at Launceston Church Grammar School.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce Fairfax was appointed as Director of Studies at Launceston Church Grammar School

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1988. Prior to that he taught at the Armidale School and Canberra Grammar. He was a

Speaker: NA
Text: master English scholar. He taught religion and philosophy. Like many who excel where

Speaker: NA
Text: others only serve, it was the manner of his contribution and the mastery of his subject and his

Speaker: NA
Text: rapport with his students that distinguished his role as a teacher.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a particular personal interest, having served on the board of Launceston Church

Speaker: NA
Text: Grammar School, and my son of the class of 2014 was taught by Bruce Fairfax. I've read

Speaker: NA
Text: many tributes from former students. They have been fulsome in their praise of Bruce Fairfax.

Speaker: NA
Text: I asked my son to collate a few of the observations from his peers in the class of 2014. From

Speaker: NA
Text: Jesse, 'I remember us having really off-topic, heated discussions about so many things, and

Speaker: NA
Text: then thinking we learnt nothing. But then you come to do assessments and realise the

Speaker: NA
Text: questions here and there point the conversation in the right direction and you knew exactly

Speaker: NA
Text: what you were on about'. From Warwick, 'It was quite common to see him not standing at the

Speaker: NA
Text: front the classroom but sitting amongst it or casually leaning on some furniture and listening

Speaker: NA
Text: to us speaking. In hindsight it feels like he spent most of the class listening, very occasionally

Speaker: NA
Text: steering conversation.' From Frances, 'He once out-ran me to the chapel. He would have been

Speaker: NA
Text: 63. He had a holistic approach to teaching which taught us as much about life as it did the

Speaker: NA
Text: topic of our study. Also I remember chatting with him about different running routes, which

Speaker: NA
Text: radio programs to listen to, current affairs, bushwalking adventures, good books and even

Speaker: NA
Text: chocolate slice recipes'. From Steven, 'He knew that learning was not teaching you how to do

Speaker: NA
Text: well in exams or getting honours degrees. He encouraged the pursuit of knowledge in

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever form it came. I also have fond memories of him breaking out into fluent Old English

Speaker: NA
Text: or some medieval language, at various stages.'

Speaker: NA
Text: He was chief examiner of matriculation TCE English studies, a life member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmanian debating society, and he coached numerous parliamentary-shield-winning

Speaker: NA
Text: debating teams. Indeed, Bruce Fairfax would probably lament the standard of some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: contributions in this place, given the expectations and standards he often set for his students.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: He is fondly remembered as a kindly, friendly man of integrity, always generous and

Speaker: NA
Text: always patient, but remaining spirited. He was directed by an unwavering internal compass,

Speaker: NA
Text: boldly directed towards doing what was right, something that was recognised by his students.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are qualities which are better imparted to others through conduct and observation rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than instruction. Each of us knows instinctively that greatness as a leader comes from being

Speaker: NA
Text: able to bring out the best in everyone. Bruce possessed this quality and used it to inspire all he

Speaker: NA
Text: encountered, whether students, colleagues or friends. It is significant that he remained a

Speaker: NA
Text: mentor to many students beyond their time at the school.

Speaker: NA
Text: He loved nature. He was a keen bushwalker. He refused to be limited by his Parkinson's

Speaker: NA
Text: disease, which he developed about a decade ago. He worked around and within that

Speaker: NA
Text: limitation. He is survived by his loving wife Louise. They were a remarkable couple, given

Speaker: NA
Text: that Louise is an accomplished orienteer, trail runner, bushwalker and mountain runner. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have two adult daughters, Yelena and Kirsten, and two granddaughters. He was reported

Speaker: NA
Text: missing on a walk to Duckhole Lake, one of Tasmania's 60 great walks. Over 60 people

Speaker: NA
Text: searched unsuccessfully for him. Staff, including the headmaster, of Launceston Church

Speaker: NA
Text: Grammar School, drove overnight to the south of the state to assist in the search.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was a man who left an indelible imprint on the school he served for over three

Speaker: NA
Text: decades. More importantly, he inspired generations of students, who loved to learn because of

Speaker: NA
Text: him. My deepest condolences are offered to Louise, Yelena and Kirsten. Vale Bruce Fairfax.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was an educator and inspiration to many.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dougherty, Mr Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: Page Electorate: Grafton Jacaranda Festival

Speaker: NA
Text: Page Electorate: Lismore Flood Recovery

Speaker: Mr HOGAN
Text: Page) (12:36): Next Monday Bill Dougherty is retiring from the board of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Clarence Village. I want to acknowledge Bill and his wife Dot today. Born in 1929 to

Speaker: NA
Text: Tony and Mildred, Bill is the eldest of five children. His siblings are Peter, Barbara, Dee-anna

Speaker: NA
Text: and Susan. Bill married Dot in 1951 and they have had nine children: Mary, Jim, Anne,

Speaker: NA
Text: Cathie, Tony, Mathew, Judith, Paul and young Bill. From there the family has obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded, with a family joke stating that there was a grandchild of Bill and Dot in each class

Speaker: NA
Text: from preschool to year 12 at the local school for quite some time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill's community service is legendary. He has been instrumental in the development of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Clarence Village, which I mentioned he is retiring from the board of. He was a volunteer surf

Speaker: NA
Text: lifesaver with the Yamba club for many years. At 88 years of age, he still swims regularly

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Crown Hotel over to Susan Island. He once swam from Grafton to Ulmarra to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: money for the disability services provider Caringa-and this is quite some swim. He has been

Speaker: NA
Text: integral in the establishment of Dougherty Villa, an aged-care home. The name says it all.

Speaker: NA
Text: He's also done a lot of work ensuring palliative care services are available in the Clarence

Speaker: NA
Text: Valley. He is an active member of the Clarence River Historical Society. He was on the board

Speaker: NA
Text: of the New South Wales bookmakers co-op and was a local bookmaker.

Speaker: NA
Text: His faith is also very important to him. He is involved with the Catholic parish in Grafton.

Speaker: NA
Text: He's been involved with the diocesan superfund and very involved with St Vincent de Paul

Speaker: NA
Text: and other Catholic entities. Every Sunday he visits the local hospital to chat to patients. In

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: business he began Westlawn Finance with his brother Peter in the 1960s. This is a significant

Speaker: NA
Text: local finance company which employs hundreds of people.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is more I could say, but I think you get the point. As his son once told me, he's a hard

Speaker: NA
Text: act to follow. Bill and Dot, it is very obvious to all of us how much you love our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me say this: your community loves you and thanks you for everything you have

Speaker: NA
Text: contributed over many decades of selfless giving.

Speaker: NA
Text: It's an exciting time in Grafton at the moment, with a sea of purple blossoms from the

Speaker: NA
Text: jacaranda trees. With that comes the Jacaranda Festival. Part of that is the crowning of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Jacaranda Queen and Junior Jacaranda Queen. The queens will be announced this Saturday

Speaker: NA
Text: evening at the official queen crowning ceremony. I wish all the candidates the best. This

Speaker: NA
Text: year's Jacaranda Queen candidates are Brielle Lentfer, Jozee Adamson, Bridgett Mawhirt,

Speaker: NA
Text: Alana Gordon, Emilee Wall, Erika Honnery and Rachael Noakes. The 2017 Matron of

Speaker: NA
Text: Honour is Patricia Hewitt. The Junior Queen candidates are Tahlia O'Hara, Kailee Rose,

Speaker: NA
Text: Madeleine Howell, Madison Nicholl, Holly Blundell, and Leah Hallam. Good luck, and well

Speaker: NA
Text: done to all of you for entering.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thousands of people turned out to see international rugby descend on Crozier Field in

Speaker: NA
Text: Lismore this week as the international Barbarians took on the Classic Wallabies. The twilight

Speaker: NA
Text: fixture saw the international Barbarians play outside of a capital city for the first time in their

Speaker: NA
Text: history. This is one of only two games that these two teams are playing in New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: and all of the proceeds from the match will be going to assist the flood recovery effort in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Lismore area. While they were here, the Classic Wallabies helped many of the local clubs

Speaker: NA
Text: with a free coaching clinic. Locals who played in the Classic Wallabies were Jake Douglas,

Speaker: NA
Text: Matt and Alex Gibbon and Wollongbar-Alstonville's Bill Johnston-Bill, I would have given

Speaker: NA
Text: you game time. Despite their efforts, the valiant Classic Wallabies were narrowly defeated,

Speaker: NA
Text: 27-24. Perhaps they needed the support of Yamba's Kane Douglas, who was intending to run

Speaker: NA
Text: on but got called up for the Wallabies squad instead. I thank everyone involved for making

Speaker: NA
Text: this happen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadband

Speaker: Dr LEIGH
Text: Fenner) (12:41): On a warm spring evening nearly 100 Canberrans gathered

Speaker: NA
Text: at the Belconnen Community Centre recently to discuss with Tara Cheyne MLA and me ways

Speaker: NA
Text: they use broadband and the challenges many of them are facing in getting a decent

Speaker: NA
Text: connection. In days gone by, fast internet was a luxury, but it's becoming a necessity. We

Speaker: NA
Text: don't just stream videos; we use fast internet to watch university lectures and for grandparents

Speaker: NA
Text: and their grandkids to stay in touch. Speedy internet is like water and electricity: a utility that

Speaker: NA
Text: we expect to be there when we need it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet there were many troubling stories. One constituent said that when their child's internet

Speaker: NA
Text: was too slow to do their homework it meant that the child had to stay up late to finish it and

Speaker: NA
Text: sometimes ended up falling asleep in class the next day. A parent of a university student told

Speaker: NA
Text: us:

Speaker: NA
Text: My daughter drives into university at night because our home connection is too slow. I worry about her

Speaker: NA
Text: returning to a deserted campus in the late hours and spending long periods alone in computer labs, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it's the only way she can get the speed she needs to get the core coursework done.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another constituent said:

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm trying to build a cyber security start-up, but it's hard to do it from home when we don't have a stable

Speaker: NA
Text: broadband connection.

Speaker: NA
Text: A constituent who lives in Spence wrote to me after the forum, apologising for not being able

Speaker: NA
Text: to make it but telling the story of her three young children, two of whom have type 1 diabetes

Speaker: NA
Text: and rely on continuous blood glucose monitors. The constituent wrote:

Speaker: NA
Text: … however due to the horrifically slow internet at our new house in Spence these devices have patches

Speaker: NA
Text: where they are useless. When connected to the home wifi (which we pay a lot for) there are moments

Speaker: NA
Text: when the internet isn't fast enough to get the data we need for the medical devices.

Speaker: NA
Text: The constituent included images-screenshots from continuous glucose monitors-and said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The horrible red band at the top shows "there seems to be an issue with your internet" and we see this

Speaker: NA
Text: altogether too much! Just below it shows NO DATA! Our worst nightmare, particularly through a long

Speaker: NA
Text: night of lows.

Speaker: NA
Text: The constituent contrasted that to using their phone, which alerts the parent to 'potentially

Speaker: NA
Text: fatal hypos'. She writes to me:

Speaker: NA
Text: Gaps in data are life threatening.

Speaker: NA
Text: When Labor announced the building of the National Broadband Network we said we would

Speaker: NA
Text: aim to connect nine out of 10 Australian premises with fibre to the home. The advantage of

Speaker: NA
Text: fibre is that light signals travel through glass cables. As scientists develop better compression

Speaker: NA
Text: algorithms, the signal can speed up. We saw the transformative potential of this at a launch

Speaker: NA
Text: event at the Gungahlin Library, where students from Harrison School who are studying

Speaker: NA
Text: Japanese engaged in a high-definition videoconference with a partner school in Japan. They

Speaker: NA
Text: were able to communicate as though they were on either side of an HDTV screen and greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: add to their communication.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the Abbott-Turnbull government's second-best model-meaning that the glass cables

Speaker: NA
Text: stop at a box in the street and the signals then travel down on copper cables-is hurting

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberra. A survey that my office has done, of a couple of hundred Canberrans, paints a

Speaker: NA
Text: picture of some of the challenges Canberrans are facing. Naturally with a couple of hundred

Speaker: NA
Text: respondents you don't necessarily get a full picture of the electorate. However, when we

Speaker: NA
Text: asked, 'Do you consider you receive the internet speeds that you are paying for?' 28 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: said never and 12 per cent said rarely. When we asked constituents, 'How satisfied are you

Speaker: NA
Text: with your internet service?' 21 per cent said very dissatisfied and another 22 per cent said

Speaker: NA
Text: dissatisfied. When asked, 'What types of internet issues have you experienced in the past 12

Speaker: NA
Text: months?' 33 per cent said slow internet speeds, 26 per cent said drop-outs or unreliable service

Speaker: NA
Text: and eight per cent said poor customer service.

Speaker: NA
Text: Canberrans simply want what the rest of Australians are demanding from the Abbott-

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull government-do it once, do it right, do it with fibre. Under Labor there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: more fibre and less copper. Malcolm Turnbull has promised that all Australians will be

Speaker: NA
Text: connected-

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Coulton): Order! The member will refer-

Speaker: Dr LEIGH
Text: The Prime Minister has promised that all Australians will be connected to the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Broadband Network by the end of 2016, but for many Canberrans that's just another

Speaker: NA
Text: broken promise from the Liberals. Whether they're in Belconnen or other parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, my electors want to see a better National Broadband Network than they were

Speaker: NA
Text: promised by this government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment

Speaker: Mr HOWARTH
Text: Petrie) (12:46): We saw some great news in relation to jobs and growth

Speaker: NA
Text: last week-some 371,500 more people employed, more jobs, than there were just 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: ago. That's a 25-year record. At the last election the coalition government made jobs and

Speaker: NA
Text: growth an election commitment. This commitment is becoming a reality right now, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits people in my electorate of Petrie. When I'm out and about talking to people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, job creation locally is often brought up-permanent jobs but also casual, part-time

Speaker: NA
Text: and subcontract positions. We have jobs of the future-where do people go with the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: in technology-and financial education is also important. I don't think we do enough of that.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is great news locally. I want to thank the local schools for what they're doing in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to jobs for the future and financial education. I've been out in a number of different schools in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate and spoken to them about that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our plan is focused mainly on the advanced defence manufacturing plan, and NISA-the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Innovation and Science Agenda. There are our free trade agreements, and with a

Speaker: NA
Text: population of 24 million or so free trade exports are really important for us when we can

Speaker: NA
Text: export to Asia, where there are billions of people, and then there is reducing company tax and

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits of that. Reductions in company tax are now in place for businesses with up to $25

Speaker: NA
Text: million in turnover, which means that after dividends are paid and after expenses are covered

Speaker: NA
Text: and after assets are bought, whatever money is left in the business is only taxed at 27.5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent-it will go down to 25-rather than 30 per cent, which means there's more money left

Speaker: NA
Text: for them to re-invest. The instant asset tax write-off is of great benefit to many businesses in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate. In Petrie over 2,900 businesses have taken advantage of the instant asset tax

Speaker: NA
Text: write-off in the last financial year. That means that local solar companies win, because

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses are investing in solar on their roof, which is important given that most businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: use their energy during the day, when solar energy is being created. Also, the purchase of any

Speaker: NA
Text: second-hand or new vehicle under $20,000 is instantly written off. IT and computer systems

Speaker: NA
Text: can be instantly written off. You might want a new coffee machine for the office-I guess

Speaker: NA
Text: Harvey Norman benefits, or other retailers. This is great news because those 2,900 businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: in Petrie that are using the instant asset write-off are spending locally with these different

Speaker: NA
Text: businesses. It's all part of the 371,500 jobs created in the last 12 months alone-and over

Speaker: NA
Text: 300,000 of those have been full time.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that the defence manufacturing plan is now under construction. It includes nine

Speaker: NA
Text: future frigates, which haven't started yet, 12 Future Submarines, which haven't started yet, 21

Speaker: NA
Text: Pacific patrol boats, which are under construction now, and 12 offshore patrol boats that start

Speaker: NA
Text: next year. The 21 Pacific patrol boats have now started in Western Australia. They're

Speaker: NA
Text: underway right now, which is fantastic. That is a $306 million spend. There are local people

Speaker: NA
Text: working on those. They are using Australian steel. They are being built locally. We also know

Speaker: NA
Text: that a couple of hundred billion dollars will be invested in defence capability over the next 10

Speaker: NA
Text: years, but the Pacific patrol boats have started since the election. Companies in my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: are also benefiting from defence procurement. Pacific Health Solutions has a $320,000

Speaker: NA
Text: contract with the Department of Defence for medical waste.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Free trade agreements are really taking off. We've seen the China-Australia Free Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement and the Japan-Australia Economic Partnership Agreement, and the Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement is being worked on. We've seen sales of skimmed milk powder go up 99 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: sales of bottled wine increase 86 per cent in the last 12 months and sales of hay and chaff

Speaker: NA
Text: increase by 50 per cent. There's a whole lot happening there. The other week I had Assistant

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister Craig Laundy up looking at the National Innovation and Science Agenda and

Speaker: NA
Text: awarding some grants. It is great news for Petrie.

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic and Family Violence

Speaker: Ms BRODTMANN
Text: Canberra) (12:51): On average one woman is killed every week by a

Speaker: NA
Text: current or former partner. One in three women have experienced physical and/or sexual

Speaker: NA
Text: violence perpetrated by someone known to them. One in five women over the age of 18 have

Speaker: NA
Text: been stalked in their lifetime. Domestic violence is the principal cause of homelessness for

Speaker: NA
Text: women and their children. These figures are confronting and they should be.

Speaker: NA
Text: On 28 February 2015 Canberra's Tara Costigan was killed by her former partner with an

Speaker: NA
Text: axe as she held her eight-day-old baby girl. Both of Tara's sons were powerless to stop the

Speaker: NA
Text: attack and her 18-year-old sister and boyfriend were injured as they fought off the attack. This

Speaker: NA
Text: tragedy saw the creation of the Tara Costigan Foundation in her honour. Each year thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: of Canberrans get together at Lake Burley Griffin as part of Tara's Walk for Change. This

Speaker: NA
Text: walk has been going for three years. I've proudly taken part in each walk over the three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: I've joined thousands of other Canberrans who have sent the strong message that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: zero tolerance for family and domestic violence.

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic violence is one of Australia's most pressing issues and the numbers that prove it

Speaker: NA
Text: are alarming. For every woman who comes forward there are so many who won't have their

Speaker: NA
Text: story heard. They suffer in silence. A recent report published by the Women's Centre for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health Matters found that here in the ACT most women experiencing domestic violence are

Speaker: NA
Text: staying in their homes post crisis and not accessing the crisis system. This means that they're

Speaker: NA
Text: not accessing homelessness services and do not have access to the support systems available

Speaker: NA
Text: to others. Many of these women are middle-income earners and are employed full time. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are not able to access financial assistance and support because they don't qualify for hardship

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions or loans. So it's not just a case of women being afraid to leave; in these

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances they can't leave, because there's nowhere for them to go.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our culture needs to change. Not only should we call out domestic violence when we see it

Speaker: NA
Text: but we need to empower women with the tools to be able to leave a violent relationship. That

Speaker: NA
Text: means providing them with the support systems, and that means providing them with housing

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance. The 2015 Australian of the Year, Rosie Batty, said, 'We shouldn't be happy to live

Speaker: NA
Text: in a community where the prospect of returning to violence is better than having nowhere to

Speaker: NA
Text: go.' That's what so many of these women face.

Speaker: NA
Text: One fearless woman in the Canberra community, Juliet Moody, is leading the way for

Speaker: NA
Text: change. Last year she launched the Fearless Comedy Gala as part of her Fearless Initiative.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know domestic violence isn't a laughing matter, but Juliet tackles the issue through

Speaker: NA
Text: comedy. She puts the spotlight right on the issue when sometimes the community is too afraid

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak out. Juliet is the survivor of a violent relationship of more than a decade ago and uses

Speaker: NA
Text: her annual Fearless Comedy Gala to raise crucial funds for services here in Canberra. This

Speaker: NA
Text: year, the gala's second year, the gala raised nearly $40,000, almost $10,000 more than last

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: year. That's nearly $40,000 going to the Domestic Violence Crisis Service and Toora Women

Speaker: NA
Text: right here in Canberra. I want to thank Canberrans for getting behind the Fearless Initiative in

Speaker: NA
Text: such a strong way and at such an early stage, and for supporting it in so many different ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sexual violence is an important issue that I've been strongly advocating against in the

Speaker: NA
Text: broader Women, Peace and Security agenda of the United Nations. Like domestic violence

Speaker: NA
Text: here in Australia, we should be speaking out about sexual violence and we should be holding

Speaker: NA
Text: perpetrators to account, no matter where they are, which is why I'm such a strong advocate of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 'Prosecute; don't perpetrate campaign'-getting those foreign fighters back here and

Speaker: NA
Text: getting them prosecuted under sexual violence and conflict legislation and norms.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 2008, Dassi Erlich and a number of other students at the ultraorthodox Jewish girls

Speaker: NA
Text: school Adass Israel in Melbourne disclosed that they'd been sexually abused by Malka Leifer,

Speaker: NA
Text: the school principal. Leifer almost immediately fled to Israel, with the assistance of the school

Speaker: NA
Text: board. She was later charged in Victorian courts with 74 counts of sexual assault and rape. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 2014, the Australian government applied for Leifer's extradition to Australia to face these

Speaker: NA
Text: charges, but so far she's managed to avoid them. So I'm calling on the Israeli government, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Israeli Minister of Justice and the Israeli judicial system to consider a fair, independent

Speaker: NA
Text: evaluation of the accused so that she can be returned to Australia to face these charges.

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade with Azerbaijan

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Council Elections: Western Australia

Speaker: Mr IRONS
Text: Swan) (12:56): Azerbaijan is a country that we don't know a lot about, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I'm pleased to inform the House of the success of the first trade delegation from Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: Azerbaijan last week. Twenty-seven delegates, including Marcel Hilmer from my electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Swan, representing 20 Australian companies travelled to Baku to look at the opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: for trade and business. As you would imagine from a private sector delegation, meetings took

Speaker: NA
Text: place with the private business sector as well as with individual companies and the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: government agencies. The companies represented sectors that included hospitality, wine,

Speaker: NA
Text: dairy, health, mining and many more. The opportunities included trade deals, and even the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of businesses for buying a share of businesses that already exist in Azerbaijan.

Speaker: NA
Text: This delegation was a very positive step forward for both countries. I understand that a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of contracts are now being drawn up, and they will result in improved economic

Speaker: NA
Text: activity within and between the two nations. These contracts are just the start of a

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening business relationship, and I look forward to hearing of Australian businesses

Speaker: NA
Text: opening offices in Azerbaijan, and I hope to hear about Azerbaijani businesses coming here,

Speaker: NA
Text: opening businesses and employing Australians. I don't need to tell the members of this place

Speaker: NA
Text: that more jobs are good for Australia-and, of course, more jobs are also good for Azerbaijan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Interestingly, the business relationship between our countries is not new, of course. A

Speaker: NA
Text: company called Incat in Tasmania built a large ferry for Azerbaijan several years ago, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: just recently, Austal Ships built its sister ship in Western Australia for Azerbaijan. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: both companies that I dealt with through my business before I came to this place. The ships

Speaker: NA
Text: are there to support the oil and gas industry on the Caspian Sea. So, already, Australians have

Speaker: NA
Text: benefited from jobs based on Azerbaijan's demands. I also note that WorleyParsons is very

Speaker: NA
Text: active in Azerbaijan, and of course there are many Australians already employed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: commodities sector in Azerbaijan.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: There is every reason to be positive about this developing relationship between our

Speaker: NA
Text: countries, as success of the private sector means successful outcomes for this government and

Speaker: NA
Text: for all Australians. I look forward to future developments and positive outcomes for both our

Speaker: NA
Text: nations arising out of this first, historic trade delegation to Azerbaijan.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would now like to take the opportunity to update the House on the outcome of local

Speaker: NA
Text: government elections in my electorate of Swan last weekend. As we know, local government

Speaker: NA
Text: is a very important part of the democratic process. People often say it's the closest part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic process to the people. There are five local government authorities that reside in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate of Swan, and they are the City of Belmont, the City of Canning, the City of

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalamunda, the City of South Perth and the Town of Victoria Park. I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate all those who were elected on the weekend to represent their local communities.

Speaker: NA
Text: From the City of South Perth, I would like to congratulate Glenn Cridland and Tracie

Speaker: NA
Text: MCDougall on being elected to the Como ward; Blake D'Souza on being elected to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Manning ward; my lovely wife on being re-elected to the Mill Point ward; and, lastly, Greg

Speaker: NA
Text: Milner on being elected to the Moresby ward. For the Town of Victoria Park, I congratulate

Speaker: NA
Text: Karen Vernon and Ronhhda Potter on being elected to the Banksia ward; and Bronwyn Ife

Speaker: NA
Text: and Brian Oliver on being elected to the Jarrah ward. From the City of Belmont, I'd like to

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate Bernie Ryan on being re-elected to the East ward; Janet Powell and Jenny Davis

Speaker: NA
Text: on being elected to the South ward; and George Sekulla and Lauren Cayoun on being elected

Speaker: NA
Text: to the West ward. From the City of Canning, only the Beeloo and Mason wards fall within my

Speaker: NA
Text: electoral boundaries-they also fall within the electoral boundaries of Tangney and Burt. I'd

Speaker: NA
Text: like to congratulate Graham Barry on being elected to Mason ward, and Sara Saberi to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Beeloo ward. The City of Kalamunda is to the east of my electorate, and only one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wards falls within my electoral boundaries. I'd like to congratulate Dylan O'Connor and David

Speaker: NA
Text: Almond on being elected to the North West ward.

Speaker: NA
Text: From one elected member to another-as we in this place all we know-the privilege of

Speaker: NA
Text: representing your community is one of the most important aspects of your job, no matter what

Speaker: NA
Text: level of government you are elected to. As in this House, the hours are not just nine to five,

Speaker: NA
Text: Monday to Friday. My wife attended a meeting last night and left the council chambers at

Speaker: NA
Text: 11.35 last night. That is the type of work that we as elected representatives do. We're expected

Speaker: NA
Text: to be on call at all times to help, whether a member of parliament, a councillor or the

Speaker: NA
Text: president of the local cricket club. You are there because the people have put their faith in you

Speaker: NA
Text: to represent them, and the one piece of advice I can give all of you is to ensure you never

Speaker: NA
Text: breach that faith. I'd like to also thank those who previously served as councillors but were

Speaker: NA
Text: not re-elected and those who put their hand in the race to represent their community. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: dedication of people like you that makes our community what it is.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation Chamber adjourned at 13:01

Speaker: NA
Text: NA
